1113111121212112141321.content:
"Oh, Thora!" Olga said upon opening the door, coming face to face with the familiar red-head.

"Good afternoon, Miss," Thora nodded respectfully, tone curt as ever when it came to her. "The Mistress requests your presence."

"Oh," Olga said, her hand falling to cradle at her stuffed tummy. She was still feeling her breakfast digest. "Is it time for lunch?"

"Not at the moment," Thora shook her head. "The Mistress would like to see you in her room."

Olga blinked, and then stared. She was to go to Cameena's personal quarters? In all her time here, that had never happened. A feeling of unease welled up in the pit of her gut, and she was sure it wasn't from digesting her hearty breakfast.

"Come on, then," Thora indicated towards the door. "The Mistress does not like to be kept waiting."

Olga had long gotten used to the maid's stiff tone. Granted, the other maids had warmed to her somewhat. Aina was all-business, but she made sure to come across as accommodating, especially when answering whatever questions Olga might have. Phyla seemed to enjoy being helpful in every way she could, be it making sure her bed covers and pillows were clean and comforting, or even willing to sit down and converse if the farm girl had anything on her mind. Even Giovanna was warming to her, the head of the kitchen always taking the time to ask her how she would like her eggs, if the bacon servings were adequate, and if she had enough butter for her bread.

In general, every other maid in the castle had gotten used to Olga's presence and spoke to her with a degree of familiarity bordering on warmth to make her feel welcome. Not to say Thora wasn't accommodating, no no. She worked hard and was as helpful as her fellow co-workers. She was just a tad blunt, is all.

Which is why she didn't try to make as much small talk as she usually would with the other maids. Thora did indulge her, but her short answers made it clear she would grow slightly irritated at being forced to converse.

"Did she say what this was about?" Olga asked hopefully.

"She only said to bring you to her," was all Thora said, eyes forward as she lead the way.

Olga didn't say anything else, instead opting to glance around the grand halls while cradling her belly and arching her back slightly to calm the unease of moving on a full stomach. As they moved along, the passed another pair of maids carrying cloths. The two working maids didn't pause in their walking, but they did look Olga's way for a moment. That was all it took for the two to engage in some light conversation.

"Looks like the Mistress has summoned her," One of the maids whispered to her co-worker.

"She is coming along quite well," the other maid cut her eyes at Olga's figure, making the blonde turn her eyes forward to Thora's back as she self-consciously shrunk a little into her shoulders. "Her round stomach, and her posture...is she with child?"

"The Mistress claimed a pregnant maiden? Poor dear.'

"It could be just a food baby, however. You know how it works around here for these girls."

At the light--very light, as even during gossip these maids maintained professionalism--giggling that ensued, Olga felt her face flush hot. She brought a hand to her mouth and looked down to conceal her embarrassment, completely ignoring Thora shooting a look at the passing maids that made them go quiet and hurry down the hall.

"Ignore them," Thora spoke up after noticing Olga was still looking down in embarrassment as they continued their trip to Cameena's chambers. "They don't mean to be mean-spirited. No one would dare insult Lady Cameena's chosen cattle."

"Oh," Olga said, feeling slightly better but still embarrassed that her new size had gotten her mistaken for being pregnant.

"Besides," Thora's tone had a dismissive edge to it. "As the Mistress' favorite sow, you are expected to be growing. Think of their comments on your size as compliments."

That most definitely did not make Olga feel better.

"We are here."

Olga perked at that, her eyes beholding a set of two grand doors in the center of the hallway. Intricate designs trailed the wood of the doors, lined up with what looked to be golden handles and silver lines. Definitely a set of doors befitting a rich and powerful monarch. Thora opened one of the doors, stepping in first and bowing low to her waist as she made way for Olga to toddle in.

"I have brought her, Mistress."

"Ah, very good Thora," Olga heard Cameena's purring voice from within the room. As she stepped in, she took a good look at her surroundings.

Cameena's room was similar in design to Olga's room, wide space with tall walls and everything. Except it was all at a much, much grander scale in terms of luxury. A red carpet that covered the entire floor. A bed that could accommodate five, possibly ten, people and still leave plenty of room, draped over by purple curtains hanging off the canopy. Massive windows with hanging curtains that lead to a balcony outside. From the corner of her eye Olga spied a set of hanging curtains that lead to a bathroom.

All in all, similar to her room, but naturally Cameena's was at a much grander scale. She wondered if this was similar to how royals lived in Adinah.

"Ahhh, my most prized cow!" Cameena cooed, stepping forward to bounce bellies with the human girl and plant her hands on her shoulders. "I take it breakfast was satisfactory?" She made a slight rearing back and then thrusting forward motion, coyly bumping her gut against Olga's slightly bigger one.

Olga blushed as she felt her flesh jiggle ever so slightly in tune to Cameena's own flab at the forced collision. "Y-Yes, Mistress..."

"Hmm..." Cameena's hand fell down to caress at the swell of Olga's belly, lightly poking it with her finger. "Yes, you are coming along quite nicely. Why, the effort it's taking me to hold myself back..."

Olga blanched.

"Oh stop, I'm only kidding darling!" Cameena laughed, patting the terrified girl on the cheek. "Although...only just."

"What?"

"Nothing important," Cameena said dismissively as she snaked an arm around Olga's shoulders, guiding her deeper into her room, by the bed. "Now then, on to business. Please, have a seat."

She pushed Olga down a little to eagerly on her bed, and the former barmaid at once felt like a dirty intruder. Was it really alright for her to sit so casually on her mistress' bed? To ruffle the neatly arranged covers so brazenly?

"It has come to my attention that you often request my maids read to you."

Now Olga felt like she was in the center of a town, everyone pointing a finger to her as she was caught taking bread from a baker's stand. She tried to say something, but the only sound that came out was a broken stammer.

"Oh hush now," Cameena said distastefully, hands on her broad hips. "You haven't done anything wrong. I merely want to know if books fascinate you so because I could arrange to have several sent down to your quarters if it's a hobby you love."

"It's not that I like books," Olga started softly. "It's...a good way to pass the time, and...." she hung her head. "....I can't read."

Cameena stared at her in a curious manner, wondering why it pained her precious cattle to admit such a trifle problem. "And do you wish to learn how to read?"

"What?" Olga snapped her head to look at the immortal. "I, uh..."

Cameena watched as the fattened farm girl fidgeted, and mused on the benefits herself. The taste of human blood is determined by many factors. And Olga already had a unique blood quality that made hers particularly delicious even before being as fat as she is now. The Lady of the Castle wondered if adding literature knowledge to her already unique being would enhance her flavor slightly. It wouldn't be same as the flavor from her eating lots of succulent meals, but experimenting with taste is always a welcome event.

"I think..."

Cameena was brought out of her musings by the blonde sitting on her bed. She looked her over, from every inch of that new chubby body of hers to her blonde hair and distinctly pretty blue eyes. Something seemed to wash over her being then. A sense of pity mixed with fondness. Of all her acquired cattle over the years, Olga really was more special than any of them.

Now why she thought that, she didn't know. Maybe it was out of sense of being a good master. Olga had done good adjusting to living in the castle and eating as was required of her. That had to be it. Cameena felt a need to reward such a good, loyal calf.

"If it's something you truly want, I will grant it," Cameena said after a moment, earning a surprised look from the human. "You don't need to fear overstepping your bounds."

Olga just stared at her with those big blue eyes of hers. Cameena stared back with indifference, yet couldn't deny the tiny bit of a fond smile dimpling her cheeks ever so slightly. It gave Olga the courage to proceed.
1113111121212112141321.title: Cameena's Charity

choices: A few moons later, Cameena was deep in teaching Olga  how to read.
Several weeks later, the Vampiric Masquerade Ball has begun.
The next day, Cameena received an envoy from Eviana Stranken's court. How fun...
11131111212121121413211.content:
Although she felt rather encouraged by her mistress's softening demeanor, Olga almost felt as if a decent weight had been lifted from her shoulders, if only slightly.

Upon seeing a slight hint of hesitation from her "Chosen cattle", the plump vampire countess (strangely enough) instinctively but slowly placed a cold talon-like hand upon Olga's chubbier limb, sending a brief shiver down Olga's spine upon feeling her mistress's cold corpse-esque touch.

"...I said you were not a prisoner here, my dear. What you truly want is of your choosing." Cameena softly spoke, as her fingers curled up upon Olga's hand, gently gripping it with ease, which ultimately culminated in the exact words that the vampiric noble was expecting to hear, as Olga exhaled a calming breath and inevitably answered, "...Yes. I...I-I would love to learn how to read, Mistress."

And with that, a curved smile appeared upon Cameena's blood red lips, to which she then promptly yet soothingly retorted, "An excellent choice, dear Olga. And please..."

From there, as if intentionally unexpected, Cameena leaned close to Olga's right ear and hushly whispered in a seductively soothing tone and said, "...Call me Lady Cameena~"

It felt as if time had seemingly stopped for the young Forgedotter, as (much to her utter surprise) her fuller cheeks began to...blush?

No, she had to be feeling a little under the weather. She had to be! Why would she show such expressions to her jailer and captor?

But such thoughts were unable to linger for long, as Cameena then stood up from the lavish bed, clapped her nailed hands twice or thrice, which prompted Aina to proceed inside, bowing before her mistress then flatly asked, "How may I assist you, Mistress?"

"Aina? Would please be a dear and escort Olga here to my personal library? It seems our guest is long overdue for some proper education." Cameena calmly ordered, speaking with the same regal yet soothing tone she always used, to which Aina voluntarily obeyed her vampiric mistress's orders, as the maid proceeded to escort the rotund Olga out of Cameena's private quarters and towards a new destination.

However, once the two individuals had finally disappeared from her view, Cameena slovenly slumped back down onto her bed in some sense of relief...to an extent.

Curiously, she momentarily examined the hand she used to grip Olga's own, and found a rather intriguing revelation:

In all her decades to centuries as an immortal vampire of the illustrious Stranken Family, Cameena Stranken...her hand was legitimately shaking!

Was it from eagerness to sink her teeth into her newly chosen cattle? Was it from the stimuli of being so enthralled with molding and developing Olga's addictively succulent crimson nectar?

Or...Was it something more. Something...primal, something...Human?

Instantly, Cameena attempted to shake off such humane thoughts. She was a vampire! A child of the night! She was above such sentiments from a lesser race!!

And yet...As she closely examined her mildly shivering hand with fervent curiosity, she couldn't help but be aware of the lingering warmth from gently grasping Olga's hand, which oddly wasn't as painful as she would've expected.

Was this...what falling in love feels like?
11131111212121121413211.title: A Vampiric Education

choices: "Alright, girl. Hop in." And so she did, her life changed forever...
"Absolutely not." And they drove off, leaving Olga's life changed forever...
1113112.content:
"You." Cameena extended one taloned finger, pointing squarely at not Olga, but her older sister—Tora.

This couldn't have been happening. Out of all the women in Racovania, how could Tora have been picked for the Culling? Tora was all she had left! After Mother passed, her father had taken such great care to make sure that everyone stayed together, growing stronger. Tempered Steel. And after he passed, they had gotten through it together... but how could she live with the last remaining member of her family being literally taken from her?

Poor Tora could only stand there, letting everything pass over her. She wasn't saying anything—why wasn't she saying anything?

"You'll do quite nicely." Cameena said with a smile, "Come now. Into my carriage."

"No!" Olga threw herself over Tora's shoulders, which wavered quietly as tears filled her big blue eyes, "You can't take my sister! She's all I have left!"

"Olga..." Tora chided her softly, "I-It's alright, just..."

"No! It's not alright!" Olga was sobbing like a child, snot running down her nose and her cheeks all puffy, "I won't let you take my sister!"

If she had been touched by Olga's sense of familial duty, Cameena Stranken had failed to show it. She merely stood there, bemused at the show being put on for her. Even the townsfolk ushered their eyes away, fearful of what may happen to Olga now that she had gone against the agreement that the Racovanian settlers held with the vampires, and saddened by their inability to do anything about it.

"You, my young friend, have made a grave mistake." Cameena arched her eyebrows as her smile turned sickly, "My people protect your kind so that you may prosper—but make no mistake, I will kill you if you continue to literally stand between me and my next meal."

"Olga, settle down." Tora whispered, "Somehow I don't think she's playing."

"But I can't..." Olga shuddered as Cameena removed her sister from beneath her, "I can't lose you..."

"T-Tora?" Olga cried out, "Tora?!"

"Be brave, Olga!" the older Forgedotter shouted as Olga was ushered to her coach, "...Be brave..."

No. No no no no. This wasn't happening, this couldn't be happenening this wasn't supposed to be like this she and Tora were supposed to grow old and she was going to be the bridesmaid when she got married and they were going to go into town and see the sights and visit Adinah and this couldn't be happening because Tora was all she had left in this whole forsaken world!

"T-Then take me with you!" Olga cried out suddenly, catching the attention of Cameena Stranken as she lowered the elder Forgedotter in her seat, "J-Just... Just let me be there! I'll do whatever you ask! I... I just have to... she's my sister..."

And it was here that Cameena Stranken, mistress of the night, gray-skinned snatcher of sisters and sucker of blood, paused.

When her lips parted, she said...
1113112.title: Taking Tora

choices: "You'll be shown to the servants quarters—so you may ASSIST with our supper."
"You'll be taken to my chambers—you and I are about to have a GRAVE discussion."
"You'll be given a room in the West Wing—supper is in an hour."
11131121.content:
If it were any consolation, at least Olga and Tora would die together.

That was the only thing keeping them quiet as the incredibly cramped carriage clacked and clamored up the road. It was unused to bearing the weight of three people. The horses moved slow and the cab was stuffed tight. It was a two-seater by design. Cameena faced the front of the carriage while her unlucky guest faced the back, going up the road. However, it wasn't meant to hold both the Forgedotters and their "hostess". The ashen woman was surly, pouting petulantly as the sisters held each other.

"I don't want you to think you've gotten away with anything." Lady Cameena said through pursed lips, "Your sister is here because I allowed it—I'm feeling particularly generous tonight, and it makes things go by so much easier if my new pets aren't weeping about missing mommy or daddy."

There was a pause as the two sisters looked at one another, equally confused and frightened.

"Or, sissy... as in your case." Cameena rolled her eyes to Olga, who flinched, "At any rate, I don't want you to think that you'll have it easy. I've taken you from that dank little village on behest of your moxie. Just because you impressed me doesn't mean that I'm going to let you do as you please."

"Y-Yes ma'am..." Olga hung her head low.

By Faldir, what did that mean? What was this blood-sucking monster going to do to them? Maybe it would have been better if Olga had kept her mouth shut...

No! The Forgedotter Sisters stuck together! Tora was all that she had now—and the fire of losing both of their parents had born them both strong. Whatever was coming their way... Olga would just have to accept it. The same way that, by her solemn expression and the way she pet at Olga's hands, Tora had appeared to. Gods only knew what could be going through her mind right now. After all, Lady Cameena had selected her first...

Again, what in Yndyre could that blasted blood-sucker be cooking up?

"Now, when we get to my manor—that's it, right up ahead there—we're going to have to make an extra stop." Cameena said aloofly, reapplying her lipstick through the use of a small mirror (how she could see her reflection, Olga could only guess) as if she weren't leading two young girls to their imminent doom, "Tora, dear, we're going to let you out at the front gate where one of my lesser vampires will show you to your quarters."

"As for you..." Cameena furrowed her brow, her yellow eyes flitting back to Olga as her tone stiffened...
11131121.title: Forged Together, Forsaken Together

choices: Tora wouldn't, or couldn't, stop eating—what had Cameena done to her?!
Tora was so calm, even friendly with Cameena—it's like she's been brainwashed!
111311211.content:
Of all the things that Olga had imagined about herself—the things that she could become, the things she would do, the places that she would one day live—she had never imagined herself taking residence in one of the Stranken Clan Castles that dotted the mountainside.

It had been so painful watching Tora be ushered into the awaiting maw of such a beast; big and made of black stone, which seemed all the more ominous as it began to rain. Her older sister gave a sad little smile of false reassurance, her crop of blonde hair matted down by the deluge, as she was ushered inside by one of Cameena's servants. She was ghastly pale, though Olga was unsure if she was a vampire like her mistress. Tora gave a little wave her way in the rain.

"Everything'll be fine, Olga." Tora lied, "I promise."

Somehow, even then, Olga knew that that wasn't the last time she would see her sister alive. Sure she welled up again, her eyes watery as she pressed herself against the small window afforded by the carriage door. But it didn't feel like she was saying goodbye. Perhaps it was denial, perhaps Olga was more attuned to the workings of the universe in that moment than she realized. But all that mattered was that, rather than bawl her eyes out, Olga simply sunk into her seat.

She felt bad about it.

"Now then." Lady Cameena sniffed, extending one thick gray leg into the rain, "Come with me. Your presence was... unaccounted for... I do hope it doesn't cost us too much time."

"I-I'm sorry..." Olga whimpered, "I-I just... I didn't..."

"Oh hush. And stop your sobbing." the grayed woman scowled, "Just because your sister is my guest, don't assume you'll receive any special treatment."

"I-I'm afraid I don't understand...?" Olga whimpered, "What... what do you want me to do?"

***


This wasn't exactly what she had in mind.

Upon entering the servant's quarters around the back, Olga was outfitted with a maid's uniform, not unlike the one that Lady Cameena's attendant had been wearing out in the rain. It was a long dress maid of thick material. It covered her legs up to her ankles and her arms all the way down to her elbow. It was a bit tight around the chest, even moreso once she had tied on her apron. Her old clothes were taken to a small room with a cot and a nightstand.

But that wasn't the unexpected part.

"Stop dragging your feet." came the husky voice of a woman about her sister's age, with cropped black hair and a sense of duty about her, "The mistress wants Supper to be ready by the hour—we've got five minutes to make our entrance."

Olga had been getting kicked around by servants since she set foot in the door. They were a terribly insistent lot, making her change her clothes and shuffling her into the kitchen. No one would tell her what was going on or what was expected of her. She was just confused! It wasn't like Lady Cameena had told her anything other than what a burden she was being.

"I want you to go to the servant's quarters." Lady Cameena had barked over the sound of the rain, "Put on your uniform. My maids will instruct you from there."

But they hadn't.

In fact, Olga found herself more confused than ever. Why was a vampire preparing such lavish meals? They weren't supposed to be able to eat... were they? And so much of it. Lady Cameena seemed plush, but reasonably so. She was a woman of wealth, so naturally she'd be a bit fuller figured, right? But the amount of food readied for delivery into the dining hall... it was insane! Enough to feed an army, let alone one woman.

Who were these women? Vampires? Humans? Where was her sister? And why weren't they already dead yet?

"You—" a platter was placed in Olga's hands by (whom she assumed to be) the head maid. It had an entire turkey on it, cooked to perfection, "—don't drop it. Walk in pace with the one in front of you. Put it directly—directly in front of Her Darkness's guest and then stand to the side. Don't speak unless spoken to."

"Wh-What?" Olga stammered, "Gods this thing's heavy..."

"Good." the maid said, "Alright everyone, Lady Cameena is expecting flourish tonight—on my mark, move into the dining hall for presentation."

Before Olga could process what was going on, lost in thought as the confusion of the day overcame her, the backs of her shoes were getting stepped on as the maid behind her moved forward. She stumbled, but caught herself and the tray.

The most important question of them all... what had she gotten herself into?

***


The Grand Dining Hall wasn't at all like Olga had expected.

There was no blood, for starters. Everything was very tastefully decorated. Sure it was gaudy, but that was according to the tastes of a poor smithee's daughter. There were a lot of brass trimmings. Huge portraits hung along the walls of the hall, the biggest and most stunning was of Lady Cameena herself, seated at the head. One long table traced the radius of the room. It could have seated twenty... thirty people with no trouble. With such a huge waitstaff, how often did this room get filled to the brim with thirsty blood suckers?

Olga could hardly posit the time it took to wonder as she was shuffled along in line. Her uniform was uncomfortable, and a little snug. She had to take steps far bigger than she was accustomed to, so as to keep up with the strangely enthusiastic maids at Lady Cameena's beck and call.

Was this to be her life now? Waiting on some vampire hand and foot, like the rest of these women?

Olga shuddered at the thought.

Each maid delivered their plate to the head of the table. Hams, fish, turkeys, stews, breads, all were placed artfully and carefully within reach of the grand seats at the tip of the table. Olga had never seen so much food. It looked so delicious—what in Yndyre could a vampire want with all of this?

And then, as she got closer, Olga got her answer!

There was Tora, sitting next to her! She had been all prettied up, decked out in an elegant green dress that had to have belonged to Cameena (once upon a time, anyway) and she had been made up to look anything like the tomboyish girl who toiled at the fires every day.

But the longer Olga stared, and the closer Olga got to delivering her heavy platter, the more she noticed something was... off about her older sister...
111311211.title: Olga, Suited for Servitude

choices: Cook—she was a natural! Between her and Somaria, Helga was so ROUND these days!
Cast Spells—she'd been learning magic, but wasn't exactly good at it...
Enjoy Studying—Olga had become so interested in the various species of Yndyre!
11131122.content:
It hadn't been easy losing Tora.

Watching her get carried off by that blood sucking she-devil in the back of her black carriage, sobbing in the fog as her sister was taken away from her, it had left Olga feeling well and truly alone. For the first time in her life, she was alone. Her mother was gone, her father had passed, and now her sister had been spirited away from her by some horrible... thing who was going to feast on her blood. The last of her kin had been taken from her, and it left the once bubbly bar maid feeling more than a little hollow inside.

She sat there on her knees for a while, alternating between eerie silence and uncontrolled sobbing. The townsfolk of Racovania pitied her, but knew all too well the pain of losing someone close to them to those Strankens up the mountain. So one by one, the townsfolk flitted away into their homes—contented that it wasn't their who had been taken, or their daughter, their kin or otherwise who had been abducted without provocation. The ring of condolences surrounding Olga slowly dissipated.

Not that she noticed.

Olga was lost in herself. Her mind racing, but blank. The hows and whys weren't important. She was beyond rational thought by this point; ruled entirely by her emotions as they raged and stormed inside of her. The poor thing might have honestly snapped, and no one would have blamed her if she had. She wasn't nearly as strong as her sister had been, taking charge of the family when both their parents died. Everyone knew that. Olga knew that. The only recurring, comprehensible thought that echoed in her mind was

What do I do now?

And, as if to answer her question, a blanket was draped over her shoulders. Her eyes widened in confusion and fear as strong hands wrapped themselves around her. Soft flesh enveloped her back as the familiar scent of stew and mead embraced her.

"There now, blue eyes. Come on." Came the friendly sound of Helga's thick Racovanian accent, "Let's get you inside the tavern. You can stay in the spare bedroom—the one we rent out from time to time."

Then she was helped onto her feet, the blanket still draped around her shoulders, as Helga took her inside. She closed down the Tavern—no one was in much spirits to celebrate after such a thick gray cloud rained on their good times anyway—and set Olga up with some hot porridge and a roaring fire.

"There now, atta girl." Helga said as she sat her down on the bench seat, swathed in the thick blanket like a child, "You're going to be fine."

"If you'd like to stay with us, we have an extra room." Somaria suggested invitingly as she stroked Olga's back, "Not much sense in it now that the Inn's repaired—I'm sure Helga wouldn't mind if we let you stay there for a few nights."

And as they stroked her back, petted her and called her blue eyes, Olga knew that her life would never be the same again...

***


That's not to say that her life was comparatively worse from that point on. Just a bit more different. A little less lonely in some ways, and a lot more in others. Not a day passed where Olga didn't think about her poor sister in the back of that Stranken Carriage, but over the course of the next year the pain she felt in her heart faded with her passing thoughts. The wound would never heal, not completely, but she had found ways to keep herself busy.

Olga had been forced to sell her home. There was no way that she could keep up the fare on such a land working as a barmaid. It went to a nice family who moved to town with no daughters. They were smithees and looking to set up shop in Racovania. Olga felt guilty every time she saw her home under the care of another family—she tried not to go that way too terribly often.

With the gold she had earned by selling her family's homestead, she had permanently settled into the spare room in the Bleakfrost Tavern. Helga regularly charged her rent at a decent rate, and she got to keep whatever she made from working at the bar. It was a busy life—something that turned out to work rather well for Olga in light of recent tragedies. She could pour herself into her work, and that helped her deal with losing her sister.

It wasn't easy at first. For the first week, Olga hadn't gotten out of bed. And for a while after she wasn't quite "herself" (if she ever could truly be that again.) the patrons were kind to her, mostly, and gave her generous tips. It wasn't too terribly long after, though, that she was back to at least keeping up the illusion of herself. Some nights were harder than others, even a full year after Tora had been taken, but Olga survived.

And night after night, she became a little bit more "herself" than the last.

In that time, Helga and Somaria had come to be like a sort of surrogate family to her. They had taken her in when she needed them, she and Helga lived together, and Somaria was always there for her with advice when Helga was being especially demanding. Having them around helped ease that tide of loneliness that rose and fell within her heart. Since all three worked at the Tavern and two of them were roommates (Somaria lived very close anyway, in a small one-bedroom home near the Tavern) so the three of them grew quite close. Despite the bickering and the teasing, Helga and Somaria obviously cared for Olga—a sentiment which she shared.

In a weird way, it almost felt like Olga had parents again. It wasn't the same of course, but... it had helped.

In fact, one of the best pieces of advice that had gotten Olga through her recent string of tragedies had come from Helga.

"You need to keep your mind occupied, blue eyes." Helga had said one day, early on, "When you're not at work, all you do is sit in your room. You need to go out. Or at least get a hobby or something. It'll help... trust me."

Olga had neglected to pry further into Helga's expertise on the matter, partially because it seemed personal and otherwise because that particular piece of advice had come at a time when she just wasn't ready to open up to anyone yet, but she had taken it to heart. It wasn't long before she had found herself a hobby to do after her time at the Tavern was spent.

Truly it was this that had kept her going. Helga was right, in so many more ways than one! It had given her confidence, she was learning a new skill, and every time she made a major breakthrough, Olga would feel over the moon! It made her happy to know that if her older sister could have seen her, and how much she had grown since Tora had been taken from her, she'd be proud of how far she'd come.

But truth be told, in all of her lifetime, Olga had never seen herself actually learning how to...
11131122.title: Olga, On her Own but Not Alone

choices: Helga—grown to more than twice the size she was when she took Olga in!
Greta—someone was wanting to speak to the "chef of Bleakfrost Tavern"?
A thief!—a black-clad cad looking for gold to steal from the Tavern!
111311221.content:
But truth be told, in all of her lifetime, Olga had never seen herself actually learning how to cook—and she never could have imagined that she'd be so good at it.

No one would have really considered Olga the "creative" type, so to say. When they were girls, Tora was always the one who picked the games that they played in the streets or around the house, and she had never really had much talent for painting or sketching like her mother had. Meanwhile her father, and eventually Tora, showed such a passion and tendency towards smithing and forging that Olga might have sworn up and down that they were born from the very coals that they used if she hadn't known better. Olga had never really given much thought to cultivating her own creative interests, even when she was left in the stead of her sister. There was gold to be made and tables to serve—Olga had no time for foolishness!

But now that she didn't have a sister to look after, or parents to help, Olga's time was almost exclusively open. When she wasn't busing tables and delivering meals to hungry customers, refilling mugs and mopping up spilled mead, Olga had nothing to do but find herself. And now that she lived in the Tavern with Helga, she had to find something to keep her mind occupied and to distract herself that she wasn't living in her home of eighteen years.

So one night, Somaria had asked for her help in the kitchen. It was an especially busy night—a troupe of minstrels had wandered into Racovania unannounced and kept the town up far into the night—and, despite her inherit clumsiness around the kitchen, she offered to help the poor overworked woman. What began as paced tips and orders barked over steaming pots at the haste of hungry customers gradually became actual lessons. As the night wore on and the bards tired, Somaria's fires cooled and she took the time to teach Olga her way around the kitchen.

The meats were kept there, the salt there, this was the spice rack, this was how to make stew...Just a precaution, really. In case Somaria ever got sick, someone needed to know how to cook for the Tavern—it'd go out of business!

But after a couple more nights, Olga found herself bored, and Somaria found herself in the teaching sort of mood. Soon Olga was learning how to make dishes and soups, what to put where in order to make her meal scrumptious and inviting.

Before long, Olga was in the kitchen almost every night for a study session with Somaria! She would spend up to two hours after she hung up her apron taking notes and experimenting with the firepit. Sometimes she'd make sauces to be drizzled on the meat, sometimes she'd cook the meat, and sometimes Somaria would let her bake the sweet rolls. And with every passing day, it seemed, Olga came closer and closer to matching Somaria's years of practice.

But more importantly, she liked to cook. It took her mind off of more recent troubles. Olga could throw herself into the kitchen, and walk out with her head held high and a deserved sense of accomplishment.

Was this how her father would feel after forging a sword or armor? Is this how Tora felt when she took over their forge?

The thought would sometimes bring a little tear to her eye as she carried this treat or that into the dining area of the tavern, much to the applause of whomever she happened to be waiting on. More often than not it was Helga—most of her "experimenting" came to fruition after hours, when only Helga remained—but even the taverners had taken a shine to her cooking. It meant a lot, knowing that so many people thought her skills were coming along so quickly.

***


It was a night like any other in Bleakfrost Tavern.

Olga had just finished preparing a hearty plate of sweet rolls as practice for the upcoming festivities. These would keep until the morning, and would make fine appetizers for the Racovanian Festival. She would place them in the pantry to keep, that way they'd be safe from Helga's greedy fingers. Not that Olga could blame the tubby tavern keeper—her cooking really was coming along nicely.

Incidentally, Olga would have to make a mental note to go by the dressmaker's shop a little further into town. And to stop sampling from her own wares, unless she wanted to pop out of her dress in the middle of the festival.

The many hours in the kitchen, surrounded by all that wonderful food and privvy to popping little bits of this and that into her mouth to taste, Olga wasn't quite as lithe as she used to be. All her frequent snacking had put some extra padding along the edges of her figure; her bust was bigger and her hips were wider. Between them, a soft little tummy was developing as a slight curve outwards. It was nothing serious—in fact, most of the barflys had barely noticed it. But it was a little troubling to know that her dress from last year's festival that she had bought before Tora had been...

Well, she hadn't worn it last year. Maybe it was tight then too, and she just didn't know it.

Olga shook those thoughts out of her head. She had a big day tomorrow—and was getting paid as such. She'd be working all night in the Tavern, but in the kitchen. Helga had Greta and Claris (her newest, youngest and prettiest barmaids) picking up Olga's slack while she worked alongside Somaria at the fires. She couldn't afford to let herself get down now, when she was going to be working from nine til well into the next morning.

As Olga opened the door to place her tray of sweetrolls into the pantry, a second set of hinges squeaked behind her.

Olga whipped around, the kitchen door opening to reveal...
111311221.title: The Cheery Chef in Bleakfrost Tavern

choices: "Word of our tavern's cooking has spread—we're getting quite famous you know!"
"Theres a chef's school in the Plains—after the festival, why don't you enroll?"
"I sort've need you to run a very special errand for me..."
1113112211.content:
"Aye, blue eyes!"

Olga breathed a sigh of relief. It was just Helga in the doorway; she must not have heard her heavy footsteps, or the floorboards below her squealing at her girth. How a woman of that size had snuck up on her, Olga would never know—she really was thinking too hard about Tora.

In the time it had taken Olga to realize her passion and calling for the kitchen, Helga had become twice the woman in weight that she had been before she had taken Olga in. Perhaps it was a consequence of having two talented chefs at her beck and call, or perhaps it was Olga's fault for being a bit too insistent that she tell her how she had done on this dish or that, but regardless of the reason, Helga the Taverner had become very large indeed.

Her long brown hair fell over her heavy shoulders, rolling and cascading like a river of chocolate past her chubby cheeks and resting onto her heaving chest. She was breathing hard, no doubt from toddling all the way from her room to the Tavern's larder. How often, Olga wondered, did Helga make such a trip in order to get so large? Olga definitely wasn't feeding her that much extra. And Somaria was always insistent that Helga stop eating so much recently, so it wasn't her fault either. Where had that big belly come from? It was bigger around now than almost anyone, short of that Orc who hung out at the Inn, could reach. It fell into two distinct rolls, outlined by the tautness of her dress and even her aprons. Her arms were thick and wide, much like her legs. It had gotten to the point where Helga rarely dismissed herself from behind the bar due to her colossal hips and overly broad bum getting stuck fast in the space between it and the wall.

"Helga!" Olga exclaimed, her chest pounding, "You nearly scared me to Damus and back!"

"I apologize!" Helga said, her accent as thick and rolling as her waistline, "I knew you were poking around back here, practicing for tomorrow. I just wanted to see you to bed!"

"Uh-huh." Olga put her hands on her hips wisely, "You can't fool me, you sneakthief. You were going to walk me to my room and then thunder back here to raid the pantry again!"

"I was not!" Helga's round cheeks grew flush and hot, "Th-The thought that I would sabotage my own business with my own heedless snacking is ridiculous. You've been hanging around Somaria too much, girl!"

Having both Somaria and Olga around, both constantly creating treats and snacks that were off-menu and tantalizing to the taste, had certainly not done well for Helga. She had gotten so greedy and round, seemingly unable to go one day without a feast fit for the royalty of Adinah. Her weight had been the talk of the town lately. In a town where not much happening, a barmaid blowing up to twice her size in less than a year made for ready gossip, after all. The way she walked with her back arched, or how she stroked her gut greedily even in conversation, some had thought she was pregnant. Some still thought she was—perhaps with an Orc.

And that habitual stroking of her stomach told Olga that she was much more right than wrong. Even as she denied it, Helga couldn't keep her eyes off of the pantry. Her pink lips wetted as her breathing became husky.

"Well, maybe just a little." Helga rescinded, "I can't be helped for sampling my own wares, can I?"

"Go to bed, Helga." Olga chuckled, "I'll be done soon—don't want to nod off during all the partying I'll be doing."

"You had better be partying in my kitchen." Helga put her chubby hands on her wide hips, the change in stance making her belly bob menacingly in front of her, "You didn't make any plans tomorrow, did you?"

"Of course not, I was joking."

"Good." Helga softened, "But I didn't just come up here to chide you like an old nag. Or to get your guard down so I could raid my pantry."

"Really?" Olga piqued, her blue eyes wide with wonder, "What's up?"

"Well..." Helga purred...
1113112211.title: Huge and Hungry Helga

choices: "Pyknos Verge—We've got one of them Elves coming to visit us just for the food!"
"Motee Marshes—The Snake Queen is touring the countryside, and we're up next."
"the Caverns of Sarkos—the new high priestess is very sociable...and demanding."
11131122111.content:
"Word of our tavern's cooking has spread—we're getting quite famous you know!" Helga announced happily, her chubby cheeks spread softly by a smile, "It's all thanks to you and Somaria that we're getting so well known—and that I'm getting so fat."

The two of them shared a good-natured belly laugh at Helga's expense. Say what you want about the tremendous taverner, but at least she could take a joke. If anyone had pointed out Olga's recent, and comparatively tiny, weight gain like that she might have broken down into tears. But Helga's great gut wobbled and shook with mirth, her double chins quivering as she laughed.

"Well that's good!" Olga settled, her cheeks rosy, "I'm happy to know that my lessons with Ms. Somaria haven't been a complete waste."

"Don't talk like that, blue eyes." Helga said with joyful reassurance, taking a couple of heavy steps forward so that she was completely in the room, "You've been making me a lot of money since I brought you in. It's like you're my little golden hair good luck charm!"

See, it was comments like that that made Olga feel appreciated. Wanted. Maybe even loved. She had to get used to not having a family for the past year, but no one other than Helga and Somaria could have made the transition so much easier than it had already been. Between Helga being so generous and Somaria teaching her so much, Olga had fit right into the tavern lifestyle. Even the other barmaids were beginning to become like family to her.

"You're sweet, old woman." Olga said with a smile, a bit more somber than the last one, "Thanks for letting me play around in your kitchen."

"Not at all!" Helga said triumphantly, "In fact, I bring it all up because I really need you to bring your best to the table tomorrow. We're expecting visitors to this years Racovanian festival, and I can't have you slacking off."

Visitors? To Racovania? That almost never happened. Even with the festival being a big deal, the most "exotic" they got around here were the miners who lived further up north in the Peaks visiting home for the day. No one dared venture into Vampire Country. Even if they tended to stay to themselves, those bloodsuckers up the mountain had put quite a reputation on this place—one that kept away a lot of potential business!

"Visitors?" Olga repeated, closing the pantry door, "What do you mean?"

"Well, I say "visitors"... but what I should say is something like "foreign dignitaries". All yours and Somaria's cooking has attracted quite the crowd." Helga slouched onto the counter, which cut into her fluffy side like a knife, "In fact, word's reached as far as...
11131122111.title: Spreading the Word about Olga

choices: ...who's heavily pregnant, with an appetite of three, no four, no FIVE naga!
...she's become immensely fat, and is desperately trying to lose weight!
111311221112.content:
"Motee Marshes—the Snake Queen is touring the Countryside, and we're up next."

Olga couldn't help but squirm at the mention of the Naga. Living a relatively sheltered life in Racovania, she'd never had to deal with many reptiles. And the ones that she had were small, manageable. Decidedly less humanoid than any Naga that she'd ever heard of. They lived in the Southern region of Yndyre, a far cry from the icy region that Olga had called home all of her life. How could anyone be so excited to hear that the queen of those slithering serpents was coming to rain down scales on their little festival?

Come to think of it, how had she even heard of it?

"That's... great!" Olga said with a smile that she hoped didn't seem too forced, "Just... great..."

"You're damn straight it's great." Helga said in her thick accent, "Having someone of Queen Coatzintli's status at our festival is about as big a celebration as we get here up in these mountains—can you imagine, a whole city of them snake people gabbin' about what a good time we showed them up here?"

"Y-Yeah..." Olga cringed, "That'd sure be swell..."

"They'd send their dignitaries our way when they were in the area, we'd make so much more money—" Helga's fat face began to flush, "Oi, look at me... I'm getting myself worked up over it already."

It was here that a distinctive sound emanated from the other side of the room. Helga's gut growled urgently, commanding to be fed in order to ease her appetite. Whenever she got herself worked up like this, Helga had taken to eating. Exciting news called for a leg of lamb, and maybe a few pies to go around the bar after all. She had been in such good spirits since Olga had started helping out, it was no wonder Helga had gotten so large. What with staying leaned up against the bar, as she was now with her belly oozing over the countertop like that, Helga probably got more exercise working herself up than anything.

Meanwhile, Olga couldn't have been less enthused. She wasn't racist but...

Okay, maybe a little.

But she'd never met one of these snake people before. They sounded... they sounded creepy!

"With that in mind, Blue Eyes, you need to get to bed." Helga pushed herself off the counter with a grunt, "We've got ourselves a busy day ahead of us tomorrow."

And so she did. Olga closed the pantry (making sure that Helga was in no way close to the yummy contents inside!) and hurried off to bed. She did have a big day tomorrow, snake people or not. She couldn't be all tuckered out for her big day...

Little did she know, she would have her work cut out for her with this Queen Coatzintli...
111311221112.title: Catering to Coatzintli

choices: Yes of course! She would be a fool not to!
No...Olga needed to wait here to rescue her sister.
1113112211121.content:
The day finally arrived, and the village was all hustle and bustle as the festival went underway. There were drapes, attractions, food-stalls lining the roads; it was amazing watching this normally dreary rather dower hamlet suddenly spring to life.

Olga was on a short break, and using it well. The barmaid-turned-chef was exploring all the local sights, taking in every sight and smell around. As blonde lass took in an extra large breath she smelled something…new. It was an odd scent, like the earth after heavy rain, but much stronger. As she turned around that breath was lost as Olga opened her mouth in awe.

Rising above, and parting, the crowd was what appeared to be a large palanquin. The massive dais was covered in rich bright green foliage (that explained the rich earthy smell); as it approached Olga caught a glimpse of four large burly men that were lifting the stone and wood construct, they were wearing only some kind of toga made from heavy scales and their muscles were well oiled. But the oddest sight was just who it was that sat upon this portable throne.

At first Olga mistook the person for a human woman, but a second glance brushed that thought to the back of her mind. The figure lounging back had brown skin with black stripes above her waist, while below a thick heavy green tail (also with black stripes) coiled itself neatly like a spring. The figure was clearly female, with a pair of very imposing breasts and no less than four lithe arms; two of which were waving to the crowd while the others roved lower…to a gigantic belly!

Olga had been around quite a few years and she knew pregnancy when she saw it, but this serpentine woman looked more heavily pregnant than several woman put together! The serpent’s girth did not seem to distress her though, her thin face with its lacking nose looked calm and serene.

The barmaid continued to stare even as the palanquin passed her by. Finally shaking herself out of her trance Olga realized the time, her break must surely be up and the customers must be famished!

Diving back through the crowd and winding through some shortcut alleyways, Olga ran back to the Bleakfrost Tavern as fast as her long legs would carry her. Carefully she slipped through the tradesman’s entrance and began to slip her apron on just as Ms Somaria spotted her.

“Olga! Where have you been!” The older woman hissed.

“S-sorry…” Olga sheepishly replied.

“No time for ya sorry’s girl, you wouldn’t believe who just came in!” And with a beckoning finger, Somaria called Olga over to take a peek through a crack in the kitchen door. Olga’s eyes widened again as she saw the four burly men from before, standing with their arms crossed and acting as a wall of muscle between the other patrons and one very BIG customer.

Olga had not seen the Naga queen next to another person, but she never realized just how BIG the woman was! Had she been a human this green and brown-skinned queen would easily have been eight feet tall!

“She’s asked for more food than we have prepared!” Somaria explained, “We are going to need some of your magic touch here.”

And so Olga set to work, employing all her skill and technique she had learned since her sister’s abduction to cook up a storm. Each dish barely lasted a second before it was sent off disappear down the snake queen’s gullet.

Hours passed and still Olga cooked, how much could this woman eat!? Just as the blonde woman felt like she was going to pass out from exhaustion Somaria returned to her side.

“Do you mind taking this last one to her?” She asked; “My old leg is acting up.”

“Sure…” Olga replied, half in a haze as she took what must have been an entire cake and wandered out. As Olga approached the guards they parted in one motion to reveal Coatzintli, the queen of the naga’s and lady of the Motee Marshes.

“Mmmm, divine!” The snake-woman cooed as she dropped a fork to her plate, her forked tongue licking her lips. It was then that she noticed the much smaller woman’s presence. “Ah! You there! I asked to see the cook of these fabulous dishes…is that you?”

Olga stood stunned for a second, dam she had been tricked. Somaria must have sensed she was nervous earlier.

“Y-yes your majesty.” Olga replied, trying to bow whilst still holding on to the cake.

“I must congratulate you.” The queen replied as she snapped her fingers and nodded to one of the guards, who took the cake and placed it at the queen’s table; without wasting a second she began to dig in. Queen Coatzintli was certainly ravenous that was for sure, but she was sure dainty about it. Every swift twirl of her fork was elegant and never spilled a drop onto the masses of gold that covered her gravid figure.

And boy was she looking round! Olga didn’t know that naga’s had super-stretchy skin, otherwise there was no way Coatzintli could have demolished the food stores of an entire tavern by herself. But she sure looked like she had; the queen’s belly was carefully placed under her table, swelling out and downwards until her soft brown skin was just touching the wooden floor.

“Mmmm, exquisite, another perfect dish! I must say ever since I started being ready to spawn nobody has tickled my taste quite like you have…I do look forward to eating here every day, but it would pain me to leave such delicious food.” As another forkful of cake disappeared between her sharp teeth the queen’s eyes were the ones to bug. “You…” the stated firmly, turning her gaze for the first time to meet Olga’s.

The girl gulped, her majesty’s eyes were yellow with a black slit running vertically trough them, they seemed to pierce into her very soul.

“Do they pay you well here?”

Olga was caught unawares by that. “Uhhhh”

“Is that a yes or a no? Because if not I can offer you a very…handsome salary. My kitchen staff no not how to cook like this, and I would adore for your cooking to be available to me at any day or time.”

“They uh…pay me enough here…” Olga replied a little more firmly.

“What a shame…because I AM a queen you know…I can pay any price you want; do you desire richs? I have gold, jewels…or is it romance you seek? I can offer one of my naga subjects as a bride if you so wish...”

Olga felt like she had a frog in her throat, go and work for a QUEEN? How could she respond to that!?
1113112211121.title: The appetite of a serpent

choices: "A bride to one of my advisors. A fat bride. She likes Humans."
"A part of my war advisor's obese harem."
Actually, her answer was different than expected...
11131122111211.content:
At first, Olga wanted to blatantly refuse such a temptatious offer, considering that she still needed to rescue her sister from the vampiric Stranken Family. But on the other hand though, she was being given the offer to work for a Queen. A Queen! One could swear her mind would blow a fuse or two upon thinking of what her ultimate decision should be. However, Queen Coatzintli soon queried once more toward the chubby chef and said, "So, my dear... What is your decision?"

Olga yelped nervously, swiftly turning her plump form to face the Naga Queen, where she hesitantly replied, "...Y-Yes! O-Of course I will work for you, y-your majesty!" Suffice to say, said frog in her throat made her croak aloud and unintentionally.

But then, in response to such an answer, Queen Coatzintli soon but sluggishly rose up from her lounged position, her pregnant-esque belly straddling against the front scales on her serpentine lower half. From there, she calmly slithered toward the plump Olga, where Coatzintli then grasped both of Olga's chubby hands, expressing a gleeful fanged grin on her brown-skinned face and said, "Tell me: What is your name?"

"...It's, um... O-Olga. Olga Forgedotter, y-your highness," Olga nervously answered, her somewhat cherubic face blushing profusely, considering that she honestly wasn't expecting to be holding hands with royalty today. And yet, here she was, holding hands with Naga royalty.

"...Well, Olga Forgedotter... You are quite lucky and skilled for a Human. I am looking quite forward to your culinary mastery when we return to the Motee Marshes in the South."

However, moments later, just as the Naga Queen was slithering back towards her lounge area, Olga's mind began to race once more, wondering what she should do now. That was, until an idea popped into her head, as she instinctively blared out, "A-Actually, um... T-There is something you can do for me, your highness."

In response to such a query, Coatzintli then turned around to confront the tubby human female and questioned, "Oh? And what exactly do you have in mind?"

Olga nervously fidgeted with her chubby hands a little, her eyes darting from left to right slightly as she hesitantly retorted, "...It's...I-It's my dear sister, Tora, she... *sob* ...She was taken from me by the Strankens. I-If you could possibly negotiate for her release, I'll... I'll, um... Please! I'll do anything for you if you free my sister!!" And just like that, Olga began to mentally break down, worried day and night over the fate of her older sister at the deathly hands of Cameena Stranken.

At first, Coatzintli felt a little embarrassed watching Olga bawl like an infant over the loss of the human's sibling. And yet, despite such an depressive outburst from the female chef, the Naga Queen couldn't help but feel a twinge of sympathy towards Olga's familial plight. It almost reminded Coatzintli of an event many moons ago when her beloved wife and childhood friend, Patli, was injured when they were younglings. Suffice to say, Olga's plight was certainly pulling one or two of Coatzintli's heartstrings. After all, it seemed it would be in her best interest to keep her new chef quite happy if she managed to negotiate for Tora's release and freedom.

So, after a full long minute of hearing Olga sobbing like a lost child, Coatzintli then approached the distressed female human, placing a hand upon the human's shoulder out of calm reassurance and answered, "I see you have endured much hardship, Olga Forgedotter. Fortunately, I am a benevolent leader of my people. So, out of sympathy for your plight, I will see if I can grant your sister freedom from her vampiric captors."

Upon hearing the words from Coatzintli's forked tongue, Olga swiftly wrapped her chubby arms around the Naga Queens bulbous fertile stomach while she yelped, "Thank you, Thank you, Thank you!!" Of course, such physical contact with the Naga Queen didn't exactly sit well with her entourage, as they began to maliciously leer towards Olga to intimidate her, but Coatzintli successfully persuaded them to back off some, considering how much of a fragile state Olga was currently in.

But then, Coatzintli gently placed a hand on Olga's cherubic face, leaning the human's head upwards to face the Naga Queen, where Olga still had a few tears streamjjng down her somewhat chubby cheeks. From there, Coatzintli spoke toward Olga with a clear but commanding tone of voice as she quipped, "However, there is a certain...condition, you will have to endure if you want my aid in your sister's freedom, my dear Olga."

"Anything. I'll do anything to save my sister, your highness," Olga retorted, showing a wave of utter conviction towards rescuing her sibling from the vampire lords of Racovania. Right now, she didn't care if such a condition included becoming a part of a Naga noble's obese harem, or becoming an immobile obese pet or bride to one of the Naga Queen's personal advisors. Overall, she almost didn't care about her own fate at this point, as long as it meant granting her sister freedom from possibly a fate worse than death.

Eventually, after a moment or two of silence, Coatzintli spoke toward Olga and said, "I admire your conviction and bravery, Olga Forgedotter. But as for what the price shall be for your sister's freedom, you will have to become..."
11131122111211.title: An Irrefusable Offer

choices: "Because I prefer some variety in my life."
"Because I heard you are the best cook in Racovania. Are you not?"
Actually, her answer was entirely different than expected....
111311221112111.content:
"...One of my advisors, Quessa, has been quite... let's say 'fascinated,' with your species, with humans..." Coatzintli explained, divulging on what the price was for her granting Olga's sister freedom from the Strankens. She continued to speak toward the chubby Olga Forgedotter while she slithered toward a nearby window, observing the jagged mountaintops as she explained, "Now, I am not one to pry into such personal trivial matters that each of my advisors hold dear, unless it involves the safety and well-being of my people, whether they be warrior, farmer, priestess, or noble."

"What....are you saying, your highness?" Olga asked, attempting to steady her rattled nerves while she keenly listened in on every word spewing forth from the Naga Queen's forked tongue.

Of course, in response to such an unavoidable question, Coatzintli calmly turned around to face the plump female chef, all four of her arms positioned behind her back as she retorted, "What I am saying, Olga Forgedotter, is that if you truly seek my aid in granting Tora her freedom from Racovania's vampiric lords and ladies...you will have to become the bride to my advisor, Quessa. Now, you will still be given the duty of being my personal chef, catering to giving me such addictive...'delicacies.' However..."

From there, Coatzintli soon calmly but slowly slithered toward Olga, where she then placed one of her lower arms and hand upon the chubby human's left shoulder, as she continued speaking toward Olga and continued, "Once we return to our capital city, Vaal Za'haraam, you will be arranged into a marriage with Quessa." Obviously, Olga could clearly see that Queen Coatzintli wasn't sugarcoating every detail of what would transpire within the near future of her life, thus allowing the depth of such a price for her sister's freedom to sink in.

And yet, deep within the recesses of her subconscious, Olga didn't seem to care that this would be her fate, just as long as her older sister would be free from the Strankens. Right now, she didn't give a damn about her own fate, just Tora's, and nothing else. But, if she was to be betrothed to one of the Queen's advisors...so be it. However, another thought seemed to have crawled it's way into her subconscious, where she soon uncharacteristically but calmly spoke toward the Naga Queen and bluntly replied, "I don't care about what my fate will be from now on, your highness. Just as long as Tora is safe and free of the Strankens. Nothing more, nothing...less."

Slightly surprised at how determined the chubby female chef seemed to be, Coatzintli then displayed a calm but reassuring smirk, where she then patted Olga on the shoulder twice or thrice then retorted, "Your determination to save your sibling is quite admirable, Olga Forgedotter. I must admit, I never have thought humans such as yourself would display such bravery and courage in the face of...inevitability."

"Thank you, your highness. But...if I had to ask, what is your...advisor, Quessa, really like? If I am to be her betrothed, at least tell me who she is like to you," Olga asked, lowering her head some to show respect toward her superior, despite the racial and species difference.

Fortunately for the plus-sized female chef, Coatzintli was quite willing to disclose such information to her new personal chef. After all, Olga had undoubtedly proven herself to learn such information, where the Naga Queen slowly yet calmly slithered around Olga in a wide circle, speaking toward the female human as she thoroughly explained, "Your bravery, courage, and tenacity is commendable, Olga Forgedotter. Thus, you deserve the right to learn of your betrothed. Quessa, she is...'unique,' to say the least. Before I became Queen, she was one of my closest friends, always the optimist. And yet, she was known to have, um...what is it that you human's call something unique to an individual?"

"Quirks?" Olga said, answering Coatzintli's question, thus allowing the Naga Queen to continue speaking as she continuously explained,

"Ah, quirks! Thank you, Olga Forgedotter. Anyway, she had these, 'quirks,' as you humans would say, which always involved studying and understanding humans. From your kingdoms, to your laws, even your...anatomy. Eventually, shortly after I was coronated, I made her and a few other exceptional Nagas as my council of advisors, with Quessa being Priestess of Knowledge, archiving our civilization's history and lore with extensive proficiency.

"And yet, even after many moons have passed, her fondness over your species had only increased in ambition and anticipation. It is one of the reasons why I have decided to journey across the lands of Yndyre, from the vast forests of the Pyknos Verge, to the sprawling cities of the Futotta-Machi, even to the snowy mountains of Racovania," Coatzintli answered, where she then looked out the window and observed as the sun hid behind the jagged mountaintops and mountain peaks. From there, Coatzintli soon turned her head to look back at Olga once more, where she continued to speak as she explained, "Overall, my point is, Olga Forgedotter, that if you are worried if Quessa will chain you to a wall and study you like a parasitic disease. Then fret not, she is not a malicious individual. For most of my life, I have known Quessa to be very compassionate towards others. And who knows, Olga Forgedotter? There is a chance you will truly find her as your one and true soul mate. *chuckle*"

Of course, Olga couldn't help but feel somewhat relieved from Coatzintli's solemn truthful words, even though her biggest priority was to free her sister from the vampiric Strankens and their fortress of a manor. However, shortly after that, Coatzintli then gestured one of her servants to pour a pitcher filled with what appeared to be alcohol into a bronze engraved goblet and a iron beer mug. From there, Coatzintli handed the beer mug to Olga, who swiftly grabbed it, while Coatzintli grabbed the engraved goblet. Obviously, the plump chef spoke toward the Naga Queen and asked, "Um... Your Highness? What is this?"

"This is a special brew of my people's famed alcohol. We call it 'Serpen-Kaja.' We usually use this in special ceremonies of romance and fertility. Consider it as a 'consolation gift' to what will be in store for you when we arrive in Vaal-za'haraam," Coatzintli elaborated, just as Olga took a good sip of Serpen-Kaja from her mug, feeling the alcohol's tangy but spicy taste, nearly spitting the brew from her mouth due to how intense the flavor was. "Do not worry, your tongue will become accustomed to it's intensity, Olga Forgedotter," Coatzintli replied, just as Olga managed to recover enough to speak.

Once more as she asked, "Your Highness, you...you said earlier that you would like me to be your personal chef, but you never gave me a reason for such an offer. Why me? You probably have a small army of cooks dedicated to serving you. Why pick me over them?"

From listening to Olga's question, Coatzintli understood that the chubby female human wanted to know why the Naga Queen chose her over numerous cooks and chefs in the whole Motee Marshes, which did raise a valid point to the dark-skinned Naga Queen. So, after a sip of Serpen-Kaja from her engraved goblet, Coatzintli then looked back towards the plus-sized female chef, gazing upon her with a pair of serpentine eyes and calmly answered...
111311221112111.title: A Bridal Exchange

choices: Meanwhile, Olga returns to her home to sleep it off.
The next day, Coatzintli fulfills her end of the bargain.
Actually, something else happened instead...
1113112211121112.content:
"Why pick a human such as yourself over much of my people's finest culinary artists? *chuckle*" Coatzintli quipped, chuckling a little over Olga's semblance of curiosity. So in response to such curiosity, Coatzintli casually slithered her way toward the plump female chef, almost to the point where the front scales on the Naga Queen's serpentine lower half was clearly brushing against the front of Olga's outfit and chubby potbelly, as if Coatzintli was almost boasting her physical dominance over the human, as Coatzintli looked down at Olga due to towering over her.

From there, she continued speaking toward Olga and explained, "Because, Olga Forgedotter... I heard that you are the best cook in all of the villages in Racovania. Plus, I am one for quality over quantity. When I entered the first village of Racovania, some of the humans in the tavern spoke highly of your mouth-watering cuisines and delicacies with great reverence and appraise. Tell me, with your heart...do you truly believe yourself worthy of such appraise, Olga Forgedotter of Bleakfrost Tavern?"

Obviously, hearing that her still-growing reputation managed to reach the ears of the Naga Queen, Coatzintli of the Motee Marshes, Olga couldn't help but become a little unnerved from such a question. After all, her mentor, Somaria, was the one who truly deserved such praise, not her. After all, she was merely a prodigy, who still had a lot to learn in the culinary arts. So eventually, after five full minutes had passed, Olga proceeded to gulp heavily out of nervousness before she even uttered a word. From there, Olga slowly began to speak toward the dark-skinned Naga Queen, still showing signs of unease as she bluntly answered, "...I...I-I never truly claimed myself to be THE best cook in all of Racovania. That title...i-it belongs to m-my mentor, Somaria. I-I'm merely a student t-taking lessons from someone m-more experienced than me. B-But I... I can promise you th-this, your highness: I...I put a lot of heart, passion, and soul into every p-plate of food I cook, whether it's a slab of meat or a barrel of mead."

As Olga spoke toward her, Coatzintli began to see the truth in the human cook's words, whilst Olga continued to speak as she explained, "...I-I may not be a true master cook like Somaria, but... I am a swift learner a-and a keen listener. I-If you want a specific m-meal in mind, I-I can make sure it is cooked to your needs and desires. You m-must be pregnant if y-your belly is as big as it is n-now, I-I can make sure you have enough food to feed both you and your hatchlings." When Olga was finally finished talking, Coatzintli soaked in every truthful word that came out of the chubby female chef's mouth, as it began to paint a clear enough mural within the Naga Queen's subconscious.

Eventually, after several long minutes of silence, Coatzintli eventually came to a decision, where she soon began to understand what made Olga Forgedotter such an extraordinary culinary artist. From there, Coatzintli displayed a generous fanged grin, where she then placed all four of her hands upon Olga's rounded shoulders, gently patting them once or twice as she boldly answered, ...I admire the truth and conviction in your words, Olga Forgedotter. You truly have the heart of a Marsh Wolf: honest, tenacious, and unrelenting. You truly have earned my respect. This is why I have chosen you as my personal chef."

In a way, Olga felt like her heart had skipped a beat or two from the tension and suspense. However, she was undoubtedly glad to have earned Queen Coatzintli's respect out of all that has happened to her recently. But in the end, all of this insanity might be worth it if Coatzintli could truly free her sister. So, in response to the Naga Queen's gesture, Olga looked up at Coatzintli with a reassured smile on her cherubic face, where she then spoke toward the dark-skinned Naga and said, "Thank you, your highness. I'm glad to have earned your respect."

"The pleasure is all mine, Olga Forgedotter." Coatzintli quipped, where she then looked outside the nearby window and witnessed the skyline darken and fade to black. From there, she soon turned back to face Olga and said, "Well, it seems it might time for you to head home, Olga Forgedotter."

"Wait, what about my sister? You promised to rescue her!" Olga exclaimed, which soon prompted Coatzintli's bodyguards to brandish their golden spears, thinking that Olga was threatening their queen. However, Coatzintli swiftly gestured her bodyguards to stand down and lower their weapons, which they reluctantly did.

From there, Coatzintli placed all four of her hands upon Olga's rounded shoulders once more, staring directly at her, where the dark-skinned Naga Queen then spoke toward the chubby female chef and calmly but sternly answered, "I have not forgotten what was promised, Olga Forgedotter. We Nagas never break a promised oath." Fortunately, this managed to calm Olga down some, as Coatzintli continued speaking toward her as she explained, "Listen, I greatly understand the concern for your sister, Olga Forgedotter. But right now, I need you to head to your home dwellings and rest. After all, you will need your strength for the journey back to Vaal-Za'haraam. I promise by tomorrow morning, you shall see Tora once more."

Left with little to no other choice, Olga reluctantly complied with Coatzintli's solemn oath, as she huffed out a deep sigh of stress, where she then spoke toward the Naga Queen and replied, "*sigh*...I understand, your highness."

From there, Olga walked toward the coat rack and put on her ramshackled winter coat, ready to head out and return to her home, as she pulled open the wooden door, allowing the cold mountainous air to flow through. However, before she exited the Bleakfrost Tavern, Olga soon turned to look back at Coatzintli then firmly said, "I'm not leaving my village until my sister's free from Cameena Stranken."

And with that, Olga finally left the tavern, closing the door behind her in the process. Moments later, one of Coatzintli's bodyguards approached the Naga Queen, where she then spoke to her and asked, "Not to be rude, My Queen, but... Are you sure that this is a wise decision? Eviana Stranken and her brood are quite persistent in keeping what they claim to be theirs."

"Yes, I am fully aware of their persistence, Shemal. But then again, this isn't my family's first time negotiating with these 'bloodsuckers.' And besides... I have something in my possession that Eviana Stranken herself has been yearning for for five centuries now."
1113112211121112.title: The Best There Is
