1113112211121112211121122121424312131.content:
Tora eventually decided that it was now or never. She had to have some way to understand what was going on with her sister. Maybe if she heard Olga's side of the story, she would get it. If not, then maybe she would be able to at least respect her decision. She took a deep breath and plunged for it.

Olga had been given the day off, for now anyway. The naga queen had gone into her state of laying her hundreds of eggs, and clearly wasn't in a mood for eating anything right now, so overtaken by the ordeal. Quessa had been sent for to be at the queen's side and offer particular blessings and remedies. That left Tora completely alone with her sister.

"So...I wanted to ask you something, and try not to get mad about it, okay?" Tora began, sitting beside Olga, but then scooting back a bit when she felt the uncomfortable squish of both of their bulks squeezing together. "But, what exactly is going on with you and Quessa? I mean, I know you're married and all, but how does that even come about?"

She didn't seem to mind the question. That, or perhaps Tora just hadn't said it right. "Well, that was part of the arrangement I made to bargain for your freedom. I would become the queen's chef, and marry one of her priestesses."

"I know all that," Tora said. "But, I mean, it's not like you act like you had to marry her. You look like you actually care about her. I don't want to be judgmental or anything, but I just don't see it. I don't see you in that kind of light. So, just help me understand: why do you love Quessa, or how did you love her?"

She laughed. "It's hard to explain, I guess. Yes, at first, I wasn't at all interested in the marriage. I just did it to save you. To be perfectly honest, at first, Quessa was really off-putting. She doesn't exactly understand personal space, but that may just be how naga are used to communicating. She's sometimes loud and over-excitable. And, someone who's that peppy all the time can be tiring. But, she was incredibly nice and helpful, especially when I was missing you so much."

Tora nodded, having followed along so far. Perhaps then, it was just a situation in which Quessa had become a "replacement" sister while Tora had been in a coma, and thus, Olga was confusing a very strong friendship with love.

Olga continued, "But I guess things changed around the time of the rainy season feasts. I felt like a fish out of water there. I've never seen such a culture as this before, and it all felt strange and new. Quessa just made me feel...like I wasn't a stranger, and that I actually mattered. She focused only on me that whole time. She did everything she could to make me feel better in this new world. I've never had anyone do that before. No one's ever given that much time an attention to me before, like I was the only person in the world to them." Tora coughed. Olga backpedaled. "No, no, I don't mean that you haven't, but it's just been different, you know? Oh, I don't know how to explain it, but Quessa made me her equal in a place where I felt so small and inferior. That...that means a lot to me."

Tora listened intently. Olga spoke with such passion and sincerity, it was hard not to hang on her every word right now.

"So, I don't know," Olga finished. "It just sort of worked out in a way I can't explain. I really do love her, Tora. It's not some passing infatuation like before when I was a girl. She really is special to me. And, I know you're having trouble understanding everything and getting used to everything. I would be too if I woke up out of a spell and coma for several months. But, if you just give her a chance, I think you'll like her as much as I have...well, maybe not that much. She is my wife after all."

She laughed, but took her sister's hand in hers. Tora wasn't sure she understood all of it. After all, she had never been in love, true love that is, before, so she had no context to compare this to. Yet, she did trust that her sister was honest in her feelings, and that there would be no changing them anytime soon.

"Sure," she said. "I'm glad you've found someone who makes you feel special, and I'd like to try and like her myself. Quessa is nice and everything, but how do you...you know, get past the snake thing?"

Olga giggled. "It wasn't easy at first, I'll admit. But, after a while you get used to it. Besides, the four arms really makes up for it. She really is pretty grabby in bed."

Tora pinched a little of Olga's flabby side. "Well, she certainly has a lot to grab, that's for sure. Does that worry you any? Quessa said that most everyone loses the rainy season weight, but..."

"A little. I mean, it is starting to make moving around the kitchens a bit of a trick. I've knocked over a few things, as wide as I am, but I don't mind too much. I figure this is going to be what I look like after every rainy season anyway."

Her stomach started to growl on cue. "Hm, a good meal sounds good right now. I know Quessa's still busy at the palace, but I can whip something up. Come on."

Tora shook her head, heaved herself up, and followed Olga to the kitchens.

11131122111211122111211221214243121312.content:
As the dry season progressed, things seemed to return to normal among the nagas. Very few of them lazed about their homes anymore. As their fat stores had helped them conserve energy, and their metabolisms came back to speed, many left to go and conduct business as usual in the city. There was a bit of a fuss the day the queen celebrated laying all her eggs, and the city held a grand festival, but otherwise, their otherwise humdrum lives resumed.

To an extent, that had happened for Tora and Olga, but they weren't exactly blessed with all the usual trappings of things resuming to normal.

"Ugh, there has to be an easier way," Tora sighed as she managed to heave her bulk out of bed that morning.

Despite everything, the two sisters of Racovania had remained just as fat as they had after the end of rainy season, Olga perhaps being a tad heavier since then. Perhaps that was because what the naga considered a scarcity of food was nothing at all like the occasional famines the girls had been used to back up north. To them, there seemed to be plenty of food, if how much triceratops meat Olga packed away every night was any indication. Perhaps nagas needed much more food than humans, Tora reasoned.

Still, the sister's reactions to this situation varied greatly. Tora bemoaned the fact that she hadn't lost even an inch of her size since waking up. Of the two, she really wasn't eating all that much. She didn't care for the dinosaur meat, and found herself giving at least the other half of her meals to her sister. Still, she remained flabby, wide, and big as a house, she thought.

True, Tora hadn't exactly been a skinny twig of a girl before, nor did she obsess over being a slender and attractive catch like all the other girls in town had done back home. But, she had been hoping that now that she wasn't being stuffed around the clock like she had been under Cameena's care, she would perhaps go back to her original size, or at least start to. It seemed she had made no headway, and that upset her. She didn't want to be in the body that a vampire had created for her.

Olga, on the other hand, didn't seem to mind at all, and perhaps embraced it a little. And that may have been because Quessa encouraged it. She regularly told Olga how pretty she thought she looked, could hardly keep her hands off of some of Olga's fatter parts, and was part of the reason her meals were so generous. She felt loved, which meant, she had no reason to hate her size.

Perhaps that was what was bothering Tora. She had grown accustomed to her sister's relationship with the naga. It was still a bit creepy, since she didn't find nagas all that attractive, but she could clearly see that Olga was in good hands. Quessa really did love and respect her with all her heart. It was hard to not like that. But, at the same time, seeing them together reminded Tora that she didn't have anyone special in her life to make her feel comfortable, no matter what size. She could not help but feel a twinge of jealousy for that.

She waddled through the halls of their home to find a typical scene in the mornings. Quessa was bustling about before leaving for the temple, fetching Olga a hearty breakfast, which always helped give her the energy to start her day in the queen's kitchens. She was just finishing the meal, licking meat juices off of her fingers, her belly full and almost taut.

"Mmmm, I'm starting to wonder who's the cook around here," Olga laughed. "I've never eaten this good back in Racovania."

Quessa giggled, placing a hand on Olga's middle. "Well, of course not. You were such a skinny, little waif of a thing back then. What on earth were your people living on? I can't imagine going that hungry."

"Mostly mutton," Tora answered, sitting across from the two. "Mostly sheep farmers in the area. Sometimes we'd get beef if we were so lucky."

"Oh, Tora, I didn't hear you come in," Olga said. "Did you want some breakfast?"

"A little, not too much though."

Olga looked concerned at her sister. "What's wrong? You don't seem like yourself."

"Just didn't sleep well," Tora lied.

"Oh..." was all Olga said. "I guess I had better get going. The kitchens await."

She kissed Quessa on the cheek before tottering off. The naga priestess served a plate to Tora. "I don't think lack of sleep is what is bothering you," she said bluntly. "Surely it is something else bothering you."

"No offense, but I'm not interested in talking about it right now." Tora didn't mean to sound short, but it was hard for her to open up to anyone but her sister.

Still, that didn't seem to faze Quessa. "You know what I think? I think you're tired of being cooped up in this home all day. Olga and I have our positions in the city, but you still have not found your purpose here. Maybe you could try going and exploring the city? I'm sure inspiration will strike you soon enough."

It was better than nothing, and Tora had to admit she was getting a bit stir-crazy being here all the time. "Um, thanks, Quessa. Maybe I will."

111311221112111221112112212142431213122.content:
Although she had voluntarily explored a decent portion of the city of Vaal-Za'haraam, Tora eventually grew bored of repetitively waddling through the streets of the capital city. Suffice to say, the repetition seemed to be getting on her nerves quite easily.

Becoming a little worn out from waddling her corpulent self across parts of the Naga capital city, Tora soon managed to find herself a sturdy enough stone bench that could support her rotund girth. From there, she began to contemplate to herself, thinking aloud as she thought, "*sigh* I can't believe how huge this place is! And yet..."

Momentarily, she briefly groped the undercarriage of her flabby belly with a chubby hand, her mind weighing in on her available options. Then, she continued, "...Why can't I help but feel like I'm missing...something? *sigh* ...Maybe I should go pay my sister a visit. I just hope she's not too busy." Tora soon sluggishly dismounted herself from the stone bench and began waddling toward the Palace.

-- 45 minutes later --

Despite it being quite a struggle considering her newly established flab and bodily girth, Tora finally managed to reach the gilded palace of Vaal-Za'haraam, taking a brief moment to recover from such a long trek, which left her rather winded from all that waddling. Ahead of her, she could see two armored Naga guards standing firmly, watching over the main entrance armed with golden spears.

"*sigh* ...Well, Tora...Here goes nothing," Tora thought to herself, regaining her strength, as she waddled toward the main entrance to the gilded palace. However, before she could even proceed inside, the two Naga guards swiftly crossed their spears in an X formation, thus denying Tora access to the palace.

One of the two Naga guards firmly spoke toward Tora with an air of authority in her tone as she said, "No entry into the Palace of Vaal-Za'haraam except for the Queen, the High Priestesses, or any of the royal staff! Identify yourself and state your business."

"Um...My name is Tora Forgedotter. I-I am here to see the, um...Royal Chef, Olga Forgedotter. She's my sister," Tora hesitantly replied, obviously a little unnerved by the Naga guards intimidating presence.

Fortunately for Tora, just as the two Naga guards were about to deny Tora entry once more, Olga just appeared just a few yards away from the main entrance, where she then turned around and easily saw her equally large sibling outside the main entrance.

From there, she quickly waddled over toward the two Naga guards, quickly reassuring them as she retorted, "It's okay! She's telling the truth. You can let her in."

"Of course, Royal Chef! We were unaware of your relation to the human," the second Naga guard replied, and both guards uncrossed their spears, thus allowing Tora entry.

Olga answered, "It's perfectly alright. You're merely doing your jobs, that's all."

"*chuckle* We appreciate the compliment, Royal Chef," the first Naga guard retorted, just as Olga then grabbed her older yet equally fat sister by her chubby hands, pulling her along through the main entrance to the palace.

From there, as they both stood inside the lavish main lobby of the gilded palace, Olga spoke toward her sister with a cheerful demeanor and quipped, "So, what brings you all the way up here, sis?"

"Oh, um...To be honest, Olga, I...I kinda wanted to see you and where you work," Tora answered, which caused Olga to, despite her bulk, swiftly wrap her fat sibling in a flabby loving hug.

Olga then retorted, "Aww, that's so sweet of you, sis! Say, how about I show you where I work?"

"I...I would like that, Olga," Tora answered, which prompted Olga to swiftly grab her sister's hand and pull her along towards the palace kitchens.

Once both siblings passed through a pair of double doors, Tora's sense of smell was hammered with a barrage of various aromas, all of which originated from within the large, spacious, and ornate kitchen. There were large platters filled with delectable and succulent cuisines, ranging from large fattened roasted boars to hefty servings of pies filled with fruits from the Motee Marshes. Overall, Tora subconsciously began to drool a little from such delicious meals.

Off to the side, Tora could easily see four enormous iron grills and roast spits, as they were in the midst of cooking another batch of succulent meats. Overall, this definitely was a vast improvement over the kitchens back in the Bleakfrost Tavern. However, Tora could also see that Olga wasn't the only chef in the kitchen, as Tora noticed that each of the 4 to 5 Nagas were considerably chubby and plump. But hey, as the old saying goes: "Never Trust A Skinny Chef".

But then, just as Olga was about to introduce her sister to her fellow chefs, they suddenly witnessed a massive and rotund Naga slither her way inside the palace kitchen, who was none other than Queen Coatzintli herself. Immediately, the other Naga chefs suddenly ceased their activity to bow before their elephantine ruler, as Coatzintli calmly approached Olga, easily bearing a friendly expression on her cherubic face.

From there, Olga began to speak toward the substantially larger Naga Queen and cheerfully queried, "Welcome to the palace kitchen, your Highness! So, what brings your royal presence before us, my Queen?"

"Not much, Olga Forgedotter. Though I must admit, we are truly grateful that you have accepted our offer to become our personal Royal Chef. But as you are aware at this point, Olga Forgedotter..." Coatzintli answered, where she began to lightly drum the side of her vast apron belly with both her plump upper and lower left hands, "I am carrying yet another batch of future Naga, thus I am required to gain an enormous amount of weight to properly give birth to such an amount of offspring."

"Of course, your Highness! We'll make sure you're getting more than enough food to eat," Olga swiftly replied, agreeing to give the Naga Queen the necessary sustenance to aid in Coatzintli's pregnancy.

But then, just as she was about to give thanks to Olga, Coatzintli easily became aware of Tora, looking at her with a curious look in her serpentine eyes, which made Tora cower behind her sister, which of course, failed miserably due to her bulk and girth.

"Oh? And who is this, Olga Forgedotter?" Coatzintli curiously queried.

This soon prompted Olga to introduce her sister to the Naga Queen, as the rotund female chef swiftly answered, "Oh, I almost forgot! Your Highness, this is my older sister, Tora. Tora, allow me to introduce you to the very individual who helped me rescue you from the Strankens: Queen Coatzintli, Queen of the Nagas." Olga waddled a bit off to the side to reveal Tora to Coatzintli and vice-versa. Suffice to say, Tora was undoubtedly unnerved some by Coatzintli's sheer size and girth, which was understandable considering.

From there, despite her immense bulk and girth, Coatzintli proceeded to bow a little in greetings toward the rotund Tora, where the elephantine Naga Queen then spoke toward Tora and said, "It is a pleasure to meet the sibling of such a talented individual in the culinary arts. Although we have previously met in the snowy mountains of Racovania, I'm afraid you were in not the best predicament to properly greet us."

"...Yeah, even though my memories are still a little...vague, from what happened during my time with Cameena Stranken, your Highness, I, um...I vaguely remember...someone, carrying me out of that damned nightmare," Tora replied, lightly scratching the back of her head a little.

Coatzintli then retorted, "But still, we are greatly relieved to see that you have made a full recovery, Tora Forgedotter. I was well-informed about your progress by my High Priestess of Knowledge, Quessa."

But then, Coatzintli spoke toward the two siblings once more and said, "I assume that you are not currently busy at this moment, Olga Forgedotter?"

"*giggle* Fortunately for you, your Highness, I am just about to take a lunch break when my sister stopped by for a visit. Why?" Olga quipped, just as Coatzintli turned herself around.

She looked back towards the two equally obese siblings and queried, "Would you both mind taking a stroll with me around the palace? We would appreciate the company."

"Of course, your Highness!" Olga swiftly replied, which made Coatzintli gleam with a fanged grin on her cherubic face, where they soon followed the elephantine Naga Queen out of the Palace Kitchen and down a lavish marble hallway. However, whilst they slowly trekked through the palace...

1113112211122.content:
In a spirit unseen since she was a girl, Olga's sleepy town was thrust wide awake with the arrival of the Naga from the South.

The morning after was when the had arrived. Naga women slithering up the mountainside with their queen. Most of them were taller than the strongest and hardy men of the sleepy mountain country, and they looked to be just as strong. The sight of them intimidated the uneducated farm folk of the land. Vampires, they were used to. Fangs and bloodlust were all there in their new guests, met with scales and an extra set of arms, the fact that they towered over the women and children, and just the way that they wriggled across the ground... Olga wasn't the only one who felt that they ought not to have stopped here.

But what were they going to do? Aggrivate them? That didn't seem smart.

Especially not when they seemed to be in such good spirits.

Foreign music filled the cobblestone streets of Racovania upon their arrival as the approaching monarchy made its presence known. Queen Coatlzintli was a massive slug of a snake, standing more than half as tall again than any of the others in her entourage and incalculably more fat, being carried by a rhumba of their most robust warriors on a dais. Her great green tail, thicker than even the oldest tree in Racovania by several times over, flicked and sloshed uselessly while her great brown blubber rippled and quaked at the uneven terrain. She waved her uppermost arms, bigger around than most women, pleasantly as her puddling face smiled. A smaller snake woman, surprisingly slender and without much muscle, waved happily at the astonished crowd of farmers stuck stupid by such a sight.

"They're celebrating new life." Somaria said, hands on her hips as she watched the snake women come into town, "The queen has endured an especially heavy birth, if memory serves."

"You can say that again." Olga watched the tens of servants huff and puff beneath their queen, "She's enormous."

"That's new." Somaria said with a wry smile, "Queen Coatlzintli takes after her mother, that much is for certain."

"Aye, she's a fat fuckin' wad that one." Helga huffed as she waddled out from behind the counter, "But that just means she's gonna be a hungry fat wad, so let's stop gawkin' an' get out there an' make some money."

***


The awkwardness of having these creatures at their festival was palpable. The Racovanians weren't too keen about sharing the celebration of their survival from being picked off by monsters with other, less {i]outwardly cannibalistic monsters. And the naga were equally testy, being cold-blooded and in a land that didn't get much warmer than a brisk springtime. Not to mention the fact that their hosts were uneducated, ill-tempered farmers.

But alcohol helped--alcohol always helped.

The Bleakfrost Tavern was booming with business. Helga had gone and sent word ahead that snake women would get the first drink free and, upon being informed that there was no way that would do any damage to a naga's metabolism, Helga generously bumped it up to two. So again, her place was popular.

These snake women ate like holes--like you were shoving the food into their mouths to try and fill up their tails! In the money they spent giving away two free ales, they made that and more back keeping them well-fed. The barmaids were busy trying not to trip over their long bodies as the tavern filled with Coatzintli's personal entourage, plus some of their more open-minded customers. Olga and Somaria were kept in the back, keeping up with the orders as well as they could, while Helga did her best to keep the guests entertained.

"Mmm, you're a big one." one of Coatzintli's guard purred, her cheeks flush as her tail flicked flirtatiously back and forth, "Are you with child?"

"Aye, a food baby." Helga sloshed her gut proudly, her accent drunk and thick, "Been eatin' great since I got m'new chef!"

"You remind me of our queen." the naga slurred, leaning into the bar to better pitch woo at her hostess, "Would you like to be my queen tonight, human?"

Olga wretched as she avoided the scene as best she could. Something about these snakes didn't sit right with her, and the idea of her boss getting cozy with one made her feel very uncomfortable. She pushed through the door to the kitchen and placed the empty dishes she'd collected on the low wooden table by the door. Somaria leaned against the stone wall, wiping sweat from her deep brown brow.

"Ms. Somaria, I don't understand why they're all coming here." Olga grouched, "I mean, there's a whole town to explore."

"Helga's good with customers." Somaria said in an aside sort of way, "She knows how to keep naga entertained just as well as she does humans."

"Yeah but, still..." Olga trailed off, scraping the scraps out the window and grabbing her rag, "I just don't understand why it had to be here..."

Somaria rolled her eyes and served the roast.

"You've got a lot to learn, Blue Eyes." she said, "About the world, and about the people in it."

"They're not people." Olga crinkled her nose, "They're monsters... the whole lot of them. Just like the ones that took my sister."

There was an awkward silence between the two of them as Olga's opinion hung in the air around them. The younger girl seemed to realize that she'd made some sort of faux pas, but what could it have been? Surely Somaria wouldn't sympathize with these creatures. How could she? They were barely half human! And with those scales and those fangs... they were so scary! They were bigger and stronger than anyone else in town, and there were tens of them! Maybe a hundred! They could eat this whole town at the rate they were going, and leave nothing for the other monsters just up the mountainside...

"Why don't you go visit the Queen?" Somaria said after a pause, "On behalf of the Tavern."

"The Queen?" Olga made a face, "That--"

"Esteemed dignitary who represents another country and all of these very nice people who have paid us a lot of money?" Somaria cocked a thick black eyebrow, "Yes, that Queen. Trust me, she's hard to miss."

Olga could see her from the window. Queen Coatlzintli was far too fat to come into the tavern. She'd instead been steaded outside on her dais, revelling in offerings made out of respect (and probably fear) from the native Racovanians. She was a big scaly hill of brown blubber and hair, who had been sitting there like another hill added to the mountaintop since she'd gotten here.

"She asked for you by name." Somaria said with a smile, "Helga's been talking your cooking up all day."

"I don't..."

"Just trust me. You might learn a thing or two."

***


The short walk outside felt like a lifetime. All these snakes slithering around, the festival going on, it was just so much noise. Especially given what happened just this time last year. The last thing that Olga felt she needed was to talk to another monster on the anniversary of her sister's abduction. But admittedly, it was a distraction.

The air was beginning to chill as the sky began to dim. The stars were peeking through the sky and the torches were being lit around the town. On her dais, surrounded by torches of Naga design, was the Queen. Just as massive and bloated as she had been when she arrived. Maybe even moreso.

Her four arms rested heavily on her great stomach. Her lower rung of waist-thick appendages hung low enought to grip her great swells of fat that hung over her waist around her brown belly as it dipped low over her crotch. Well, where her crotch would have been if she were a normal woman. But her wide flaring hips and long meaty tail rose high in the air as she lay on her side, casually stroking her great brown landslide of a stomach as it pooled in front of her. She was as tall laying down as Olga was standing up--she was massive in every sense of the word.

And it took everything she had in her to not think about the fact that the Queen could eat her, right now, without any hesitation.

"Um... hello?" Olga asked sheepishly, "Y-Your majesty?"

"Ah, yes, hello! I was... busy." the queen said with a lull, as if she'd been fast asleep or in deep thought, "Well, if it isn't a little blonde girl. And such big blue eyes!"

"Yes, they're... I'm blue." Olga bit her bottom lip in frustration, "I mean, yes, they're blue, I'm Olga. The, uh..."

"The chef!" Queen Coatlzinti's black eyes lit up like stars, "Oh, your patron has been talking about you endlessly. All night long."

"She... she has?"

"Yes, yes, you're the Bubble Chef of Bleakfrost Tavern!" the Queen's chins rippled with laughter, "The reason my den is leaving your country with full round bellies!"

"Well, me and Ms. Somaria..." Olga admitted sheepishly, "Um... are you cold, your highness? The other snakes..."

"Are not nearly as well-equipped to deal with the cold as I am." Queen Coatlzintli said with a pat of her chocolate-brown tonnage, "I won't be feeling a chill any sooner than I will be slithering into that Tavern of yours."

"Right, right..." Olga smiled awkwardly, "So, um... you wanted to see me?"

"Yes!" the Queen said, hands rising from her pillowy flab, "I have heard tale of your fabulous cooking skill, Olga Blue Eyes..."
1113112211122.title: Olga and the Corpulence of Queen Coatlzintli

11131122111221.content:
“I… um… you’re not that uh…” Olga stammered, whatever she was expecting this monolithic matriarch to say, diet plans was not one of them.

At the sight of the already flustered girl becoming even more put at unease, the great mountain of a woman laughed. “Ho ho ho! It’s ok, you can call me what I am. I’m fat, no need to butter me up… gods know that’s how I ended up like this…”

Olga was slightly more taken aback, she didn’t want to laugh at the joke, never being around royalty before, Olga didn’t know if that was correct behavior.

“Anyway…” the titanic queen continued, “that is my request. That you travel with me and my entourage back to my city in the Marshes, and become my personal chef.” As she finished her sentence, a great rumble came from queen Coatlzintli as the simple act of her shifting position slightly was followed by much creaking and groaning from the platform beneath her immensity.

The comparatively tiny woman was still confused though; “Why me? Do you not have chefs that would do so back home?” She asked.

A long draft of air was sucked through the reptilian woman’s nostrils as she sighed, before Coatlzintli then looked at the door to the tavern and back to Olga. “Because even if were to ask them, they would not do so. We Naga can be very traditional, and the idea of a queen who is not fatter than she is long is foreign to my people.”

As the queen finished her explanation, Olga remembered what Somaria had said about Coatlzintli taking after her mother; if Coatlzintli had been resisting her expansion into obesity... how big had the previous monarch been?

“So as you can see, this is why I requested for you.” Coatlzintli stated, pointing at Olga with one short pudgy finger on her upper-right-most arm. As Olga continued to look flustered, Coatlzintli quickly added, “But do not rush to answer me right away. We will be staying in your little town for a bit longer. Come see me before we depart in three days time… now go enjoy your evening.” Coatlzintli gave Olga a warm smile from her multi-chinned face, one which the young woman struggled to return, even out of politeness.

---


Olga had a lot to think about when she went back indoors, the warmth of the building barely registered to her as she went over what the queen had said. She didn’t like these snake-people, but at the same time she was so deathly afraid of the vampires… not to mention it was hard earning a living in such a bleak little town. In a large city, and as a head chef no less, she would certainly be well taken care of. Ugh this was so difficult! She needed someone to confide in, to at least speak her mind to and get this off her chest.

The best person to talk to would be her current employer. So Olga began to peer around the various guests, looking out for Helga’s well-rounded figure. But she was nowhere to be seen.

“Somaria!” Olga called as she spotted her co-worker, “Have you seen Helga?”

“I think she went to her room!” Somaria bellowed back over the general hubbub.

Winding her way past the various snake-women as discreetly as possible, Olga made her way to the bar and around the back. From there she went through a set of doors and then onto a second set.

*Knock knock*

Olga rapped her knuckles across the wooden surface, in a bid to get her boss to answer. There was no answer though, but she could hear Helga’s voice coming from inside. Throwing caution to the wind, Olga placed her hand on the doorknob and turned the handle. “Helga? I need to talk to you about something im…por…tant…”

The sight that greeted Olga had her in stunned silence. On Helga’s bed, was her boss… but ontop of HER was a very enthusiastic Naga. Helga had her arms wrapped around the serpentine-woman’s brown-skinned waist, holding her tightly but not too roughly. Meanwhile the Naga had her top-most set of arms passionately fondling Helga’s breasts, while the lower set were tenderly fondling the bottom of Helga’s belly, and occasionally disappearing beneath it. Her long tail was encircling Helga like a massive muscular rope, and from the way that Helga was bucking, she was holding on for dear life.

Both women had their lips locked together, eyes closed in passion as their tongues danced down each other’s throat; while the floor was covered in strewn clothes and armour. And they were naked… both completely naked.

Unable to hold her response internally, Olga screamed. A high pitched scream that caused the entwined women’s eyes to bolt open, their lips breaking apart with a wet pop sound, and look in her direction.

“OLGA!” Helga screamed. “WHAT ARE YOU DOING!?” Now the tavern owner and the Naga fully relinquished each other, with the latter women using one set of hands to cover her breasts, and the other to cover her crotch.

“I… I wanted to discuss something important... but but… I…” Olga was on the verge of tears, panic overtaking all other emotions as her legs locked, refusing to budge.

Helga whispered something to the stunned Naga, who nodded and slithered off of the bed, fetching Helga’s dress and handing it to her. The bulky brunette hastily tossed it over herself and waddled over to Olga. “It’s ok, I’m sorry for yelling… let’s take this outside.”

Leading Olga by the shoulder, Helga escorted her from the room, shutting the door behind her. “What did you want to talk about?” Helga asked, putting on her most sympathetic tone.

“It’s… *sniff* about the queen.” Olga explained, drying her tears. “She… she wants me to leave Racovania and travel back to the marshes to cook for her.”

Helga was stunned, “Wow… good on you girl! I would have killed for an opportunity like that!” The beefy woman was about to clap Olga on the back in congratulations, but tears were still welling in her eyes.

“I… I don’t know if I want to go…” Olga sniffed.

“Hey hey… it’s ok if you don’t want to go.” Helga backpedaled, trying her best to be responsible. “But, as someone who has lived here all her life… you should go.”

“Really?” Olga asked.

“Yes! Racovania isn’t the place for a young sweet girl like you to grow up; there is barely any sun here, our crops wither every other year, and every so often, a bloodsucking fiend comes down and snatches people up at her leisure.” This didn’t seem to convince Olga much. “I’m just trying to say, you can build a life for yourself so much easier there, they clearly WANT you in the Marshes. Plus, when are you going to get the opportunity to travel like this, without paying a coin.”

“I… guess…” Olga replied, still hesitant.

Helga smiled, still trying to convince the girl. “Sleep on it, ok? This might be the best thing that happens to you…”

Olga smiled and nodded, surprising Helga with a hug before returning to the front of the tavern to get back to helping Somaria out with the influx of customers.

Helga straightened herself up and tip-toed back towards her room, opening the door a crack she hissed, “She’s gone…” Within moments, she felt two pairs of strong hands clamp around her shoulders, and the sound of passionate moans filled the room once again.

111311221112211.content:
Over the next three days, the Racovanian festival trudged along at a horrendously awkward pace.

The Nagas’ welcome didn’t get any warmer after their first night in the mountainous country. If anything, everyone dealing with a hangover (humans and snakes alike) only invited more opportunities for clashing cultures. The stress of supporting the reptilian women was enough to make a few fights break out between the uninitiated and uninformed farmers and those who dared to suggest that maybe they weren’t all bad. Then there was the odd “fight” between a snake woman and a Racovanian, though those ended very quickly. The size difference and warrior training made quite the difference.

This had truly been the longest festival that anyone could remember, for sure. But for Olga, there was an entirely different reason for the drag in this year’s festivities.

“What do you think, Ms. Somaria?” Olga asked the head chef for what must have been the hundredth time that day, “Should I go?”

“Aye, if that’s what you want to do.” Somaria had repeated for what must have been the hundredth time that day, “But it wasn’t just two days ago that you were calling them monsters.”

“I know…” Olga frowned, “They still scare me.”

“Lords know they ought to scare somebody in this bar.” Somaria said in an aside, passive-aggressive sort of way. Olga supposed that it was just the work getting to her. “But plenty of girls your age would love to travel. And besides, you don’t want to live your whole life up here buried in snow, do you?”

“You moved here, though.” Olga turned away from the dishes, “And you’re from the South.”

“Aye, but that’s much, much different.” Somaria chuckled, “I don’t think you’ll be comparing notes with me on that any time soon.”

“But you’re here, and not there.” Olga blinked, “Maybe I want to be here and not there.”

There was another long, poignant pause between the two women. Those had been happening a lot lately. Ever since their first conversation about the queen, when Olga had gone outside to meet Coatlizintli. Whereas before Ms. Somaria had talked to her in a pleasant tone of voice, she had suddenly become much more… motherly. If that was the right word. She was still very nice, just more stern. It made Olga feel like a little girl now, when she talked to Ms. Somaria. She was so much more worldly than her and having all of these snakes around really made Olga realize that she hadn’t seen that much of the world to begin with…

“Maybe.” Somaria finally said, “Now hurry up and get those plates clean. Helga wants us opened up early tomorrow.”

***


The day of the Naga’s departure was a happy one for many involved.

For the snake women, they were getting away from these ignorant farmers who wanted to chase them off the mountain with torches and pitchforks. And for the farmers, they finally felt like they were getting back to some semblance of normalcy. Vampires were one thing, but something about shifty snake ladies made just about everyone uncomfortable.

Coatlzintli had been satisfied by her stay in the mountains, having eaten far more than her fair share of Racovanian cuisine at the behest of her people and her wife. The smaller snake, Patli, slithered around and over and on top of her big brown blob seeing to her every need for three days straight, keeping her positively full of food at every opportunity. The Queen’s diet was in shambles already, but at least it had been a pleasurable shattering experience.

And Somaria was simply happy that Helga’s three-night-stand snake girl was going to be leaving with the rest of her army.

“I’m going to miss you, my beautiful little snowflower.” The Queen’s guard who had slept with Helga said as she cupped the barmaid’s cheek, “Our nights together have been rapturous.”

“I ain’t no flower ye scaly sweet talker.” Helga chuckled thickly, her belly bouncing as her lover’s lower rung of arms held her close, “You’re just lucky y’ae only spent a few nights with me, or I’d have yae poppin’ raeght outta that armor.”

The staff of the Bleakfrost Tavern rolled their eyes at the courtship. Helga had hardly left her bedroom since she and Amoxtli had began their affair. But as the taller, burlier woman’s hands fell and she slithered back towards the departing party, one of her hands clapped on Olga’s shoulders.

“Coming, Blue Eyes?”

Olga squeaked in attention. She’d gotten everything she could carry together. It wasn’t much. Given that they didn’t exactly have a lot of money even before her father fell ill, she’d not been able to keep her room full of things in the Tavern. Now, leaving with even less than she had when Tora had been taken by the Strankens, she’d been left with but a few changes of clothes.

“Aye!” Olga said finally, “I’m ready when you are.”
111311221112211.title: Olga on the Road

1113112211122112.content:
The trip back to the Marshes would take some time. Racovania was in the North, the Marshes were in the South, and Yndyre was a big continent after all. They would cut through the capital at Adinah in a few weeks, stay there for some time, and then resume their trek along the most prominent cities until they reached the marshes.

“All in all, I’d say it’ll take two months.”

Patli was Queen Coatlzintli’s wife. When compared to her queen, or even to just the other naga, she was very small. About Olga’s height, with caramel colored skin and dark brown hair. She was somewhat plain looking, and lacked the colorful exotic scales of her sister snakes. Except for the vibrant yellow patterns along her back, she was almost completely earth-toned.

What she lacked in color and panache, Olga was learning that she made up for in attitude.

“Two months?” Coatlizintli asked, immobile from her platform, “Patli that seems a bit much.”

“How long are we planning on staying in the capital?” Olga asked from her seat on the Queen’s dais

Olga had never been below the mountains. Even when Father went into town, he was just going a little bit down to the base, and she’d only ever gone once. Tora had been below a few times, when she ran the forge. But Olga was surprised at just how flat everything was. And how green, too. The animals were different—softer, and sleeker than the burly beasts that lived up in the peaks.

She was in an army full of snake women, one of whom weighed more than ten of the others combined, and she couldn’t stop staring at the rabbits.

“Two weeks.” Patli answered matter of factly, “King Roland loves to show the royal families of the Marshes a good time.”

“You mean he likes to feed me until I feel like I’m going to pop.” Coatlizintli touched four handfuls of the belly’s bigness and rubbed it defensively, “Patli, I won’t have it.”

“Oh Li, you can always begin your silly diet when we’re not visiting the King.” Patli said placatingly, stroking her wife’s lower-hanging belly rolls as she slithered underneath and around her, “After all, diplomacy trumps diets every time.”

The queen let out a low whine, looking to Olga for support.

“U-Uhm, ma’am, I—” Olga interjected, “I-I think, a-as the um… the… er…”

“I’m sorry, who are you again?” Patli sniffed, “Just keep seated, sweetie. And quiet, please. We’ll set up camp soon and you can get back on those… little things you have. Legs.”

Olga grumbled and hunkered back down into her seat.

***


“Don’t take it so hard.” Coatlzintli’s boulders of cheeks sloshed, speaking and chewing with precision and force as three of her two of her four hands fed her waiting maw, “Patli’s always been that way.”

“I didn’t say anything, your highness.” Olga squeaked from her seat next to the mountain of her new boss, “I mean, thank you though.”

“You didn’t have to say anything.” The queen burped, “I recognize that look.”

The Queen got her own tent—the size of most homes back up in the mountains, Olga had added. Housing Coatlizintli’s immensity meant that the size was anything but unnecessary. She and Patli slept there while the troops were given their own tents and bedrolls. Olga was to share a tent with Amoxtli, based on their mutual friend Helga back in Racovania.

That being said, Coatlzintli had made Olga feel very comfortable by her side. Much moreso than she would have been in the pit with the other snake women.

Coatlizintli was well and truly immobile. Far too fat to slither underneath her own power. It took half of their army to move her with the speed required to make the trip in the time that it had. She was this massive woman, more slug than snake. And with the way her army kept her fed, Olga had very few reasons not to believe that she had earned every extra pound or inch that clung to her tonnage.

“Ever since we were kids, she’s been the smallest. I suppose that big mouth of hers is what makes up for it.” Coatlzintli stroked her belly idly with her lowermost set of arms, “She can be a bit… difficult at times.”

Patli was at the tents with the guard, looking up at them as she made them stand at attention. Ostensibly, she was debriefing them for what they were going to do tomorrow. But from what Olga had gathered, it was equal parts organizing a hunting party for breakfast.

“She doesn’t seem… nice.” Olga chose her words carefully, “Or to like me very much…”

“Well you’re here to undo some of this.” Coatlizintli chuckled huskily as she lifted up a tier of her tonnous tummy as it pooled out in front of her, “If it were up to Patli, the whole mountainside would be emptied out and served to me for breakfast.”

“Your custom is weird…” Olga bit back, realizing what she’d just said to whom she’d just said it to, “N-No offense… your highness.”

“No, no, it’s definitely… strange.” Coatlizintli’s puddling face frowned tightly, “I’m the first queen in some time to venture outside of the marshes. I told Patli I’d get as fat as she wanted if she’d let me see the world.”

“Your queens don’t see Yndyre?” Olga asked in moderate confusion, having taken everyone who wasn’t a dumb farm girl for being far more apt to travel than she was, “Why not?”

“Because they’re all too bloody fat.” The queen said sourly, “And that, my dear, is where you come in.”

“I don’t know exactly what you want me to do about it…” Olga thought back sourly now on all the weight Helga gained once she’d been put on staff, “I’m happy to help cook you food, ma’am, but… with how much you eat…”

“Exactly my point in hiring you, Blue Eyes.” Coatlzintli winked, “I'll only be eating what you make for me once we get back to the Marshes. But Patli is going to keep you plenty busy, and my kingdom will get leery if you don't make enough food for me.”

“Um…”

"My point in saying all this, is that I'll need your help in disposing of some of the food so that I'm not tempted and that no one will suspect anything." Coatlzintli giggled like a girl and less like the mountain of monarchy that she presented, "That way I won't be tempted."

Olga briefly pictured herself even attempting to eat the amount that one of the soldiers ate on a daily basis.

"Ma'am, you don't mean..."

"Oh no, of course not." the queen waved a hand dismissively, an action that wobbled throughout her entire upper half, "You would explode before you'd be of any use to me."

Olga tried not to look too relieved

"No, I want you to share whatever I don't eat with..."
1113112211122112.title: Snakes, Size, and Subterfuge

11131122111221122.content:
“Your daughters?” Olga repeated. “Uh, won’t that make them a bit…” The blacksmith’s daughter struggled to get the word out still, so instead resorted to using her hands to mimic a large ring of fat around her middle. The queen however was much more casual about the idea.

“Ho ho ho! Don’t you worry your golden locks, it will barely be any extra to them.” Coatlzintli chuckled, while Olga looked at her quizzically. “How many children do you think I have in one sitting, hmm?” The queen asked with a smile.

The blonde girl scratched her head; clearly her majesty was trying to make her guess some high number, or she wouldn’t have asked the question. From what Olga could remember, the tailor’s wife a few houses away had three children at once some years back, so perhaps that was a good base to go off of?

“Five?” Olga answer hesitantly.

Instantly, the monolithic matriarch chuckled, her great wall of lard body rippling with mirth. “Five… oh I wish… during my last pregnancy I laid almost one hundred and fifty eggs.”

Olga’s eyes bugged at the number, “One hundred and fifty!?” She spluttered, almost forgetting the notion that queen Coatlzintli had said she had laid eggs rather than given birth. Somaria had said it had been an especially heavy birth for her, but THAT heavy!?

“It is my job as queen.” Coatlzintli explained, “Most Naga only have one child if any at all, so it is my duty to keep the population well supported”. There was a tone of wistfulness in the queen’s voice, and her gaze turned to the tent opening. Olga felt almost bad for the queen; clearly she had planned great adventures for herself, but was (literally) tied down by the weight of her duties. Perhaps agreeing to go with her entourage was the best idea she had had in a long time…

“Well… I am honored that I will be helping you.” Olga replied, breaking the poignant silence.

“Thank you, I do hope you are up to the challenge… Patli will be putting you through your paces when we arrive back in my palace”. Coatlzintli broke her speech off for a moment to pluck a few tender morsels from her platter and stuff them past her ham-sized cheeks. “Your first job will be helping me lose whatever I am going to put on in Adinah, that king loves to make sure everyone around him is eating well… you would do with loosening your belt around him.”

Olga gulped; she hadn’t for a moment worried about her own waistline in all this. Now though, looking at the hillock-sized woman that lay prone next to her, potential weight-gain was a serious concern.

Both women were shocked out of their pensive moods though, as a figure slithered her way through the tent opening; “Sweetie I… oh… you are still here…” Patli wrinkled her nose in mild distaste as she saw the tiny little human sitting so close to her beloved. Turning back to her queen, Patli proceeded to act as if the tiny woman wasn’t there, “I have instructed the troops for tomorrow’s march, made sure that there are sentries on guard at the edges of the camp. We are perfectly prepared for daybreak.”

“Wonderful.” Coatlzintli replied pleasantly, “I guess time got away from us as we talked. Better catch some sleep Olga Blue-eyes, it’s a long trek tomorrow.”

Olga nodded, getting up off the tent floor and walked towards the exit, Patli watching every movement.

As Olga left the premises, the consort to the queen swiftly pulled the screen across the gap. The blonde woman couldn’t see what was going on anymore, but she could still faintly hear what was being said.

“Now that the mammal is gone… we can have some fun…”

“If you make me have another clutch, you won’t be able to get me back inside the palace when we return…”

“We will have the doors widened…”

Picking up her pace, Olga headed back to her tent as fast as she could; she had had enough of snake-love for one lifetime already. Not that she could truly escape it; as on return to her tent she was swiftly reminded of the sight that would be burned into her mind’s eye for the rest of her life.

“Hmmm hmmm hmmm…” Amoxtli hummed as she neatly placed her armour and weapons by her bedside. “Oh! Olga, I didn’t hear you come in!” The serpentine woman exclaimed as she noticed the smaller woman’s presence.

Staring to the other side of the tent, Olga noticed how all her things had been arranged much more neatly than she remembered leaving them.

Spotting where her tent-mate was looking, Amoxtli explained; “I tidied up a bit… thought you might like that when you got back.”

“Uh… thanks…” Olga replied, not really looking the Naga in the eye as she walked to her bed-roll.

Amoxtli sat in silence all four hands placed on top of each other, hoping for some positive remark, but none came. Instead Olga just sat on the edge of her bed, turned away from Amoxtli and lay down, still dressed in her day clothes.

Silence pervaded over the tent, until Amoxtli tried to make conversation again. “If you’re not getting enough to eat here, you can share some of my rations.”

“Mmhm…” was all the response she got.

“It’s because you saw me having sex with your boss isn’t it?” The Naga suddenly stated, causing Olga to sit bolt upright; Amoxtli continued, “You probably think I am so no good whore… but I’m not! I don’t let my hair down often, and Helga was really beautiful… and…”

“STOP!” Olga exclaimed, holding her hands up; anything to stop that mental image coming back.

“I’m sorry, I just thought we could be friends…” Amoxtli added.

Olga still had her reservations; while she had started to get used to Coatlzintli, the woman was basically harmless unless she accidentally rolled on top of you. Amoxtli however was often bedecked in military finery, and wielding strange weapons embedded with the teeth of sharp-fanged animals of who-knows-how-big; not to mention she was really buff, and looked like she could break Olga like a twig if she felt like it.

“I don’t even know you…” Olga mumbled. This however seemed like a challenge to her tent-mate.

“Ok then, my name’s Amoxtli,” The snake-woman started counting her life events off on her fingers as she went, “I am of low birth… that means I am not one of the previous queen’s daughters. I was the best Pok-ta-pok player in my street when I was ten, I joined the barracks when I was sixteen, and I was promoted to a royal guard when I was twenty two. I like my meat well-done, I’m currently single… as you may have guessed, and I prefer the rainy season to the dry season.” With a deep breath, she finished. “Now you know me.”

Olga smiled a little, there was certainly more humanity to the Naga than she initially thought. “I guess it’s my turn then…” And with that, Olga recounted her life’s story, and the pair chatted long into the night.
11131122111221122.title: Serpent Socializing

choices: The Army arrives back home in the Marshes, Olga settles in
The Queen(s) decide to stay, and Olga is sent ahead to get situated
111311221112211221.content:
Over the course of their campaign back to the Marshes, Olga and Amoxtli continued their awkward dance of getting to know one another.

In a troop full of unfamiliar faces attached to strange serpentine bodies, it served Olga well to have at least one snake woman that she could talk to. The Queen was not always available, turning away either due to her duties or her appetite, and Olga's presence was not always welcome in her tents. The Queen's wife certainly didn't seem too keen on including the "legger" (she'd picked up the term almost as soon as she'd been added to the Queen's court) in many conversations. It always helped to have a friend that she could turn to. But in this dire circumstance, the snake that she had walked in on her boss having sex with would have to do well enough.

It was strange, Olga thought, that a woman older than her, stronger than her, and more worldly than her seemed to work so hard to gain her approval. Amoxtli seemed eager enough to make sure Olga was fitting in and did her best to fill the awkward silence as best she could. And given the nature of their first meeting, there were many awkward silences.

"Of course she's trying to make you feel comfortable." Coatlizintli snorted one night over dinner, two arms working feverishly to pour another helping of stew into her belly while the lower two sensually rubbed her digesting stomach, "I have ordered her to. You are her responsibility."

"Okay, but..." Olga winced, "I have... erm... seen her naked..."

"Oh-ho!" Coatlizintli snorted, soup dribbling down her cheeks and chins as she bowl jostled with her boitrous belly laugh, "So she has been making you comfortable!"

"N-No, ew!" Olga slipped, her face growing bright pink, "She and Helga, my boss! Back home!"

"You mean back in Racovania." Patli corrected as she dabbed at the spill on her wife's face, "Your home is wherever your Queen is."

"Correct." Coatlzintli said appreciatively, "But try not to think too much of it. Have you ever known someone in an army?"

"No." Olga answered softly, stirring her own stew petulantly, "But I don't see what--"

"In due time." Coatlizintli answered quickly, "Now, Blue Eyes, be a dear and hand us the Mastodon. There's a girl..."

As awkward as it was at first, the two of them worked out a sort of agreement. How things would be carried out from then on, if they were going to be "friends". Amoxtli was to be Olga's personal guard due to the "handicap" of not being Naga-born. She was the one member of their traveling army who was directly responsible for Olga's migration to the Marshes--a small extension of Coatlzintli's will bequeathed to her private chef. And Olga needed it! She was a farm girl, not a fighter. And with some of the dangerous meals that they hunted in the name of keeping their great queen full and fat, she needed the protection.

"Tyrantosoreus?" Olga repeated with some genuine diffculty

"No, no, Ty-ran-o-saur-us." Amoxtli spoke slowly, as if to a child and counted the syllables on her fingers, "It's one of the many lesser reptiles that live in the marshes."

"It... didn't seem that little."

"No, lesser, like dumber." the red-scaled snake woman bit heartily into her slice of the great lizard, "You will see. Tyrannosaurus is one of the Queen's favorite meals. She will have you learn many recipes."

Olga frowned at the tough chunk of meat she'd been battling with for the better part of the night. It was from somewhere along the breastplate--a good hunk of the stuff, deemed high quality and split only with the Queen herself. It was a sign of respect that she get the prime cut, however, she'd barely been able to make a dent in it. It was like eating leather! Luckily, Olga had eaten her fill of the vegetables and the stew. What she'd tasted of the ty-ran-o-saur-us in there had been good, but still chewy.

"So she eats this a lot then?" Olga made a face, "I don't see how..."

"Naga have strong jaws and fangs to help pierce the flesh." Amoxtli ripped a good bite from her own portion from along the tail, "Are you not enjoying your supper?"

"I'm... too full." Olga smiled weakly, "Do you want it?"

"Um, absolutely." Amoxtli said with a greedy grin, reaching forward, "You sure?"

"I can't even bite into it." Olga rolled her eyes, "You're more than welcome to have it."

Even during their stopover in Adinah, where there were far more many two-legged people for Olga to talk to, she still felt out of place in the population of city folk. She was a farm girl through and through, and couldn't help but think that these civilized, cultured types were looking down on her. With the added inclusion of Sirens and Satyrs and Minotaurs and the various other strange species migrating to the hub of Yndyre, it felt so strange to be gravitating to her familiar den of snakes.

"Aye, that girl's giving you the once-over." Cuicatl—a member of the Eagle Warriors brought along to scout—ribbed Olga in the breast during their stay in the HopFrog Tavern, "You oughtta go over and say hello. Flash those pretty Blue Eyes, Blue Eyes."

A roaring laughter filled the booth that the five naga women, plus one dwarfed former barmaid, occupied in the rich Adinahn bar. The Queen and her mate, plus the members of her royal guard, had been at the King's castle for hours. There wasn't much to do for those so far from their native culture, the Marshes and farm girling respectively, to do in a hub like this except to drink.

"I don't think so." Olga smiled and waved awkwardly to the busty siren looking her over, "I... don't really like girls. Or birds."

Another roar of laughter.

"What do you mean you don't like girls!" Eztli snickered, "What good are menfolk for anyway?"

"Make good eatin'."

"Aye, aye, that's true."

"You need to get out of your shell a bit more, Blue Eyes." Amoxtli said drunkenly, winking at a very heavyset barmaid, "You're not gonna find many men in the marshes that much is for sure."

"Then how do you—"

The snake women gathered at the table conversed in their native tongue for a moment before throwing their heads back in further drunken laughter. Olga didn't know much Naga, but it was probably a joke at her expense. She sunk lower into her seat, feeling more ignorant than ever, and wishing that she'd never agreed to come with these stupid snakes.

"Cheer up ya legger, we're only teasin' ya." Amoxtli shoved Olga a bit on the shoulder, "Want anything from the bar? I'm going to go see if the Big One is free tonight."
111311221112211221.title: Snakes Slithering into the Capital

choices: Olga and her squad of snake-ladies advance forward, and make it to the Marshes!
Olga and her squad get off-course, and head into decidedly NOT the Marshes...
1113112211122112212.content:
Despite all of the hiccups that came with being an outsider, Olga found herself fitting in well enough. Even if it was only as a "legger" could. She felt included at least, and that was something. The rest of the troop—a few select members—were kind enough to her, and promised to help make her feel at home. Which wound up working well for her.

"You're staying here?" Olga asked in bewilderment, "C-Can you do that?"

"For a few more weeks at least." Coatlzintli said in a thick, heavy voice as she reclined in the massive room that His Highness had set aside for her opulence, "There are matters to attend to here in the Capital that are best suited to be done in person."

Olga somehow doubted the legitimacy of that claim. For all of the time that the Queen had been on her tour of the country, she'd been kept up well enough. But in Adinah, there was talk of her eating for hours on end with the King and his wives. Did His Highness have more than one wife? There were rumors about an entire court set up for decadent meals. His own royally robust figure suggested that he was no stranger to overindulgence. Perhaps he was just entertaining Her Majesty, who was clearly equally (and exponentially) predisposed to a similar affliction.

For all her talk about wanting to diet, Coatlzintli would be hard-pressed to leave meals of this caliber on her own.

"So... what does that mean for me?" Olga wavered, "Do I... stay here with you, your highness?"

"No, no, I will be sending you with Amoxtli and a small squad of scouts." the Queen purred, stroking her magnificent stomach with her many hands, "She will command them and make sure that you complete your migration to the marshes safely."

As the conversation came to a close, the doorway to the Queen's provided chambers cracked open. Her mate slithered in, along with a small crew of the King's personal servants. Adinahn women, all of them, with plump round figures and healthy weights about them. Even Patli, scrawny as she was, had taken well to the portions provided by the crown in the three weeks they'd been staying in the Capital.

"My love." Patli purred, "It is almost time for your meeting with the King."

"Of course." Coatlzintli turned to Olga again, "You and your squad will leave on the morrow and march ahead of the remaining army. This will give you a few days to get situated in your new station as my head chef."

Coatlizintli then winked, slyly. Such a small action on such a mountainous figure was truly insignificant to anyone who wasn't looking.

"And to meet my daughters."

Olga left the room, massive oaken door shutting heavily behind her, feeling more conflicted than ever. On the one hand, she was finally going to be out of the city. She'd rather gotten used to life on the road, even if it was with a bunch of snake women. She was protected and safe, and the conversations she'd have with the queen while on her dais were often quite pleasant. But on the other hand, six naga didn't sound like enough to adequately protect her from some of the beasts that had attacked them along the way. Add into that, she still wasn't very comfortable around the slithering, scaly beast women. They were loud and obnoxious, and being around them made her feel so... weak.

To add to the mixture, with the way her Queen was eating, Olga would have her work cut out for her when she finally managed to make it back to the Marshes. Even if they had to roll her there...

"Suddenly I miss vampires." Olga joked bitterly as she slumped against the wall, head in hands...
1113112211122112212.title: Advancing Party

choices: Olga meets Coatlzintli's daughters(1)
Olga meets Coatlzintli's daughters(2)
Olga meets Coatlzintli's daughters(3)
11131122111221122121.content:
Thankfully, the smaller party did not have as much trouble with the native fauna as before they entered the city. With a relatively small force, they were a lot quieter and attracted a lot less attention. Good thing too, as Olga had overheard whispers in the tavern they had rented out for the few nights they were staying, there was apparently a creature called a Hydra that had been terrorizing the local farmsteads. The timid blonde was quite nervous as they had initially left the city, in case this beast attacked them.

After a few days travel, Olga had completely forgotten about the many-headed monster, thinking that they had long left behind any risk of it attacking them.

One day though, as the small troupe was making camp for the night…

*Snap*

Despite all the seven women being present and accounted for, the sound of a twig being trodden on echoed from out of a nearby copse. The guards stood to attention, with Amoxtli silently giving orders with naught but hand gestures.

Then they saw a pair of yellow eyes glinting from between the trees. Amoxtli instantly reacted, using her upper arms to level her weapon at the best, but also using her lower pair to grab onto Olga and hold her tightly. Within a second, Olga had gone from shivering alone to having Amoxtli’s girl-abs rammed into her face.

Olga tugged her head up, trying to allow herself to breathe properly again. Her gaze was filled with Amoxtli’s gold breastplate as it hung down over her torso. But Olga could still catch a glimpse of underboob, and all of a sudden, her mind’s eye was filled with that image of naked Amoxtli again. Her dark brown teats the only thing Olga could think about.

Blushing furiously, Olga buried her face back into Amoxtli’s abdominal muscles, and closing her eyes tight.

Mistaking Olga’s behavior for fear, the snake-woman thought little of it. Instead she kept her eyes locked on this predator that stared out from the shadows.

*SMACK*

Within seconds, the eyes vanished from the darkness, as one of the Naga’s javelin’s struck it clean in the forehead. Going in to retrieve her weapon, before returning, dragging back with her the body of a very large wolf.

Amoxtli slammed the pole of her weapon into the ground. “Put away the rations girls, looks like meat’s back on the menu!”

---


As the group continued to travel, Olga was quite intrigued as she watched the landscape change. From wide open plains, they then entered thick forests not unlike the ones at home… only with trees far larger than she could have imagined. Then the trees began to change as they headed further south, becoming thinner and taller. Their roots tall and thin like erect lines of parchment.

But as they entered what Olga thought must have been the Motee Marshes, there seemed to be a lack of… well marsh.

“Isn’t there supposed to be more water here?” Olga asked as the group passed over a wooden bridge, covering an almost completely dry riverbed.

“Aye, but it’s the end of the dry season. There has been no rainfall for months.” Amoxtli explained.

“Dry season?” Olga repeated.

Amoxtli began to elaborate further. “Here in the marshes, we have half a year where it rains and food is plentiful, and the rest the rain stops and we have to make do with what is left after that rainy season. We are coming up to the end of the dry season now, so things will look a bit barren.”

Olga may have had her curiosity sated, but it was certainly strange that was for sure. Did that mean they never got snow here? That was likely, she thought, what with how hot it was becoming.

---


Finally, after many months on the road, Olga got a glimpse of the great city of the Naga. There was a wide stone bridge to cross first, and here she was really feeling like she was somewhere totally alien. The number of Naga women was starting to increase, with many stealing glances at her as she passed. They were not dressed as the soldiers that had accompanied her were; they were mostly of similar design, a single color with bright colors edging the material; some wore large draping clothes that resembled huge shirts, others long dresses and a couple that were only wearing skirts… their breasts out for all to see.

The city was nothing short of impressive as well. The buildings were all cut from stone, the houses topped with either flat stone roofs or triangular straw ones. Dotted amongst them were some larger buildings that must have been markets, apothecaries or barracks. But even rarer were some towering colossal buildings, the size of the castles in Racovania. They were huge triangular structures, with what looked like temples on the top and steps up to them.

It was no less crowded than Adinah had been as well. Woman hustled and bustled here and there, while children played in the more open areas. One group were even playing with a ball, trying to pass it through a hoop attached to the side of a house using just their elbows.

Then they reached the queen’s palace. Like the triangular buildings, it towered over the cityscape. While similar in its base to the temples, it was a lot larger at the top, with a large multi-building complex atop it. There were plenty of plants as well, perhaps a series of gardens?

Olga was escorted up the stone steps and through the gargantuan doorway in the middle. On arrival, Amoxtli slithered over to some other guards and chatted with them for a moment, sending them off in several directions across the palace.

“Ready for the grand tour?” Amoxtli asked as she returned, leaning down towards her charge.

---


It wasn’t really a grand tour, more a whistle-stop glance at all the important rooms in the building. Some not even shown to Olga, just directions were given instead. It seemed she was being hurried in one direction though, down towards the kitchens.

And what kitchens they were! The room used to prepare queen Coatlzintli’s meals could have held several Bleakfrost Taverns!

“As you can see, the staff are not in right now.” Amoxtli stated, gesturing as to how there was nobody around. “Buuuuut…” the serpentine woman added, “NOCHTLI!”

Within moments there was a sound of crashing from one of the back rooms (this place had MORE to it!?) and a voice called out. “Coming!”

In slithered another Naga, like all the women so far, she had brown skin and black hair, which flowed down her back like a waterfall. She was shorter than Amoxtli, but certainly taller than Patli. Her lower half was a deep navy blue with a black stripe down the back, leading to a red-tipped tail. But what was most striking about her was that she was really fat!

Now that Olga thought about it, she hadn’t seen a single overweight Naga other than her majesty… until now. This Nochtli seemed to be the only exception; her face wasn’t all that chubby, but all four of her upper arms were seriously big. Her belly was quite large as well, and her hips and tail were REALLY fat.

“This is Nochtli, the queen’s official taste tester.” Amoxtli introduced, before adding, “If you couldn’t tell that already” patting the back of one of her hands on Nochtli's big brown stomach, sending ripples across the surface.

“Hey!” Nochtli huffed, putting her fists on her fat hips. “My job is very important thank you!” The Naga stated proudly, before turning towards Olga, “Hello! You’re a human! Ummm Amoxtli, why is there a guest in the kitchens?”

Amoxtli placed one of her hands on Olga’s shoulder, to try and give her a bit of moral support. “Because she’s not a guest. Olga here will be your new head chef!” The guard announced with a hint of pride.

“Oh!” The fatter woman cooed. “That means we are going to be working together a lot!”

“Nice… to meet you… but what does a taste tester do?” Olga asked, having never heard of the job before

“My duty is to eat a little of the queen’s food before it gets to her. To make sure any poisons, either natural or unnatural are spotted first, I have a really good sense of taste, so I am a natural!”

“Alrighty Nochtli.” Amoxtli chuckled, calming the bubbly woman’s enthusiasm. “We need to get Olga going, she has a few more important duties before she gets started… the other guards should have rounded up the royal hatchlings by now...”
11131122111221122121.title: The Grand Arrival

choices: It's Olga's job to prepare the Marshes for the Rainy Season, & the Queens return
Olga needs a few days to herself to get acclimated before any work
Free Choice
111311221112211221211.content:
Olga and Amoxtli had entered the eastern wing of the labyrinthian castle. The humidity of the region was unlike anything Olga had ever experienced, and it had left her pink and damp. The change of summer clothes that she'd brought with her from home still left her moist and dripping with sweat. The suffocating warmth surrounded her, even in the great spacious caverns of the temple. The ceilings were built high and the walls seemed miles apart—she imagined that the Queen would have no difficulty slithering underneath such construction, had she been able to move under her own power. The dais's added height and the servants hoisting her Highness's humongousness would even be able to account for the top of the structure.

Though Olga had seen many strange things since she'd left Racovania, she'd never imagined living in a city of stone. Or, for that matter, a place so blasted hot. How could anyone think straight with this heat beating down on them?

Olga had been so busy puttering along trying not to get heat stroke that she almost didn't notice the entourage that was awaiting her.

"Welcome, Head Chef!" said a chorus of voices in unison, shocking the sweaty blonde girl back to scaly reality

The word "hatchlings" didn't exactly foster the correct imagery in Olga's mind.

She had expected some small creatures, slithering up to her ankles. She had no idea how big or how small Naga got when they were children, and calling them "hatchlings" didn't instill the sense that they were anything bigger than housecats. When Olga and Amoxtli entered the royal chambers and were greeted with the sight of no less than a hundred snake women of varying shapes and sizes, her mind boggled. She had an entire unit of children, almost as many people as there were in her home town!

At once, as soon as the chorus was broken, giggling and conversations broke out amongst Coatlzinli's children. Some of them looked to be as young in the face as Olga, while others took more after Coatlzintli's strong royal features. They were anywhere from as tall as the Queen to as short as her wife, Patli. All dark-skinned with black hair, and a varying color scheme of scales between the lot of them that favored greens and vibrant yellows.

"Oh my..." Olga gulped, turning to the one friendly face in the room, "Are these... all...?"

"They are all highborn." Amoxtli said with a laugh, "Her Highness bears more in her clutches than any Queen in this dynasty."

"You can say that again."

"Um... Her Highness bears more—"

Getting a better look at them as they all got a good look at the Legger who had walked into their chambers, Olga noticed the subtle differences between a select few of them. They represented all of the diversity that Olga had seen in the short time since coming to the Marshes. Each of them decorated themselves in ornate feathers or teeth, colorful skirts wrapped around their tails or... sometimes nothing at all. The lot of them looked to be around her age, though Gods knew how old they actually were.

But, like Nochtli, there was a distinctive difference between the Naga within the royal walls and the naga who lived in the village outside.

She could certainly tell that some of these girls were the Queen's lineage, that much was for sure. The Queen's ulterior motive for hiring her, so she could pass along the portions to some of these girls, seemed a bit redundant. There were some that were nearly as long as the queen herself and already quite heavyset. Even the smaller ones, some of them were quite plump.

"You'll forgive them for being a bit rowdy." Amoxtli said with a laugh, "They've never seen a Legger before."

"Oh, it's fine." Olga said in an attempt to remain respectful in the faces of her employer's daughters, "I'm a bit used to it by now."

"They all wanted to see you for themselves, and now look at them—still girls, the lot of them."

"They're always like this?" Olga winced as the echoes bounced off of the high ceilings and spacious walls

"Always." the red snake snorted before repeating, "Girls, just girls."

Olga introduced herself as well as she could. The crowd quieted, mostly, so she could speak to the Queen's daughters. Many of them looked at her with a sort of awe that Olga and her Racovanian friends would have looked at a Naga. They were entranced by her two bony tails, and the way she moved effortlessly without slithering around. Her soft, pretty features were untouched by scales and her fingers were so... dull!

The poor farm girl never would have thought that being an ordinary human would be so strange to some people.

"Ooh, ooh!" one of the girls raised her hand and said in a somewhat broken attempt at common tongue, "Will you be preparing the dinner tonight?"

"No, no, Ms. Olga has to get some rest." Amoxtli answered for her, "It's been a long trip and we're both very tired."

"Will you be preparing the feast for when Mother gets back?" another, bigger, deeper voiced snake asked from the back

"Absolutely, yes."

"What about when the dry season's over?" another girl, smaller and a bit fat, shot her hands up in the air, "You only have two arms! How will you cook so much food?!"

As the questions poured in Olga felt herself shrink at all the attention. Somehow, she felt that this was going to be a lot more than simply cooking for her new Queen...
111311221112211221211.title: Clutching the Farm Girl

choices: Olga tries to wrap her head around Naga cuisine
One of Coatzintli's daughters will not stop following her
Olga bumps into Nochtli... literally
1113112211122112212112.content:
Amoxtli had insisted that Olga get herself used to life in the city before she should get her hands dirty. While Olga appreciated the gesture, she was still not quite sure what to make of the big warrior-woman. Different species not taken into account, the two had nothing in common. Olga was shy and a bit soft, but sweet; while Amoxtli was tom-boy-ish, covered in iron-like muscle and quite outgoing. They both had a helpful nature though, so that was something… Olga supposed.

“You really should get something more appropriate to wear.” Amoxtli commented half-way through a tour of the city streets.

“I’m… fine…” Olga huffed, quickly wiping the sweat from her brow to hide the droplets from her Naga escort.

“You’re not fine.” Amoxtli insisted, “I can see the heat building up.”

Olga was baffled, could Nagas see heat!?

“If you will not wear something more comfortable…” The guard added as they continued down the cobbled street, “You should at least go topless.”

The blonde woman’s face turned the color of a tomato as she processed what Amoxtli had just said. She had seen enough snake tits from just that accident with Amoxtli to scar her for a lifetime, let alone coming to this sweltering city and seeing every tenth woman here with her bouncy reptile-boobs out!

“Ugh now it’s getting worse!” Amoxtli added, mistaking the blush for Olga’s poor ability to cope with the heat worsening. “I’m taking you to the market.” She added firmly, roughly grabbing Olga’s wrist in one of her caramel-colored hands and directing her down a side-alley.

They passed a few houses, weaving in between the stone buildings before emerging into a much larger street. While Olga may have been in an unfamiliar city in an unfamiliar land, she could tell right away that this was a market. She could hear women bartering around her, tents covering people’s wares as they flogged them and all kinds of items on display.
