As Amoxtli let go of Olga’s wrist, she felt a bit more comfortable. Here she at least knew the ropes. Meanwhile, her serpentine guide busied herself peering over the tops of the crowd, trying to spy a stall that was selling clothes.

“Over there!” Amoxtli called out, pointing at a shop just across the street. Olga was still reluctant, but went along with it. As the pair approached, the owner slithered out to greet them.

Like most of the Naga Olga had seen in the city, she was brown skinned, dark-haired and slim. She was comparatively modestly dressed, in a long skirt with a poncho draped over her top, but that might have been to show off her wares to potential customers. Beneath the skirt, Olga could spy a long vibrant green tail slithering behind her. “Welcome! What are you ladies… looking… for…” The shop-keeper’s greetings were stalled as she noticed the tail-less two-armed customer.

“We are looking for a loose dry season top, nothing with arm-holes.” Amoxtli snapped firmly, she was all business.

“Right away, is this sort of thing what you are looking for?” The shopkeeper replied, twirling around so the pair got a good look at her poncho.

“I guess…” Olga nervously replied, she was at least happy that she had been taken for clothes, instead of Amoxtli being more insistent about her strutting around in the buff. “Does it come in a blue?” She asked, gaining a little confidence.

The snake-woman nodded, before rifling around with all four of her arms in a pile of clothes, before whipping out a bright electric-blue poncho. “Matches your eyes.” She commented, holding the garment up to Olga.

Amoxtli saw the smile on Olga’s face. “You like it?” She asked, receiving a nod in response. “How much?”

Olga jumped, “Oh no! Don’t waste money on me!” She quickly asked.

“Nonsense, I am supposed to be showing you a good time here, it’s my treat.” Amoxtli replied, her lower set of arms producing a small pile of coins from a drawstring purse at her waist. “Just promise me you will put it on when we return to the palace.”

---


“It flows so much!” Olga giggled; she couldn’t stop twirling around in her new outfit.

“I’m glad you like it, good to know my coin did not go to waste.” Amoxtli chuckled. The pair had gone to try on Olga’s new outfit; the guard’s quarters had been empty at the time, so Amoxtli waited outside as Olga changed.

As Olga picked up the hem of her outfit, curious about the design that edged it, she heard little noises coming from the doorway. Turning her head to face the sounds, she saw strands of long black hair dart away, followed by giggling.

“I think they like you haha!” Amoxtli chuckled.

Olga had suspected that some of Coatzintli’s daughters had been spying on her. It was clearly harmless fun, after Olga found out it was them. The first time it happened she had felt a creepy sense of being watched come over her, it hadn’t helped her with settling in.

“If you want, I can tell them to stop it.” Amoxtli added, trying to break the awkward silence.

“Oh! No no! It’s fine,” Olga insisted; some of them looked like they were just kids after all, plus she didn’t want to be known as a bossy bitch right after arriving.

“Well if you need me to tell them off at some point, let me know.” The guard added, “You are living in the palace after all, don’t want them bothering you at the dead of night or something.”

That was another thing Olga had to get used to. She had been given one of the servant’s quarters in the palace; although calling it that was a bit harsh. It was very well furnished, with plenty of decorations and exotic plants to try to banish the dungeon aesthetic the stone walls would otherwise have put off.

“Well if you don’t need me, I’ll be off on my shift.” Amoxtli added, picking up her halberd and slithering for the door. “If you need me, I am stationed in the barracks. It’s the building to the left when you leave the palace.”

Olga watched as her only friend for hundreds of miles left the room, followed by some yelling as the muscular Naga shooed the offending kids from earlier away. Guess it was time for her to do some of her own exploring before hunkering down with her new kitchen.
1113112211122112212112.title: Can't Beat the Heat

choices: Quetzalli—the longest and tallest of the Queen's daughters
Chantico—the roundest and laziest daughter of the Queen's clutches
Nenetl—the smallest and shortest of the Queen's daughters
11131122111221122121122.content:
Despite Amoxtli's interference with the small gathering of royal hatchlings, Olga would not find herself without an audience.

Everywhere she walked, she attracted stares. No human had set foot this deep in the Marshes for quite a long time, and certainly not one with long golden hair and such fair skin. The occasional pirate or explorer, for sure, but a chef? Olga was the least capable human that anyone had ever laid eyes upon! She stood lower than even the shortest Naga by at least a head, and scurried around beneath them.

She was a strange creature, some tailless armless thing that had wandered into the palace one day. The children were mesmerized by her presence. Many Naga in the Marshes went their entire lives without seeing hide nor hair of the scaleless, squishy species and were more confused by their seeming lack of defenses than anything. How did this poor "Olga" get around on those stubby little meat sticks? She was low to the ground, with no way to extend beyond standing on her... "toes", was that what they were called? And she had only half as many arms as any Naga proper, without claws or even wings like the occasional Siren that would fly inland from the Bay. Whereas Humans feared the Naga, the snake women were just more perplexed as to why (and how) this odd little species seemed to have claimed so much of Yndyre for itself.

But among the countless pairs of eyes that seemed to watch her, one set seemed the most diligent.

It had been a few days since Olga had come to the palace. She'd done some exploring, gotten to know a few more of Coatlzintli's servants, and had a more general idea of what she was supposed to be doing throughout the day. Once she'd picked up a few more tunics (long enough on her to be worn as short dresses) and had been given a cursory tour of the Palace by Amoxtli, Olga had decided that it was time for her to get to know the kitchen.

Which naturally, given the vast difference between their two cultures and the stance of the people she'd be servicing, was much different than the one from the Bleakfrost Tavern.

"You light the coals underneath the stone," Amoxtli lowered a torch into the long bin of kindling that ran underneath the slab-built that extended from the wall, "And while it warms, you prepare the meat."

The kitchen and larder were incredibly spacious. Various carcasses of felled beasts hung high up the walls, with barrels full of spices and vegetables. The heat was not kind to the meat's odor, this much Olga would admit to. It wasn't overpowering, but the smell of animal corpse was everpresent in the room. So much meat went into the Naga diet.

"Don't be afraid to really season it. Peppers, spices, anything that will give it flavor." one of the kitchen aides demonstrated with one pair of arms while gesticulating with the other, "I've been told that you humans have better tasty parts on your tongues than Naga. It might not taste good to you, but you're not the one who we're looking to satisfy."

Olga couldn't help but feel overwhelmed. Just a few months ago she was an assistant chef to Ms. Somaria back in Racovania, and now she was going to be running an entire castle's kitchen and making meals literally fit for a queen.

"Use your human sense of taste to say what goes well with what, and then double it." the aide said, kneading some mammoth muscle, "No, triple it. We want the Queen to be happy, full, and not at all regretting her decision in hiring you."

"Atzi". Amoxtli hissed at the kitchen aide before cursing at her in Naga

"I just meant given your lack of experience in cooking for Naga." the smaller snake corrected, "Given that you're just a Legger."

"Atzi."

Olga had gotten used to these kinds of comments. As harshly as the Naga were treated back in Racovania, at least they were respected. Here, Olga was treated like some kind of commodity. She often idly wondered how she'd been put in a position where not having a snake's tail and four arms had her considered a freak. It was sobering, that much was for sure, to be constantly talked down to. For having such a high position in the royal palace, she still felt like every bit the barmaid she'd started out as...

It was in her grouching that she noticed a set of brown fingers wrapped around the edge of the arch that led into the rest of the palace. One golden eye peeped over the edge for just long enough to meet with Olga's before zipping back behind it.

"Amoxtli?" Olga said with an awkward and forced laugh, "Looks like I've got another visitor... again..."

"HEY!" Amoxtli shouted, "Royalty or not, I will tan your hide!"

The offending snake woman's tail flicked into sight as whichever one of Coatlzintli's clutch that it was flinched at getting caught. A small squeak of voyeuristic intention gave her away entirely, and the red-tailed guard snake rattled towards the doorway. She swore at the girl in Naga, all four of her arms flailing around angrily in her wild gesticulation.

"You have been following around Ms. Olga since she got here!" she said, finally, in Common, "Present yourself and apologize!"

With much shame and embarrassment for all those involved, the hatchling in question came into view...
11131122111221122121122.title: Snake Eyes

choices: Lunch with the Snake Ladies and brave the awkwardness!
Go back to the Servant's Quarters to de-stress and decompress!
111311221112211221211221.content:
With much shame and embarassment for all those involved, the hatchling in question came into view. And once she'd ducked her head and slithered more than partway into the kitchen, Olga found herself taking a step back.

Most of the Naga that Olga had met with stood taller than her. It came with having long tails to stand on instead of legs. Some were bigger than others, naturally. But apart from the Queen, the Naga that slithered in shamefully with her head ducked in the doorway, out of both shame and necessity, was easily the biggest one that Olga had ever seen. Not accounting for girth, she may have been as long as the Queen herself, with especially large humanoid parts to match! Had she stood on two legs, this member of Coatlzintli's clutch would have been a giant!

"All the way, Quetzalli." Amoxtli said sternly, both sets of arms crossed tightly, "It's not befitting your status to do apologize halfheartedly."

The giant Naga let out a little sigh and did her best to coil her long tail in from the hallway. Feet upon feet of green and brown, with little yellow speckles long the pattern, wriggled into some semblance of place as she got into what Amoxtli apparently considered a more apologetic stance.

"M-My apologize, Head Chef." she said in a surprisingly high voice to contrast her mother's contralto, "I-I didn't mean to offend you."

"Um..." Olga blinked dumbly at the sight, "No sweat?"

The naga blinked dumbly at Olga's human expression.

"I mean, it's uh..." Olga gulped, "It's okay."

This girl was easily twice the size of Amoxtli beneath her. It was quite the sight, seeing the shorter red-scaled Naga bossing around someone so large and imposing. With her broad shoulders and strong features, Quetzalli almost looked more like a warrior than Amoxtli did. Albeit without the bulging muscles. While not fat by any means, the sturdy and sizable Naga was a bit soft. A lifetime in the castle, for sure, was the culprit.

"Do you wish for me to send her back to her room, then?" Amoxtli said like a stern parent

"No, it's okay." Olga relented easily, not wishing to upset the Naga any more than she already had, "You're free to stay, um..."

"Quetzalli." the princess answered excitedly, "I'm Mother's oldest daughter."

"And next in line for the crown." Amoxtli added helpfully, "So we expect her to act a bit more responsibly than her clutchmates."

Olga could literally sit on this woman's shoulders and ride her like a steed. This was so wild. The Queen was an example of just Size. Of course Coatlizintli was hugely tall as well as obscenely fat. But Quetzalli was rather slender at her size. It somehow put the difference between their two peoples into perspective. The various breeds of Naga came with different sizes, scale patterns... everything!

"Ms. Olga?" the princess asked, "Are you, um... okay?"

Olga snapped back to attention

"O-Of course! Just thinking."

"My mother says that when she's hungry."

"Are you hungry, Blue Eyes?" Amoxtli pat her friend on the back, "It is about time for lunch."

Olga had never thought that she'd be put into such a strange position. Snake women, great stone buildings. Giant dinosaur carcasses hanging from the wall. Being put in charge of... anything. She was a humble smith's daughter, and now she was leading the charge in feeding a bunch of women with snake parts. It was all a little... destabilizing.
111311221112211221211221.title: Quite a lot of Quetzalli

choices: The Queen(s) returns from Adinah, even larger—Olga has her work cut out for her!
The Queens stay in Adinah as the Season changes—why is everyone eating so much?!
1113112211122112212112212.content:
"I... I think that I'm going to head back to my room." Olga smiled politely as possible, "I'm suddenly not feeling very well."

"Are you ill?" Amoxtli slithered forward a bit, "Should I call the shaman, and—?"

"No, no, I just..." Olga struggled to come up with a good malady that no one would be able to object to, "Rest my legs."

At once, a nod of understanding swept through the kitchen. Atzli, Amoxtli and Quetzalli all let out a soft "ah" of approval. Their heads bobbed as they seemed to understand the problem. Of course her legs were tired, those weird bony things. Moving them so much and across such a big palace, no wonder the poor human was feeling tired.

"Yes, that's right." Olga said a bit more confidently, having successfully gotten away with her deception, "My legs."

Amoxtli slithered forward and placed a comforting hand on her charge's shoulder. Her hands were rough and battle-worn. They were strong but, admittedly, comforting. In any other time that she was experiencing a sudden and acute culture shock.

"Would you like me to have a dais prepared for you?" she asked in all sincerity, "It's quite a, um... walk back to your quarters."

"No, no I'll be fine."

"M-May I accompany you back to your quarters, Ms. Olga?" Quetzalli squeaked, "Ms. Amoxtli? May I?"

Olga's blue eyes widened, suddenly feeling the pressure in her chest again. She very suddenly wanted to be alone and away from these snake people. To get some peace and quiet with the only bit of normalcy she had left in the world—herself. But she'd gone and done made herself sound like a cripple, practically. How could she possibly have said no without also opening up the possibility of her going to lunch?

"Suuuure..." Olga said with a forced smile, "That'd be... greaaat."

"Well, if she's okay with it." Amoxtli nodded approvingly

"Yes!" Quetzalli pumped her four arms excitedly and grabbed Olga by one of her hands, "Come, Miss, I know the way!"

Olga was practically dragged off by the speed with which the Naga slithered away, left looking back at her bodyguard and kitchen aide as they looked on at her pitiably. It would appear that the handicap of being "human" was going to come in handy here...

"Would you like me to carry you, Miss?" the big Naga asked helpfully, "With your little... walkers... and all being hurt?"

"What, no I—"

***


Olga was put down gently in front of her private quarters about ten minutes later. Quetzalli was able to hoist her up and put her down without so much as breaking a sweat, despite all of her squirmings. Naga were much stronger, much more naturally muscular than humans, so even a spoiled city girl like Quetzalli was able to throw Olga around. Somehow, she was less than enthused by that fact.

"Here you are, Ms. Olga." Quetzalli said, much more chipper after her little "stroll" with the honored guest, "Would you like me to put you in your bed—"

"No." Olga said sharply, "No thank you, Quetzalli."

The large naga woman was excitable, that much was for sure. She'd been one of the hatchlings chiefly bent on following her around. She'd never gotten a good look at her before, but now she was sure of it. Quetzalli had been stalking her since she'd come to the palace, and Amoxtli had only confirmed it. Any other day, it would have been sweet. But as she headed towards her bedroom, Olga found herself a bit annoyed with her fan.

"M-Miss Olga?" Quetzalli peeped from behind her back, "Um, I was wondering..."

Olga sighed deeply.

"Yes, Quetzalli?"

"Would it be okay if I... asked you some questions?" Quetzalli did her best to hide a smile, "About your culture. I-I've never met a Legger before.'

Olga was about to snap and let out all of the frustration that she'd accrued over the course of her journey away from home loose on the girl. Damn the size difference and damn the fact that she was a princess and damn the fact that she could literally eat her. Olga wanted some peace and quiet and to be away from anything that reminded her that she was literally across the land and far away from anything she'd ever known.

But then, she looked over the giant snake woman again. She seemed so excited. Amoxtli had been right when she introduced them to her—they were just girls. Despite the fact that she was bigger, and maybe even older than Olga, Quetzalli was just as sheltered about the world as she was.

Maybe even moreso.

"Fine." Olga sighed, "Come in. Um, mind your head."

***


Olga's private chambers were high enough to accommodate Quetzalli's stature comfortably. Her long tail stretched across the room, giving Olga a good look at just how long and vibrant it was. Patli's bright yellow stripe coursed through Coatzintli's brown and green pattern, tracing the splotches in golden trimming that stood out in the candlelight. Olga sat on the stone bed (that was all that it was really good for, certainly not sleeping!) while the princess stretched across the equally stone floor.

Her head propped up in her hands, elbows resting on the floor as her tail swished excitedly at the end, even Olga had to admit that she was very cute.

"So vampires are real?" she asked with wonder in her eyes, "And they like snow?"

"Nobody likes snow." Olga said sourly, "They're just already cold and dead so they can't feel it."

"Wowww"

The princess was awestruck by every bit of Olga's Racovanian heritage that she could recall. Or embellish upon. Since coming here, everyone had treated her like a second class citizen. But this girl ate up everything that she could remember from her homeland—how could she not at least try to impress the one Naga who didn't think she was a cripple?

"So are you a cook for your Queen?" Quetzalli leaned forward again, "Do humans have Queens?"

"Humans do have Queens!" Olga answered helpfully, "But no, my Queen lives in Adinah, and I am in Racovania."

"Are those far away?"

"Super far away."

"Oooh."

Despite the fact that she was so big and broad, Quetzalli carried herself like a girl Olga's size. She was so shy in front of what she considered to be "adults" like Amoxtli and Atzli, even the other members of the servitude. But Olga had seen her really open up to her. It was sweet—in a way. Olga was a commodity for the right reason here. A stranger from a foreign land, as she felt was more appropriate. Even if she was just a farm girl.

"Are you going to stay through the Rainy Season?" Quetzalli blinked, "Oh shoot, you already said you were."

"I'll be staying here until your mother sends me back." Olga laughed, trying a little too hard not to think about never seeing home again, "But with the way she eats, I don't think she's one to turn away cooking."

"Ooh, when I'm Queen will you be my chef?" Quetzalli asked, "Is your Queen big like Mother, even in the Dry Season?"

"I, um... what?"

"In Naga culture, it's a sign of wealth and status to still be able to stay large in the Dry Season. Like, the bigger the better" Quetzalli explained, "When it's the dry season, is your Queen still fat?"

"We don't have a Dry Season." Olga answered matter-of-factly, "We have two seasons where I'm from. Winter and Summer. So Cold and... Less Cold. So I guess she's fat all year 'round? If she's fat. I don't know. I've never seen her."

"Wowwwww" Quetzalli said for about the hundredth time.

As strange as it was... Olga rather liked the big naga. She was sweet. And reminded her a little bit of herself. Not that she'd suddenly gotten all the more worldly since coming to this new place that she'd barely explored. But Quetzalli made her feel... important. It was nice.

"When I begin cooking." Olga offered, "Would you like to watch?"

"Ohmygodsyes."

Yes, something told Olga that she'd made another friend in a rather high place. Somehow. Her luck had been awfully hit-or-miss lately. But Quetzalli seemed to be a nice addition to her growing circle of scaly friends. Things may have just begun with her new career at the palace, but at least someone here thought she was interesting.

She'd need that, if she was ever going to get acclimated here.
1113112211122112212112212.title: A Royal Interest

choices: The Queens return home, after extra servants were sent to help carry her dais
Olga's new friends show her what food fattens up the best for the dry season
Olga struggles to make her way around the city, now everyone is getting fat
11131122111221122121122122.content:
When Quetzalli called it the rainy season, she meant it. Olga had seen more than her fair share of rain living in Racovania, through rain or snow there was little sunlight, but this kind of rain felt unnatural.

Once the rains had come, they didn’t stop. Day-in day-out it rained and rained, with the water flowing through the various channels and gutters built into the city, sending the excess water out into the lake. It wasn’t light rain either, thick heavy droplets that were almost painful pounded down onto the stone rooftops.

After what must have been two weeks of this deluge, it finally stopped… somewhat. There seemed to still be some rain every other day, but it was far cry from the torrential downpour that preceded it. As the rains slowed down somewhat, another change came over the city. The plant-life came into bloom, turning the dark-gray city into a rainbow of color. Not only that, but the markets were filled with foodstuffs, it made gathering for the royal kitchens far easier now that every stall seemed to stock everything required.

“It rains for *oomph* months, and then we get no rain *gulp* for months, then the cycle starts anew.” Amoxtli explained as she and Olga leaned out of the palace window, observing the beautiful landscape.

“Riiiight…” Olga replied. She understood the rain/no rain concept perfectly fine, but why was Amoxtli eating all the time? It wasn’t just her either; whenever she took trips down into the markets, almost every Naga seemed to be snacking on something; women washing their clothes with their upper arms, whilst passing roasted animal legs past their lips with their lower ones; gaggles of chatty teenagers using all of their limbs to pass snacks around as they gossiped. Even the soldiers who normally stood still as statues were eating on duty.

Olga had just started to feel like she was finally getting the hang of this city and its quirks, but then it just seemed to throw another weird cultural activity at her like this one. Feeling bold, Olga decided to pry.

“Soooo why is everyone eating so much?” She prodded, hoping it wasn’t something sensitive.

Amoxtli finished her mouthful, and licked her fingers. “To try and get fat.” She responded casually, as it is was the most normal thing in the world.

“What!?” Olga replied. She was already kinda weirded out that pretty much the entire population wanted the queen to be the size of a large house (apart from ironically, queen Coatlzintli herself), but this was bizarre.

“Oh you do not have a dry season! How silly of me.” Amoxtli added, berating herself. “During the dry season, food supplies run low, but during the rainy season we have more than enough food to go around several times over.” She explained. “So during the rainy season we build up fat stores to help us through the dry season.”

“But there was still food around when I arrived.” Olga pointed out.

“Because there is still some food, but not enough to keep the population going on an empty stomach,” Amoxtli continued. “Everyone rations, but their fat stores help keep them going. You should put on some weight as well; you won’t make it through a whole dry season being all skinny like that.”

Olga was a bit taken aback by that. “ME!? I uh…”

“The dry season is many months long,” Amoxtli added. “You were fine when you arrived, as we only had a little left of it… but a whole dry season? We better get you ready for it.”

---


“You ok Olga?” Atzi asked, shaking the blonde woman out of her thoughts. “You’re going a bit slower than usual there.”

Olga looked down, she had become so lost in her thoughts, that she practically stopped cutting the meat on the chopping board. “Sorry, just… thinking about something.” She hand-waved; Atzi shrugged, and got back to work, helping herself to a bowl of mixed sugared fruit as she passed it.

Staring at the bowl, Olga wondered if she should take some as well. If getting fat here was supposed to be good for your health in the long run… perhaps she should? Ugh, but her instants told her that she shouldn’t indulge, this whole concept and attitude towards obesity was so… foreign.

“You ok?”

Olga jumped again as the python-like Quetzalli slithered up to her.

“Yes…” Olga replied, but then thought. Quetzalli had experienced nothing but Naga life and culture, perhaps she might be able to help her?

“Actually… Quetzalli.” Olga began, getting the snake princess’ attention. “The whole, getting fat for the dry season thing, what do you think about it?”

“I think it is normal.” The young serpent replied, “Is it not normal where you come from?”

Olga then remembered how fat her former employer was getting before she left. Well, perhaps there were… some exceptions. “Let’s say it’s not.” Olga answered. “I have just, never done this sort of thing before.”

Perhaps she had opened up a little too much to the girl, but Quetzalli seemed to honestly want to help.

“Well, the first time I remember it, it was fun. You get to eat anything you want, and you don’t have to worry about eating too much.”

The head chef was rather surprised by that answer, fun? Quetzalli then continued, spurred on by happy memories. “One time, I ate a whole buffalo in one sitting!” She giggled.

“And nobody judged you for it?” Olga asked.

Quetzalli looked confused. “Why would someone do that?” She replied in her high pitched voice, “Chantico ate two that very meal. Everyone is trying to get fat in rainy season; nobody will look harshly on you.”

That seemed to cheer Olga up a bit, “Thank you Quetzalli.” Happy to have helped, a blush overtook the huge snake-woman’s face as she struck a great beaming smile.

Perhaps she should eat a bit more, Olga thought to herself, at least not too much.
11131122111221122121122122.title: The City of Eating

choices: Olga isn't about to get fat—but she DOES add some "human" changes to the kitchen
Olga relents, just to be on the safe side—when in the Marshes, do as the Naga do
Oh Olga's getting fat, alright—and she's definitely not happy about it!
111311221112211221211221222.content:
"The object of the Rainy Season is to stockpile." Atzi raised one finger, her other hands bent at the elbows on her hips, "Over the centuries, we have learned the most efficient ways at doing so."

The Marshes were not easy to traverse, even on two legs. Where the snakes could slither over and under, Olga was trudging along and stepping over this root and under that branch. The hot, muggy temperature meant that she was forced to dress light, and the terrain meant that she had to stay mobile. The long, flowy tunics that she'd gotten used to wearing in the Dry Season were unfeasible in this climate as it once again became strange to the unfortunate chef. The tan she'd been left with between sunburns had darkened her skin a bit, but her soft stomach was still every inch the Racovanian shade of snow-white. She'd dressed in a half shirt that left her ivory-white underbelly exposed for all to see and scoff at, and a short skirt with boots. It should have been shorts, but... well, snakes didn't have much use for those lying around.

A small team of scouts had come along to protect the kitchen's hands as they gathered the ingredients for the season. Though the Queens had not yet returned, no one was going to let the royal staff slack off. And besides, there was an outsider among them. If Olga was ever to cook for the Queen in any season, it was important that she familiarize herself with the ingredients of their culture.

"Likewise, the Marshes provide everything that we need to survive." Atzli continued, one hand rubbing a steadily rounding stomach that pooched into a pot-belly, "Today we'll be gathering Rainberries."

"That doesn't sound so hard." Olga panted, happy to hear that her excursion into this damp damnation might go smoothly, "So is that why we brought the sacks?"

"Good thinking, White Belly." Atzli snorted as she tossed the Legger a burlap bag, big enough for Olga to crouch down in, marked with something in Naga, "Guess you're the head chef for a reason."

To Olga's confusion and surprise, she handed each of the accompanying guards a sack. The fit, toned bodies of Coatlzintli's guards were slowly being buried underneath the excessive consumption that had gripped the Marshes. Abs bulged underneath brown naga chub as arms swelled fit to burst under the golden armbands that denoted their rank. They were no less fast or strong, but it was strange to see the women she'd seen as protectors slowly growing so plump.

Even stranger that they would be helping. They were just picking berries. How many could they possibly need?

"Um... okay." Olga blinked, "So where are the berries? Let's get started!"

"Couldn't agree with you more." Atzli laughed, "I'll show you what we're looking for."

Extending herself upwards on her long black tail, Atzli disappeared into the canopy of trees. Some rustling followed, as well as the distinct sound of branches snapping. Accumulated dewdrops and stilled rainfall poured down on top of the gathering party. After a moment, Atzli returned to the ground level of the marshes with a piece of fruit the size of her head.

"Oof, this's a good one." Atzli laughed tossing it up and down a bit, "Nice and ripe."

She tossed it into Olga's sack, which sent her backward by a few steps. It was deceptively heavy! Olga thought that they were just going to be picking berries, like... berries. Snowberries back home could fit between your fingers! These weren't berries! These were fruit!

"Rainberries soak up all the nutrients of the marsh and store 'em all year round." Atzli slapped her belly proudly, comparatively small to some of the soldier's fleshy brown tummies that bulged beneath their armor. "We Naga eat them during the rainy season to help make sure we put on lots of weight."

"So this fruit... makes you fat?" Olga gulped

"Enough of them might, but you can't just eat fruit all season long. Gotta have meat." Atzli said with a smile, "But that'll make putting on weight easier, and it'll help you shed your skin when you get to outgrowin' it."

"Um... my species—"

"Alright ladies, get to climbin'!" Atzli clapped her two upper hands together, "We've only got a few hours before the rain starts again so let's make it snappy!"

***


"You see that?" Amoxtli whispered, "That's a gigantopithecus—you ever had one of those before?"

"I've never seen one of those before." Olga grimaced, "Let alone eaten one."

"Oh, right, you're both monkeys." the red snake apologized, "Sorry, forgot."

The Marshes supported a wide variety of life. Olga was learning that. From the great lizards to the gigantic fish to the hairless mammoths and also apparently giant monkeys. Over the past few days, Olga had been invited out on hunting trips with the Queen's Guard. Atzli had recommended it, but Amoxtli had been the most adamant.

"We risk our lives every day in the Marshes. Sometimes we don't all make it back." she'd said in a surprisingly stern voice, "I would really appreciate it if you came along and watched what we do so this kingdom can eat."

And sure, she knew that it was hard. She'd watched a few of them take down the Tyranto-thingy on her way from Racovania. But these beasts in the Marshes were enormous. And seeing the great monkey, this giganto-whatsit, really helped put it in perspective.

"See, Rainy Season, everything knows to get nice and fat." Amoxtli kept her voice low, "The Marshes provide us and our food with everything we need to make it through the Dry Season, and that includes our friend there—looks like he's already overdone it though."

Olga watched as the great monkey, gorged so full and fat that it could barely move, continued to feast on some of the very same kinds of foliage that she'd gathered with Atzli over the past week. Seeing it stuff itself so fervently, so easily made Olga realize just how ill-equipped humanity was for the Marshes. She'd worked for hours to get what that Monkey ate in minutes. But at the same time, he'd loaded himself with enough of the same nutrients that the Naga required to make it through the season and then some. He must be filled with everything the Naga needed to survive...

"It might not be sporting, but we're gonna wait until he's gone and fallen asleep." Amoxtli continued, "Then we'll take him back to the capital and Atzli will show you how to cook him up good."

***


"What do you think?"

"It's getting better." Nochtli's face scrunched up in displeasure, "But I've also had better. So make of that what you will."

Olga and the blue-tailed Naga had been in the kitchen since the morning, with Olga attempting to familiarize herself with the strange inner workings of what was to be her kitchen. While the other staff worked tirelessly to feed the guards and the Queen's many children, Olga had been put on a sort of probational assignment. Until she learned the Rainy Season recipes—rather than simply grilling and cooking the various meats of the Dry Season—she was to do nothing else but gather ingredients and cook them.

"Are you going to throw this one out too?" Olga sighed despondently

"Well, I can't exactly afford to go hungry now can I?" Nochtli snorted, snatching the bowl of stew with one set of thick arms while the other caressed her further fattened form, "I have a figure to maintain."

Like all of seemingly everyone, Nochtli had begun putting on weight the second that water fell from the sky. However, she took to it with much more fervor than the others. Already quite large, she had quite the head start. Her position in the castle was an important one, and she had the diet (and appetite) of any royal hatchling. The Queen and her mate still predisposed in Adinah, she had taken to tasting food for the hatchlings so as to "ensure that her Highness's lineage remains safe" but, in all honesty, it was an open secret that it was just an excuse for her to eat more.

Nochtli hadn't moved from her spot since the morning while Olga puttered around the kitchen, content to be fed and provide as much feedback as possible. All she'd done all day is eat, without any of the exercise that the other staff members had managed to perform.

"I'm coming along quite nicely, don't you think?" Nochtli purred as she lifted up her big brown belly, letting it collapse back into place as it hung low over her skirt. She hefted it in her two lower hands, brown flesh bulging heavily between her thick clawed digits as it sloshed from side to side. "The Queen might mistake me for one of her own if I'm to keep going at his pace."

Olga simply rolled her eyes. She'd never understood this culture's fascination with fat. Their Queen was massive and had hired her with the explicit intent of being slimmed down. Everyone stuffed their faces for half of a year and encouraged her to do the same. But Nochtli was the most open and adamant about how much she loved her own size.

"You're definitely getting fat faster than anyone else." Olga said, deadpan, "That much is for sure."

"And you'd better start packing on weight as fast as you can, Olga." Nochtli stroked her gut lovingly, "Before the Season's over and you wither away into nothing!"
111311221112211221211221222.title: Adaptation and Co-Habitation

choices: Olga's increased passion for cooking DOES have a downside...
Olga's increased ego about her position DOES have a downside...
Olga's disregard for taking stuff from the Marsh DOES have a downside...
1113112211122112212112212221.content:
Olga didn't receive much of an education working as a barmaid. As a smith's daughter, she had very little access to book learning. Or books, for that matter. Everything she knew how to read came from order slips and things that Helga and Somaria had written down, back at the Tavern.

But it didn't take a fancy city-girl education to know that Humans and Naga were different.

As friendly as the Naga had been to her, they clearly didn't know what was best for her biology. Half the time, they forgot what the word for "legs" was. She had to explain, at length, that she did not shed her skin and could not ingest barely-cooked meat. Nor could her throat stretch and she didn't lay eggs. Also, they kept calling blood "cold"? Olga was pretty sure that wasn't right. With all of that in mind, she took this whole "get fat for the Dry Season" thing with a grain of salt.

Olga imagined toddling around at Helga's size, and it would have made it almost impossible to keep up with the heavy workload she'd been placed under. Feeding an entire Queen's den of servants was not an easy job, and she needed to use her feet as much as possible. With the great spaces between cooking slabs and the general distance between most destinations to be reached, Olga didn't see herself being able to put on weight during her tenure here, let alone wanting to. She'd been getting plenty of exercise since she'd started her position at the palace and it had helped to keep her slim.

Sure, a little bit of belly bulged out from underneath her ripened breasts. In a land of plentiful food, her figure was allowed to flourish as the Gods had intended in a way that would have never been possible in the scarce snowy landscape of Racovania. But Olga was just filling out a bit. Some muscle was underneath those ivory-white legs that carried her back and forth, back and forth across the stone floors of the palace.

She might have been hired by the Queen to feed the den of snakes, but only because she didn't think like them. She was hired because she was new, and provided a fresh outlook on things!

So why do things the way that the Naga had always done them? Why not bring a little bit of Racovania into the Marshes?

***


"You absolute fucking madwoman." Amoxtli gasped, "You can't... Olga, I don't think that you can do that!"

"Of course you can. It's just a plant." Olga snorted as she picked a Rainberry from the vine, "When Aztli said that they grow on vines, I had an idea on how to keep them ready year-round!"

Two especially tubby guards stood on thick meaty tails, brown bellies smooshed against the stone as they looped the long green vine from one end of the kitchen wall to the other. Resting them on the uneven stones that extended from the wall, they drooped lazily from a safe distance to the heat of the stone slab below them. On one end, Olga had it potted and set to the corner.

"Olga these berries are sacred to us." Amoxtli said in a hushed voice, hunkering down and bunching her belly rolls, "You can't take them out of the Marshes."

"But we're still in the Marshes." Olga said matter of factly, "And we take them back to the palace to eat them, right?"

"But... but Olga." Amoxtli pursed her lips, "I don't think you—"

"And it's still soil from the Marshes. They might not get as big as they do out there, but this way we can keep them all year 'round!" Olga beamed proudly, hands on her hips as she gestured to the other guards performing similar tasks, "As long as we keep them watered, they'll keep getting bigger and bigger!"

"As long as..." Amoxtli grimaced, "I don't know, Olga, I still don't like it."

"Trust me, it'll all be okay." Olga pat her friend on the meaty back, "It's called farming, Amoxtli. We do it where I'm from all the time."

***


"Ms. Olga?" Quetzalli hefted a potato in her hands, "What's this?"

"It's a vegetable, Quetzalli. And if we save the rain in containers or pools, we can keep them alive and healthy even in the Dry Season!" Olga smiled, plucking it from her big brown hands and beginning to peel it, "I know how to cook these very well. Everyone where I'm from puts these in almost everything."

"Is it... is it meat?" the great snake asked, genuinely confused, "It doesn't smell like meat. It's very, um... cold. And hard. And a little joyless."

Olga laughed a little tossed the now naked potato into the bucket with the rest. She, and some of the chef hands, had shucked plenty of them in not a lot of time at all. A lot of things, Olga balked at. But the "four arms" thing easily had to be the most useful part about having Naga assistance. She and Ms. Somaria would have had to have worked all day to get this much done.

"Maybe now, but you can do anything with potatoes." Olga smiled, feeling at home for the first time since she'd come to this temperamental place as she peeled the brown skin from the starch of her homeland, "Cook them, bake them, boil them... and they grow right in the ground, so no need to climb any trees!"

"Do they... taste good?" Quetzalli made a face, sniffing an unpeeled one from the bag

"Do they ever!" Olga answered with no small amount of pride, "They're full of good stuff and they take on the flavor of whatever you put next to them. You put them in stew, you chop them up, you put cheese on them... Ms. Helga used to love them!"

"O-kay..." Quetzalli smiled nervously, "I-If you say so... are you sure you can't just cook meat?"

***


As the Rainy Season progressed, Olga did her best to acquiesce to her new position. Having suitably made herself at home in the kitchen and gotten more used to the ingredients she'd be working with (and a few of her own!) Olga finally started to feel like she'd found her niche.

Sure there were still some hiccups. Naga culture was still so strange to her, and the constant raining made it very hard to go out and explore the kingdom! With little to do other than cook and cook and cook, Olga had plenty of time to experiment when she wasn't managing to scrounge out a social life.

"Oh I love it~" Nochtli gushed, kneading both sides of her boulder-big belly as it swelled out in front of her, "Olga, sweetie, your cooking is soooo good."

Olga couldn't help but feel the pride welling up in her chest. Nochtli's whole job was to eat. It was literally almost all she did. So if this fat snake liked her cooking, she must have been doing something right! For a species so obsessed with bulking up for the Dry Season, they could be surprisingly picky! And at the size that her blue-tailed taste tester was, Olga would have hardly believed that she'd have been anyone to turn down food. Thankfully, ever since she really found her routine in the kitchen, there hadn't been much of that.

"You're too kind, thank you." Olga said with a polite little bow, feeling her head swell, "It's just... I added a little something from where I come from."

"I don't care what it is, I just want more!" Nochtli's quivering gut, folding into an apron of two sagging folds of brown blubber, rippled as she tittered in appreciation, "The queen is going to love what you've done here."

"I hope so."

"Can I have more?" Nochtli clasped her fleshy hands together over her blooming bosom, "Oh please oh please?"

"You'll just have to wait until dinner time." Olga whipped out another Racovanian delicacy that she'd brought to the Marshes "But you can have a sweet roll!"

Yes, things were going well for Olga. She'd finally settled into her own! In a whole kingdom where everyone was clamoring to get fat, her food was becoming more and more appreciated. As bellies swelled and appetites grew, figures fattened and flesh bulged, the Naga ladies got less and less peculiar about the "Legger food" that had been decried when she'd first taken the position. Now, there were hardly any complaints about anything that Olga managed to whip up!

The improvements she'd made would, hopefully, mean that she could sustain these recipes in the Dry Season. Not to this volume, of course, but there would be much less moping about the lackluster food options available during the former part of the year...

"At least as long as I'm around." Olga said proudly, stirring her stew, "Maybe the Queen was right about hiring me..."
1113112211122112212112212221.title: Olga isn't about to get fat—but she DOES ...

choices: Amoxtli—she'd gone from solid soldier to soft, supple, & super-sized in no time!
Atzli—she was less a kitchen aide and more of a kitchen disposal these days!
Quetzalli—the princess looked more and more like her mother every day!
11131122111221122121122122211.content:
Olga's position in the Palace was secured, finally. Not just by the Queen who had hired her, and was still absentia with her wife in the Captial, but by a majority of the staff.

All of what anything that anyone had to say about her mostly amounted to good things. Sure she was an outsider, but she could cook well! "For a Legger" was usually added as a sort of a cultural afterthought. She was still seen as something of a small, defenseless creature that needed protecting. But with the way that she cooked, no one minded protecting her really. She was one of them now! Even if she had those weird wiggly leg things.

Olga took to her newfound passion for introducing Racovanian flavors and styles into the Naga diet with gusto. Even the things she wasn't sure about, she was willing to try. She would spend hours in the kitchen, whipping up recipes for no reason other than experimentation. She was introducing new items into the menu whenever she found a combination that worked. With plenty of herbs, spices, fruits, and rich fatty meats to choose from, there were plenty of options.

Moreover, with everyone still trying to bulk up for the Dry Season, there were plenty of contenders waiting with open mouths.

That being said, she tended to show favorites to those closest to her. While her newfound fame around the Palace had meant that there were a lot of people who were beginning to warm up to her—like snakes to a rock in the sun—Olga stayed loyal to those who had helped her acclimate in the first place. She made sure that her friends were treated well! After all, it was the least she could do. Showing a little favoritism wasn't exactly uncalled for in this situation, was it?

Even though Nochtli was her "official" taste tester, Olga was happy to provide her friends with extra portions. It was how she showed affection, after all. So, when they'd visit her in the kitchen, Olga would sneak them extra helpings. At the dinner table, Olga had them served more. And when off the clock, Olga was happy to bring treats from her homeland back to their rooms.

And that meant that a few key players in Olga's story were getting fat—even for the Rainy Season.

But among the quickest and most startling gains was...
11131122111221122121122122211.title: Rainy Season Figures

choices: "Too good of a time if you ask me."—She hardly supports Amoxtli's indulgence!
"Feeling a little jealous?"—Atzli mistakes Olga's favoritism for something more!
"Indeed, she's fattening up nicely. She'll make a wonderful sacrifice."—WHAT?!
111311221112211221211221222111.content:
Everyone in the Marshes overindulged during the Rainy Season, obviously. Olga knew that by now. She'd spent more time with the snakes stuffing themselves than she had when they were skrimping by. Something about their biologies allowed them to pile on weight quickly and efficiently and, presumably, lose it just as quickly. It had only been a few months and some women were twice the size that they had started out as. Bellies every shade of brown bulged happily out of tunics, bras, and dresses as they flopped lazily over the base of their tails. Arms swelled, and some even started to jiggle as cheeks chubbed and chins bunched. Olga had never seen so much indulgence, not in any of the Racovanian Festivals, or even all of them put together.

"I love the Rainy Season."

Amoxtli tipped her head back and opened her fanged mouth wide as an angry belch ripped through the air of the cantina. All four hands resting on her stomach, pressing deep into the squishy brown blubber so as to squeeze that last bit of burp out, Amoxtli sighed contentedly as she poured back another pint, and leaned into the stone table for another morsel. The warrior grunted as her belly rolled onto the stone slab, grabbing at the pot of skewered meats with two chubby arms.

"Look forward to it every year" Amoxtli continued drunkenly, rubbing her exposed apron of a stomach with one lower hand, "I get to eat whatever I want, and damn the consequences."

The Naga pulled pieces of meat from the skewer with her teeth, audible scraping against her fangs as she yanked the iron stick from one end of her mouth to the other. Six or seven chunks were left in her mouth, chewed and swished between chubby brown cheeks as her forked tongue lathered the bites. She swallowed with a happy sigh, took another drink, and went back to the pot.

"Between you coming here an' giving me an excuse to stay off the front lines," Amoxtli pulled Olga close, pressing her into her sloshing stomach, "And getting to fill my belly on all that Legger food, this might be the best year of my life!"

Amoxtli tilted her head back again, letting the ale flow down her throat and cheeks. She wiped the excess away with one jiggly brown arm, patting her gut contentedly as it distended out in front of her. Full of lunch, a hearty dinner with an extra portion from Olga, and the appetizers she'd just wolfed down as they awaited dinner from the Cantina, Amoxtli's belly was drawn taut. Shiny with sweat and humidity, she rested her hands on it proudly, stroking it for good measure as it burbled in digestion.

"You might want to slow down, Moxxy." Atzli stirred her drink—a fruity liquor from the Bay—across from the two, "The Rainy Season can't last forever, you know."

"You're such a—" here, Amoxtli cursed in Naga dismissively, "Don't lecture me on our night out."

"I'm just saying, eventually the rain is going to dry up." Atzli said in her pretty voice, taking a sip of her small but potent bourbon, "And they're going to have to roll you out onto the front lines for exercises."

Amoxtli wasn't listening. A particularly buxom snake the overall shape and size of a caramel dollop had caught her eye behind the bar. Judging by the flirtatious wink of her heavily made-up face, Amoxtli's affections were not at all unmutual. The swollen soldier pulled the remaining meat from her skewer, tipped Olga's drink behind her head, and snatched Atzli's from her clawed fingers.

"The only place I'm gonna be rollin'," Amoxtli purred huskily as she struggled to unwedge herself from their seat, "Is around the slab tonight, ladies."

Once she was finally free, taut belly wobbling back into place as it hung over her lap, Amoxtli slammed ten pieces down on the table and slithered drunkenly towards the bar. Olga and Atzli watched as she sauntered up to the barmaid, belly pouring onto the bar, and struggled to prop her elbows up flirtatiously on the carved countertop.

"Well she seems to be having a good time." Olga said in a pleasant tone, sliding her glass to the end of the table, "So... what's the protocol here? Do we ask for another barmaid, orrr...?"

Atzli put her glass at the end of the table and said...
111311221112211221211221222111.title: An Ample Amoxtli

choices: Olga decides that enough is enough, and puts Amoxtli on a diet.
Olga sees nothing wrong in making her friend happy, and keeps on.
1113112211122112212112212221111.content:
"Too good of a time if you ask me." Atzli watched from afar as her little glass clinked at the end of the table, "She needs to keep herself under control."

Olga frowned. It wasn't entirely unlike the Amoxtli she'd known since before she arrived to have casual sex with heavyset barmaids. In fact, that was (unfortunately) how they met. Since they'd spent some time together, Olga liked to think that she knew a bit more about her red-scaled bodyguard by now, and she couldn't quite get what Atzli was driving at.

"How so?" Olga asked as another waitress slithered up and filled her cup, "She seems happy."

"Do your people have fables?" Atzli asked, leaning onto the table boredly, "Stories you tell to children so that they can learn lessons?"

"We do, but... most of them are about Vampires." Olga clicked her tongue, "Don't think that's very applicable here"

"Well, we have a story about the Sisters and the Seasons." Atzli said, taking a sip of her newly refilled drink before continuing, "A long time ago there are two sisters; Mara and Amara. They both endure the hardships of the Dry Season and go hungry. When the Rainy Season comes around, Mara is mindful and only stockpiles only what is necessary to make it through the next Season. She grows fat, but only out of necessity. Meanwhile, Amara, her sister, eats everything she can get her hands on. By the time the Seasons change, Amara has gotten too fat to hunt for herself and has to rely on her sister to feed her. Because Mara has to hunt twice as much, and Amara is too soft to properly defend herself—they both die."

There was a beat as Atzli's story hung heavily in the air.

"Somehow my fables about Vampires are less depressing." Olga said with a drink, "I thought Naga were supposed to get fat during the Rainy Season?"

"The story has many meanings, but it's more about mindfulness." Atzli took another sip, "We're all trying to stockpile, yes, but within reason. Amoxtli still has a job to do—what would you do if she was too out of shape to properly defend you, should war happen?"

Olga looked over to her friend at the bar, having coerced some sweet bread from the waitress as the two of them flirted. No doubt, Amoxtli was getting heavy. Heavier than most of the other Naga by this point, for sure. But she was her friend! And as her friend, shouldn't she want her to be happy? Amoxtli seemed happy...

"Food for thought, as it were. Sorry to get so heady during what was supposed to be a fun night out." Atzli said with a sudden, forced change of subject, "You work entirely too hard to have to put up with me being so hard-nosed on and off the clock."

And even as the mood lightened and alcohol began to fog their minds, Olga felt a bit troubled by Atzli's frank discussion of Amoxtli. She had always known the Naga to be a very direct, forward people. It came with the culture, she supposed. So why, all of a sudden, go behind her back to discuss her attitude? And with Olga of all people—was it because she was genuinely worried about her friend? Was it because she blamed Olga for showing her friend favoritism? Was that it?

Even as it got easier to justify, with alcohol, that this was just some deep-seeded desire to gossip that was everpresent in all species in Yndyre, Olga found herself troubled.

Eventually...
1113112211122112212112212221111.title: Soldier Going Soft

choices: “Fine, I will go on a diet… but only if you agree to finally start getting fat."
“Fine! I will quit being a guard. If it means more of your legger food..."
“Perhaps I can protect you AND keep eating to my heart’s content… hmmm?”
11131122111221122121122122211111.content:
The next day, Olga was a good way into preparing the meals for the palace staff and the queen’s offspring. She had become such a dab hand at cooking in her new environment that she didn’t require the assistance of any of the other Naga all the time, so she was alone for the first hour or so of the day.

As the blonde woman finished up the first batch of stew, she heard the tell-tale slithering sound of an approaching snake woman.

“Hey Olga!” Amoxtli greeted as she appeared in the servant’s doorway and slithered through it. Or at least, she tried to. Amoxtli only got to her waist before suddenly stopping. The extra-plush Naga had become jammed in the frame!

“Ugh really?” The red-tailed woman grunted as she placed each of her palms against the frame, pushing with her considerable might until her whole serpentine length slithered through. “That was… annoying…” Amoxtli grumbled in a snotty tone, turning her nose up at the door before turning back to her friend.

“Hey Moxxi… what are you doing up so early?” Olga asked with a slight air of hesitation. She remembered the conversations from last night, and was worried about what answer her friend would give. Olga was also struggling to look straight at Amoxtli; it seemed that even the market stalls rainy-season wear had its limits... either that or the humidity and her swaddling blubber were getting to Amoxtli... because the overweight serpent was topless!

Thankfully Amoxtli was wearing a skirt around her waist, obscuring her crotch from Olga's sight. But her big brown breasts were fully on display! Huge orbs that were kept somewhat perky, as they rested upon her shelf of a stomach, with fat dark-brown teats tipping them. Still, gravity could not be fully denied, as the great sphere were leaning to either side of her colossal stomach.

Amoxtli slithered back and forth innocently, clawed fingers drumming her belly. “Oh just… woke up early and wondered what that ravishing smell was…” The Naga replied, her eyes flickering to the pot greedily.

“It’s my stew… the same one I cooked before…” Olga replied, trying to subtly ward Amoxtli away.

“Oh really?” Amoxtli replied with faux innocence. “It smells different though… can I have a taste to be sure?” She wasn’t really asking. Amoxtli slithered closer to the pot, her size still hadn’t impeded the speed at which her snake half could cross the floor.

“Are you sure? It’s just stew.” Olga replied, literally having to waft one of Amoxtli’s wandering hands away.

“But you make such good stew!” Amoxtli teased with a grin, another arm trying to get around the smaller woman.

“It’s not finished!” Olga added, turning around and holding two of Amoxtli’s wrists to try and stop her. This was of course, futile; Amoxtli’s additional appendages instantly tried to snake around so she could help herself to the broth.

“Oh come on!” Her guard replied, leaning closer and causing her big brown belly to envelop the diminutive human slightly. “We both know it’s going to be good anyway… can’t I have just a taste?”

“NO!” Olga snapped. The noise startled Amoxtli, causing her to back off, she had never heard her human friend be so loud before. “Moxxi… you’re my best friend… and I didn’t want to say this… but I have to…” Olga continued, her bottom lip trembling. “You’re getting too fat!”

The Naga scoffed, the air blowing a loose lock of black her out of her face. “Duh, all Naga get fat in the rainy season.”

“I know… but look at Aztli, you are way bigger than her.” Olga pointed out.

“Well she does not have to eat a soldier’s rations.” Amoxtli huffed, crossing both sets of arms.

Olga sighed. “There are guards all around the palace, and I have passed the barracks every time I go to market… none of them are as big as you… I’m worried that you are going to get too big to do your job…”

Amoxtli still wasn’t happy with how this conversation was going. “But the rainy season has barely started!” She argued, “I have so many more months of eating to do!”

“And how big will you be by the end of it?” Olga asked rhetorically. “As big as the queen? Too big to move?! You are already so much bigger than anyone else… what’s going to happen during the dry season?”

The obese Naga didn’t have a response; she had a lot of thinking to do. In the past she had responsibilities during the rainy season, even with the go ahead to eat like a pre-hibernation bear she had never gone flat-out like this before. But now, with Olga coming into the picture things had changed. Had she gone too far? Or was this what she really wanted all along?

Sighing deeply, her big brown breasts heaving across her rotund stomach, Amoxtli answered…
11131122111221122121122122211111.title: Inter-serpent-vention

choices: Olga's Innovations mean Rainy Season food is still available come Dry Season
Olga's Innovations don't work out so well, and the people are NOT happy...
11131122111221122121122122211112.content:
As Olga came to see it, Amoxtli might have been her friend, but she was also an adult—and in charge of making her own decisions.

The Dry Season was a little more than halfway over, and yes, she might have gone a little overboard. Months of eating to her heart's content was a cultural matter, one that everyone did every year. Olga's innovations, recipes, and blending of Racovanian cuisine with that of the Naga sensibilities were just new and exciting. Plenty of the guards had gotten fat with nothing to do, and Olga found it very hard to take criticism from the same snake who she'd caught licking the bowl of her porridge one morning.

Amoxtli just liked Olga's food, and she wasn't alone in that respect. Everyone liked her food. Her cooking was good, and it had taken her from an orphaned, sisterless Smith's daughter working in a tavern as a waitress to serving royalty in the Moatee Marshes clear across the continent.

Olga saw no reason to punish or reprimand her friend and bodyguard for enjoying her amazing cooking—she'd have to punish the whole palace, princesses and all, for such a crime!

No, Olga was going to keep doing what she had been doing. Amoxtli was going to keep getting her extra portions because she was her friend. And so would Atzli, if she wanted it. And the Queen's daughters too. Olga had so many mouths to feed and they all loved her cooking so much, it'd be a crying shame to deny them of what they wanted.

The Rainy season was halfway over, and she was having entirely too much fun carrying on as she had been. If anything, she had have to make sure that everyone got plenty of extra helpings. After all, she might not have understood it, but Naga wanted to eat, drink and be merry during the Rainy Season.

Might as well give them all the best time that they could ask for.

***


"Ms. Olga, I still don't understand why we're not eating the Rainberries." Quetzalli folded her hands behind her meaty back, distended potbelly surging forward as she stood at attention, "Is it because they're not very big?"

"Well, because we need to make sure that we have plenty of them." Olga pinched an overripened, squishy one, and plucked it from the vine that hung over her stove, "So we're taking the bad ones and we're going to plant new ones in other parts of the palace."

"But Ms. Olga, the Rainy Season is gonna be over in a few months." Quetzalli's thick body slithered across the stone floor as she followed Olga around the kitchen, "Rainberries won't grow during the Dry Season..."

"Because there's no water." Atzli said affirmatively, her lower rung of arms folded tight across her fleshy belly, "Which is what I've been trying to tell her."

Ever since Day One, Olga had thought that she was just a dumb girl from the mountains, coming into a foreign and strange land where everyone was smarter than her, worldlier than her, and more experienced than her. But living here, with these snake women, made her realize that they were just as sheltered in the damp mucky swamps as she had been living high up in the mountains! Even as the berries grew thick and lush on the walls of their kitchen, rather than high up in the trees in the forest, they doubted her. Even as their bellies grew fat, they doubted her!

"The reason they only grow in the Marshes in the Rainy Season is that there's no rain in the Dry Season." Olga fought off Atzli's skepticism with a roll of her eyes, "So that's why I've been having the guards saving water all season."

"Is that why all those pots are in those rooms in the West Hall?" Quetzalli scratched her head

"You have them in the West Hall too?" Atzli huffed, "Olga, I think you're overestimating your abilities here. You can't make Rainy Season appear just by saving the water. Even our Shamans—"

"Look, just... trust me, okay?" Olga huffed, "I know I'm not a Naga and I know I have legs and all, but eventually you're going to have to start believing I know what I'm doing."

"You haven't even been here a season." Atzli snapped, "And lately you're far more concerned with praise than you are with practicality."

A silence hung in the kitchen, Quetalli's yellow eyes darting back and forth between the two chef hands. She smiled awkwardly, in hopes of breaking the tension. But unfortunately, the two of them simply parted. Olga went back to work plucking the overripened berries from the lowhanging vines while Atzli exited the kitchen entirely.

"I'm sorry you had to see that, Quetzalli." Olga shook her head, "She's been such a thorn lately."

"N-No problem." Quetzalli quickly answered and even more quickly rushed to change the subject, "Um... what are you going to do with the berries?"

"Well, I'm going to take the seeds out of them and plant them in other pots along the palace." Olga said with a sigh, "And the berries that are leftover, I think maybe I'll make them into a jam."

"Jam?" Quetzalli repeated, "I've never had that."

"It's like a fruit paste. You put it on bread or biscuits." Olga smiled, "I'll need a couple more to make a good sized jar."

"A couple more... Rainberries?" Quetzalli looked quizically at the mushy fruit in Olga's hands, "Just one is—"

"Oh, fine, I guess you don't want to try any jam." Olga sniffed playfully, turning away from the massive snake woman, "Your loss."

"N-No!" Quetzalli relented, "Of course I do!"

Olga chuckled. It was good to know that some people were loyal. Not like Atzli. Maybe once the Queen returned she'd ask for another hand in the kitchen. She'd been fussy lately. Maybe she wasn't getting enough to eat. Everyone else around her seemed happy enough.

"Good." Olga said with a playful pat on Quetzalli's belly, hanging at eye-level to the blonde Legger, "We'll split Atzli's share between you and Amoxtli's."

***


Amoxtli panted as she wriggled her thickening body down the stone sidewalks of the kingdom. Her long, coiling tail had grown thick and heavy this season. It shone slick with moisture in the air, her mouth hung agape as her breath ran ragged. Her belly, turgid and taut, distended low over her lap and sloshed from side to side at every awkward wriggling motion.

"Thanks for walking me home Amoxtli." Olga no longer had to extend her legs for a wide gait when walking alongside her friend, "I don't normally stay out this late."

"You were the one... huff... who was cookin'..." the swollen soldier gasped, two hands pressed tight against the arch of her back while her gut billowed outwards, "I'm just happy you convinced them to invite me in."

In light of the Queens' extended stay in Adinah, many of the Naga aristocracy had taken to inviting Olga over to cook for them. Sometimes in exchange for money, but often just as an extension of good favor. They were high-ranking women, after all, and Olga should have been honored to feast with them. However, as Olga's reputation continued to grow and swell with the Rainy Season, it was becoming very much the opposite. Nobles would sometimes fight each other over the honor of having the chef cook for them for the night. Sometimes literally. Or at least, by proxy.

"Can you believe the size of that one though?" Amoxtli burped, "I woulda thought she was the Queen herself a few years ago."

"Like you're one to talk." Olga snickered as she poked Amoxtli's big brown belly, "You're less a snake and more of a slug these days."

"I'll work it off...huff... come the Dry Season." Amoxtli sleepily dismissed Olga losing her finger knuckle-deep in her apron of brown belly with a half-hearted swat, "Not too much longer now before everything and everyone starts drying up—me included."

"Oh I think you'll survive." Olga said knowingly, "I wouldn't be surprised if you find it a little hard to pass up what I have cooking for everyone next season."

"Getting fat off of jerky and salted meats? Ha." Amoxtli snorted, her round cheeks rippling, "That'll be the day."

"You'll see." Olga teased, "You'll see."

111311221112211221211221222111121.content:
Olga had never seen anything like it—all of the sudden, the rain just stopped coming. It went from clockwork, six times a day, to three times, then once, and then just... never again.

And in just as much time, everyone went to complaining about having to get back to normal. Rationing, baking in the sun, and enduring the sweltering heat and sweat that plagued everyone's fattened figures. Going outside to run their shops, do their chores, and hunt for food was still just as necessary as it was when things were wet and fun, but now they had seemingly become unbearable.

For those who had to go outside and do such things.

While the heat was still the worst part about the Dry Season, for those with more insular positions in the palace, they were not put under nearly as harsh circumstances as the villagers down below. While everyone else sweated and toiled, keeping their homes and businesses afloat, those who were privileged enough to not have to do much of anything in the Queen's absence found themsleves living a much easier life. As they days crawled by, slowly becoming what were the first weeks of the Dry Season, they found themselves adjusting poorly to the heat.

"With how much we ate, how do we still have Rainy Season food?" Quetzalli whined, cradling her paunch as it lapped over onto her scaly crotch, "Ms. Olga must have been holding out on us."

"That's a scary thought." one of Quetzalli's sisters, of a similar size but slightly more round than her older and taller sister, said as she lounged in the sunlight on a dais, "Considering Chantico can't even slither around anymore."

"If Ms. Olga has been holding out on us, I we ought to demand that she relinquish whatever she's cooked!" Chantico growled from her position, dolloped on a dais further down into the long room as her puddling face grew bright red,"All she has done since the Dry Season is scrimp and save, and I am not pleased!"

Despite the brown-tailed blob's suppositions, Olga had done anything but "scrimp and save" the portions that she'd been feeding everyone on the Palace. If anything, she'd continued with the Rainy Season fervor now a full month into the Dry Season, with no signs of stopping. She hadn't addressed it, the word "rations" hadn't even left her mouth. Unlike Atzli, their old head chef, who would have been barking at them about slimming down halfway through the season...

Quetzalli was beginning to become concerned.

"It's lunch time your highnesses!" Olga's voice echoed through the stone room like a bell as a legion of significantly slimmer guards slithered into the princesses' royal chambers, bearing the load of what their Queen's heirs would wolf down today, "I've worked long and hard on today's menu—who here has had fried monkey before?"

Ever since she'd taken over the kitchen, Olga had been feeding the princesses more than they'd ever been fed before. Not that many of them minded it, given the connotation between royalty and rotundity in their culture. Their mother was enormous, and continuing to grow. According to her letters, that was the main reason she hadn't come home already—she'd grown so fat that getting her through the Adinahn gates proved to be a logistic and financial concern on the foreign kingdom. Maybe it was just, without their mother around to eat everything, there was more food to go around, but something about eating so well into the Dry Season rubbed Quetzalli the wrong way.

"Quetzalli, would you like to try some of my special fried Gigantopithicus?" Olga asked pleasantly in a sing-song voice, a large slab of the stuff being presented to the heir apparant of the marshes, "I know it's your favorite, and I think you'll really enjoy it cooked this way."

Then again, she was Coatlzintli's daughter. As her mouth started to water and her mind started to imagine the succulent taste of fried monkey meat, she wasn't exactly concerned with rationing or the lackthereof in her kingdom...

***


"Heard there was a good hunt yesterday." Amoxtli managed over thick juicy bites of her monkey, "Hear they got a Triceratops and a few of them buck-teethed cats."

"Heard?" Nochtli's eating was more posh, but equally appreciative. She hadn't eaten anything this good in what felt like weeks, "You didn't go with them?"

"Nah, gotta stay here." Amoxtli smacked her lips as juice rolled down her cheeks, "Protect ol' Blue Eyes and all that."

Amoxtli snorted as she ripped a hearty mouthful off of her slab, hammy arms trembling with the effort. Swollen to the size of Pok-ta-Pok balls with none of the firmness, Amoxtli's once impressive biceps, triceps and deltoids were buried deep under inches of brown blubber. Her four flabby grabbers hung at an angle at her sides, propped up by fluffy arm fat nestled beneath and around them. With two hands, she wrestled with dinner, and with the other two, she caressed the great gut she'd been nursing since the Rainy Season. Grown large enough to fill the distinct fold that divided it before, Amoxtli's great belly poured outwards into a singular expanse of fat.

"From what, all the food she cooks?" Nochtli laughed, "She barely leaves the palace."

"I don't like your tone, you noble twat." Amoxtli bit back, "My job is very important, thank you."

Nochtli tittered to herself in a pleased sort of way, having decadently enjoyed watching the soldier that had teased her so go soft. Not that she had any room to judge her; but the difference between them was status. Nochtli was supposed to be large. She was a member of the upper echelon of society here in the Marshes. She wasn't expected to go out onto the battlefield like the Soldier was. Her size was a badge of honor. Amoxtli was just lazy.

The blue-tailed naga had only grown increasingly honorable since the Dry Season, much to her susprise. She was bigger than she'd ever been before the Human came around and started feeding them. Doing her little Farming thing and taking half of the soldiers and servants to get their livestock up and running. Why in Yndyre that woman felt the need to keep beasts so close to the palace was anyone's guess, but she was far from a position to question how she got her job done. After all, Olga's job was to feed—Nochtli's was to eat.

"Will you please hand me a biscuit?" Nochtli purred, rap-tap-tapping on her avalanche of belly blubber. She couldn't taste them without an extreme amount of what Olga called butter, but she was definitely a fan. They helped sop up the juices well. "I'm a bit full.'

Her fullness was not the reason Nochtli wouldn't get the biscuit herself. She had grown far too fat to move easily. Even with the size and strength of her tail, Nochtli's lazy habits and incredibly appetite for Olga's rich, fattening foods had left her weak and limp. Buried underneath blubber like everyone else and thensome. Due to her larger size in stature, she could contain quite a lot of food. But her metabolism wasn't checked by exercise in the fields or chores around the palace. She was en route to being pinned down on a giant dais like the Queen before her, and she knew it.

That wouldn't dissuade her from having another biscuit.

Amoxtli grunted in response, tearing herself away from her own meal for a moment to palm two lumpy piles of cooked dough. One for Nochtli, and one for herself.

"Heading out to the bar tonight?" Nochtli chuckled behind one chubby ball-like hand as she caressed the acres of her own belly, pouring onto the dinnertable like high tide at the rivers, "I know that's where you usually go to work off a hard day at work."

"Nah. The barmaids are slimmin' down—got no use for a skinny limptail in my den." Amoxtli snarfed, completely missing Nochtli's tone with one cheek bulging full of biscuit, "I'll be staying in the Palace tonight."

"Well I'm happy to hear it!" Olga entered the conversation happily, "I'll make sure you have a table set at dinner tonight."

She came bearing extra helpings, setting down a platter of various meats meant to tantalize any Naga's tongue. Rainberries, plucked early from the vine so they were small and managable, rolled around on the plate as appetizers. Rubbing her hands together, Amoxtli smacked her lips appreciatively as she tucked into her latest morself. Her earlier helping set to the side, though, it would ultimately be eaten within the hour.

"You're a rightful wizard in the kitchen." Amoxtli salivated as she popped juicy rainberries into her mouth, letting their juiciness wash away the dryness of her mouth, "How you get these things to grow in the Dry Season I'll never know."

"Racovanian witchcraft." Olga winked, patting her friend on the shoulder. Her back meat wobbled at the impact. "Or at least, that's what I'm going with since no one here seems to believe me when I say it's farming."

"Whatever it is, I'm on board." Nochtli wriggled her chubby little fingers in a flirty noblewoman's wave until Olga slid her her own extra portion, "You Leggers are surprisingly capable."

"We keep the magic in our legs." Olga snorted, "Now eat up. Dinner isn't for another few hours and I'll be entirely too busy to deal with you two begging for snacks."
