111311221112211221211221222113.content:
As Olga grew better and better at adapting the recipes she was given, a certain heir to the throne grew in sheer mass alongside her. Quetzalli wasn’t exactly a waif when Olga first met her, but she was nothing like her mother… that had changed.

“Hiiiiii!” Quetzalli greeted in her high pitched voice, greeting her new friend as she worked in the kitchens.

“Hello Quetzalli, here to watch me work again?” Olga replied, turning around to greet the interloping serpent.

The princess’ expression shifted to downcast though. “Awwww! I was hoping to make you jump…” She admitted.

Olga chuckled; “Well I did hear you coming.”

“No way!” Quetzalli huffed. “I thought I was being so quiet…”

There was no way the royal heir was going anywhere stealthily in her current condition. As Olga sneakily fed Quetzalli more than her siblings (even gluttonous Chantico), Quetzalli had fattened up far more than her peers. Her gut hung low over her scaly lap, big boulder-like and free of any dominating fold. It was like a big pregnant belly, just with way more give and jiggle to it. Atop it were some truly colossal breasts, big sandbag-like things that swelled outwards and over the supporting frame of Quetzalli’s belly. Resting upon those breasts, were some ham-shaped arms, four brown appendages that wobbled when she so much as breathed. Quetzalli’s tail was filling out in due course as well; her widening scales scraped noisily across the stone floor wherever she went. The princess’ face hadn’t fattened up quite as much though; a second chin was all she had so far gained from Olga’s influence.

“Uhhhh…” Olga replied, taking in all of Quetzalli’s vastness. Her instincts told her not to call out the girls obesity, even though there was literally not a single skinny Naga in the city right now.

The green-scaled girl seemed to sense this unease written on Olga’s face though; “It’s ok. I know I am getting really fat,” Quetzalli stated flatly, hands patting the flanks of her big swollen stomach, “It’s expected of me. Someday I am going to need to nurture my own clutch of eggs, than I am going to get really big.”

Olga turned back to her cooking, the Naga’s words bringing to mind what her mother had said. How Coatlzintli was so against how big she was, and wanted to slim down to something, Olga thought at least, would be more reasonable. “Have you thought about it much?” The blonde farm-girl asked, still concentrating on her cooking.

“About what? Being queen?” Quetzalli replied.

“More like… thought about how big you will get.” Olga pried. This was a good opportunity to find out more about the Naga mindset on this matter. She couldn’t really ask Amoxtli, Nochtli or Atzli about it, as they were so devoted to their duty that they would only give the same answer, that the queen should be the size of a small mountain. And asking Coatlzintli about it had yielded a different answer than she had expected.

The overweight Naga paused, slithering around the pot and stove Olga was working at as one of her clawed fingers scratched at her double chin. “I haven’t really thought about it… I would need to be married for all that to happen.”

“Have you thought about that then?” Olga asked, before adding with a sly grin, “Anyone you have a crush on?”

This sent the obese snake into a fluster. “Nobody!” She squeaked, gesticulating with all of her arms.

“I was just pulling your leg… I mean tail.” Olga replied, before picking up a large nearby ladle and spooning a great dollop of the mixture she was cooking into it. “Here, have some stew.”

Quetzalli leaned in gratefully accepting the offer, before rising back to her full height. “I… I guess I have imagined what my future bride might be like… but I haven’t actually met anyone I would want to marry yet…”

It was somewhat comforting to Olga that despite all the differences between herself and the Naga, their views on love still seemed the same.

“What about you? Do you have a wife?”

Apart from that.

“I... don’t…” Olga replied, honestly but hesitantly.

“Oh! Perhaps you will find one here…” Quetzalli replied with a big grin, thinking she was helping.

Olga however tried to let her down gently. “I… don’t really like girls…” She answered.

“Don’t like… girls?” Quetzalli replied quizzically. It suddenly occurred to Olga that despite talking at length with the inquisitive Naga about human culture, this topic had not come up before. “Then… do you not want to mate?” She continued.

“I do… I just like men.”

Quetzalli still looked confused, “Men?” The Naga was so naive of the world; she hadn’t even seen the envoys that passed through the palace walls; so had never actually seen a man before. “What do you do with a men?”

Olga didn’t really feel like explaining something this… explicit with her employer’s daughter. “Let’s just say that you can marry them and leave the details alone today.” She finished, offering the Naga another spoonful of stew.

“Ok then.” Quetzalli replied, her mind seemingly completely off the topic as soon as food was presented to her. Leaning down again, she took another mouthful of the stuff, cooed happily and rose again.

“*Gulp* Well there are no men here, what do you plan to do?” It seemed Quetzalli wasn’t quite done with the topic after all.

“I… I don’t know…” Olga replied honestly. She had always dreamed of getting married someday, but at the same time, she had no idea how long she would be working in this city. It had been the opportunity of a lifetime, but clearly there were downsides. Unless somehow she started seeing women with four arms and a scaly tail as sexy one morning…

Quetzalli was twigging that the topic was making Olga uneasy. She had been a bit too nosey and pushed it too far. “So… I was told that my mothers are returning this week.” She added, changing the topic.

“Really?” Olga replied, her optimism at seeing Coatlzintli again was stronger than she initially thought.

“Yes! There was a letter that arrived this morning!” The blubbery girl explained with a big beaming grin. “But you better make sure you cook plenty before she gets hear, the letter said…”
111311221112211221211221222113.title: Like Mother like Daughter

choices: Olga's gain tapers out—she's big, but the snakes are bigger. WAY bigger.
Olga gets bigger—she WANTS to slow down, but she just CAN'T!
Olga gets huge—she falls in love with the indulgent Rainy Season lifestyle!
1113112211122112212112212222.content:
And so, Olga relented—over the course of the Rainy Season, she'd try to fatten up a little.

Animals did something similar in Racovania during the Winter. A lot of the native wildlife would bulk up for hibernation, storing fat to keep them warm while they slept in their burrows and nests. Olga had remembered asking the question plenty of times when she was a little girl, and had probably had the concept explained to her every year when she would ask why all of the squirrels were getting so cute and chubby.

When looking at the Rainy Season as the closest thing that the Marshes got to Winter (in the same way that "less snow" was the closest thing she'd ever gotten to a true "Summer") it wasn't that hard to understand why the chiseled warriors' bodies of the Naga women suddenly started to soften. This was their chance to put on weight that would sustain them during the Dry Season, when food wasn't as plentiful. Her father had told her once that the cute little squirrels and bunnies and bears who didn't get enough to eat during the rest of the year died in their sleep come Winter.

It had sounded horrible at the time, but she supposed that it was far more preferable to leaving an agonized, shriveled husk on the dry stone walkways of the city. Going out and hunting such dangerous game like the Tyrannosaurus and the Giganto...giganta... those big monkeys, the Naga would need all of the energy that they could spare.

She had only been in the Marshes for a little while during the Dry Season and it had already seemed like a barren hellscape outside of the civilization of the Palace.

Maybe there was some merit into what Nochtli and Amoxtli were saying—if there wasn't going to be a lot of game to hunt after the Rainy Season, then she might need a little extra padding to burn through during the Dry season...

***


From then on, Olga did her best to go with the flow and indulge in not only Naga customs, but Naga food, drink, and merriment.

These people, being warrior folk with a relatively high mortality rate, had celebrations for just about everything. Even with their queens in Adinah, they were happy to set the torches aflame and blast the horns in favor of a hunt's large bounty, every single time. There were nightly raucous feasts and parties with Naga roaring in the stone streets as the bars stayed open well into the morning. Amoxtli was happy to sherpa Olga into their culture but was rather surprised when the farm girl took so well to this particular part of life in the Kingdom.

The girl could pound back a pint of ale like she had been born with four arms, scales, and a tail; eagerly and expertly getting pink-faced and tipsy while the rest of the naga cheered her on. Drinking was in the blood after all—Racovanians had just as pervasive a survival-based celebratory culture as any Naga after generations of hiding from vampires up in the mountains.

Nightly outings to the bars and taverns became customary as Olga began to truly adjust to life in the Marshes, with Amoxtli happy to tag along and explain any of the strangeness that she might have found in what was to be their day to day life in the Rainy Season. Olga was slowly learning that much of what she considered to be odd or unappealing at first had very simple explanations; namely in that the Naga were just boisterous, hardy people who liked to celebrate as much as they liked to eat and drink.

And boy did they like to eat and drink.

Olga was already beginning to put on weight as early as a month into the Dry Season. Not just learning and acclimating to, but basking in the high-calorie, over-seasoned cuisine of the Naga people by day and indulging in hearty boozing with nightly binges had left her with a small tummy that persisted even on an empty stomach. Never quite flattening out, Olga's cute little belly was the subject of much cooing and crowing by the palace staff as it rounded out from underneath her tunic and bobbed with her dainty little steps.

"Awwww, look at the widdle belly~"

Olga winced as she felt Atzli's clawed hand poke gingerly into her exposed tum, the pale white flesh that lapped over her trousers marred with an angry pink mark. She ran her hands over her fleshy middle, turning away from the snake lady's strike zone; a learned habit from living in a place where everyone wanted to pinch her with calipers built into their fingertips. This culture's obsession with food and drink were fine, but its openness was going to be the death of her!

"Don't poke me so hard, Atzli!" Olga whimpered, "I don't go around pinching and poking your fat, do I?"

Atzli chuckled, her thick brown belly trembling with her laughter. Even as one of the more reserved Naga, sensible and very Western in her beliefs, she had thickened up nicely. Her stomach now folded over into her lap in two neat little folds of chocolate brown flesh. Her tail had widened and grown in time with her half-human hips, sliding lazily across the palace floor and kitchen tile where once it flicked and swished.

"You're such a soft little thing, aren't you Legger?" Atzli purred, "Well, you've got time—by the end of the Season, you'll probably have so much Rain Weight you won't even feel a little pinch~"

Olga whimpered and whined as Atzli continued to poke and prod the porky barmaid belly-first, unable to match the four-headed charge that Atzli launched against her creamy white belly. The poor little farm girl had been getting this everywhere she went lately; what was so special about her getting fat in a whole kingdom full of snake people with four arms who were also getting fat! And faster! The Naga metabolism meant that everyone in the kingdom was bigger around than her, but no one would stop picking on the poor little farm girl for her tummy!

"Stooooop!" Olga whined, "It's not funnyyyyyy!"

***


As time wears on, and the Rainy Season continues...
1113112211122112212112212222.title: When With Snakes, Do As Snakes Do

choices: Quetzalli goes to walk Olga to her chambers
Olga waddles to her room alone, and exhausted
11131122111221122121122122223.content:
In Racovania, Olga had never really been allowed to indulge herself.

Even during the most bountiful times of the year, the splendor that came with a successful season in her homeland wasn't particularly boastful. After the crops traveled down the mountain and into the lands below, the farmers would divvy up what they could afford to donate (lest it go bad) to the town's celebrations. People would give what they could afford to lose, which wasn't much—plenty a festival had been cut short because the beer had run dry and the food had run out. And almost every year since she was but a child, Olga had been working at the Bleakfrost Tavern. She had never been able to truly enjoy herself and celebrate the season and perhaps had been making up for lost time while in the Marshes.

"Another rack of ribs for ya then, Blue Eyes?"

Olga let out a monstrous belch as she slumped back into the stone seating of their booth at the tavern, a stupid satisfied smile on her ruddy pink face. She panted breathlessly, overseasoned sauce speckling the corners of her mouth as she looked with lilted eyes over to Amoxtli.

"You just wanna see me pop out of another pair of trousers again, don't you?" she purred drunkenly, "I'm onto—RRRURP—nto you, youuuuuu snake!"

Amoxtli chuckled huskily as she leaned back into the table, her brown belly smothering the edge as she leaned in hard to place one hand on Olga's distended gut. Gurgling and squelching with Gods-knew how many courses past, Olga's gut sent another burp up the pipe at the sensation of Amoxtli's touch.

"What can I say, Blue Eyes—the longer the Rainy Season runs, the more I start to like you!"

Amoxtli palmed Olga's supple white gut and squeezed it for good measure, gaze fixed tightly on the pudgy dome that rose high to touch the lip of the carved stone table. Her chubby little fingers spread over the surface of her stomach, pressing slightly into the fleshy mass of fat that was her tummy. Olga, emboldened by far too much alcohol, gave her a saucy little wink and blew her a kiss. The more the season had gone on and the bigger Olga had gotten, Amoxtli had taken to being very open about how she appreciated the changes that had undergone in the once little barmaid. Olga had more or less gotten used to it—the daily pinchings, pokings, squeezes and gropes... not to mention all of the free food that Amoxtli would treat her to at the bars.

"You're such a tease, y'filthy Legger." Amoxtli rolled her eyes, a smile on her face as she slithered towards the bar, "Flirtin' with me for more food in your belly."

"I like boyyyyyyyys, Moxxy." Olga tittered, resting her hands on her jiggling jelly belly, "And ribs. Lots and lots of ribs."

***


Coming into work, still full and hungover from the night before was apparently a Rainy Season tradition among the Naga; one that Olga could claim to have adopted in recent weeks.

Guided, vaguely, by the notion that she was supposed to be putting on weight for the Rainy Season, it made it easier for Olga to ignore her rather rapid weight gain and the toll that it was taking on her ability to actually get around the palace. The tunics that she wore always bore her midriff, and the trousers were supposed to be baggy. The humidity of the season left everyone with some shortness of breath after a while, and everyone would sweat—the corpulent cook waddled in bigger and rounder than ever, and she only had a foggy notion that perhaps she should cut back.

Of course, it was hard for her to keep a sense of scale with everyone around her plumping up so quickly, and with such proficiency. Amoxtli had put on another sixty pounds in just two months, and she had been Olga's closest companion in the Marshes. Atzli, Chantico, all of the guards and Coatlizintli's royal clutch, everyone was putting on weight, so why should she be concerned?

But walking on her two chubby little legs, bouncing and bobbing with every waddling step, was a uniquely human thing in the palace. As Olga ripened and swelled like a rainberry, growing ever larger by the day as she gorged herself on Naga meals that were designed to put on weight as fast as possible, she just jiggled and wobbled more while moving less—one could often hear her huffing and puffing as she trudged through the muggy stone hallways of the palace keep.

One being the royal clutch, as they continued to watch in amazement of this scaleless, tailless thing that continued to astound them with her every belabored step.

"She's so cute~!" a particularly small naga by the name of Nenetl squeaked, "Look at her little beans! They're all round and chubby like the rest of her!"

"I think they're called feet Nen."

"Beeeeans~" the little garden snake gushed, "She almost even looks like a bean, don't you think Quetzalli? With her cute little tummy sticking out like that? Don't you think?"

Nenetl's tail slithered approvingly against the stone floor as she hid with her sisters. A small group of royal children had taken to watching their chef's expansion intently. Most of them thought that Olga adorable; her tiny size, her little walkie-sticks, and her only two little arms. She had blonde hair and ivory white skin, which gave her this exotic look to these sheltered little snakes, they were fascinated by her—even moreso now that she was getting so round.

"I didn't even know that humans could get fat." another sister chimed in, "I mean, what with the legs and all."

"Yeah, they burn a lot of energy walking around all day." yet another said, "She must be eating a lot."

"She looks tired." Quetzalli frowned

"She's all tuckered out~!" Nenetl squealed, "So cute!"

The oldest and largest of the three (comically hidden behind a large pillar, and just barely at that) Quetzalli couldn't quite explain why she was so interested in watching Miss Olga. Sure, she thought that she was cute. Who didn't? But there was something more, something... else that she couldn't quite explain. A fascination with the human who had come into their lives so suddenly. There was an interest in human culture for sure, but now that attention had shifted onto Miss Olga herself...
11131122111221122121122122223.title: An Awful Lot of Olga

choices: As the Dry Season rolls around, Olga can't manage to slim down!
Before the Dry Season comes, the Queens return—one last feast!
111311221112211221211221222231.content:
"Thanks for the... lift..."

Quetzalli grunted as she set the palace chef down on her fat little feet, feeling her soft skin and supple flesh settle back in its rightful place as it bulged between her fingers. Being hefted around was just something that Olga had gotten used to as she continued to live in the palace—the larger Naga like Quetzalli could pick her up without any issues, even as her weight had continued to climb. The act had still left her breathless though, toddling on her feet back in her bedroom. Quetzalli's grip was still evident in the pink angry marks that had flared up while she struggled to heave Olga down the halls.

"No problem, Miss Olga!" Quetzalli chirped excitedly, "You looked like you were having some trouble."

"So you've said." Olga frowned, running her hands over the circumference of her stomach, "Several times."

"Oh!" Quetzalli smiled sheepishly, "I'm sorry, I didn't... mean to offend you or anything, I just—"

"No, no, it's my fault..." Olga sighed deeply, her stomach sagging lower, almost as if it shared her dejection, "I think that it might be time for me to start cutting back..."

Olga drummed her chubby little fingers along the surface of her stomach as it drooped low and heavy over her trousers. Her breasts splayed to either side of her doming gut, their heaviness and soft curves visible beneath the triangle cut of her tunic. Her double chin creased into a tight little frown as she looked upon her body in concern, marvelling at what only a few months on a Rainy Season diet could do to her poor little farm girl's figure.

"C-Cutting back?" Quetzalli gulped, minding the lower ceiling as she stood hunched in Olga's chambers, "B-But Miss Olga, the Rainy Season isn't over yet!"

Somehow the suggestion that the corpulent little cook start to skip meals personally affected the Queen's eldest daughter, as if she had some sort of stake in Olga's Rainy Season figure. But... of course she did! If her chef was in low spirits, or worse, grew ill when the Dry Season came again, the food that she prepared might not be as good. Yes, that was it—Quetzalli was the prima of her clutchmates after all! She had to start thinking of these... queenly matters!

And of course, Olga would look so sad and skinny again, like a raisin in the sun. The thought of her cute little belly going away made Quetzalli... not quite sad, but somehow disappointed seemed like the more appropriate word.

"I know, but..."

Olga hefted up her belly with both hands, letting it slap against her thighs. The pale ivory chub, only lightly browned since moving, glistened with the humidity that had accumulated over the course of the day. Her stomach was a wobbling, smooth thing that folded neatly into two meaty rolls that quivered and jiggled and shook with her every step...

Quetzalli gulped.

"Look at me—" Olga said with a slap of her stomach, "I'm huge!"

Quetzalli made a small mewling noise as she watched Olga examine herself in the mirror of her chambers. Running her hands up and down the tank-like middle that had sprung up over the course of the Rainy Season. Smooth and soft to the touch, yielding to her chubby little fingers.... even her fingers were fat! She was so domesticated and curvy, her body was a thing of beauty! And the more of Olga that there was, the more that Quetzalli found that she couldn't stop thinking, wishing that there were more...

"Miss Olga, I don't think that you should take risks with your health!" Quetzalli piped up suddenly and rather loudly, "What if you aren't fit to serve us when the Dry Season comes? Or when Mother and Patli return?"

Olga made a face, scrunching her lips to the side in thought.

"I guess you're right..." she relented, rolling her tunic back down over what it covered of her drooping gut, "...Besides, the Dry Season is gonna start soon, right? That's when everyone loses weight and goes back to normal?"

"Uh... yes! In a few more weeks, the rain should stop." Quetzalli felt her heart sink at the realization, "B-But, um... you know..."

"Great—" Olga laughed, patting her belly with both hands, "Because any longer and you guys are gonna have to roll me into the kitchens every morning!"

As Olga laughed, her great gut trembled in amusement. Resting her hands on either side of her stomach had become a staple of hers as it had only gotten larger and doughier, a more reliable place to set her hands when they weren't busy cooking. Or drinking. Or eating. Quetzalli wasn't alone in thinking that it was the cutest thing for their little Legger chef to do. She had seen her once or twice, basking on a slab so much like the snakes that she serviced with her belly pouring between her legs. Such strange parts of her anatomy, spreading wider and wider into two little bony tails that looked less and less bony by the day.

Quetzalli was... invested in watching Miss Olga's continued growth, continually and perpetually perplexed in the growing human's anatomy.

It wasn't... so strange that she was fascinated by this human's fattening figure... right?
111311221112211221211221222231.title: Fat Little Legger

choices: Enroll—After the Festival, she's off to the Plains to make something of herself!
Stay—Olga redoubles her efforts to be the best barmaid and chef she can be!
11131122112.content:
"I was talking to Somaria just a little while ago, and she mentioned that there's a chef's school in the Plains." Helga purred, stroking her jutting belly in that habitual way that she did, "After the festival, why don't you enroll?"

Olga had never thought about a career in the culinary arts. She hadn't really considered what she was doing in the Tavern after hours working "towards" anything, especially not becoming an honest-to-the-Gods chef. That was what Somaria did; why would Olga need to step on her toes? So it was no surprise that Olga knew nothing about a school for aspiring chefs was out there somewhere in Yndyre. A place where folks who wanted to cook better went to learn how to cook better—studying in one subject and that's all? How odd!

"The Plains?" Olga repeated, "Like... the plains below the mountains?"

Helga laughed her bellowing laugh, her swaddling chins rippling and her huge belly quivering beneath her tight dress. She threw her head back and howled at Olga's seeming ignorance.

"No, child! The Plains of Grobland." Helga held her belly, still recoiling from her bout of laughter, "I'd imagine if there were a school for chefs that close to us, I wouldn't have had to look so hard to find a chef of Somaria's caliber!"

"So... this is the school that Ms. Somaria went to?" Olga asked, confused. That was an awful long way away...

No, scratch that. She was terrified—Olga had never been that far from home before!

"Aye, you sheltered little waif." Helga was still chuckling, "Somaria studied there when she was about your age and had about half your talent. She mentioned that the new semester was starting soon, and that you'd be best to take a shot at enrolling."

Olga was silent as Helga explained everything to her. Her blonde brow furrowed as she opened the pantry door and slid the tray of sweetrolls inside, gently shutting it behind her. Had she done something? Could Helga just be trying to get rid of her? How could the only family she had now try and turn her out into the snow, away from everything she'd ever known? Surely that wasn't what this was... was it?

But then again; getting out of Racovania. Away from vampires. Away from the memory of her sister, looming over her like the fog and clouds that hung so drearily overhead. There was an element of enticement to it all.

"So... what would you and Ms. Somaria do, then?" Olga asked, equal parts nervous, excited and somber, "If I were to... you know... go there? And stop helping out at the Tavern?"

"Oh blue eyes, I think we would manage." Helga laughed again, "Without all your delicious food around, I might manage to lose one of my extra chins, and Somaria could get off her lazy arse and stop shunting all the prep work on you for a change."

Helga was laughing, but it didn't make Olga feel any better. And it must have been plainly obvious, because even a woman as thick-headed as Helga managed to see the conflict behind her eyes.

"It's just a thought, love. Not a suggestion." Helga recounted, a bit more softly, "Somaria and I love having you around. And not just because you spoil me so, either. You're a delightful girl, Olga. It's just... there aren't a lot of callings for people with your talent in Racovania. If you ever wanted to get out and make something of yourself other than a barmaid, this might be the way to do it."

Olga leaned against the wall, still silent. Tears welled up in her big blue eyes.

"It's just a thought." Helga said again, stepping forward and wrapping her ward in a big fleshy hug, "Don't even bother yourself thinking about it until after the festival. I need you at your best tomorrow, so you best hurry on to bed."

***


Despite her best efforts, Olga couldn't sleep a wink that night.

All she could think about was leaving. Or, rather, whether or not she should leave. And whether or not she wanted to leave. And whether or not Helga wanted her to leave. Had she done something wrong? Had she messed up one too many times? Why did she feel like she was being politely ushered out the door? Was she that much of a burden on Helga and Somaria?

Hot tears streamed down her face. She wasn't well to deal with this. The town festival was coming up in just a few short hours, and she hadn't slept at all.

Her heart weighed so heavily—did she want to go? But why would she want to leave the only home she'd ever known? Racovania was the only place she'd ever lived, and this Tavern had been like a second home to her ever since she'd lost her sister...

What was a poor barmaid to do?
11131122112.title: You Could Make Something of Yourself, Olga!

choices: the Minotaurs. They come to our halls with more than just healthy appetites.
the Satyrs. Their revels can get pretty wild around here.
the Werewolves. Best, you don't stay out late at night.
111311221121.content:
Ultimately, Olga wasn't thrilled to go. In fact, she hated the idea altogether. But, there were some benefits to going off on this adventure that she couldn't deny.

Somaria was a big influence in that decision. All throughout the festival, when she wasn't running the kitchen like the king's generals, she spoke fondly of her time at the school, mentioning all the friends she had made. She was also quite adamant that the strong farmer's sons that worked the fields there weren't too bad on the eyes either. But more importantly, Somaria described the friends she had made as family. It had been a long time since Olga had anyone to call family. With her father gone, and her sister...she still wasn't ready to think about that, only Somaria and Helga had come anywhere close to being a place she could call "home." Maybe this was just what she needed.

There was also the fact that she did indeed love to cook. She loved how happy it made people. She loved seeing their smiles when they took that first bite of a new dish. It was a look that one only got when they were warm by the fire in their own cozy home. Perhaps she would be happy continuing to share that joy outside her home.

But, most importantly, it was the fact that danger lurked around every corner that finally put the nail in the coffin for Olga. The big festival in Racovania brought in many guests, and Somaria and Olga had their work cut out for them trying to keep up with all the incoming customers. But large gatherings of people brought other uninvited guests. Krusva Stranken made sure to make an appearance after the third night of the festival. While not actually related to her by blood, Krusva was recognized as Eviana's "son," hand-selected and directly turned by the mother of vampires herself. And he lived up to his title as "mama's boy," always fetching his mother's collections to please her, hence why only a handful of Racovanians could say they had seen Eviana in person.

He was a tall, lanky, and incredibly handsome. They always were, the vampires, and Olga often wondered if Eviana selected her brood based on looks alone. Krusva always stuck out in her mind because of the way he selected the maids. It was that look in his eye, like he was already tasting you that sent shivers up her spine ever since she was a girl, too young to have been chosen. When he spotted one he was fond of, he would lean in, close his eyes, and smell her, nearly bringing the poor girl to fainting. He really was a connoisseur, probably a trait he picked up from his "mother."

In the end, he had whisked away some poor, plump, round-faced girl, who wasn't even a Racovanian native. She was just someone who had wandered in for the festival, only to have it end for her so abruptly. That did it for Olga. She couldn't take anymore of this savagery, and told Helga she would go to the school once the festival was over.

That was nearly three days ago...

Though Helga was happy for her, and did want her to go to this school in the first place, she was awfully sad to see her go. "You...you write to us everyday, you hear, blue eyes?" she said, getting misty-eyed.

She buried the barmaid in a gargantuan hug. Hm, she had gotten even softer since the festival, Olga thought. "I promise," she said, coming up for air.

Somaria clapped her on the shoulder. "Just take care of yourself, have fun, and don't worry about us. We somehow managed before you came along."

By now, Olga could feel the cart finally slowing down. "We're nearly there," the man said, flicking his reigns to turn the horse slightly to the right.

All around her there were fields upon fields upon fields. She had always heard that the plains were the breadbasket of the central kingdom, but she had never imagined it so vast. Men, women, children...and a few creatures she didn't recognize were all tending the fields. She recognized satyrs. As a child, she had seen several small bands of these creatures wander as far north as Racovania, escaping elven armies. She had never seen elves before, only heard the stories the satyrs told. Elves very rarely left the verge, she knew, and they didn't seem all that nice, but the satyrs were fine, a bit rowdy, but fine. Though, these days, if rumors were true, the wars between the two had finally come to an end. Now, it seemed that satyrs were finding new places to call home.

But there was some other creature here that she had never seen before. They were kind of like satyrs, but they were bigger, way, way bigger, she thought. Their horns were huge, and not nearly as pretty looking. Their faces were different too, almost like a cow's. This was definitely going to be an adventure, she told herself.

The cart driver deposited her in front of a stone building, almost the size of one of the churches to the various gods, Olga realized. It might have been that before it became a school. Upon opening the door, she was hit with all manner of heavenly smells. Spices and herbs, some of which she didn't know, and it smelled like everything she expected out of a place like this.

She couldn't see where all the smells were coming from since she only stood in the main hall, but she had a feeling it was upstairs, and made her way towards those. A hand tapped her shoulder, stopping her. "You must be the new girl," a voice said.

As Olga spun on her heels, she saw who she assumed to be the headmaster. She was an older woman, perhaps only a few years older than Helga, with a cheery smile complimented by rosy red cheeks, matched only with her lustrous red hair, kept neatly in a bun. She was tall, and slightly imposing, but her overall demeanor put Olga at ease. "Yes," she said, bowing slightly. "Olga Forgedotter."

The woman nodded. "Yes, I was told that you had been training a bit under Ms. Somaria, one of our favored daughters here. I expect you'll find yourself right at home here, and we can expect great things from you. I'm Ms. Wadham, headmistress, and chief instructor here. Allow me to show you to the dormitories."

She moved briskly, beckoning Olga to follow her. "This place is magnificent," Olga said, still in awe at the impressive architecture. "Was this once a church?"

Ms. Wadham nodded. "Indeed, this was once a monastery to Araris. In fact, the great library where the monks copied many Yndyrian epics is still in the west wing. You are more than welcome to visit it when you are not in classes. Now, you'll notice that the arches..."

As she droned on about the history of the monastery, Olga was still trying to process just where she was. She really was here, a place far, far away from Racovania and all its horrors, but also all her friends.

"Now, I'll let you settle in, and we'll see you in the kitchens in the east wing first thing in the morning. Be sure to ask one of the other girls where that is. They'll be happy to help. Is there anything else you need?"

Olga shook her head. "No, I just...I can't get over how wonderful this place is. Racovania was always so...dangerous. Thank you for accepting me here."

Ms. Wadham smiled tightly. "I'm glad you like it, though I will say the plains aren't without their own troubles. You'll have to be careful for...
111311221121.title: School's in Session

choices: Lunch was still being served—and Olga was awfully hungry from the ride over...
Why not get to know the students?—No harm in being friendly...
Better start strong—Olga unpacks, heads to bed, & wakes up for her first lesson
1113112211211.content:
"I'm glad you like it, though I will say the plains aren't without their own troubles. You'll have to be careful for those Minotaurs.” Mrs. Wadham smiled tightly, “They come to our halls with more than just healthy appetites.”

Having been raised in the sheltering snow of Racovania, at the hip of her mother and father, Olga had never been officially schooled in many matters. This included the non-human inhabitants of Yndyre. The strange creatures that loomed overhead Racovania in the Overvektige Peaks, harpies her father had called them, were as non-human as Olga had ever experienced. The Orc that lived outside their village back home, and even those wretched vampires were at least human in shape—if not oddly colored. The most experience she had with satyrs was through her father’s smithing business, and seeing those odd half-animals in the plains… Olga didn’t have any doubt that they could cause some damage.

“I’ll be sure to watch out for them.” Olga noted politely, “Erm… which ones were they?”

“All in due time, girl.” Ms. Wadham touched Olga’s back and guided her deeper into the stone building, “I assure you there is much more to concern you in here than there is out there.”

And so began Olga’s grand tour of her newest home.

“This school is formally known as the College of Grobland, the foremost learning center for all those looking to further their knowledge of culinary preparation and execution.” Ms. Wadham began as she lead Olga deeper into the old building, “The legend goes that our forebearers were taught by Jynera herself, when the world was young.”

“Jynera?” Olga made a face, struggling to keep up with the surprisingly swift woman

“That’s a rather complicated story in and of itself.” Ms. Wadham said stoically as she rushed through the stone hallways, “Whether or not you choose to believe in some… pagan God is of no concern to me—it just helps provide the framework for our first lesson.”

From inside the halls of the College, Olga could see out into the plains. Through the high windows, the fluffy white clouds gave way to the bright sun. Such a foreign sight—even in the daytime, Racovania was at least partially illuminated by candlelight.

Olga picked up her pace when she’d seen that she’d fallen behind.

“This is our dining hall, where meals are provided for breakfast, lunch and dinner.” Ms. Wadham waved a hand into the bustling hall, “While most of what we provide goes to the Capital, we provide what we can to our eager minds. After all, how could one expect to learn on an empty stomach?”

There wasn’t an inordinate amount of students at the tables, Olga supposed. Twenty, maybe thirty characters. Still more than any school in Racovania could ever claim. The majority of them were young women, all of various age. Olga supposed that it was smart in this day and age for a woman to learn a trade to make her valuable… after all, that’s why she was here…

Of course, they weren’t all human, were they? That was definitely a tail, peeking out from underneath the Academy’s tunic…

“Thanks to the resurgence in Jynera’s popularity, we’ve had something of an influx of students recently.” Ms. Wadham said with a slight distaste to her tone, “I’m afraid that had you come even a fortnight later, we would have had to turn you away.”

Olga’s head turned from side to side as she absorbed the collegiate setting of her new home. She sure was a far cry away from Racovania, wasn’t she? The architecture was different. It was warm. The air even smelled strange. Even as she got further into the building, that was the one thing she couldn’t seem to shake.

“These are our culinary labs.” Ms. Wadham said proudly, “Yndyre’s finest chefs have all rolled up their sleeves and bumped elbows with one another in these very rooms—soon, I’m sure we’ll be able to say the same of you.”

Five or so stragglers fiddled with various recipes and tools. One was kneading dough, another mixing stew. In the center of the room there was a great fireplace, with many copper pots and cooking animals roasting over an open fire.

“We have four of them, and you may use them at any time you’d like.” Ms. Wadham said, “So long as you have permission from myself or one of your instructors.”

Before Olga knew it, she was being rushed along yet again! Mrs. Wadham sure was a quick woman…

“And these—“ she waved her hand down an odd hallway, “—are the dormitories. One of which will be yours for the remainder of your time here.”

The older woman paused, looked to the doorway on her immediate right, and turned back to Olga.

“This one seems nice.” She sniffed, “Now then, are there any questions?”

“Um…” Olga blinked. She had a lot of questions. “When do… classes start?”

“Tomorrow morning, after breakfast.” Ms. Wadham said with an officious smile, “Now be sure to get your rest. You’ve got a big day ahead of you.”

And with that, the older woman turned on her heels and left, leaving Olga to her own devices...
1113112211211.title: the Grand Tour

choices: Classes are much easier than Olga expected.
Classes are about what Olga expected.
Classes are much harder than Olga expected.
11131122112112.content:
Olga was eager to start unpacking. It had been a long time traveling, and just getting a little time to get off her feet and just sit would feel like heaven right now.

She sat down and started laying her things out on the bed to sort out later when she heard boisterous laughter coming up the stairs. It took Olga longer than she would've liked to admit to realize that these must be her new roommates. There were obviously other beds in the dormitory. It had been so long since she had actually lived with anyone, though. True, her sister had been one thing, but they were sisters. They had been used to it. Complete strangers on the other hand...

"Should've seen it," one of the voices bellowed. "Once the pot boiled over, you never saw her dance so much."

The door opened and Olga was greeted with the site of three people she had never seen before. The first was an ordinary woman, not all that much older than herself. She was a chubby, but quite attractive girl. Her brown, curly hair seemed to bounce on her shoulders with every step. She flashed a charming smile, and her green eyes shone warmly. "Oh, you have to be the new student, right?" she said, eagerly going to shake Olga's hand. "I heard you're all the way from up north, in the country. That's just fascinating. You'll have to tell me all about it when I can take you into town to start looking for proper clothes."

Olga looked down at her own dress, which was a plain brown, not like the vibrant colors the girl wore. "Rhoslyn, be nice. She's just fine the way she is," another voice said, nudging the talkative city girl.

The second woman was actually a satyr, though she sure didn't look like the ones Olga was used to seeing in the north. Satyrs were usually lithe and nimble looking creatures, but this one was practically a boulder of a woman. She was incredibly round, near spherical really, but maybe that was because she was just a tad short. Olga didn't think they could get that big, and she wondered how the poor thing could totter on her hooves at that size. She was an adorable ball of fuzzy black fur, and short, thick, rounded horns. In short, while not being the most typical-looking satyr, she was at least the most friendly looking Olga had scene.

"Don't mind her," the satyr woman continued. "We just thank the gods you're here. It's always nice to get a new face. I'm Agapo."

"Olga," she said nodding. "So, you're my new classmates."

"Something like that," Agapo said. "We'll be in a few more advanced classes than you when you start out, but we'll see each other in due time. After all, each of us is gifted, and we should appreciate each other's different gifts."

"Okay, quit all the free love junk," the final member of the three said.

Olga wasn't sure what she was looking at exactly. True, she had seen these creatures in the fields earlier, but she didn't get a chance to see one up close. They were similar to satyrs in that they had hooves and horns, but they were far taller, stockier, and had the heads of cows. This one in particular was quite husky, but had all the curves to indicate she was female. Her hair and fur was a deep roan color with little flecks of black. She stood in the back corner, leaning against the wall, her massive horns nearly scraping the ceiling.

"Well, I respect your strong feelings, Mageiras. You are a bold and honest person," Agapo said, clearly not looking offended at the comment.

"So, you're the new meat?" Mageiras said, looking Olga over. "Not bad. Nothing special, but not bad."

Olga nervously shook her hand. "Um, nice to meet you too." She wasn't so sure she liked her. She wasn't necessarily mean, but just so intimidating, it was all Olga could do not to shrink back into a corner.

"Well, we'll have to see what you got come tomorrow. I'm one of the best in the class, and I could sure use some better competition these days." She gave a hearty laugh as she said this, which put Olga somewhat at ease. True, she was bold, loud, and a bit of a boaster, but she seemed okay.

"Did you want us to help you unpack?" Agapo said.

Olga nodded. "That would be helpful, thank you."

So, for the next hour or so, the other women helped Olga get settled in, chitchatting all the while. Rhoslyn would comment on how adorable or quaint Olga's items were, not realizing that she was being a tad obnoxious. She didn't seem to mind. Must be a city thing, she reasoned. Mageiras was good for a few funny stories about all the mishaps that were known to happen in the kitchens. While Olga giggled at the thought, she secretly hoped that none of that would happen to her during her first few days. She would've been mortified. Agapo was the most helpful of the three, telling Olga where rooms were, what kinds of things to expect in class, and other such useful tidbits. She just hoped she could remember it all.

That night, she was far too excited to sleep, that and Mageiras' snoring made that difficult. She couldn't wait for classes to start, though at the same time, she was very nervous.
11131122112112.title: Friends and Rivals

choices: In her quest to prove her worth, Olga winds up making her boss REALLY fat.
Free Choice
111311221122.content:
It wasn’t that Olga didn’t see herself as talented. In the short time that she’d taken up the culinary arts as her hobby, it’d been made quite known to her that she was a quick and natural study for the craft. She had a keen pallet and knew which herbs went best with which meat. She knew how long to steep the stews and how pink was too pink for those tricky exotic meats. What’s more, she’d been learning how to bake all by herself now. Ms. Somaria had been teaching her the finer aspects of the craft for only a little while now, and there’d been plenty of progress made.

But it wasn’t her progress in the kitchen that had made her feel so at ease. In light of losing her sister just a bit more than a year ago and her father not long before that, the constant companionship of Ms. Helga and Ms. Somaria had helped her enormously. She’d come to view them as extensions of her family—the closest thing that she had anymore after Tora had…

Blinking the tears out of her big blue eyes, Olga rolled over in her bed and gripped her pillow tightly. She didn’t want to go. She couldn’t go. Helga might have thought that she was helping by suggesting that she go off, but what did that old woman know anyway? How could she possibly know what living here in Bleakfrost Tavern had meant to her?

Sucking up saliva and the run from her nose, Olga made her decision:

If she wanted to keep her new family intact, she would have to show Helga and Ms. Somaria just how valuable she was!

***


Racovania’s annual festival was founded in celebration of a bountiful harvest. Given their relative isolation and the harshness of the land, Racovanian citizens had to find just about any reason to celebrate that they could think of. It was always as grand a time as any—the townsfolk made plenty of food and hosted a sort of potluck between them, the prettiest girls put on their finest dresses to impress the stout farmer boys who slicked their fair heads of hair back, and wandering minstrels made pilgrimages up this way every year for the signature Mountain Mead that was home brewed by the Ridgeclimber kin. The whole town seemed to come alive for one night—and that meant that the Bleakfrost Tavern was bustling now more than ever.

“Greta, get these dumplings to table four.”

“Brigitte, a leg of lamb and a hen breast for the fellas at two.”

“Anna, I need you to take all this mead and get it into those bellies.”

The sight of Olga Forgedotter behind the counter and not toiling away in the kitchen was a strange one, at least for the regulars at the Tavern. The curvy kitchen wench was usually just that—Somaria’s student to do the hard work while Helga slung the orders around. But tonight she seemed to have stepped up her game. She’d been going back and forth from kitchen to counter, taking orders and dishing them out. All while a certain tavernkeeper made merry and drank her weight in adult beverage…

“Unbelievable.” Somaria rolled her dark eyes as she eyeballed all of her business partner, “Our biggest day of the year and she goes and gets drunk.”

“I don’t mind.” Olga smiled as she wiped down the counter, “I mean… don’t you think she’s happier? Yesterday she was so stressed—but look at her now! Happy as a—”

“Pig in slop. And twice as greedy.” Somaria couldn’t help but crack a smile at her own joke, “Aye Helga, move your fat arse off of that poor bench before you break it!”

“T’Damus with ya ye… big nosed somethin’ or other!” Helga sloshed stupidly in her seat, meaty arms wobbling with her wild drunken movements, “Take it up with the bottom o’this keg—I’ll help ye get to ‘er!”

The busty mature threw her head back, long brown hair flowing like a chocolate river down her rolling hillside of backfat, as she killed whatever remained in her goblet. The crowd cheered as Helga let loose a roaring belch.

“Aye, gimme summathat!” she toddled uneasily as she snatched a leg of lamb off of Brigitte’s serving platter, “Looks good—damn good!”

Her round cheeks parted as her teeth sunk greedily into the meaty limb. Juices poured down her face, catching in her swaddled chin.

“You’ve outdone yerself withisone blue eyes!” Helga held up the leg triumphantly, “A whole lot of ‘em fer everyone—on the house!”

The whole bar cheered as Somaria’s jaw fell slack.

“Helga you fat wad, you can’t be serious?”

“I am I am I am!” Helga burped, “Go an’ be a good little cook and cook us all up some of that yummy lamb!”

Olga watched as Somaria grumbled defeatedly, trudging off into the kitchen to fetch what was surely a humongous order. No doubt that would keep her busy for a while. She would have to make sure to put Greta at the counter so that she could help her culinary teacher and fellow tavernmate out. But first…

“Pst!” Olga whispered, “Ms. Helga!”

Reaching underneath the counter, Olga pulled out an entire platter of sweet rolls, cooked in secret for just such an occasion. She knew that they were her boss’ favorites—what was a little positive reinforcement going to hurt?

“Yer kiddin’ me—blue eyes y’might just be a saint afferall!”

Helga’s meaty arms pumped roll after roll into her waiting maw, plucking them up like sugar-coated berries from a bush outside. Her appetite for food fueled by her appetite for booze, Helga could eat on and on; especially when it was Olga’s sweet rolls in the mix.

“Y’sure y’don’t mind me lazin’ around like this?” Helga puffed, her stomach full and round enough to make her lean uneasily in her seat, “I feel a little bad, sittin’ on my arse while you an’ the girls do all the hard work…”

“No Ms. Helga, of course not! It’s a festival!” Olga smiled pleasantly as she handed the tray off to her overfed boss, “Like I said this morning, you deserve it—you work far too hard for your own good!”

“That much is true.” Helga said with an appreciative slosh of her stomach with one hand as she stuffed another sweet roll past her inflated cheeks, “Aye, what would I do without you blue eyes?”

Olga smiled a little wider.

“Here, I think I saw a few more crab cakes stashed away at the counter.” Olga touched Helga’s shoulder appreciatively, “I’ll go grab them for you and then go help Ms. Somaria in the kitchen.”

Helga washed down her mouthful of meat, dough and glaze with a hearty swig of beer.

“Good!” Helga called after her, “If Somaria goes and passes out back there, I might have to actually start doin’ something around here!”
111311221122.title: Appreciating Olga

choices: Stories of Olga's incredible cooking had reached far and across Yndyre...
Stories of Helga's vast girth had reached far and across Yndyre...
1113112211221.content:
There are many legends in the land of Yndyre—many of which have some basis in reality.

And though the harsh snowy mountains were home to legends of things such as harpies and vampires, soon they became subject of another rumor that made its way down to the valleys below. One no stranger than the tall tales of some mystical beasts or of the strange inhabitants of certain parts of the land.

The tale of the fattest Taverner in Yndyre was somewhat far-fetched in a land such as this one. Supposedly so wide that she could naught enter anything short of a barn, and so heavy that her footsteps quaked the ground below her. Ne’er before had something so relatively plain tickled the tongues of those who gossiped about the sleepy town of Racovania, but as weeks past first-hand accounts of Helga the Hungry inched their way further down the mountainside and towards the plains…

By all means, the stories weren’t incorrect. Perhaps they had embellished a bit, as storytellers do to their party around a campfire, but the owner of the Bleakfrost Tavern had undergone an incredible transformation in a comparatively short amount of time. Almost no one could remember the Helga that had been—the sturdy but feminine bar wench who would flirt with every handsome out-of-towner. The stern but soft matriarch of the small mountain village. She filled a certain niche within the quiet community that she lived in with her barkeep’s wisdom and a keen listening ear for rumors. That wasn’t to say that she didn’t fill just as many spaces now—in fact, she filled a lot more spaces than she used to, pardon the pun…

“This is getting ridiculous, Helga.” Ms. Somaria put her hands on her hips distastefully, “We shouldn’t have to bribe you into coming to work.”

Helga lumbered into the quiet tavern like a tree falling in the morning. She was huffing and gasping for breath like she’d never gotten her first wind, let alone her second. She was sweating like a hog, and as pink as one too. Her fleshy cheeks were bright red with the struggle it had taken to keep her great girth moving the full ten meters that separated the entrance from her home to the back end of the tavern.

“Just a little bit further, Ms. Helga!” Olga cheered her elephantine employer on with a smile on her face, “You know you want one of these yummy apple tarts!”

“Aye…” Helga huffed weakly, her eyes glazed and stupid as she struggled to lift one meaty pillar of leg in front of the other, “I want it so bad~”

Her pink tongue lolled to the side as she took deep, open-mouth breaths, Helga held her hands out as far as they could reach in front of her, as if she stood a chance of catching the much smaller girl or the delicious pastries she was quite literally waving in front of her. All of the tenacious taverner jiggled fiercely with her movements, her footsteps thundering throughout the bar like a one-woman earthquake.

Finally, the walking mountain of mass reached her destination—the log that they’d rolled into the area by the fireplace so that she could have a place to sit when she got winded—which was often. Helga collapsed onto the mighty trunk, her great gut sagging to the floor as she gasped pathetically in her seat. True to her word, Olga placed the tray of apple tarts on top of Helga’s barely-dressed midsection. Her piggish brown eyes lit up with delight as she wiggled her chunky fingers before stuffing tart after tart into her awaiting mouth.

“By the gods, Helga, you’d think that we starve you.” Somaria rolled her eyes, “I dunno where you got the idea that you could just sit around and eat all day, but you’ve become a fat lump of a woman—y’know that?”

Helga’s cheeks bulged with pastry.

“I have not.” Helga huffed, her voice thick and husky, “M’just… a little preoccupied is all…”

“With how fat you’re getting?” Somaria sauntered over and lifted Helga’s great gut with both hands, allowing it to come back to the floor with a wet SMACK! Helga swatted her longtime companion away. “Ye gods, Helga, are you going to eat us out of house and home?”

“I may, if ye keep up as you are.” Helga gasped, “Aye, Blue Eyes, unlock the sweets. Mama needs to take a look at what we can afford to lose today.”

“Olga, don’t.” Somaria cut her eyes at the ever-obedient barmaid, “She’s just going to have you empty them directly into that gut of hers.”

“They’ll be goin’ through my mouth!”

Disregarding Somaria, who had developed a reputation as something of a wet blanket around the tavern now that Helga was all about living it up, Olga happily did as she was told. Inside the cubbard were sweets of all sorts—and it looked like Helga couldn’t have been happier.

“That’s the ticket.” Helga smacked her lips stupidly, rubbing her vast gut with both hands, “Let’s start with the sweet rolls.”

Helga’s heaving breaths caused her vast ocean of chest to flow like tides. In and out, in and out. Milky masses of fat hung in her dress, stretching it to the point of implausibility. How long until another one of Helga’s famous wardrobe malfunctions, where the whole town chipped in to buy her something new to wear? They were good for business at least.

“Aye, blue eyes, what would I do without you?” Helga smacked her lips proudly

“Weigh less.” Olga said as she smacked her boss’s belly proudly—

In all honesty, she wouldn’t have had Helga any other way. There was certainly no way that she could run the bar without her. It helped Olga feel… needed! It may have been a little underhanded to exploit her boss’s appetite like this, but she seemed happy.

Little did anyone, least of all Olga, know that…
1113112211221.title: Huge & Hungry Helga Barging into the Bar

choices: a bloated, fattened Cameena Stranken—looking for only the tastiest blood!
a very eager, very horny King Roland—a woman so vast surely HAD to be single!
a curious Jynera—the goddess of food and revelry taken form!
11131122112212.content:

In fact, onesuch listener was en route to come face to face with the fabled fatty.

who was it?

choices: She'd gotten fat! It seemed that however Vampires lived, she lived well...
She'd gotten quite big! Toddling around at her size was a making her winded...
She was huge! Cameena was having difficulties just getting out of her coach!
111311221122121.content:
It was true! The legends of the Tremendous Taverner of the North had spread far and across the great land of Yndyre.

In fact, onesuch listener was en route to come face to face with the fabled fatty.

Behind the thick cataracts of altostratus, the sky above the sleepy mountain town pinkened as twilight rose once more. The clip-clop of shadowy horses as they descended the worn mountain road seemed to echo throughout Racovania menacingly. A brass bell began to ring as the first spotting of the Stranken Clan in almost three years loomed heavily over everyone’s head.

Had it really been so long since the vampires that watched over their town descended upon them? Two festivals ago, Tora Forgedotter had been the sole casualty of their culling—leaving Olga effectively orphaned to the two tavern wenches. It had been an annual tradition before—or whenever one of their clan felt like it. But as lives carried on and suspicion died… perhaps they’d gotten forgotten what true fear had felt like.

The brass bell ringing overhead was enough to make Olga freeze in place. The last time she had heard that…

“Olga?” Ms. Somaria touched the barmaid’s shoulder tentatively, causing the icy blonde to tense, “Olga, are you in there?”

“What?” she answered curtly, “F… I’m fine.”

“Good.” Somaria nodded affirmatively, “Look, I know it must be hard for you, but we all knew this time was coming. We’ve had it good for a while now, and—”

“Let’s just get Ms. Helga standing up.” Olga insisted as she grabbed the massive mature by one of her pillowy arms, “Gods help us…”

Getting Helga to a standing position was almost as hard as getting her into the tavern these days. She was a wide woman, and didn’t lift easily. Her bottom was heavier than Olga alone, and her vast swinging stomach that folded and bunched onto her legs in front of her didn’t make things easy either. Combined with her endless appetite, she was practically immobile when she wanted to be.

The sound of her idle crunching on sweets was drowned out by the footsteps and general clamor of the crowd. As Olga, Somaria, Helga and the rest of Racovania fell in line, Olga could see why…

“Good morning everyone.” Came the dark purr of the head of the Stranken clan, “This will only take a minute, just…”

A winded gasp escaped the mistress of the night

“Give us a moment.”

What vampires were made of—what they could do, how they were made, composed, whatever—were more or less a mystery to the uneducated folk of Racovania. Even scholars were still trying to figure out how they subsisted on blood and (seemingly) blood alone. What they did with their captors was unknown and, frankly, a source of extreme terror for those who were unlucky enough to live under their thumb.

But by all means, no one would have ever figured that they could get fat.

It was true—Cameena Stranken, a monster that Olga had known to look more or less the same her entire life, had undergone a rather dramatic change in appearance…
111311221122121.title: Cameena Stranken's Doughy Descent

choices: Helga—"Your blood must be SO delicious! I must have you!"
Olga—"You're the sister of my last prize, no? I'll bet you're just as tasty."
Someone else—"You have potential..."
1113112211221213.content:
It wasn’t just Olga—everyone in the entire village seemed to take a step back as one pillowy gray leg extended from inside the coach, leaning visibly to one side.

“Give us a moment…” Cameena repeated breathlessly, “It’s… it’s a little tight in here…”

An avalanche of what appeared to be flesh and fabric pressed against the opening of the carriage. It lapped over the leg and quivered with the thumping impact of whatever was trying to get out. The Stranken coach’s passenger bucked against the sides of her carriage. Olga couldn’t help but notice that the wheels were warped—bent out to all sides. And the frame was bent too…

Finally, with a rip that seemed to sound throughout all of Racovania, Cameena Stranken’s corpulence had made itself known.

Olga could barely believe it—all of her anxiety over the occasion melted away for just one moment as she drank in the sight. The lady who loomed overhead, the woman who had personally plucked her sister from the village almost three years ago, leaving her with nothing other than her employers at the Bleakfrost Tavern, had become incredibly, enormously fat.

Cameena Stanken was so large, so vast, that she wasn’t able to remove herself from the carriage. At least not entirely. Her great gut was wedged between the comparatively narrow wooden opening. Small imp-like creatures rushed to her aide, pulling at her cankles and steadying her stomping as the elephantine immortal struggled to so much as stand under her own power. Her big, billowing belly hung low over her knees and swung far out in front of her, certainly further than either of her pathetic meaty arms could reach. The source of the rip was made clear—inches of dimpled, cellulite-ridden grey flesh made itself known through a gash just over the right thigh.

“There we are…” Cameena huffed, her jowls rippling with the effort it took to so much as speak, “Now then… Racovanians…”

She steadied herself by placing both of her fluffy hands along the circumference of her massive midsection as it raised up, and down, up and down.

“Oh you all just look so tasty~” she squealed, “I could just eat up every single one of you!”

This caused a chill to run up everyone’s spine at once.

“But I jest.” Cameena chuckled, “Even I—voluminous as I am…”

She shifted the vastness of her stomach for emphasis.

“Can settle for one, maaaaybe two of you dirty, delicious poor people.”

Cameena licked her blue lips lovingly, her eyes dazed as she rubbed her belly in concentric circles. Larger, then smaller. Larger, then smaller.

Olga could hardly believe that this was the same monster as what seemed like a lifetime ago.

“As you can probably guess, I’ve been spoiling myself a bit.” Cameena said cheekily, lifting her belly ever so slightly for emphasis, “I’ve been awfully greedy. And I require only the richest, tastiest blood, comparable to anyone else in my stable…”

Everyone in Racovania—not nearly as well-versed in her Majesty’s taste in blood as they ought to have been—clenched simultaneously.

“It needs to be rich.” Cameena sighed dreamily, stroking her jiggling flank, “Decadent even. Why my latest feast, her blood alone is enough for me to… well, I best not say too much…”

Resuming her slow, ponderous waddle in front of the stilled and stunned denizens of Racovania, Cameena began making her choice, eventually coming to settle on…
1113112211221213.title: Big Blobby Bloodsucker

choices: Cameena can't take Helga if she's too fat for the carriage!
Make the trek up the mountain and appease Cameena herself!
Something Else!
11131122112212131.content:
Cameena's movements were slow, and non-deliberate. It was clearly a struggle just for her to kick one meaty gray leg in front of the other one. Her stomach swayed slowly and pendulously in front of her, fleshy knees colliding with quivering ashen mass as she hefted herself further and further away from her carriage. She could clearly barely be bothered to move her muscles, let alone strategize just where her bigness was heading.

Her red eyes flicked over the crowd, her nostrils flared wide. A hunger came across her face, her blue tongue moist in her mouth as her breathing hastened. This greedy undead goddess was absolutely ecstatic at everything these poor pitiful Racovanians had to offer, and she was clearly getting the most out of her imagination. All that blood, everyone's fear as they quivered in their boots at the mere sight of her--not that there was anything particularly "mere" about her anymore...

She clearly pondered over abducting quite a few citizens. Her lusty gaze travelled over one, two, three, four of the mountain folk. Greta the barmaid, Jackson the axe-grinder. People that no one would have particularly missed, but still not ones that anyone felt particularly deserved whatever fate awaited them in the Stranken castles higher up the mountain trails...

Meanwhile, Olga was having a fit. Her mind paced a thousand miles for every half-step the blobby blood-sucker took. The last time she had seen her, Cameena had abducted her sister, Tora. It had been so long since the vampiress had descended upon her village. What more did she have to lose? What else could possibly have been taken away from her?

And the answer came with a girlish squeal.

"Ye gods!" Cameena absolutely screeched as she laid eyes upon the fatted tavern wench propped up on a log, "Look at you darling~"

Helga, who hadn't so much as had to think for herself lately, snorted in response. It wasn't until she remembered the very real danger that the vampires above posed to those below that the super-sized server began to worry. Sweat rolled down her fat face, cresting over the folds of her chins and down into the valley of her cleavage. Her hoggish breathing quickened as she looked to Olga for condolence.

The blonde apprentice could only stare with watery eyes at her boss's big bovine gaze, wide with fear.

The collision of two such enormous women was inevidable. Cameena and Helga looked to be about the same size, actually. Their bellies brushed against one another, pressing lightly at the mounts and then more harshly as they collided. Cameena's great sea of gray flab was cold to the touch, and made goosepimples run across Helga's fatted, gasping form.

"Muh... me?" Helga whimpered like a small child, "You want... you want me?"

"How could I not?" Cameena purred as she placed two hands on the still-seated barmaid's fleshy flab, "You look so scrumptuous! You're so fat you can barely stand!"

Helga's beady brown eyes watered as Somara and Olga began to feel their hearts pound within their chests. This didn't look like it was going to fare well. Helga may not have been much help around the tavern lately, but she was still their boss and close friend. But Olga specifically felt a particular strand of guilt.

"She wants her...Because she's so fat!" Olga realized in pain, "And I... I helped make her this way!"

Olga had already lost her sister. And her parents. And now, it looked like she was going to lose her surrogate mother too...

"You're quite the little heiffer, aren't you barmaid?" Cameena flexed her stomach, pressing it more tightly against Helga's distended gut as a sign of intimidation. She reached over and tickled underneath her chins, "You weren't nearly this big and scrumptious when I came to visit you all last time, were you?"

"N-no..." Helga gasped, "I... I..."

"Got good and fat is what you did." Cameena chuckled, her belly wobbling in delight, "Too fat for you and me to fit in my carriage, for sure."

It was true. Cameena Stranken herself was obviously too big to ride in that awful horse-drawn thing. The black wood was bent and warped, the horses were clearly overworked. The wheels and suspension were bent as well. There was no way that Helga was going to fit in there, given her vastly belly-centric shape over Cameena's more rounded one. The big blobby barmaid was safe... for now.

"But don't you worry, you little cutie pie." Cameena said with a pinch of Helga's hearty gut, "I've commissioned another carriage. One that can carry twice my weight, easily."

Cameena rubbed her exposed gray stomach with a chubby hand. She lifted the upper tier of her terrible tummy slightly and let it fall back into place as she idled. Clearly she was enjoying herself with her size, if her mannerisms and confidence weren't enough of a giveaway.

"I didn't expect to find such a prize when I made my descent, or I would have just waited until it was finished." Cameena purred, patting Helga's gut, "But don't you worry. By the season's end, I'll have something about your size to carry us both up the mountain."

***


Whenever times were tough, Helga ate.

This was a habit that she'd formed well before Olga had helped blow her up into the useless lout that she was now. But at her current size, Helga's need for comfort eating was intensified. She was practically emptying the larder all by herself while her barmaids watched.

They'd closed up shop after Cameena's carriage wobbled off. Everyone had. No one felt much like celebrating, even if no one was taken this time. It only meant that Cameena would come back. And if she changed her mind about wanting Helga, she could just as easily fit four or five of the villagers, should she wish to fill up her new carriage to the brim...

"Well we can't let her take her." Somaria said definitively, "I've worked with Helga for years, and I'm not letting that fat leech get my friend."

"What choice do we have?" Greta whined, "She may be fat now, but it could be a trick! Or she could be just as powerful as before!"

"Or she could be more powerful than ever" Sandra, the other barmaid, wailed, "Nobody knows how vampires work!"

As hysterics overcame the Bleakfrost Tavern, it was Olga who remained quietly. She had already lost everything she'd ever known to these undead lunatics. And she wasn't about to let her life fall to shambles again. She'd helped put Helga in this situation, so it was her responsibility to help keep her safe.

And it was in that moment that Olga felt she knew exactly what to do...
11131122112212131.title: Hungry for Helga

choices: The Tavern staff, Somaria and Olga included, were getting plenty fat too..
Hegla's not big enough. Not yet. And they only have a few more weeks...
111311221122121311.content:
At first, no one was quite on board with Olga's plan. It... didn't sound very smart. No one would have ever pegged the blacksmith's daughter for a scholar, especially if they'd ever listened to her try and calculate tip percentages. But even by her corn-haired standards, Olga's idea for saving Helga's skin was rather... insane. No, insane was definitely the right word. But at the same time, they were dealing with a vampire, so all logic was more or less thrown out the window there. No one knew anything about the race of night stalking ne'erdowells, so Olga's ridiculous ideas were just as sound as any of the more "logical" ones that anyone else in the tavern could come up with... not that there were any.

And, in time, everyone came around. It just sort've became the norm.

Serve customers, work the back, feed Helga. Make the stew, cook the lamb, feed Helga. Check the ale, mind the mead, feed Helga. Passing through the hallway? Feed Helga. Find yourself without a table to wait on? Feed Helga. Extra scraps went to Helga, anything that someone refused to pay for went to Helga, the overcooked meat went to Helga, the uglies from the biscuits went to Helga. It took an entire Tavern's staff to manage it, but the girls of the Bleakfrost Tavern managed to keep their Innkeeper fed literally every waking hour of the day—and if you would have asked that fat blob, it still wouldn't have been enough.

"Aye! Keep it up ye... ye lollygaggers..." Helga's jowls came in waves as she bellowed throughout the Inn, "M'wastin' away here..."

You would have never known that the very fate of her life was at stake by the way she took the preparation for the next season in stride. She was a hog in heaven, stuffing herself day in and day out without a care in the world! Barking around her employees and going on and on about how she wasn't getting enough to eat.

"I s'pose ye want to get rid of me!" Helga would bellow drunkenly as she shook whatever she could reach of her always-growing gut, "Make sure ye feed the next Taverner more than ye do my skinny arse!"

The revelation that came with Helga's hoggishness was unprecedented. Her jovial laughter and drunken bleating of demands for more, more, more was unlike anything anyone had ever experienced. And as she grew larger and larger, her mobility failing her more and more, she became incredibly dependent on her staff.

"Mm. Look at you." Somaria tugged her lips to the side as she placed a dark palm on Helga's exposed gullet, "I can't help but think we're just fattening you up for that bloodsucker."

"Aye, then what's your excuse?" Helga's ruddy red cheeks were flush with alcohol, "C'mere Somaria an' lemme give those hips a jiggle."

"You pig." Somaria clicked her tongue as she sashayed over, her (admittedly widening) hips swaying severely, "You're enjoying every moment of this aren't you?"

"More 'n I ever thought possible." Helga gasped, "Be a good lass an' hand me summa those... those delicious... mm..."

Helga, the formerly demure and responsible innkeeper, had indulged so deeply in the carnal pleasures of gluttony that there was no coming back. She was a stomach now, with brown hair and useless little arms and legs that used to get her places. She'd plop down and gorge herself til she was good and fat for the day, take a nap, and wake up ready and raring for more. All in the name of her own survival, of course.

"Aye Blue Eyes." Helga's voice had gotten deep and husky once her neck began to disappear beneath the rings of her chins, "C'mere an' give Mama a belly rub."

Life was good. For Helga, anyway. And admittedly, the staff of the Tavern. "Helping" Helga by turning her into the largest woman this side of the land had given them something to strive for. Bond over, even. Helga had gone from their boss to something like a mascot. How much could she eat today? How much did anyone think she weighed? All in the name of her own safety, it had become something of a game. The next season passed faster than anyone would have liked...

There was just one problem.
111311221122121311.title: Helping Helga Get Huge

choices: Cameena descends upon Racovania once more...
Cameena... doesn't descend upon Racovania. What?
1113112211221213111.content:
The only problem with keeping the tavern filled to the brim with more food than any one person could possibly eat, as well as the one woman alive who was ready and willing to test that claim, was that there was no real sense of normalcy anymore.

Not that there was ever really a sense of normalcy to begin with. Given that vampires could just swoop in and snatch up whomever they pleased, whenever they felt the need to do so. Harpies loomed further up the mountains and there was an Ogress setting up camp right outside of town, "normal" was a very loose term here when looked at objectively.

Olga's wish would be granted, in an odd sort of way, by way of the Racovanian Festival.

It happened every year, so it seemed somewhat strange that this particular festival would be the answer to her prayers. The forge was ringing til after sundown so that Tora could get her order finished in time so that she didn't have to work through the festival and miss out on the festivities.

Oh and the festivities to be had! Neighbors would bake special treats like ceremonial cakes or pies made from whatever they could spare from their larders. Racks of ribs were thrown over the fire and marinated with special sauces (there was a contest every year for the best entry!) and the Bobbings would sell their fish at a discount. Beer and mead were sloshed around, practically given away while bards and minstrels were hired to serenade the whole town.

Which was why Olga was so eager to offer a helping hand to her new employer. Helga no doubt had a lot on her plate, considering she was always in charge of providing the drinks for the whole village. Not only was it a way for her to spice up her life, but the extra coin was much appreciated around the Forgedotter home.
