121311.content:
Tsarra had been sent by her brother to go and collect some berries out on the edges of the village. At least that would be something for her to do and to stay out of his hair. True, Arlen loved his sweet twin sister, but she was sometimes a handful in his eyes. He just hoped that someday soon, a husband who could tolerate her would come along. Until then, she was just a lazy good-for-nothing who ate more than she should, in his opinion.

She was considered rather plump, at least by elven standards. She couldn't help it. If they were meant to be thin, then why would the gods have made food taste so good? Arlen had clapped her ear for that response one day when she gave that as an answer when he chastised her excessive eating habits.

And it wasn't like she genuinely was lazy. There was just so little to do these days, she thought, what with the wars over and everything. Plus, half the time, Arlen didn't like the way she did one thing and would instead do it himself, and then proceeded to call her lazy when she had nothing she was allowed to do by his standards.

Today, she was more than happy to be out and about. She actually liked being helpful. Course, her brother wouldn't be too happy with her if he saw her now. She perhaps ate half the berries she was collecting. They were hard to resist. They were just that sweet and ripe.

Tsarra would have been content to continue just this way, but that was when she saw the hulking orc standing before her. At first, fear gripped her heart, and she could hear it thundering in her ears. She stood stock still, perhaps hoping that maybe she hadn't seen her.

But then the creature spoke to her. "Hello, my name is Varehl. What is your name?"

In truth, Tsarra had neveeer seen anything like her. She knew it wasn't a human, was it? She had heard stories about what humans were like, even if she hadn't seen one herself, and she didn't think this fit the description of what a human was. So what was it?

Perhaps what got her into trouble so much was her natural curiosity about the world. She always asked the questions others dared not to ask. She went to the places others feared to go. And in this case, this was someone she had never met.

Plus, the orc was unarmed, and hadn't threatened her, so that seemed safe. And, she looked lost. She felt bad for her.

She nodded her head in a sort of bow. "I am Tsarra. Are you lost?" she asked sweetly.

The orc smiled as though she was glad for just this little bit of kindness in the world. "Yes, actually. I've been on a long journey, looking for a friend. I'm not even sure where the first place to look would be."

She smiled. Arlen would not be pleased about this, but she felt the need to try and help her out. "Why don't you come with me? At the very least, we can give you a good hot meal before you have to be on your way."

"That would help a lot, thank you. What is it you were picking?"

It was as if she remembered why she had been there in the first place. "Oh, berries. My brother sent me to get them for dinner. I live with him."

Varehl smiled coyly at her. "They must've been good then, huh? You have a little berry juice on your lips."

Tsarra hastily wiped it off. "Oh, goodness! Thank you. Arlen would have my head if he knew I was eating all the stuff I was supposed to be getting. I'm getting much too fat as it is."

Varehl let out a hearty laugh, that was more like a snort. "You, fat? I'd hardly call it that. You're such a tiny twig of a thing."

She smiled back. "I suppose I am small to your kind. What...what are you anyway?" She blushed, realizing she had asked a rude question.

She didn't seem to mind. "I'm an orc. I guess you guys don't get a lot of people like me around here."

No, definitely not, Tsarra thought. And she wondered how the village would handle having an orc in their midst. By now, they had reached her home, and she could see Arlen waiting at the door impatiently. His impatience soon turned to fear very quickly.

"I hope you have an excuse for being so late," he had started to say. "Sometimes I wonder if you just pretend to be lazy on purpose, you..."

He stopped mid-sentence when he saw her guest. "Tsarra, what is this?"

She swallowed, ready for a good lecture from him. "This is Varehl. She's an orc, whatever that is, and she's lost. I said we could maybe help her."

This seemed to make him regain his senses. Arlen wasn't always intentionally mean. He loved her, and she knew it, but he was a bit of a perfectionist, and expected the same out of her. She never could understand how they shared a womb together all those years ago.

"Are you insane?" he began. "What were you thinking bringing her here? She's...she's...she could be dangerous. What if she had hurt you? What if she's planning on hurting us?"

He looked up, realizing that Varehl was listening to them. "You will stay for one night. We will give you directions, and you will leave, understood?"

Varehl didn't exactly look too keen on being anywhere near him, but nodded her agreement.

1213111.content:
About an hour later, Varehl was sitting at the table with Tsarra. Arlen had just finished making a soup, and set the berries in a bowl on the table, and sat with the two. From the looks he was shooting Varehl, he still wasn't happy with their impromptu guest.

"So," Tsarra began. "Why have you come to our home? We mostly only see other elves and satyrs."

Varehl frowned. "I was actually hoping to speak with whoever is in charge. I've lost someone. A friend. Her name is Zela." She explained.

"Oh my." Tsarra said. "What happened?"

"I don't know." Varehl replied. "She just up and vanished one night. I've been searching for two years now. I've already checked several other place, but had no luck."

"Perhaps your friend was kidnapped." Arlen finally spoke up. "We've had that happen a few times here in the Verge."

"That thought scares me more than any other." Varehl said. "All I want is to find Zela, safe. Once I talk to your... um..."

"Elders." Arlen said.

"Thank you. Once I speak to your elders, I'll be on my way." Varehl finished.

"Good." Arlen muttered, before turning to his soup. At this point, Varehl got the hint that he didn't want to talk anymore, and simply started to eat her own soup.
In the corner of her vision, Varehl could see Tsarra digging into her soup with a surprising amount of vigor. It actually reminded Varehl of Zela a bit, with how much the naga adored pies. Put a pie in front of Zela, and it would be gone in seconds.

Varehl chuckled at that memory, and looked at Tsarra again. The elf hadn't shown much fear when she saw Varehl, and seemed quite curious about her. She showed sadness when Varehl talked about her lost friend. This made Varehl wonder two things: how Tsarra and Arlen could be siblings, and if Tsarra would like to see more outside the Verge. She'd have to ask after supper.
--------
A little while after supper, Varehl was following Arlen. He opened a door, and led her into a small bedroom.

"This is where you'll be staying for the night. But only tonight." Arlen said curtly. "Once you've spoken with the elders in the morning, you're leaving, right?"

Varehl nodded. Then she pursed her lips. "Actually, I have a question. I've heard that the elves are slowly building relations with other races, so I was wondering: could Tsarra come with me?" She asked. "If she brought back good stories about other races, it might help you guys. Plus, I heard you call her lazy. This might get her more active."

Arlen briefly looked at Varehl like she was completely mad, but then considered the last part. Tsarra was a rather care-free elf, and she did laze off and eat too much. Perhaps if she did this, it would teach her more responsibility.

"You'd have to speak with the elders on that." He said. "But I will say this: if it actually gets her to be responsible, I'd send her off. But if she gets hurt, I will hold you responsible." On that, he left the room and shut the door.

Varehl stood there for a moment, before sighing and walking over to the bed. The thing was obviously not built for someone nearly seven feet tall, so Varehl simply decided to sleep on the floor. She pulled the pillow and blanket from the bed, set them on the floor, and laid down.

As she drifted off to sleep, she began dreaming about past times with her friend. Those had been the only dreams she had for 2 years, but they were still some of the best dreams ever, at least to her.
-------
Sometime during the night, Varehl was woken up by the door opening. Looking up, she saw Tsarra, holding a candle.

"I'm sorry to wake you, but I wanted to talk to you for a minute." Tsarra said.

Varehl sat up, as Tsarra walked over to the bed and sat on it.

"I overheard you talking to my brother. About letting me go with you." Tsarra said. "It's the elder's choice, but I would love to go with you."

"You would?" Varehl asked.

Tsarra nodded. "I've been rather curious about the other races. I haven't heard all that much about them. Only humans really." Tsarra said. "There was one human who visited a while ago who ended up marrying an elder's daughter, Glesheri. The other elves didn't know, but the two were found out eventually. The elder disowned Glesheri, and the couple were being harrased so badly they had to leave."

Varehl frowned. "Sounds awful." She said.

"I think so. As did at least one other elder. While he didn't approve of the union either, even he thought this was too far. He's a bit more trusting to other races." Tsarra said.

"Hopefully, he's the elder I get to talk to tomorrow." Varehl said.

Tsarra smiled. "He is." She said. Then she thought for a moment. "What's it like being so... big?"

Varehl was confused for a moment, but then smiled. "Well, the muscles are very helpful. Means I can fight really tough opponents, and most of the time win. I can also break stones with my bare hands." She explained.

"Wow!" Tsarra said. "Incredible. But what about..." She trailed off.

Varehl got the hint. "My butt? That's mostly from eating." She said. "It's not much help. But Zela was fine with it. She had a similar build, only not as muscular. Actually, her butt ended up helping us escape once."

"Really? How?" Tsarra asked.

And that's how the rest of the night was spent: Varehl telling stories of her and Zela's adventures, as Tsarra listened. That night, a connection was formed.
-------
The next morning, Arlen and Tsarra had taken Varehl to one of the elder's homes. Varehl obviously got some odd and sometimes worried looks from other elves, but they mostly just kept their distance from her.

Inside the home, Arlen introduced Varehl to the elder. After an inital moment of shock from seeing her, the elder agreed to speak with her on the issue of Zela. Varehl sat down with the elder at a table, and began explaining her story. During this, she also asked the elder about taking Tsarra with her, explaining that it could help with relations to other races, and it would help her become responsible.

Once she finished, the elder rubbed his chin in thought, before speaking.

"Well, that is certainly a sad tale." The elder said. "I'm afraid to say that no naga ever passed through the Verge."

Varehl frowned at this. "Oh." She said, sadly.

"However," The elder began. "About two months ago, one of our scouting parties saw a caravan pass the entrance to the Verge. They described several people in the caravan. One of them claimed to see a green tail, about 6 feet in length. It sounds like your friend. From what I was told, the caravan was heading for the Spekkfitu Tundra."

Varehl face lit up. This was it! The first lead she had in 2 years! She stood in excitement.

"Oh, thank you!" Varehl said. "You have no idea how much hearing that means to me!"

"You're welcome." The elder said. "Now, regarding your request for brining Tsarra with you. I'll need a minute to think about it." He then got up and went into another room.

A few minutes later, he returned. "I've decided." He said. "Tsarra..."
1213111.title: Night Talk

choices: A little while later, the two fall asleep.

12131111.content:
"Tsarra may go with you," he said. "There is still much we don't know about the world outside the Verge, and unfortunately, our scouting parties are not coming back to give us much. I do believe with you, she does have a chance of staying protected. I doubt you've had too much trouble?"

Varehl shrugged. "No more than the usual person, but I can handle it."

He nodded. "Very good then. Provided she is willing to accompany you, she may go."

Tsarra was practically bouncing on the balls of her feet when Varehl told her the good news. "I can come? Really?"

"Yes, but you'll just have to be careful. This isn't some kind of game. There are a few dangers out there. But, if you stick with me and do what I say, you'll be fine."

She eagerly rushed to pack a few necessities. Arlen was waiting by the door, eager to get rid of the orc. "You had better know what you're doing," he said. "I really do love my sister, and I don't want to see anything happen to her."

"She'll be safe with me. I promise."

In truth, Varehl wasn't entirely certain of that. True, she would do her best, but she had faced her fair share of scraps that had been close calls. Plus, Tsarra wasn't exactly warrior material here. She wouldn't be able to help all that much in a fight when it came right down to it. At least, she could maybe hide.

Tsarra was ready to leave fairly quickly, and she eagerly hugged her brother as he rattled off instructions like a nagging mother.

"Now, be careful. Don't go anywhere without Varehl. Help her when she says to. And please, don't get in the way and follow directions."

She laughed. "I'll be fine. I think I'll be pretty safe with an orc."

He hugged her again, noticing that she felt even softer than usual. Hm, too much snacking between meals, he thought. Hopefully, all this travel would help her lose a little weight.

The two set off on their own by midday, and were out of the range of the village within an hour. The Verge was still fairly big, and it would take them several days to get out of it. This was when Varehl was first made aware of how little Tsarra knew about the outside world. She hardly knew where they were once they were out of the village. So, the orc had to rely on her maps, hoping for the best, as she tried to head north.

"So, where is it we're going?" Tsarra asked.

"The elder I spoke to said there may be a lead up near Spekkfitu Tundra. It's way up north. We'll have to pass through Racovania and Overvektige Peaks to get there, though. It'll be a long journey. But, hopefully, we can catch up."

The elf thought for a moment. "What's the north like?"

"Dunno. I've never been there much myself. I expect it's cold though."

Varehl looked over at her traveling companion and realized that may be a problem. The orc was at least big and thick. At least she'd have some protection against the cold. A pale, thin thing like Tsarra wouldn't really do all that well up there. Hopefully, they'd find some fur traders to buy some cloaks from to stay warm. That, or they'd have to get creative.

Well, they could cross that bridge when they came to it. They were still a long ways off from getting anywhere near the north. When they had stopped to rest for the night, they made camp in a small clearing. Varehl went out hunting for their dinner, while Tsarra stayed back, setting up the camp and getting fresh water. When the orc came back with a large elk, the elf's eyes nearly bugged out. "You got all that for dinner?" she asked, looking over the massive creature.

"Well, not all of it," Varehl said. "I mean, we can save some of the meat for a few days before it goes bad, but you do know that orcs need a lot of food to keep up our strength, right?"

She looked at her friend's significantly larger frame. "I suppose that does make sense."

Varehl took to skinning the animal and cooking a large portion of it over the fire. The skins would make a good blanket to help keep them warm as they got farther north, she thought. Once the meat warmed over their fire, she took to devouring her piece with great gusto, having missed having a good meal in a while. Tsarra only ate a bit, but Varehl could tell she was longing for a bit more.

"You know, you can have more if you want," she said. "Your brother isn't around to tell you no."

She looked at the meat cracking over the fire. "I probably shouldn't," she said.

Varehl shrugged. "You know, you're not really all that big. In all honesty, you probably could use a little more meat on your bones. Elves are incredibly frail looking, I've decided. I don't know how you guys do it. But, whatever. More for me."

This made the elf laugh, and she was glad to have been able to put her at ease. "Alright, I guess a little more couldn't hurt," she said, reaching for another piece."

"That's the spirit! Trust me, if there's one thing you're going to have to get used to with me, it's eating well whenever you can. Never know when you'll get another meal."
12131111.title: The Journey Begins

choices: Varehl's usual: cooked pig and goat. Nothing too big
To Varehl's surprise, a huge feast. Aoi thinks Tsarra needs to eat
121311114.content:
For once in Varehl's life, the night had been peaceful. Usually, she would be interrupted by an angry animal she'd easily kill, or an angry person she'd manage to drive away. But tonight, she was finally able to get a full nights sleep.

So she was much more refreshed then usual when the sun rose. Varehl looked over at Tsarra, who was still fast asleep. Chuckling a little at just how adorable she looked, Varehl gently nuged the snoring elf.

"Hey, time to wake up. We've got to move." Varehl said.

Tsarra groaned, and slowly opened her eyes. "What time is it?" She asked quietly.

"Based on the position of the sun, I'd say somewhere between 10 and 11." Varehl answered.

On that, Tsarra giggled a little. "Arlen usually has me up around 7 in the morning. I don't really like waking up early." She said.

"I don't usually have a choice." Varehl said. "To me, this is rare."

Tsarra frowned. "That's no good. You should be able to wake up whenever you want." She said.

Varehl just shrugged. "Come on. We've got a few hours before we reach the tundra." She said.

Tsarra nodded, and after the two cleaned up the tiny camp, they headed off.
------
About two hours later, the two were walking down a large dirt road. Spekkfitu Tundra was still a few days walk away. The two would first have to pass through Racovania, then the Overvektige Peaks, which Varehl wasn't exactly looking forward too. There were some harpies there that still held a grudge.

However, that wouldn't be for a while. The first thing Varehl wanted to focus on was at least getting to Racovania. From there, they could hopefully catch a caravan for the rest of the trip and cut down on travel time.

"Is it going to be much longer?" Tsarra asked. "It's rather hot, and I'm getting rather hungry."

Varehl had to agree on that. The heat was becoming rather bothersome, and Varehl herself was growing famished.

"Don't worry." Varehl said to Tsarra. "I've travelled this road before. There's a tavern a few miles ahead. Owned by a married couple. Zela and I helped them with a bandit problem sometime before she vanished, and they said I and any of my friends could eat free anytime.

"You and Zela must have travelled a lot." Tsarra said.

Varehl nodded. "That was mainly what we did. Got into scraps, helped out some people, made more people angry, and just wandered."

"Wow." Tsarra said, intrigued. "You've had such a fascinating life."

Varehl chuckled. "Tell you what. We get to that tavern and eat, and I'll tell you my life story."

Tsarra smiled at that prospect.
----------
Another 2 hours of walking and occasional stops to rest later, Varehl and Tsarra came up to a building. The sight made Varehl smile. This was the tavern she had mentioned to Tsarra. It was a two story building, simple in construction. A sign above the door read "Homestead Tavern".

The two made their way to the building and entered. Much like the outside, the inside was simple, more resembling a cozy home then a tavern. The only way you could tell it was a tavern was the counter in the back and the numerous tables.

Behind the bar were a human male and a Futakuchi-Onna. The man was tall and skinny with sandy-blonde hair and a small beard. He was wearing an apron. The Futakuchi-Onna was shorter with long, wild black hair. She was a very fat woman, her white gown strained over her wide frame.

The woman looked up and saw Varehl and Tsarra enter. With surprising speed, she left the counter and ran up to greet Varehl.

"Varehl! It's so good to see you again!" The woman said. She then saw Tsarra. "Oh! Who's this?"

"This is my current travelling companion, Tsarra." Varehl said. "Tsarra, this is Aoi and her husband, Des."

Des smiled as he walked up to the two. "Always nice to see you drop by, Varehl." He said. Then he frowned. "Still nothing on Zela?"

"Actually, I got a lead from the Pyknos Verge. I'm heading for Spekkfitu Tundra. Thought we'd stop here for a bit." Varehl said. "And I'm also kind of showing Tsarra around. She doesn't know the area."

"Well, I'm certain she'll love the area." Aoi said. "So, take a seat anywhere, and we'll get you a hot meal. I'm guessing the usual?"

Varehl smiled. "You know me so well." She said. On that, she and Tsarra went over to a table and sat down. Aoi and Des went through a nearby door to the kitchen.

"They seem very nice." Tsarra said.

"They are." Varehl replied. "Everytime I come down this road, I make a point to stop here. I've offered to help them out from time to time, but they always refuse."

"I see." Tsarra said. Then she thought of something. "You said you were going to tell you're life story."

"Not much to tell." Varehl said. "My parents were killed in a hunt when I was a kid, and I was adopted by an alchemist. Maria. She tought me alchemy and combat. Left home when I was 18, been travelling ever since."

"Oh." Tsarra said. "When did you meet Zela."

"4 years ago. She was looking for some pirate treasure. The pirates weren't ready to give it up. I happened to be walking by and helped her escape. We instantly became friends after that. We adventured together for 2 years. Then she vanished, and... well, here we are."

Tsarra was about to say something when Des came back into the room. He walked up to their table.

"Sorry, forgot to ask, what do you two want to drink?" Des asked.

"You know me. I'm taking ale." Varehl said.

"I'll just take a glass of water." Tsarra said.

"All right, and it's going to be a while before the food's ready, just to let you know." Des said, before heading behind the counter.
-----
Des was right when he said it would be a while. About 3 hours later, Varehl and Tsarra were discussing some of Varehl and Zela's adventures.

"...so now the poor succubus has a butt so big, it doesn't fit through her door. Guess she deserved it for conning Zela and that kitsune." Varehl finished.

Tsarra giggled a little. She was about to say something when Des and Aoi finally entered the room.

"Dinner is served!" Aoi said, as she and Des revealed...
121311114.title: The Homestead Tavern

choices: The next day, luck is on their side. A caravan is leaving nearby.
The next day, luck is on their side. Varehl hears another lead.
The next day, they aren't so lucky. They have to travel for quite a ways.
The next day, they aren't so lucky. A band of rogues ambushes them.
1213111142.content:
"Dinner is served!" Aoi siad, as she and Des revealed a huge feast.

Varehl couldn't believe it. There had to be some kind of mistake. Even she and Zela couldn't have eaten that much on their best days. Plate upon plate was set at their table, and she was having trouble taking it all in. Did they get the wrong order? Tsarra also looked surprised, her eyes barely contained in her skull as she saw all the delicious foods set before them.

"Um...Aoi," Varehl started to protest.

She waved her off. "Oh, I know it's more than the usual. No charge, I promise. I just saw this adorable little one you've got with you and couldn't resist. She looks like she hasn't seen a good meal in ages. Are elves always that scrawny? And if you're heading out to the Tundra, the poor little thing is going to freeze to death without a few extra layers on her." She patted Tsarra on the shoulder and shook her head. "See, much too thin. You two enjoy your meal now."

As the couple wandered off, Varehl looked back to Tsarra. "I'm sorry about that. She means well and everything, but she can sometimes be a little 'too' helpful. I think it's something about her people's culture. Trust me, I think she's personally responsible for Zela and I adding a few inches to our frames. You really don't have to eat all that much if you don't want to."

The elf gave her a small smile. "But, it does look good," she said. "And, it's cute that she called me skinny. I've never been called that before."

She gave Tsarra an odd look. "But you are, if we're being totally honest. I've been all over the world. I mean, compared to what I've seen in Adinah, you'd be considered downright starving. Has your brother really made you feel like that?"

The elf had already started to dig into the food, grabbing several different things to put on her plate. "No, it's not just him," she said between bites. "I mean, he doesn't do it to be mean. He just worries about me. It's been just the two of us since we were teenagers. Our father was killed in the wars with the satyrs and our mother got sick shortly after that. So, he's always trying to make sure we're able to make it on our own. I think sometimes he worries if I'll be okay by myself. We are twins after all. We've always had each other for longer than we can remember. I wonder if he's worried what he'll do without me."

Varehl nodded and started getting some food herself. She didn't exactly see what Tsarra saw in her own brother. To her, he was cold and sometimes cruel to her, but if Tsarra saw the good in him, good for her.

She continued. "But, it isn't just him. I know what other elves look like. I'm a little heavier than them. I'm not blind."

"Yeah, but I don't want you to feel like you're unattractive because of it. A lot of guys would be lucky to have a girl like you."

She blushed. "Oh, I don't mind it. Food is too good to want to pass up on. If I end up larger for it, so be it."

And she certainly lived up to that mantra. Varehl hadn't seen anyone with an appetite like hers since Zela. Tsarra was eager to try at least one of everything, and still had room for seconds. The orc was impressed. Looking at the scrawny little elf, she would never have guessed she could put away as much as she did.

But, after a while, the two travelers' eating began to slow. Varehl was feeling pleasantly full, as she always did after a good meal from Des and Aoi. Tsarra, on the other hand, looked like a goose, stuffed just before a winter feast. Her thinner frame meant that her overly full stomach was much more noticeable. She rubbed at it gently, a small grimace of pain on her face. "You didn't make yourself sick, did you?" Varehl asked, genuinely worried.

She hiccupped. "No, but I may have eaten a little too much."

She laughed. "No kidding. I think your eyes were bigger than your stomach this time."

Tsarra was about to speak when Aoi came over, setting a pie down, fresh from the oven. She looked the elf up and down. "Well, now that's more like it," she said. "You sure she's getting enough to eat, Varehl?"

"Yes, she's just not used to all these different kinds of foods outside the Verge. She wanted to try everything."

The futakuchi-onna laughed heartily. "Well, that's my kind of girl. I hope when you both come back from your trip, she's looking much healthier. Anyway, I thought I'd bring her a little something sweet to try."

"All for me?" Tsarra asked, her ears perking at the thought.

"Yes, you haven't seen those women up north. You've got a lot of catching up to do. You both staying the night?"

Varehl looked outside. It was already dark out, and Tsarra looked too full to be traveling in her state. "Yeah, looks like. You still got some empty rooms?"

She winked. "For you, of course. I'll tell Des to make sure there's a hearty breakfast ready for you in the morning." She waddled away.

Tsarra looked at the pie, and groaned a little. Varehl laughed. "I'll help you eat that."

"Good, because I think I can only get a few bites in. I've never eaten so much in my life."
1213111142.title: A Feast for the Eyes

choices: Someone knock at the door: it's Glesheri's parents!
While Glesheri sleeps, Nessar gets creative with the lunch
12132.content:
The sun was rising above the vast forest of Pyknos Verge. The light permeated through the branches of the trees and lighted up the Verge, which began to take life. The birds began singing different melodies, and some villagers left their huts to work in the gardens or to go about their daily lives. After not even an hour more elves spread into the village, and the natural sounds of the area reached every corner of the Verge.

After more than two hours since the sun brought light to the Verge, in a house on the outskirts, Glesheri opened her eyes and came out from under the blankets. Her long fawn-brown hair was all messy and covered her face. She stretched her skinny arms while making a big yawn and got up from bed. She was very tired from the night before, spent cuddling with Nessar, her new husband, whom she married secretly only a week ago.

She removed the hair from her face and washed it with the water in a basin. That was really necessary to help her wake up in the mornings...and realize that her willowy body was completely naked...

She rushed to the wardrobe (She thought she remembered that word right. Human devices and such were hard to remember sometimes.) and picked an emerald-colored dress with long and large sleeves and a gown that reached her ankles, she tied the ribbon around her waist, as the dress was large, and put on a pair of loafers.

While Glesheri was combing her hair, Nessar was in the kitchen, preparing the breakfast.

Nessar was a young 25 year-old man with shoulder-length, black, messy hair and a little beard under his chin. Due to his lean build, he decided to become a scholar and one day he went to study the elves. He would have never thought that this decision ended up being so meaningful in his life. But there he was, living in a little house in the Verge with the Glesheri, the elf he had fallen in love with.

That morning he woke up earlier than usual (stupid cockatrice), so he had more time to check the vegetable garden, and boy, there was a lot to collect. They didn't have a large garden, but that day he could pick up half of the vegetables he planted, including all the potatoes. He collected enough stuff to fill two chests.

Nessar moved a lock of his black hair from his forehead wet by the steam of the stew he was preparing. After the smell of rosemary was strong enough, he decided it was ready and could serve it. That day, he decided to make a special dish for Glesheri. The stew itself wasn't anything special, just a broth with some potatoes, carrots minced meat and spices, but it meant a lot for the couple, as it was the first dish Nessar made for Glesheri. Until now, they had lived off of the stores that had been sent to him by the scholars who had sent him on his journey.

He put the stew in the bowl, but noticed a problem: he made a bit too much, and a single bowl was not enough.

"And now what should I do?" muttered Nessar, scratching his chin. He could've eaten some, but he already ate enough.

While he was thinking of the solution, Glesheri jumped in the kitchen.

"Hi, honey," said the elf, walking energically, with her long straight hair waving side to side at every step.

"Hi, dear," replied the man putting the bowl next to the chair, "look at what I made today?"

"Ooh, stew!" said Glesheri with a big smile. "Thank you! You know I how much I love it." She kissed her husband on the cheek and sat on the table, where she began eating the breakfast-lunch. It was delicious, the pork was especially good, and it was something the elves didn't eat very often.

"You should make human cuisine more often. It has something that elven food doesn't," commented Glesheri, putting another spoon in her mouth.

"I would, but the ingredients aren't so easy to get here," replied Nessar, watching with satisfaction how blissful Glesheri was in that moment. “My fellow scholars should be sending me a new shipment of supplies from Adinah fairly soon.”

Not long time after, the bowl was already empty.

"If you want, there's still more. I've accidentally made too much," said Nessar, pointing at the pot in the middle of the table.

“Oh, yes, thank you! I feel I could eat it forever," said Glesheri, handing the bowl to him for more.

Nessar served more and the elf began digging in. Since she met Nessar, Glesheri became more curious about the humans' customs, and there wasn't a day where she didn't ask him something about human life. It was sad that the others of her own kind didn't have the same interest she had.

"So...." said Nessar, scratching his neck, "do your parents know about us?"

"Not yet," answered Glesheri. Her parents were very strict about this. She remembered their reactions when she told them she met a human. She wondered what they might say now that she asked for Yva's blessing... still, she'd been missing for a week; they'd find out soon.

"Want to talk to them about it? I can come with you if you need support."

"Don't worry, I can handle it alone. Is there more?" asked Glesheri, looking inside the pot. There was still a little in the bottom.

----

Glesheri leaned back on the chair. She was full, maybe even more than full. But she couldn't resist. Nessar was an amazing cook, especially when he prepared meals using human ingredients, and was also very affectionate to her. This first week of marriage had been an amazing one, and she didn't bother about what the others might think; the two were happy.

Glesheri stood up. Her stomach was full and round at that moment, and felt heavy. Suddenly, Nessar hugged her from behind.

"So you've enjoyed the meal," commented the man, gently patting Gleshira's belly. It was round, full of his stew, a different sensation compared to her usually flat belly… and he liked it, probably because it brought memories of the women of Adinah, which were much curvier than the elves. Still, he loved her much more than any woman from his birthplace, and would've done anything to satisfy her, but if she had some more curves, maybe... Or perhaps there would come the day when there would be their future child in that belly.

His thoughts were interrupted by a kiss on the mouth, followed by, "I'm tired, I think I'm going to sleep."

“Already?” Nessar said with concern. “But, you just got up? Are you feeling well?”

She laughed. “I’m fine. Just eating a big meal like that made me a bit sleepy.”

So Glesheri left and went back to the bedroom. She collapsed on the mattress, with her long hair all around her. Glesheri closed the eyes, relaxed. She could use a little rest to digest all that stew.
12132.title: Glesheri, happily married to a Human

choices: The next day, Nessar gets the new food shipment. That should last them a while.
The next day, some of Glesheri's friends are out looking for her.
The next day, Nessar has a special surprise for Glesheri.
121322.content:
If there was one thing that Nessar worried about, it was that he feared he wouldn't be a good enough husband for Glesheri. He wasn't exactly like the typical male elves out there. He was a thin, scraggly scholar, not a strapping, muscular hunter, like what she was probably used to. He didn't even really hunt for their meat at all. Sure, he laid a few small traps for things like rabbit or squirrel, but mostly, he relied on the shipments of supplies his college of fellow scholars sent him for basic necessities, and even then, it was only enough stores for one person for a few weeks, not the two of them.

He really wanted to do something special for the two of them. She really deserved better than him, he thought. He peaked into the door of their bedroom, watching her sleep peacefully, with that same smile she always had. He would do anything for that smile.

He could still remember how they first met. He had been sent on a mission to document and study the elves of the Verge. The king was going to pay his college a fair amount to bring back information about this unknown species. Nessar thought he had a pretty good vantage point in the forest where he could observe them without being seen. That worked for a while, until he tripped and fell out of the bushes in a heap, right in front of her.

At first she was terrified, and she screamed and ran away from him. He felt awful having frightened her like that. Still, that hadn't stopped her curiosity, because she was back again within a week. This time, he came prepared, and tried to tell her he meant no harm. It took several days, but eventually, she gained the bravery to approach him and speak. Slowly, they had become friends. She would tell him about life among the elves, and he would tell her stories about humans.

She was always the brave one, he realized. Glesheri was the first to dare to kiss him. At first, it was just a quick peck, but they both knew it was something meant to be. Not long after that, they were seeing each other romantically, and before too long, he had proposed to her, wanting nothing more than to spend the rest of his life with the beautiful and brave elf. She eagerly accepted, but made him undergo an elven marriage ceremony in secret.

Nessar sighed to himself, thinking of fond memories. He walked to the small larder on the side of the house to grab the last of the flour. Today, he thought he might try his hand at baking some bread. Elves knew about that at least, when it came to food. They had had enough peace in their Verge recently to actually start growing some wild wheat.

The problem was, Nessar wasn't much of a baker. He could cook, or at least his wife told him he could anyway, but this required just a little more finesse.

A few hours later, he could hear Glesheri stirring. "Hey," he said, sitting beside her, stroking her hair. "I uh...tried making a little lunch, but it didn't quite come out right."

He held out a plate of roasted rabbit and some incredibly flat bread. Glesheri laughed and kissed his cheek. "Well, I think it's wonderful," she said. "And I am a bit hungry. So, what are you working on today?"

She munched on the food while Nessar spoke. "Well, I wanted to get started on the next chapter of my document on elves. You really helped a lot with that marriage ceremony. That was fascinating."

"Well, I hope it wasn't only for your research."

"Of course not, but it was nice to learn about. Anyway, I was hoping you could explain to me about the elders and the king."

She nodded. "I could try, though I don't get all that involved in politics. Besides, don't humans have a king?"

"Yeah, but it's kind of different. Finished already? You sure you're not still hungry?"

"Nessar, I'm fine, don't worry so much. You keep feeding me as good as this, and I'll start to get fat."

He chuckled and leaned forward to kiss her forehead. "You know, back where I come from, a fat wife is a good sign a man is successful. It means he makes enough to keep his family fed and then some. In some cases, it's a good sign his wife has had many children as well."

She giggled. "Thinking of children already?"

"Why not? Considering we've been going at it like rabbits these past few days, it's bound to happen eventually."

She got quiet and contemplative then. But eventually, whatever thought had gone through her mind passed on. "You're joking about that fat wife thing, aren't you? I still don't understand human humor all that well."

He stood up, heading for the door. "You don't believe me? I'll have to take you to Adinah sometime to see for yourself. Now, come on, busy day ahead of us, and you've slept halfway through it."

Glesheri stood up, and grabbed Nessar's arm, pulling him back towards the bed. "Oh, no you don't. In case you've forgotten, I've still got that newlywed glow about me."

He caught the seductive tone of her voice, and started reluctantly following her. "Oh, do you now? Well, what are we to do about that?"

"I can think of something."
121322.title: Anything for Love

choices: On the way Home, Glesheri meets a familiar face
Nessar keeps making larger portions and the food stock ends too early
1213221.content:
The next day, the sun rose in the sky and brought light to the Verge once again.

Glesheri woke up earlier, but her husband was nowhere to be seen. She dressed up and combed her hair as usual and went to the kitchen, where she found her breakfast: a bowl with mashed potatoes and some minced meat, plus a piece of bread made with the last of the flour remaining. There wasn't much more because the food stock was almost empty. That made her remember where Nessar went: to pick up the new food shipment that had to come that day.

Glesheri smiled at the sight of that nice, if little, breakfast. She found sweet that her husband found the time to prepare her breakfast, and she made sure to enjoy it. It was still warm, with steam wafting from the meat. Nessar must have left not long ago.

The breakfast was really good and Glesheri felt satisfied, too bad there wasn't more. She decided spend the morning working on the garden, but there wasn't much to do, so after not even an hour she dropped on the bed. She was getting into this habit of waking up early, eating breakfast, and going back to sleep. It was hard not to be tempted to do so. With a warm meal in her belly, finding very little to do in the mornings, and strangely feeling tired a lot, a good rest always felt nice.

A few minutes after Nessar was back.

"Honey, I'm home," said the man, opening the door.

Glesheri stood up and greeted her husband with a hug, and the tackle ended up knocking him on the ground. Nessar made a grumble of pain but Glesheri shut him up with a kiss on the lips.

"I missed you," whispered Glesheri.

"I only went to take the food shipment," replied Nessar.

"I know but it felt like it lasted a century," she said back, tightening her embrace.

"Ok, ok, I love you too," said Nessar gently pushing Glesheri. "Were you still asleep? I left a breakfast for you," commented Nessar, scratching his head, and noticing she came from the bedroom.

"I've already eaten it," answered Glesheri patting her flat stomach.

"And then you went straight back to bed. You want to eat and laze around all day?" said Nessar with a laugh.

Glesheri crossed her arms and made a pout. "Hey, I've also worked at the garden, but there wasn't much to do and I was getting bored."

"Yes, I know, I have to plant some new... oh, speaking of food, help me with the shipment," said Nessar grabbing his wife by the arm and dragging her outside, where there was a little wooden cart with six large boxes.

"My fellow said that since my research is doing well, they brought more food than usual," explained Nessar.

Glesheri placed an hand on Nessar's shoulder. "Did you tell them about our marriage?"

The man blushed and scratched the back of his head. "No, I simply told them I needed more stocks."

"Fine," said the elf with a whistle and went to take one of the boxes to find out she couldn't lift them.

"Hey, let me help you!" yelled Nessar running to help his wife.

"They're so heavy," commented Glesheri while taking the box to the free corner of the kitchen. "What did they have? Boulders?"

"No, but the food must last for a month." said Nessar.

They dropped the first box and Glesheri was already heavily breathing.

"C'mon, after we finish loading these, I can make you a human lunch as a reward," said Nessar with a smile.

Glesheri gave him a little kiss on the cheek and felt suddenly full of energy again.

------

Nessar had made lunch, and this time Glesheri observed so she could learn. Maybe one day she'd prepare lunch for her husband. She was interested in seeing how he was cooking the beef, a kind of meat that was almost unheard among the Elves, and was fascinated by how the grease poured out, making the meat reflect the light. She noticed how he handled the spices, tough she didn't remember them all, and could already smell a much better perfume that made her hungry. She also helped in the kitchen, peeling the remaining few potatoes and cutting a few carrots and boiling them all in a pot with water.

Finally, lunch was ready. Nessar realized how he, again, made more than usual, maybe because seeing all that stock of food made him use more and didn't think that the food had to last for an entire month. But he decided to let it go, next time he'd be more careful.

"Eat up!" said Nessar serving Glesheri a slice of beef almost larger than the plate, he kept the smaller one for himself. Only the best for his wife.

Thankfully, the elf didn't leave anything, and even ate all the vegetables.

"Satisfied?" asked Nessar.

Glesheri nodded. "But a piece of bread couldn't hurt."

"I'm sorry, but we are out of flour. The shipment didn't give me any. Apparently, there's a famine of wheat and they had to keep them for the people."

"Well, we can go and ask to the neighbor down the way, he's got a nice wheat field."

"Wait, we? You mean you and me?" asked Nessar with surprise.

Glesheri nodded with a big smile. "We can't keep this relationship secret forever. Sooner or later I want the other to see us"

Nessar patted her arm. He would like to make their relationship public, but remembered how the Elves watched Glesheri when the two interacted, and weren't even a thing yet. He didn't want his wife to become an outcast because of him.

"Well, let's make it later...?" he replied, still feeling unsure.

Glesheri rolled her eyes. "Fine, but I want a lot of bread for this evening then."

"Oh, really? And who was the one worried about getting fat yesterday?" joked Nessar.

"It's just a day off," replied Glesheri with a wink of her eye and sticking out her tongue.

-------

"Here it is, three sacks of flour," said a middle-aged elf, while a female elf of the same age, his wife, loaded the commodity on the little wooden handcart.

"And here's your salads," said Glesheri, passing the small green salad heads in exchange.

"Are you making bread?" asked the elf. Bread was something still new for the elves, who had only recently discovered wheat, and not many tried it, as it was a human's recipe, but the few that did liked it, and Glesheri was one of them. Actually, she loved how crust was crispy and the crumbs were soft.

She walked back home with the handcart behind her, whistling a happy melody, wondering what Nessar would make for her.
1213221.title: More food, happier couple

choices: Nessar tries to learn hunting.
The couple put a lot of effort into their garden.
They may have to ask neighbors again, but Nessar stays back.
12132212.content:
Nessar just couldn't resist. Frequently, he was cooking more than necessary for the two of them. Perhaps it was because he wasn't used to cooking. Back at his college, they had their own cooks, who saw to all their meals. So, he never had to actually plan or make anything himself. Not that he didn't know how, but he wasn't used to thinking about portion sizes.

The other problem was that he couldn't help but feel the need to make sure Glesheri was well taken care of. He still worried about not being good enough for her, and often made up for it with plenty of extra food.

Little did he know that Glesheri had a pretty strong appetite. Mostly, it was because she was so fascinated by human foods and wanted to savor them all. For as much extra as Nessar could give her, she found herself eating what he gave, and more if she could.

This came with a particular added bonus, for Nessar anyway. It was hard not to notice that Glesheri had started to put on some weight. Given her routine of eating large meals and sleeping most of the day, it was bound to happen. She had developed an adorable little round belly, her hips had widened with a little extra padding, and her sweet round face had developed a beautiful plump glow. Nessar especially liked cuddling with her at night as soft as she was starting to get.

Not that Glesheri had seemed to take notice. Either she hadn't realized it was happening, or it didn't particularly bother her. Nessar actually thought it was pretty good for her. She looked like a healthy, well-fed woman. He always did wonder how elves made it as thin as they were. It looked like they were barely surviving in his eyes.

However, all this did come with one small problem.

"Shit..." Nessar murmured to himself.

He had gone to the larder to grab the items needed in preparation for lunch that day, only to discover the inevitable. With all the extra portions he had been making, they had been going through their stores much faster than he had anticipated. Sure, he had expected that they would go faster than what he had planned. After all, the stocks were made for one person, not two. However, they had gone through it even faster. They weren't going to last another week like this.

He'd have to think of something, and soon. They needed a plan to keep going. And he knew this was something they needed to think about. They couldn't keep relying on food shipments and would need to figure out how to make their own way.

In the meantime, he'd have to tell Glesheri.

"I feel bad," Glesheri said after he had explained it all to her. "Maybe I shouldn't have eaten so much."

"You did nothing wrong," Nessar said, stroking her hand as they sat together, having this conversation. "The truth is, we're still getting used to living with each other, and that means we have to make a few adjustments. We'll get it figured out. We'll get into a rhythm that works for us."

"So, what are we going to do until then?"

He sighed, thinking it over. "I'm not sure exactly. Right now, we can go for about a week with what we have. And the next shipment wouldn't come in for another couple weeks, so we just got to figure out that last week, right? We'll come up with something. We always do work things out."

"True," she said.

Her tall ears drooped a little. Of all the things that had been a real eye opener to him was how elves used their ears like eyebrows: the movement of them conveyed a lot of elven emotions. At first it was really hard to read some of Glesheri's responses. He had to relearn communications all over again. But eventually, he had gotten the hang of it.

Right now, he knew that his wife was still sort of blaming herself, and felt disappointed. He squeezed her hand. "It's not your fault," he said. "We would've had to figure out these things anyway. I'm afraid if I don't start showing my fellow scholars some results, they're going to start cutting my funding. So, we were going to need to know how to start making our own way."

She smiled. "Okay, so what can I do to help?"

He thought. "We might have to try several different things. I might have to try my hand at actually hunting, meaning that maybe you could help me with the garden."

"What about our neighbors? Nessar, they will help us if we're really that in need."

"Correction: they'd help you, not me. We just have to be careful about that. Now, how about a little something to eat?"

"I suppose. Are you sure?"

He laughed, standing up. "Yes, silly. I'm not going to have you starve."

Nessar was more than happy to make another full meal for her, all the while wondering what they were going to do to obtain their food now.
12132212.title: Making Adjustments

choices: The others didn't like Glesheri and Nessar's relationship
The others were more supportive than it seemed of their relantionship
121322123.content:
"Thank you very much," said Glesheri with a little bow, making her long hair roll in the air.

"It's no problem, I'm sorry I couldn’t give you more," replied the old elf.

"Don't worry, two rabbits are more than enough," replied Glesheri, patting the elf's curved back.

She then went forward the next house, dragging the handcart behind her.

Glesheri and Nessar decided to ask help from the other elves in the village, and many were so nice they gave her food without even asking for something back. Maybe it was because it was a very prolific period, or maybe because the festival was in a few days, and the atmosphere that generated around it's preparations made everyone more generous. One thing was sure, no one helped her because they thought she was starving. While her new curves weren't noticeable, she looked a bit more padded than the average lean elf. She hardly heard the few whispers and murmurs of her neighbors as they speculated on these changes.

She would've liked to go asking with Nessar, but her husband was still afraid they wouldn't have trusted him, and maybe they'd have refused to give food.

Glesheri didn't complain, as she still felt it was her fault. For every meal Nessar made, Glesheri couldn't leave any leftovers, partially because she didn't want to waste his husband's work, and partially because she really enjoyed his dishes. Sometimes she was even tempted to ask for more, but didn't want to aggravate the situation.

While Glesheri's appetite played a role in the fast consuming of the food, Nessar's caring nature played an as big of one if not bigger. The young man knew he should've reduced his portions, but wasn't willing to do so; his wife was so happy when she was eating, and couldn't dare to give her less food than she was used to.

Thanks to the elves' generosity, Glesheri came back with the handcart filled with food. This would last for a week, but considering her husband's portions, she wasn't sure.

Nessar heard the sweet whistles of his wife while he was in the study, working on his research. As he needed more food for he and Glesheri to go on, he decided to work more; maybe this would convince the king to give him more stores.

"Already back?" asked Nessar with a surprised expression.

"Yup," replied Glesheri, jumping in Nessar's arms. While true, she was still small, he couldn’t help but notice that she was indeed heavier. "The cart was becoming heavy, and I think the food is enough for a while"

The two exchanged a long kiss. There wasn't a particular reason except that the two felt really happy.

"Did you seduce them to get so much food?" joked Nessar.

"Idiot!" said Glesheri giving a playful slap on his cheek. "How could I seduce anyone but you?"

"Well, you're natural beauty is enough to seduce anyone," replied Nessar, putting her down.

"Someone wants more cuddles tonight?" asked Glesheri in a seductive tone.

"It wouldn't be bad, but at the moment some help in bringing this stuff to the larder is enough"

Nessar grabbed a little sack with flour (good, more bread, thought Nessar) and what must have been a deer's filet, only to quickly run inside the house as if a vulture was ready to assault. Glesheri was confused by this act, but then noticed the neighbor’s head popping from the fence and realized everything. She sighed and grabbed the rabbits.

Once they brought all the stuff inside, Nessar noticed a sack of seeds.

"Hey, who gave you this stuff?" he asked to his wife, showing the sack.

"Romelia. I thought some seeds could have been useful for the future."

Nessar hugged her. "You're a genius! I'll plant them now, what are they?"

"They're bumblebeans; they grow pretty fast and are easy to cultivate," explained Glesheri with a proud smile.

"Wow, show me how to plant them then"

The two went to the garden, and planted the seeds in a remaining spot. New vegetables were definitely useful, as at the moment there wasn't anything that could've been harvested before the end of the month. Glesheri explained how cultivate them and how they could be cooked or used for medical purposes while Nessar took notes.

"Very interesting, I'll write about them in my research," commented Nessar.

"What about a chapter about Yva's festival? It's gonna be in a few days," asked Glesheri leaning against her husband.

"Sure, why not?" commented the man.

"Then, I guess you’ll come with me, so you can see it with your own eyes," proposed Glesheri, now face to face with Nessar.

Nessar became nervous. "I'm not sure it can work..."
But Glesheri, with a frown, interrupted, "We can't keep this a secret forever! You don't have to be afraid! I swear if they try to lay a hand on you, I'll kick them. Please, this festival is important to me, now more than ever. You have to come. It’s tradition for married couples to go and ask for Yva to bless them with children.”

"But what if they get angry at you? I don't care about what happen to me, I'm worried about you. Wait…children?"

Glesheri shut him up with a kiss.

"It doesn't matter what the others think of us," said the elf. "I love you, and if they can't understand our love, too bad for them. And, yes, children, silly. This will be our first festival like this together. I want to make it special."

Nessar was astonished, and couldn't say anything except kissing her again.

"Ok," said Nessar, "I'll come"

Glesheri smiled. "Perfect! I bet it will be a beautiful festival."

When they got inside, Nessar thought at first to continue his research, but then changed his mind and picked up the flour.

"To having the great idea of taking the seeds, I'll give you extra bread, this time with oil," said Nessar mixing the food with the water.

"Hey, go easy, boy. I don't want to run out of food again," said Glesheri.

"Don't worry, besides, I know you want it"

Glesheri didn't reply but took a seat while watching with glee as her husband made their meal. She didn't want to admit it, but he was right, and couldn't wait to eat this "bread with oil.
121322123.title: Festival in the air .

choices: Their prayers are heard. Glesheri is with child!
Their prayers aren't heard...yet. The couple keeps trying.
It seems the goddess isn't listening. Nessar worries there may be a problem.
1213221231.content:
"So, explain this to me again," Nessar said as he walked her to the center of the village for the festival.

She giggled, holding his hand all the way. "Well, a couple goes and touches the statue of Yva, and they both make a wish for how many children they desire. If both man and wife asked for the same number of children, Yva will bless them with their wish."

"Okay, so how many are you wanting?"

She shook her head. "That's not how it works. I can't tell you, or it won't come true. We have to know each other that well." She winked at him for emphasis.

He shrugged. "Oh, all right. I'll do it your way. Glesheri, are you sure you want to do this?"

Nessar was still very worried about how the other villagers would take it knowing they were now a couple. It was one thing when they knew he was an academic observer to their culture. They allowed him to proceed, but otherwise gave him the cold shoulder. So long as he left them alone, they would leave him alone. Now, this was another matter entirely.

She smiled. "Of course. We can't keep hiding forever. Nessar, I love you. I want to have a life together. I want to have a family with you. We can't do that if we're always in hiding. Now, come on."

She led him into the main center of the village. There were elves everywhere, visiting, talking, enjoying the abundance of food. New mothers were showing off the children they had had as a gift from Yva last year to friends and family. Children ran through the villages, playing games. It was all rather peaceful.

Still, there were murmurs and whispers as they began to take notice of him. They still didn't notice that he was married to her. For now, they assumed she was just showing him around. But, they would know soon enough.

Over the past several weeks of their marriage, Glesheri had been enjoying the flavors and tastes of human foods, but now, she spent a lot of time showing Nessar all the delicious foods elves had to offer. He couldn't help but enjoy her childlike wonder at the whole thing. It even took away some of his nerves.

It was as they got closer to the center of the village that those nerves returned. He knew they were getting close to the main event of this festival. "There," Glesheri said, pointing to the stone effigy.

Nessar had heard many tales about the goddess of fertility, yet he had never seen an artistic depiction of her until now. A few times, there were some statues or tapestries of gods like Araris or Ciros in Adinah, but Yva was a goddess of nature. She really had no place in a city.

The statue was of a beautiful elven woman, heavily pregnant, gently caressing her belly, awaiting the birth of the new life within her. He had always heard that Yva created the elves, and it never occurred to him that for that reason, she herself was depicted as an elf. That made sense now that he thought about it.

He watched as several couples approached the statue, touching the rounded stone belly of the goddess, sometimes leaving a small offering, and murmuring their prayers for the blessing of family. Glesheri nudged him. They were next.

He gulped, but followed dutifully behind her. But before they could get there, one of the elders blocked their path. "Glesheri?" he asked. "What is this? What are you doing here, with him?"

She took a deep breath before speaking. "Father, you remember Nessar: the man who wanted to learn about our ways."

Father? Glesheri never told him that. She had never once mentioned that her father was one of the high elders. "Um, Glesheri..." Nessar started to say.

She shook her head. Now wasn't the time, she was trying to say. Her father, meanwhile, only raised an eyebrow in suspicion. "Yes, and I'll ask again. What do you think you are doing with him right now?"

Glesheri was ready for this moment. "Nessar and I are married now. We intend to celebrate this festival to Yva. We wish to receive her blessing for children. Now, kindly step aside."

She had said this all so evenly as if it were the most natural thing in the world. He was impressed. Nessar was still to afraid to say a word.

Her father looked at both of them. "There is no way that you two are married. Glesheri, you are not thinking straight. You are far too young to understand such things. Now, step away from the human."

She shook her head. "No, he is my husband. I have undergone our marriage ceremony, honoring the gods. You cannot unbind us. Now, we are here peacefully to enjoy this festival. Step aside."

His lips pursed together in a frown. "And what do you have to say for it all, human?" he asked.

Somehow, Nessar managed to find his voice. "I...I love your daughter, sir, more than any other person on this earth. I would do anything for her. I will see to it that she is well-cared for. She has asked you nicely to let us through."

He stiffened, but stepped aside. "Know this: you are no longer my daughter. You are no longer welcome in the village. Expect no support and no sympathy from us, for you have betrayed your own kind."

If there was one thing that Glesheri had in common with her father, it was his stubborn nature. "I wished you could've understood," she said. "But if that is how you want it to be, very well."

She and Nessar walked on towards the statue.

* * *


That night, as the two of them lay in bed in their cozy little home on the outskirts of the village, Nessar was still worried. "Glesheri, I'm sorry," he said. "I never meant to be such a disturbance in your life."

She rolled over in bed so that they were facing each other. "I'm not made at you. I can never be mad at you. I just wish they could've understood."

"So, what's going to happen?"

"We're outcasts now, Nessar. I don't think they will disturb us here, but no one will help us anymore. We are on our own."

He sighed. "Oh..."

"But, Nessar, we can make it. We can figure it out. We always find a way to make things work. I'm not worried, so you shouldn't worry either."

He leaned forward, nuzzling her forehead. "You're always the brave one. But, I believe you. We can make this happen."

She smiled, embracing him closer. The truth was, she was very worried. Never before had she stood up to her people like that, to her father like that. And now, they were about to pay the price for it. But, she had to remain strong and sure that things would work out for the better.

"So, can you tell me now how many children you wished for?" he asked.

She smiled coyly. "I could tell you, but I think I'll keep it a secret. What about you?"

He smiled back. "I wished for however many you wanted. So, how about we start trying to help that along?" He wrapped his arm around her waist, while she giggled.
1213221231.title: Standing Up

choices: Being pregnant, Glesheri is much hungrier and eats much more
One day, when the couple is out for a walk, they gets mistreated by the elves
12132212311.content:
Glesheri was on her bed, digesting the large breakfast Nessar made for her. It had become almost a routine, but sometimes she tried to break it, offering to help in the garden, but a few times Nessar refused, as he didn't want his wife to tire herself.

Since the festival, Nessar had been very caring to Glesheri. He was sad that his wife was an outcast among her kin, as whenever the couple were seen together in the Verge all the elves watched them with disrespect and avoided contact, and so took extra efforts in taking care of her.

So, he worked extra hard in the garden and on his research, but most of all, the portions of food he made for her became even more abundant, with Glesheri more often than not finding her plate overflowing with food. He had done this despite their precarious situation, but Nessar sometimes even secretly skipped meals to make sure his wife was well-fed. Thankfully their garden's fruits and vegetables matured earlier, so they got a good stock.

Glesheri didn't mind this life, and ate all the rich meals made by her loving husband. She would also try some new dishes, like the roast chicken, another animal that didn't live in the Verge, though she didn't know that usually a person didn’t eat an entire one to themselves. And she was sure that her husband would've made her more once she told him the great news.

Naturally, all of this care brought some developments in Glesheri's body. She was starting to get chubby; her belly was becoming more prominent and round, while her hips got wider, her sides had started to get soft and flabby, and even her previously flat chest had started to develop a couple of bouncy breasts. Even her face had become a bit softer and rounder.

These changes were noticed by Glesheri, as she realized that needed to loosen the ribbon of her dress, but she didn't mind them, especially because they didn't seem a big deal. Nessar loved her the same as always.

Naturally, she wasn't the only one to notice it, as some of the other elves commented her chubbier form. She always felt a little down when she heard their rude whispers and murmurs about how plump she had started to become. Of course, Nessar couldn’t hear all of these comments, as his ears weren’t strong like an elf’s, but those he did hear, he would always lean in, kiss her, and tell her how beautiful she was. It was also nice when Nessar could feel all her new curves when the two cuddled in bed.

Speaking of Nessar, Glesheri recognized the squeaking of the handcart. That meant Nessar was back with the food shipment. She got up, without even bothering to comb her long messy brown hair and ran toward her husband, wrapping him in a big hug.

"Honey!" yelled Glesheri as Nessar squeezed her back.

"Hi, dear, did you enjoy your breakfast?" asked Nessar, picking her up gently. He could feel that she had gotten heavier. Thankfully she wasn't heavy enough to crush him, but she was also softer, as he could feel the cushion that was her stuffed belly.

"Yes, but then I went straight back to sleep," replied the elf with a giggle.

"You're really lazy," commented Nessar kissing her cheek.

"No, I’ve just been tired a lot lately. Besides, it's you who works too much," groaned Glesheri. "I think I need a hobby."

"Well, at the moment, you can help me with this stuff," said Nessar, slowly moving his wife away from him.

"Ok, then I have to tell you big news," replied Glesheri with a big smile.

"I'm curious to see," said Nessar, though he already had an Idea.

The couple unloaded the cart and brought the food in the larder, it seemed that even this month they sent more food than usual. However, Nessar knew he had to moderate his portions, or he would be soon unable to feed his wife.

Glesheri walked closer to Nessar, took his hands, pressed them gently to her belly and said, "Yva bleseed us. I'm pregnant"

Nessar expected that, and yet he couldn't contain his enthusiasm. A child. He was going to become father with the love of his life. When he was young he disliked the idea of having a family, and preferred be a rich scholar. But throughout his relationship with Glesheri, he changed his mind and actively desired to become the father of her children. Now that wish was becoming true.

He wanted to scream with all the air in his lungs, but contained himself and simply jumped around his house in excitement, until Glesheri caught him.

"I'm not quite sure, are you happy with this?" asked Glesheri sarcastically.

"Yes I am," replied Nessar before giving a long and passionate kiss. Then, Nessar's "husband instinct" kicked in, as he accompanied his wife to the bedroom. "But this means you must not tire yourself, or the baby will suffer."

"Hey, be quiet, it’s still early. I’m not an enormous, helpless, invalid just yet."

"You sure?" asked Nessar

Glesheri answered dragging Nessar with the bed with her, "Of course, but if you want, some company wouldn't be bad."

The two embraced in a big hug, and Nessar looked at his wife's protruding middle, where their future child was resting. It had gotten larger in the last week, and it was definitely too soon to attribute that to the pregnancy.

"I wonder what it will look like," said Nessar.

"Do you think it will have pointy ears like me?" asked Glesheri, moving her ears.

"I hope so; they're cute," replied Nessar, stroking them. Glesheri blushed and giggled, as the ears were a sensitive point for the elves and it tickled.

"Actually, I hope it will look like you; this way it will be beautiful," added Nessar.

"Because, are you ugly?" asked Glesheri.

"Compared to you, I'm like a dirty toad." And he kissed her forehead before getting up. "Well, if we want our child to grow happy and healthy, I have to work harder," he said before going to his study.

"Don't work too hard," said Glesheri from her bed.

"The same to you," replied Nessar from the other room.

Glesheri huffed. "As if I'm working hard," she commented, looking her bed. “But, I suppose you won’t mind a little rest, will you?” she said, patting the spot where she imagined their little one lay, and then she closed her eyes. It was too comfortable, only a little rest and then she would've helped Nessar.

When she woke up, Nessar was calling that the meal was ready. And she recognized the smell of pork stew from the bedroom.
12132212311.title: Yva's blessing

choices: Things start to look up. Nessar is able to get a nice bonus from the king.
The couple is able to get by. They just keep rolling with the punches.
Things get worse. Nessar is really worried about keeping Glesheri fed.
121322123112.content:
For the next few weeks, Nessar and Glesheri began making plans and arrangements for their new little arrival. True, she was barely past the first trimester, but it gave her something to do, and helped Nessar keep his enthusiasm at bay, and more importantly, kept him from being an insufferable worrier. He was constantly making sure that his wife was comfortable and well-cared for, sometimes to the point of being a bit annoying.

They began building a crib and making space for the new baby. Normally, in a traditional elven family, it was customary for the immediate friends and family to help with such things, but Glesheri still remained shunned and was no longer recognized as an elf. Not that she minded this fact. She liked the idea of her and Nessar working together for all of this. It made the situation that much more intimate.

She continued to eat well, not quite hitting the appetite of eating for two just yet, but starting to come close. In truth, if she had experienced any growth from her condition, it was a slight roundness in her lower stomach, nothing more. Though, she did continue to grow rounder all the same. She would perhaps be properly showing in the next couple of weeks.

In the meantime, the couple did have minor success. Their own home-grown crops were doing well, and with the shipments coming in every month, it seemed like they would be able to make due just fine. There would still be the matter of figuring out how to provide for a family of three later on, but for now, it was enough.

Today, the couple had gone out for a short walk in the Verge. There were still some plants that Nessar was unfamiliar with and wanted to study to add to his writings. Glesheri was more than happy to oblige. It was one of her favorite things to do with him, as that was how they first started conversing with each other. Plus, she liked how he treated her like such an expert on elven culture.

However, upon returning home, they were met with a horrible sight. Their garden had been completely torn up. Their fledgling plants had been completely uprooted and strewn about the ground. Bags of seeds had been burst open and strewn about. Everything was in ruins. "Oh, no," Glesheri said quietly, grasping onto Nessar's arm.

Nessar was at a loss for words. True, he knew they were no longer welcome in the village, but this was taking it too far. How could they do this? They weren't hurting anyone. They had left everyone alone. They didn't deserve this.

He looked around the area, hoping that there might be any clue about where they could have gone. He spotted their neighbor out working in his own field. His rage started to boil over.

Nessar started to march over to him. "Nessar, please," Glesheri pleaded, knowing there might be a problem.

He stood in front of their older neighbor, who was actively ignoring him. "Hey!" Nessar called. "Did you see who did this?" He pointed over towards their garden.

The older elf answered him gruffly. "Didn't see nothin'. Maybe that wouldn't happen if you and your whore went back to where you came from."

"Now see here," Nessar roared, "we haven't hurt anyone. I know you saw them. I can understand you ignoring us, but now you've..."

"No one asked you to be here. In case you haven't noticed, no one wants you around. Gods forbid you two start to breed like rats."

Nessar was about to shout some more before Glesheri intervened. "Please, there is no need for these hostilities. Come on Nessar, he isn't going to help."

"No one asked for your input, you traitor."

He shoved her roughly on the shoulder, and she fell back into Nessar's arms. He caught her before she could fall, but he finally lost all control and lunged at the elf.

* * *


"He was a lot stronger than he looked," Nessar said, as Glesheri started to apply a medicinal salve to his bruised eye. He was meanwhile, wrapping his bloodied hand.

"You didn't need to do that," she said. "There was no need for violence."

Nessar looked up at her, his rage still not mollified. "He hurt you," he answered shortly. "He pushed you. He had no right to... If you had fallen..."

She placed a hand on his shoulder. "But, I didn't. You were there to catch me. I am fine. I thank you for standing up for me. But, Nessar, we can't keep giving them more reason to hate us."

"We did nothing to deserve this."

She hugged him close. "I know, but the more we fight back, the more they will continue to do this to us. We can't let them see that it bothers us. We have to just keep going."

"And let them keep doing this to us? Glesheri, we can't just roll over and let them treat us like this." He placed his hands on her belly. "I can't let our child grow up treated like this."

She sighed. "I know, but we have to keep trying to make it."

He shook his head. "I suppose complaining about it isn't going to help. But, we're really going to be in a bind now. We were just making it on the food we had. this is going to set us back for sure."

She had finished bandaging him up and kissed his forehead. "We just have to keep working through these setbacks."

Glesheri hoped that was true. Right now, she wasn't sure, but she couldn't stand the thought of Nessar worrying about her even more.
121322123112.title: The Line in the Sand

choices: The couple moves to Adinah
Nessar asks the king to be moved somewhere else to study another race
1213221231123.content:
Nessar came back home with a dead rabbit. That day, he decided to go hunting, but wasn't trained for it and he could only come back with such a little mammal.

"Honey, I'm home," said Nessar.

"Hi, honey, how did hunting go?" asked Glesheri from the bedroom.

"Uhm.. it went," was all Nessar could say.

He dropped the rabbit on the table and joined his wife in the bedroom.

"How are you?" he asked her, patting her cheek. They had gotten a bit puffier.

"Fine, thanks. I worked a bit in the garden. The bumblebean will be ready for harvest in a week."

"And the baby?" he asked, patting her round belly. It was starting to properly round out as the weeks were going by.

"She's fine. This morning I didn't even feel sick," replied Glesheri, placing her hand over his.

"Wait, ‘she?’ Do elves already know the baby's gender?" asked Nessar, looking surprised.

"No," replied Glesheri as she kissed his cheek, and then whispered, "but I have this feeling she'll be a girl."

Nessar laughed, and gently patted her round belly. He imagined a child-version of Glesheri calling him daddy. He would've told her stories, played with her, given dresses and toys, and taught her many things. Then that little half-elf would be joined by another, and another and another, until Nessar found himself submerged by babies. He shook his head thinking that maybe he went too far in his imagination, but regardless of how many children he and his wife would've had, he would've loved them all the same.

After a brief loving moment, Nessar left the bed. "I'll go prepare lunch then," said Nessar while going to the kitchen.

"I'll be waiting," said Glesheri yawning and patting her belly. "I’ll bet you want a nice rest, huh?"

While Glesheri fell asleep, Nessar grabbed the rabbit and skinned it. He nearly cut himself a few times, as he wasn't used to it, but in the last few weeks he had to resort to hunting because the food wasn't enough. Or at least, it would've been enough if Nessar balanced the portions, but instead, he always gave Glesheri very rich portions and poor portions to himself.

He looked in the larder, but there wasn't much left. He grabbed just a pair of potatoes to use as side dish along with the rabbit. He sighed and gave a sad look at the garden. They managed to repair some of the damage, but there were only few plants left and nothing would be mature before they'd needed it.
He decided to not think about it and kept on cooking. He knew that Glesheri wasn't happy being an outcast, but his food always did bring a smile on her face. And recently he found himself getting better at cooking. Too bad he couldn't use all the ingredients he wanted.

----
