Turns out Nessar's promotion doesn't work out like he hoped.
121322123112312111113132.content:
The couple had much to catch up on. Nessar felt bad that he seemed to have the most to tell with all his time in the Naga city. But, Glesheri listened with wonder in her eyes and was absolutely fascinated by their culture. She didn't seem to mind at all.

"Anyway," Nessar finished, "I think with this last bit of research, they'll finally promote me to a Master, and from what I understand, most of my duties would be held at Bosch Keep. I wouldn't have to leave."

"That's good, then," Glesheri said, finishing the last bit of her meal. Or rather, meals, Nessar would argue. Glesheri had, by herself, managed to eat enough for three people at the tavern. He shook his head with a little laugh. "I mean, I'm glad you had fun and you got to experience all of that. But, I don't think we can go that long without you again."

She rubbed her stuffed gut, finally feeling full. Nessar glanced. Indeed, since they had come in, it had swelled outward, brushing against the table, and looked hard as a rock. "I can tell you missed me," he laughed.

"Eating helped me forget how much I missed you," she said. "I guess I didn't realize just how much bigger I was getting."

He scooted closer to her on the bench and helped her rub small circles, helping her ease the tightness. He leaned in and whispered in her ear. "You know, looking like this, it does remind me that we never finished our conversation on having more children."

She laughed and kissed his cheek. "No, I suppose not. I guess I wanted Nilinda to be a little bit older before we gave her siblings, but I wouldn't mind at least trying right now. If you are going to be here in the city now, it would be a good time." She sighed.

"What is it?"

"It's just...I don't miss the way people treated us back at the Verge, but I miss the Verge. I'm getting used to the city, sure, but it would've been nice for our children to see it just once, to know what all that fresh air and green earth felt like."

He rubbed her shoulder. "I know, and I would've liked that too. I'll try asking around. Maybe attitudes have changed after your princess married the king. Maybe we can visit once."

She wrapped him in a tight embrace. "I'd like that very much."

"But..." He could tell there seemed to be more on her mind.

Glesheri placed her hands on her belly again. "Well...do you like me being bigger? I mean, I've always known you love me no matter what, but is me being fatter something that...arouses you? I've kind of suspected, so I've been...sort of...eating more on purpose."

He sighed and gave her side a gentle poke. He was surprised to see that his finger sunk down to the first knuckle. "Well, I'm not going to lie, it has made you that much softer and warmer to cuddle. But, if we're being honest, yes, I guess that is something I like very much. When you're eating and I can tell how happy that makes you, it makes me happy. And, yes, I've always liked a girl with more meat on her bones. But, you don't have to go forcing yourself to eat to make me happy."

She laughed again. "It's not really forcing. I really do love eating. But, I thought if I ate just to get fat, it'd be nice. Plus, I guess, I kind of like it too. It's just...what if I got too big for you?"

"I don't think that's possible," he said, kissing the side of her head. "I love you no matter what. So, if you want to eat until you're as big as a house, I'd let you."

She raised her eyebrows in surprise. "I don't think anyone could get that big. But, I meant, what if I got too big to care for Nilinda, or any of our children? What if I was too big to even get up?"

He looked down, trying to think of his answer, and how to say it right. He had thought about that possibility, given his wife's appetite, and he had wondered what he would do in that situation. But, then, he had seen some of the Naga in their fattened, immobile states after rainy season, and the answer became pretty clear to him.

"It's like you've always told me: we'll figure it out. No matter what happens to us, we always find some way to manage. I'm not going to lie; it probably wouldn't be easy, but we'd find a way. I'll always be by your side, no matter what happens."

She leaned forward and kissed him. "I love you so much, right now."

He stroked her hair for several seconds. "I love you too. Now, I think Sorrna still has a few more hours with Nilinda. I think that's just enough time for a little time to ourselves." He winked.
121322123112312111113132.title: Tavern Talk

choices: To stay in Adinah, food is just too good
To move back to the Verge, she feels more at home there
1213221231123121111131321.content:
Nessar got used to the life in Adinah again, as very little had changed. The only differences were his new job as headmaster, Nilinda was able to crawl and not a little bundle anymore, and Glesheri was rounder with a larger appetite. But Nessar gladly adapted his portions to his wife's needs, and his new job allowed that without any economic trouble.

Still, Nessar could see that not everything was perfect for his wife, and it definitely wasn't the food, as she always ate until she was stuffed and then some. It wasn't her gain, as she even admitted to like it. It wasn't a lack of attention, as Nessar spent a lot of time with her. So, what was it? After a couple of days, Nessar got the answer: she missed home.

Adinah was a good place to live in for the elf. She was considered an ordinary citizen (even if they sometimes treated her like a pet, but it was definitely much better than being an outcast) and could eat all the delicious human dishes she wanted. But it wasn't the place she lived in. There were different traditions, different people, and different buildings. It was very different from home.

Once her husband caught on to that, he had a talk with the king, and it wasn't hard to convince him for into allowing a short trip. After all, Nessar was now a headmaster and it was thanks to his research that King Roland found a wife (and, according to some rumors, an heir).

So Nessar came home with a big smile, hoping Glesheri would smile too.

"Honey, I have a surprise," said Nessar.

Glesheri waddled to him, with Nilinda in her arms. "What is it?"

Nessar gave her a kiss on her lips and then said, "We're going on a small trip."

Glesheri felt confused. "Ok…where?"

"To the Verge!"

The elf was silent for a few seconds, almost stunned, and then said, "R-really?"

Nessar nodded.

At first, Glesheri was unsure, she didn't leave the Verge on good terms with the other elves, but then, nostalgia kicked in and she hugged her husband in a big squishy hug, along with her daughter, and thanked him.

"No need to thank me," said Nessar. "How many times did I tell you that I want you happy? So, don't worry. Now let's have a large dinner, and later we'll prepare our stuff for the journey."

So they had a very big dinner, which meant that all the extras went to Glesheri. The news of the visit at the Verge made her really happy, and it kicked up her appetite, so much that she didn't realize she had eaten enough for an entire family.

Then Nessar prepared their things, while Nilinda slept and Glesheri rested on the bed to digest all the food she ate. The elf patted her large and round stomach, wondering what capacity it would reach in the future.

-----

The next day, the family left home, and got on a cart toward the Verge. The journey was long, and Glesheri and Nessar and showed all the places they could see during the travel to their daughter, even though she was still too young to remember them.

Meanwhile, while Glesheri was at first excited, that feeling got mixed with worry, wondering if the elves would accept her or if she would still be considered an outcast. She looked at Nilinda with apprehension, hoping the best for her.

There was also the question of how they would react to her new curves. During her time at Adinah she gained new layers of fat, and while Adinah's women were large on average (still, an average smaller than what Glesheri had become), in the Verge the elves were willowy and slim, not even the half of Glesheri's current weight.

All this anxiety caused the elf to eat much more than usual, and even if Nessar was prepared enough to bring plenty of food for the journey, Glesheri dug through it in half the expected time. But her husband was understanding enough (if not downright happy).

After some weeks, they finally reached Pyknos Verge. Glesheri could see all the large and tall trees that caught the sunrays, while only some light reached the grass, could still recognize the traces left by a satyr who passed there not long ago, and could already smell the aroma of the most beautiful flowers, along with that of the sweet honey of the bees, which brought memories of some of the most delicious and juicy berries that grew in the forest, the sweetness of the fruits, and the tasty meat of the rabbits. All these memories, made Glesheri hungry, and her stomach rumbled, scaring poor little Nilinda.

"Sorry, Nilinda," said Glesheri hugging her daughter. "Mom didn't want to upset you."

"I think the first thing I'll do, once we arrive, is make a rich lunch," said Nessar, patting his wife's belly.

------

When they reached the Verge, they went back to their old house. Nessar and Glesheri recognized their previous neighbors, who also remembered the couple. The elves looked at the couple with surprise, some with curiosity and/or suspiciousness, but no one with disdain like they did before they left.

The house was left untouched, and it was all dusty. Nessar didn't waste any time to clean it up, while Glesheri slept on the bed, which seemed much smaller than she could remember, until she realized that it was she who had gotten bigger.

Finally, dinner was ready, made with elven ingredients that Nessar bought not long before arriving. It looked more like a feast than a dinner for a small family, and naturally, most of It went to Glesheri.

Once finished, Glesheri said, "You didn't lose your touch cooking with the ingredients of the Verge. It was all good, congratulations."

Nessar chuckled. "Are you sure it's not you who would accept anything edible?"

The elf blushed. "Of course not. For instance, I still prefer human food, but after so much time, it was good eating this nostalgic flavor."

"And what about Nilinda?" asked Nessar, pointing at the baby crawling around the house. "What would she eat?"

"Oh, we have a special mush made with a mixture of berries for the babies. But would probably have to ask the neighbors for ingredients," she said, the last line with hesitation. Would they lend them food again? She wasn't sure, but given their nicer looks, maybe it was worth a try.

She and her husband asked together, and, with great surprise, they were nice again, and lent a large bowl of the grains and berries used to make the dish. Apparently they had had a baby who was born not long after Nilinda. Not only that, they even apologized for their behavior from before, and explained how the reputations of the humans changed after the elven princess' marriage with the human king. The fact that it was necessary for such a big marriage to change their minds irked Glesheri, since she didn't consider it fair when she had such a loving one with Nessar that was disrespected, but it was better than nothing.

With this change in attitude, the couple could spend a wonderful week, where they could walk through the Verge without being judged. Glesheri could show her husband and her daughter some of the most beautiful places and buildings, and all in all, have a good time together.

"Did you enjoy it?" asked Nessar as he lay in the bed with Glesheri, while Nilinda was sleeping in a room next to theirs.

"The cuddles? Of course, though you tickle my hips too much."

"No, I was talking about the week here. And sorry about that, but I can't resist it," he replied, poking his wife's exposed fat again.

Glesheri giggled. "Easy, boy! Well, it was beautiful being at home again."

Nessar replied, "I see. If you prefer, we can live here. It won't tamper my job at headmaster."

Glesheri thought about it. She clearly loved the Verge; she spent most of her life there, and she wouldn't mind living here, especially if they could afford a much larger house. But at the same time, she had some friends in Adinah, and human food was really good.

In the end, she replied:
1213221231123121111131321.title: A visit back home

choices: Glesheri shops for a new dress, preferably something with room to grow.
Glesheri attends the king's feast. She's never seen this much food before.
Glesheri starts making preparations for their new arrival. Lots to do.
Glesheri takes it easy and continues her routine of resting and eating.
12132212311231211111313211.content:
"Come on, sweetie, come to mommy," Glesheri said sweetly, holding out her arms.

Nilinda was pretty good at getting herself upright, and could stand fairly stably. Moving her feet and staying balanced was another matter entirely, but she had been improving. Since coming back to the city, Nessar and Glesheri felt that their lives were finally on the right track. Things seemed to be going smoothly once again. Nessar went to work every day at the palace, and came home every night, able to spend time with his family. Glesheri had gotten comfortable in her usual routines, and spent most of her time caring for their daughter. She was getting old enough now that her mother had to keep a close eye on her.

She wouldn't have minded staying in the Verge. Life for their family there would have improved, compared to how they had been treated before. But, in the end, she had grown accustomed to life in the city, and was glad to stay there. Still, a few visits here or there weren't totally out of the question. Still, Glesheri had a life here that she genuinely enjoyed, and the food wasn't too bad either.

With a little struggle, Nilinda was starting to take her first few steps, her tongue sticking out of the corner of her mouth as she concentrated hard on walking. But, after the first few, she was able to walk to her mother's arms with relative ease.

"Look at that! You're walking now!" Glesheri exclaimed, picking her up, and holding her in a tight embrace.

Nessar came in shortly after. "Did I hear that right? Someone's started walking?"

"Yes," Glesheri said, "and pretty soon this one's going to be getting into all sorts of trouble, I'm sure."

Nessar came up behind his wife and helped her to her feet. In the past few months since coming back to the city, she had indeed gotten larger, as always, but this time, it was for different reasons. Glesheri got her balance, and placed a hand on the small swell of her stomach that hadn't been there before. "I get one walking just in time for another to come along," she said, kissing Nessar's cheek.

Indeed, not long after (and the couple suspected it had happened shortly before their visit to the Verge), Glesheri had gotten pregnant, and she eagerly awaited experiencing motherhood again. Nessar picked Nilinda up and patted his wife's shoulder. "That is the way of it, isn't it. But, I'm sure our little girl's going to be a wonderful big sister, isn't that right?"

"Sis, sis!" the toddler squealed, mimicking the sounds she heard.

Glesheri smiled. "I'm sure." Her stomach growled. "But right now, this one's making me hungry all the time."

Nessar had his doubts about that. His wife still ate quite a bit, as always, but she often liked to use the new baby as her excuse to eat even more. Still, he was happy to oblige, knowing he could never deny the rotund elf. As she ate today, he did notice that her dress was looking quite tight.

"You may want to consider going to town soon for a few new outfits," he said. "I believe this one's starting to look pretty snug." He rubbed a hand up and down her belly, knowing that commenting on her size got her in the mood.

She liked to tease him back just as much. "I don't know. I think you like it when my clothes are a little tight," she said, pulling him in closer for a kiss.

"Maybe a little," he admitted. "But, in all seriousness, you might want to consider it here soon. The king has invited me to one of his feasts here soon, and he said it would be nice if I could bring my family as well."

"Really? Oh, that would be wonderful!" she beamed. "I assume, then, that things are going well at work."

He shrugged. "More or less. I get to engage in whatever studies I want, and I hardly see the king. He only calls upon me when he's holding council and needs to make tough decisions. He's starting to think about making some arrangements with the nagas after he saw my research."

"Well, all the same, I'm proud of you. No more long trips though?"

He laughed. "I promise. Mostly, I get to read the work of other scholars on other races of Yndyre and come back to the king with my thoughts on it."

"Good then."

Indeed, Glesheri was happy to be back in the city. She had everything she needed there: a husband with a decent job, a family, friends, and all the food she could desire. She was quite content with this decision.
12132212311231211111313211.title: To stay in Adinah, food is just too good

choices: Time for the feast, and there's even more food than expected!
Time for the feast, but it seems there are problems
121322123112312111113132111.content:
Glesheri waddled through the streets of Adinah, feeling more at home than ever. She brought Nilinda with her in a pouch on her back and could hear the half-elf’s giggles behind her.

"Mum, bwed," said Nilinda, pointing at the bakery they were walking by.

"Wow, what an eye!" complimented Glesheri.

Obviously, the elf also noticed the bakery, especially because she couldn't ignore the smell of recently baked bread, but first she had another thing to do. For once, food could wait (hopefully, not for long).

Glesheri entered the tailor shop and found Mya, the tailor, busy sewing a blouse.

"Hi, Mya! It's me, Glesheri," puffed the elf. These long walks really were taking it out of her.

Mya raised her head. "Look if it isn't my favorite elf! Glesheri, how've you been?"

And she went to greet the customer in a big squishy hug. Mya was a portly woman with a round face and blonde locks. She was well-known in Adinah because of her large bosom (which very few men missed) and for being an extraordinary tailoress, especially when it came to larger sizes, something that came very handy in a city populated by women larger than usual. Even the king himself sometimes asked her to make some special clothes for his larger concubines.

"I'm fine, and you? How's business going?"

"Very well, recently I had another request from the king and... oh, but there's little Nilinda too," squealed Mya upon noticing the little half elf in the back pouch.

Glesheri put her daughter on a pouf in the corner. "Yes, recently I can't get a moment without staying close to her. She's growing into a little trouble-maker. Let's hope she wants to go to bed tonight."

"But how can such a cute bundle of adorableness cause any kind of trouble?"

"Do you want to keep her for an entire day?" joked Glesheri. "Anyway, speaking of the King, Nessar, Nilinda, and I have been invited to one of his feasts, so I need a new dress, and possibly one for Nilinda too."

Mya smirked. "Do you want something looser? With more space?"

"Why not? I'm waiting for a second child, so I definitely need some more room to grow," replied Glesheri, avoiding the blonde's eyes while pointing at her belly.

Mya nodded and giggled. She guessed that the elf would've grown baby or no. The first time she saw her she probably weighed half of what she did now. Heck, she could see the elf not-so-slowly becoming bigger than her. Probably not even the king's favorite concubines grew that fast.

"Ok then, come here and remove your clothes. I need to take your measurements."

Glesheri and Mya moved into another room, and thankfully Nilinda fell asleep, and the elf stripped herself. Mya's eyes bulged; that was definitely a lot of elf. She first measured her chest, each breast round and soft and as large as a child's head; then to the belly, and there Mya feared she would've needed a larger tape, but it was right enough for Glesheri's large middle, heaved in two by the tape around it, but offered some resistance thanks to the womb inside; then to the equally large hips, with each thigh nearly as thick as a slim woman's waist; and lastly, her arms, even those were covered by a layer of fat.

"Phew," said Mya. While not the largest woman she had met, the list of customers with lower measurements was probably longer. What surprised the tailor was her growing pace.

"Okay, I think it should be done in three days, is that fine?" asked Mya.

"Perfectly fine, and what about my daughter?"

"Oh, I should have some clothes for toddlers already done, let me show you."

After having picked a dress for Nilinda, Glesheri decided it was time for a "little" reward and visited the bakery.

-----

A few days later, it was the evening of the feast. Nessar was wearing the best outfit he had, while Nilinda was wearing a little dress with round sleeves and a large ribbon on the back. They were waiting for Glesheri, who was in the bedroom changing into her new dress. She brought it home two days ago, but Nessar couldn't see it. She said it was a surprise.

"Are you sure you don't need me to come and help?" asked Nessar. While his wife wasn't that big, he thought her new curves might be giving her too much trouble.

"No, it's ok. I'm nearly done"

Not long after, Glesheri came into full view with her new, emerald-green dress. It passed under her armpit, leaving the upper part of her chest exposed, with many knots around the waist and a large light green gown that came down to her feet. The dress didn't emphasize too much her curves; Mya thought of leaving a lot of room to grow, and it was larger on the belly. She also had a pair of elegant gloves which went up nearly to the shoulder. Her long brown hair was tied into a tail that reached past her hips and around her neck (the few that remained) there was also a golden necklace, Nessar's gift for her last birthday.

"Wow, you're... you're..." said Nessar dumbfounded.

"Beautiful?" asked Glesheri.

"No.... that would be an understatement... even more!"

"Well thanks, my dear," said Glesheri with a quick kiss on the lips, "now, we have a feast to go to."
121322123112312111113132111.title: The elves wears large

choices: Glesheri eats modestly, enough for her size, but not a lot compared to the women
Glesheri brought an appetite. She eats more than she had anticipated.
Glesheri is pretty ravenous. She is eating for two after all.
Glesheri's eyes are bigger than her stomach. She stuffs herself like a pig.
1213221231123121111131321111.content:
She could hardly believe it when she reached the palace. It was simply opulent, and it was quite clear the king spared no expense. The great hall was vast and decked out in the finest banners. Glesheri didn't even know buildings could get this big. Compared to this, the halls of the elven king seemed like a shack in the woods.

The king himself struck an impressive figure. He was a tall man with red hair, a beard, and a round gut. He too was dressed in his finest clothes, and Glesheri giggled to herself as she thought them a tad over the top.

"I see you're impressed with the palace," he said, bringing her out of her thoughts. "It's a look I'm quite familiar with. Many guests don't know what to say their first time."

Glesheri bowed slightly in greeting, and the king shook Nessar's hand. "So glad you could make it," he said to her husband. "I've been eager to meet your family. Contrary to what some might think, I do value the importance of familial bonds."

Nessar cleared his throat. "Um, yes, well, this is Glesheri, and my daughter Nilinda."

He beamed. "Wonderful. Nessar, I see you're a man after my heart. You certainly know how to keep a healthy-looking wife."

She blushed, letting her hands rest on the top of her dome of a belly. Nessar had at least given her some warning about the king's tastes, and that he may get a bit flirtatious with her as he had more to drink. While Glesheri had come to love her own size, she still found it odd that the king not only liked larger women but encouraged them to only get larger.

The king continued. "I apologize in advance, but the queen will not be able to attend tonight. She's recently entered confinement, and she cannot accept visitors."

"Confinement?" Glesheri asked.

"Ah, yes, elven customs are a bit different. What I mean is that she's incredibly far along in her pregnancy. During the last couple of months, a woman enters a confinement chamber where she can rest and remain comfortable until the birth. But, it is important that she is not disturbed. Only her midwife attends to her. I'm not even allowed in there."

"Oh..."

"Anyway, come, get seated, and the feast should begin shortly."

Nessar led his family over to the east side of the tables in the great hall. There, the family was able to find a comfortable spot. Glesheri was rather impressed with how wide the chairs were. Then it occurred to her that the king was probably trying to accommodate some of his larger concubines.

Speaking of, the elf got to see some of these immense women for herself. These women were far bigger than any of those she had seen in the city, and that was a lot of fat, quivering masses to take in for one night. Not all of them were human either, and Glesheri wasn't sure she could name all of the species present. The king did have quite the collection.

A few were so large they had to be hauled in on litters, unable to walk themselves. She couldn't help but stare at some of them. She had never seen anyone that big before. Still, they did not look like they were unhappy with their lot. Trading the ability to walk for all the food one could ever hope for seemed like a pretty good deal. Glesheri was tempted to laugh. She was probably the thinnest woman there.

Nilinda had taken notice too. She tugged at her mother's dress. "Mama, big!"

"Shh, don't be rude, sweetie," she said. "But, yes, they are...big."

Nessar winked. "I told you, you would be surprised with this place."

"It is something else," she said. "I never realized all this went on here. I don't think I could even imagine being that big."

He kissed her cheek, and rubbed his hand up and down her belly. "I don't know. The way you put away food, that could be you."

She laughed. "Stop, if I didn't know better, I'd say that was a challenge."

He shrugged. "No, you know I love you no matter your size. But wait 'til you see the feast."

And a feast it was. Plump serving girls began to bring out the dishes and set them out on the tables. There was just about everything imaginable to eat. There had to be at least ten different kinds of meats, and Glesheri was sure an entire farm's crops had to be out there, if not more. Adinah must be incredibly prosperous if they could afford to have these kinds of feasts and still be able to feed its people well.

As the tables filled with food, Glesheri began to realize that there was far more food than there was tablespace. Had the king over-prepared? She hardly doubted it. Likely, it wouldn't last long if his concubine's appetites were as big as they were.

The king, once again, welcomed all of his guests, offered a small toast, and commenced the feast. He wasn't about to let his women go hungry for too much longer.
1213221231123121111131321111.title: Glesheri Meets the King

choices: The castle's pantry. It was huge, and Glesheri was hungry again
The queen's room. Woops, maybe it was a wrong moment
12132212311231211111313211113.content:
Glesheri didn't know where to start. There was SO much food and so many different kinds that she couldn't tell what looked tastier. Then she got the idea: why decide when you could get one of everything?
She was a guest, after all, and the king would've been glad if his guests appreciated the food he offered.

So she began. First, she picked some of the warm bread with ham, a type of meat she didn't recognize but looked shiny enough under the lights to seem very good, some cheese and a bowl of minced meat.
After she filled all the reachable portions on the table with plates of "tasting samples", she proceeded to eat.

After her first bite of the steak, her taste buds where excited like they had never been before. It was really good, maybe even better than what Nessar usually made (though she would never admit it). Maybe the buttery sauce had something to do with it, and it didn't take long for the elf to finish her first plate. Then she went on to another, still meat, but this time of a different kind, which Glesheri recognized as beef that was amazing. Then she decided to eat something other than meat and went for the bread. It was crispy outside and soft in the inside and had black olives in it.

Glesheri ate and ate, without noticing, nor caring, how much she was eating. Human food always brought her great pleasure, and the elf was in pure bliss.

After a while, she had eaten all the food next to her, but thankfully the maids readily removed the empty plates and asked her if she wanted more, and Glesheri couldn't say no.

The elf didn't notice that she had attracted the attention of many guests, and even some of the concubines, many of the latter were surprised by the quantity of food the elf was eating, and they weren't slouching either (in fact, most of them were visibly fatter). Some of the concubines even began eating more to challenge the unaware elf, like a red-haired kitsune and a gorgon so fat that could barely move.

Meanwhile, Nessar was having fun watching his wife eating all that food while barely giving any care and playing with Nilinda, who was impressed by her mother's feat.

"Dad... where momma food?" asked the half-elf.

"It's in mommy's tummy," replied Nessar, pointing at Glesheri's round and stuffed gut, which was pressing against the table. Thankfully the dress Mya made had a lot of free space and could contain her.

Naturally, after a while Glesheri reached her limit, completely full, as she had never eaten that much before.

"Need any help?" asked Nessar, placing a hand on Glesheri's belly.

"N-no thanks. I can do it alone," replied the elf, who felt a bit embarrassed in doing that in front of the others. If they were alone she would've gladly accepted.

So, she massaged her round gut, and asked to the baby inside, "It's not too crowded out there, is it?"

"You sure have a big appetite, don't you?" commented her husband.

"Well, haven’t you been paying attention?" asked Glesheri. “In case you’ve forgotten, I love the food here.”

"Trust me, you've eaten almost as much as this before. If I knew you were able to eat this much, I would've made richer lunches," Then he started playing with Nilinda on his lap.

Glesheri blushed. "Oh, please, it's just the pregnancy." Though in her mind, she wouldn't have minded eating these meals at home, with Nessar helping feed her...

She began talking with one of the concubines, another elf, though she didn't look too happy about her lifestyle (and was probably the thinnest of the concubines, even slightly thinner than Glesheri), but she didn't want to talk about that, and in the meanwhile she snacked on a few things the maids kept bringing.

Then, after she more or less digested, she slowly raised herself from the chair and decided to take a little walk. Nessar would have come with her but was too busy with Nilinda.

While exploring the castle, Glesheri looked around. It was all so fancy and big, with knight statues that looked too scary for her and paintings of what looked like previous rulers, and she noticed how all of them were on the heavy side, especially the queens. Heck, some of those women had probably outgrown the already large throne.

She wondered how large this castle was, from the inside it was already huge, but now it seemed even larger, like a multi-floor labyrinth.

She even looked around for a maid as she felt like she was lost, and her legs were already giving up on her, despite the fact she didn't walk this much, and besides, she would have liked another couple of those sweet tarts.

After a bit of exploration, she found an interesting door. The elf knew she shouldn't open it, but the curiosity was just too much, so she opened it and found..

12132212313.content:
Nessar returned home as his usual routine had become. He was no longer a semi-welcome observer to elven culture. Many avoided him if they saw his presence anywhere near them. His work was starting to suffer greatly. Still, he was willing to accept all of that so long as Glesheri was happy. So long as they stayed in the Verge, in their small, but suitable home, everything would be fine.

But, all was not as well as hoped. He found her sitting by the hearth, a teary look in her eye. "Everything okay?" he asked worriedly. If anyone had caused her distress because of her marriage to him, they had better hope the gods took mercy on them.

"Nothing's working," she sighed.

He already knew what she meant. They had made several attempts to conceive a child over the past few months, and a series of failures was becoming increasingly frustrating for the two of them. Glesheri especially was becoming upset by it, as if she felt it was somehow her fault. He scooped her up in a comforting hug.

"It's okay," he said. "Our luck will turn around soon enough. Gods willing, we'll have more children than we know what to do with."

"But what if the gods aren't listening?" she sobbed. "What if..."

The door flew open as a strong gust of wind struck their home. The sky had seemed to turn several shades darker as well. Standing on the threshold of their home was a dark, hooded figure whose face was concealed by their dark cloak. Nessar instinctively shielded his wife. "Who are you?" he demanded.

The figure ignored him, strode into their home, and took a seat at their table. He removed his hood, revealing the face of an old, withered elf, whose skin was as pale as the snow-capped mountains and hair dark as a raven's. He was a dark elf of the north. His face was worn and weathered from blistering winds, and ugly scars crossed his face. He was hard to look at.

"Who are you?" Nessar asked again, his voice rising to sound more intimidating.

"The gods aren't listening to you," the dark elf said, grabbing a leg of rabbit from their dinner table and proceeding to eat without their invitation.

Glesheri was curious by his statement. "What do you mean?"

He gave a chiding laugh. "You're an elf who married a human. Of course, Yva isn't going to bless you with a child. After her first failed marriage with a human, she's always had it out for them. She isn't going to help someone who betrays their people, like you."

Glesheri wilted at that. Now that she thought about it, he was right. She had heard all the tales. Yva had been gifted with the first man to be her mate, and he gave her the twin gods, Ardoid and Enkoia, but he wasn't true to her. She turned him into a deer as punishment and removed all human qualities from her children. She hated man ever since.

Nessar was still fuming at the arrival of this stranger who only proceeded to upset his wife further. At the same time, his scholarly personality drove him to question further. "So, then, what are we supposed to do with that information?"

He let out a raspy wheeze and wiped the meat juices from his chin. "You're going about it all wrong. You want a child? You don't go to some holier-than-thou goddess who has it out for you. Let the bitch stew in her hatred." The couple winced at how easily the dark elf cursed a god. "I'm saying you need to seek out other sources."

"Such as?"

"I think the goddess of the dark elves will lend a more sympathetic ear. She doesn't care who you are or who you're married to?"

"The goddess of the dark elves?" Glesheri asked. She had never heard of such a thing.

He smiled wickedly. "Glustra."

Glesheri gasped. Nessar was now more confused than ever. "Who's that?"

"She's...she's Yva's...'shadow,' I think is the right word. A demon," Glesheri answered.

The dark elf scoffed. "Demon is just what you 'high and mighty' elves call something that doesn't fit your perfect worldview. But yes, she is another side to Yva, her opposite. She's much looser in her morals. I think she's just the person to help you."

"How?" Nessar asked.

He chuckled. "Don't you worry about that. You look hard enough for her, and she'll make sure you find her hut."

And with that, their mysterious guest skulked out of their home as mysteriously as he had appeared. The couple was still pretty shaken by the event.

"That was..." Nessar began.

"Should we?" Glesheri asked.

"Hm?"

She stopped to carefully pick out her next words. "Should we seek Glustra out to help us? It feels dangerous, but it might be our only option."

"Something doesn't feel right about all this. That guy, he just happened to come here to help us with our problem? No, something doesn't add up. But, if you really want it, I'll go with you. We're in this together."

She thought for a moment. There was so much danger in this situation. Nessar was right, this was all too convenient. There had to be something up. At the same time, the reward was too great.

121322123132.content:
"You sure this is what you want?" Nessar asked as they walked through the forest.

Glesheri had decided with conviction that she was willing to do whatever it took, and after a day of planning and gathering materials, they had set off in the forest in search of Glustra's hut. Really, they had just started off in one direction, hoping to come across any kind of a sign, having no real idea of how to find her.

"The man was right," she said, following behind him. "Yva would never help us. If this is what it will take for us to have a family, then I'm willing to try."

"But at what cost? Glesheri, I don't think she's just going to give us children out of the goodness of her heart. If I know one thing about demons, it's that everything has a price with them. At least that's what all the legends say."

"But maybe she's not a demon like he said. Maybe we've just been looking at it wrong."

Nessar didn't argue with her any further. She was determined, and there was no stopping her. They were quiet for some time. And, for quite some time, they weren't sure if they would ever find this hut. After all, they were just wandering around nowhere hoping to find something. But, at long last, Glesheri spoke.

"Do you even want children?" she asked hesitantly.

"What?"

"Do you want children? Is that why you're so unsure about this plan?"

He stopped and took her in his arms. "Of course, I want children. I want as many as you could ever wish for. Glesheri, I love you, and nothing would please me more than having a family to share that love with. But...I just feel we're getting into some dangerous territory for it. Look, in all the stories I've heard, forces like Glustra only want one thing: to torture mortalkind. They hide behind this visage of wanting to help people for the right price, only to make them suffer. And that's the last thing I want: to see you suffer."

She looked like she was thinking deeply, really considering their options. "But, if we don't try, then we don't have a chance. I'd rather suffer and at least believe there is some hope rather than just suffer."

He sighed. "Okay then, I support you."

Glesheri looked up from her embrace with him. "What's that over there?"

Looking behind him, Nessar saw it too: a faint light in the distance. Feeling a sinking sense of dread, he had a feeling. The couple walked towards it, getting closer and closer. Upon their approach, they saw it was a large but simple hut in the middle of the woods, with smoke emitting from the hole in the roof, and the faint glow of a fire from a window. This had to be it. There could be no other explanation.

Swallowing hard, the two dared to enter the doorway. Upon entering, they realized they had to be in the realm of an otherworldly being, for the hut itself was much larger on the inside than it appeared to be on the outside. In fact, it looked like one massive great hall, larger than that of the king of the elves. A long table stretched out around the room, food everywhere. And off to the sides, they could see several doors that must lead to other rooms.

But that wasn't what drew their attention the most. All around the great table were dozens of humans, elves, and other people in Yndyre, if they could be called people anymore. Rather they were just rounded, blobs of flesh, devouring any food that was within reach. They were like pigs at a trough, eating with abandon. In fact, it seemed that they really had no capability of thought beyond pressing food into their mouths. Whenever one would run out of food within reach, they would scramble about blindly, grabbing at air until one of the lithe, beautiful dark elves who served the food would bring them more. No, they weren't dark elves proper, but ethereal somehow, as if they didn't really exist, at least not fully.

Sitting at the head of the table, all the way at the other end of the hall was a rotund creature. She was elvish, at least that much they could tell, but her tall ears looked like they had been gnawed at by a wild beast. She wore crude animal furs about her. Though she was not exactly a pile of flab like the mindless creatures who feasted at her table, she was massive, looking to be one of the largest women any of them had ever seen. Her gut looked round and taut as if she were with child, it was clear that her shape was a result of her gluttonous eating. Unlike her "guests," this woman ate with some refinement, but otherwise devoured food as fast as they could, her mouth salivating with blood at each bite.

She quickly noticed her two guests in the room, and motioned for them to come forward. "I was wondering when I would expect you two," she said, taking a minor break from her feast. "Glesheri and Nessar, the couple who shocked the Verge. An honor it is."

Nessar was dumbstruck, but Glesheri was brave enough to speak. "So, you know who we are and why we're here."

She shrugged. "Not so hard really. All who truly desire to find my lair will find it eventually."

"So, you're Glustra?"

She smiled. "You got it."

Nessar was still looking around at the flabby creatures. "Who are they?"

Glustra gave an even toothier grin. "They are also people who found my halls, and decided that staying here was better than the outside world. Most are lost travelers, a few curious souls, and some like you, who thought they knew what they were looking for."

Glesheri was undeterred. "We know exactly why we're here."

"I'm sure you do. Yva certainly has been cruel to the two of you. That bitch has always had it out for humans since her mate. Of course, if she only knew a thing or two about pleasing a man, he wouldn't have run off on her."

Glesheri was hopeful. "So you'll help us?"

"On one condition..."

1213221231322.content:
"You must pass a little test of mine, a wager really," Glustra said.

Nessar was suspicious. He had expected this kind of thing to happen. "What kind of test?"

The demon took another bite from the piping hot meat she was holding. "Well, if there is one thing Yva and I do agree on, it's that men are unfaithful by there very nature. I'm just less discriminating than her and say it applies to all men, not just humans. But nothing would please me more than to see that smug elf be proven wrong, even if that means I'd be wrong as well. So, let's have a little wager, shall we? Here's how it works. Glesheri here will stay with me in my halls for an entire year. I really don't give a damn what you do during that time, but if you so much as look at another woman longingly during that time, you lose, and she is mine forever. But, if you really do love her and are true to her, then I will grant you both your wish. Her womb will be opened, and you can have as many children to your hearts' content."

"A whole year?" Glesheri gasped.

She shrugged. "If you don't think you can handle it, then be on your merry way and get out. I'm sure you're way of trying to have children before was working so well." She chuckled maliciously.

The elf turned to her husband, a determined look in her eyes. Nessar wasn't as confident. "You can't be serious," he said.

"Nessar, I trust you, and I know you would stay true to me. That means we have nothing to worry about. We can do it."

He clasped her shoulders. "But...but, a whole year without you, and what if Glustra goes back on her promise?"

The demon spoke up, clearly able to hear them, despite their whispering. "A shadow's word is binding. Even if I wanted to torment your pathetic souls, I've already promised you, and there are grave consequences for me if I don't adhere to them."

He still felt unsure about it all and was desperately trying to find some way out of it. He would do anything to talk his wife out of this. Nessar looked around the room again, the overweight beings still deep in their gluttonous daze. He had a feeling there would be more to this than meets the eye. "Please," he said, "this is dangerous, and I'm afraid of what'll happen to you."

He saw a fierceness come over Glesheri that he had never seen before. "Do you love me?" she asked.

"Of course."

"And do you trust me?"

"Absolutely, but -"

"And do you want a family with me?"

"More than anything, but Glesheri, let's think about this."

She shook her head. "There's nothing to think about. We can succeed in her test, and we'll be able to start our family. Nessar, I wouldn't do this if I didn't think it was our only option. But you heard that man the other day, and you heard her. The gods are working against us. If we don't do this now, I don't think we have any other chances."

He let out a long, drawn-out sigh. "Okay, yes. Let's do it."

Glustra smiled from her perch. "Excellent. So, it shall begin. As of now, Glesheri belongs to me. You shall return to this hut in one year's time to retrieve her, Nessar. And remember, I will know if you've ever been untrue to your dear, sweet wife."

One of the ethereal beings began to escort him towards the door. He kept his gaze focused behind him, trying to get as much of a last look at his wife as he could. He would never see her again for an entire year. He wasn't sure how he would be able to go on. As the wooden door shut behind him, he could see Glesheri give him one last tearful look of goodbye, but he also detected a hint of hope in her. He prayed she knew what she was doing.

"Hmpf, seemed awfully eager to not let you do this," Glustra said. "Makes me wonder if he questioned his own faithfulness."

Glesheri turned back to her. "I'm not going to let you get into my head. Nessar loves me, and he will return just as true to me as he is now."

"We'll see about that, my dear. In the meantime, you are in my halls, which means a welcome feast is in order. Go on now, sit."

Despite how confident she had appeared, Glesheri did feel a sense of unease about all of this. She cautiously took a nearby empty seat at the great table.

And at that moment, it was as if something possessed her. It was like her mind had only one command: eat. She began grabbing foods left and right on the table, eating with relish each delicious bite. She wasn't going to deny that the demon had a knack for amazing food. But after a while, the command in her brain urged her with new thoughts: more and faster. Pretty soon, she was hardly chewing on any of the food and found herself gorging for the sake of putting only more in her mouth. Yet all the while, a part of her knew this wasn't normal.

Glustra smirked as she noted the slight hint of fear in her eyes. "Confused? I imagine you would be. You see, Yva is the goddess of fertility and plenty. She only gives. I only take. I am mistress of gluttony and instinct. Any who enter my halls are possessed by a spell that lets you give in to your baser instincts. It's quite amusing really. And this is about to be your future for the next year...more, if I'm lucky."

For the next couple of hours, all Glesheri did was gorge on the bounty Glustra offered. But then when her hand went to reach for more, she found she had been restrained by the ethereal servants, who began trying to heave her away from the table. The spell pushing her on, she continued to try and reach, frustrated by her efforts. Glustra finally came down from her perch and looked the elf over.

"I appreciate the enthusiasm, my dear, but I'm not about to let you eat yourself to death. I do have a bargain to uphold, you know."

Glesheri followed the demon's gaze and saw her own stomach outstretched and taut, wobbling and quivering in protest for her not to eat another bite. Glustra poked her finger into it, finding there wasn't even an inch of give left. "Yes, that'll do for now. Don't worry, my dear. You'll find that as the days pass and this tiny little stomach stretches just a little more each day, you'll be able to stay at my table longer."

12132212313221.content:
Every day was quickly becoming a routine for Glesheri. She was brought to the great hall where she would eat until nearly burst, only being held off by Glustra's servants. She would be brought back to her quarters in the hut, one of the many, many rooms in this magical structure, where she was expected to rest and digest. And after a while, she would be brought back to the halls to do it all again.

The spell that possessed her never ceased and clouded her mind very easily. When she was resting in her room, her mind was plagued with thoughts of more food. The spell only commanded her to eat, and never let her own instincts tell her when to stop. She had to always be forced away from the food before she could cause herself harm. And when she wasn't near the food, her brain made her crave it thrice more.

But each day, as she gorged herself to near bursting at every opportunity, her stomach stretched just a little further, meaning that the next time she returned to the table, she was able to eat for longer periods of time. At the moment, she still ate a regular three meals a day, as she still did not have the stomach capacity to eat like the other mindless slaves at the great table. Glesheri wondered about them, who they had been, and if there was any semblance of the person they were still in those dull, lifeless eyes.

And every day, once she had been pulled from the tables, gut full and taut, Glustra would inspect her, marveling at her increased size day by day. "Certainly are coming along well," Glustra finished one day. "Of course, you did have quite a bit of an appetite before you came here. You were a little chubbier than I'm used to seeing elves." Her fingers grazed the shiny, red, swollen dome of her belly.

Glesheri winced. Even though the demon had agreed to help them, she still felt uncomfortable around her, and didn't take to kindly to being touched. Instead, she asked a question. "What has happened to them?" she said, nodding over to the piles of flesh still gorging. "Are they possessed at a state worse than mine?"

She laughed. "Hardly. They started out pretty much like you. But, the longer the urges took possession of them, the more inclined they were to give into them. After a while, they just became what they truly are: animals. I find it rather humorous that you mortal beings think yourself so advanced and mighty. It's even funnier that the gods think that because they created you, you are more gifted than any other lower creature. But, I have proven you are no more than sacks of flesh that behave just as any other creature in the wild."

"Why would you do this?"

"To prove my point. Haven't I just explained that?" she said with a huff. "But, if we're being totally honest, I like doing it just for the amusement. You have heard of the king in the central region and his women, yes? He's got nothing on me. You haven't even seen all of them. Some are so large, they can no longer be taken here to the halls. They just lie in a fleshy pile in their quarters, waiting for my servants to feed them. It's quite fun."

Glesheri was becoming more and more worried. "You don't...you don't..." she stammered.

"Eat them? Of course not. I'm not like those vampires in the north, fattening up their victims for sustenance. It's just fun watching you mortals act like the dumb animals you are. I can assure you, though, they never suffer. They die natural deaths in pure, gluttonous bliss."

"Is...is this to become my fate as well?"

Glustra gave her a toothy grin. "After only a year? No, my dear. Your mind will still be intact, if not just a tad slower-witted, but those effects would wear off upon your return to the mortal realm. That is, if you get to return. However, I must admit, that is what makes it enjoyable right now. It's been so long since I've had a newcomer I can actually converse with."

Glesheri shook her head. "Nessar will come back for me, and I will get to go home. You won't get to enjoy my company for long."

The demon laughed. "My dear, you forget that I've had much, much, much more experience on this world than you can ever hope to imagine. I think I know just a little more about men than you do. It'll be a shame to no longer have someone to talk to as your mind dulls, though."

"You don't know him," Glesheri said with conviction.

"We'll see about that."

121322123132211.content:
And just as quickly as he had been forced out of Glustra's hut, it disappeared once more in the forest. Nessar had no idea what to do with himself. He would never see Glesheri again for another year, and he had no idea what kinds of horrible things could happen to her while she was in the demon's care. And the worst part of it was that there was nothing he could do about it. He simply had to wait, a long agonizing wait.

He took a few deep breaths. He had to remain calm, he kept telling himself. If he lost his head now, he wouldn't be able to help her. He had to think. Nessar knew he would remain true to his wife. He could think of loving no one else. But, he had a sneaking suspicion that the demon's deal wasn't all it was cracked up to be. Chances were, there would be a trap lying in wait somehow, someway.

Where would he go for an entire year while he did nothing but wait? Nessar considered going back to Adinah, back to his college to continue his studies to take his mind off of her loss. But, Adinah was filled with people, including some of its buxom women of the night. Not that he would have been tempted, but what if Glustra or one of her minions used that as a disguise to try and sabotage them?

He couldn't go back to the Verge, especially not without Glesheri. The elves already hated him enough. There would be no way they'd let him back into their civilization as a human.

For the first several days, Nessar stayed in the woods, living off of what supplies he had and a little bit of hunting and fishing. For a while, he considered that as a possibility. He could just live as a hermit in the woods. He'd be far away from any female temptation and he would not be intruding upon the elves' territory. But, he knew that couldn't last. The Verge was located where it was because it was an area plentiful with game and wild plants to eat. Out here in the middle of nowhere, there was almost nothing.

And to top it all off, he was lonely. He could have endured any trial so long as Glesheri was by his side. But now, he had nothing. She was far away in essentially some other realm, and he would not be able to see her again until he had waited out the full time. He wasn't sure he could make it. He was now a man with nothing. The only thing that could make his will strong was knowing that he could see her again, but right now, at the very start of this task, with a full year ahead of him, that seemed near impossible.

After staying in the woods for a few days, Nessar knew he had to go somewhere.

1213221231322111.content:
Nessar decided to make his way north. He had heard that the small villages there were sparsely populated, but at least he would be near civilization of some kind. And, as he understood it, young women were in short supply there as well, for some reason he didn't know, but at least it would keep him away from temptation.

Yet, it wasn't an easy journey. It was actually quite a distance to reach the northern lands from the Verge. He still had to spend many days living off of whatever he could find in the woods as he journeyed on. And the further he got from the bounty of the Verge, the harder it was to find fresh water and a bit of food.

But at long last, he did start seeing the northern lands. They were far more barren looking than those of the forests he had just come from. It was colder, as he had expected. But it was also simple. The few villages he saw sprawled out in the north were simple, the people living off of what little they could grow and the livestock they raised.

He found a simple inn where he was able to come by a cheap room and a few warm meals. Supposedly, its young cook was amazing, and he had to agree. If anything, the rotund inn owner was proof of how good she was. After a few days of just resting after his long journey, he decided to try and find a little work to keep him busy and to keep his room and board.

While the north wasn't a fertile oasis, it did have enough grassland to make it's living off of livestock. In this part of the north, there were mostly sheep farms. He took up work at a small farm, run only by a man with his two sons. They were eager to have an extra set of hands to help. They couldn't offer much in the way of wages, but it was enough to keep going.

For a while, everything worked out rather nicely. He was working. He had a place to stay, and so far, nothing suspicious had arisen as far as temptations went to try and sway him away from his wife. He was still certain Glustra would try something. That is, until he learned the truth of why the north was so sparsely populated.

It had happened so suddenly one evening as he was finishing sheering the farm's sheep. The people of the village went into a frenzy as the sound of carriage wheels could be heard in the distance.

"What are you doing, boy?" Bessel, the farmer's owner shouted. "Get inside!"

Confused, Nessar followed him inside the house as he bolted the door. He and the farmer's two sons sat quietly in the house, Nessar still unsure what was going on. And despite all the silence between the group, he spoke. "What's going on?"

Bessel shook his head, muttering, "The vampires. They always come here ever few months."

"Vampires? But, aren't you going to do something about it?"

The three men laughed. "You might as well stop a river. Those vampires are the power around here. They protect us from the other dangers out there, and from any attacks from other regions. In exchange, they take their dues."

"Which are...?"

Bessel gave a weak smile. "They protect us, in exchange for the young women of our village. They take our daughters in the night, grabbing any who catch their eye. Gods know what happens to them once they disappear."

Nessar stuttered out a few words, still in disbelief. "But thats...why would...don't you try to do anything about it?"

"What did I just say, boy? You don't stop them. All we can do is continue to live on, hope some of our women stay with us long enough to marry and have children, and keep this place going. There's nothing to do about it. Right now, one of them is out there inspecting all the young women, deciding on how many to take this time. It's the natural order around here."

Nessar stood. "There's nothing natural about that. I have to..."

He started making his way for the door before Bessel's two sons restrained him. "You're not doing shit," he said. "We've got a good thing going in this village. They leave us alone so long as we give into their demands. They don't bother us, and we don't bother them. You stay out of it."

Nessar hung his head and sat back at the table until they had decided the ordeal was over. He returned to his rooms and slumped into bed, wondering how this village could live under such tyranny.
1213221231322111.title: North

12132212313221113.content:
Glesheri easily lost count of the days, and she wasn't even sure if there was a passage of days in this realm of the demon. There were periods of rest between her gorging sessions, and that was all she knew. But, as she grew and her stomach demanded more and more to be filled, the time between those rest periods was getting longer and longer, so she had no way of knowing how long she had been here.

That filled her with a sense of dread. If she could just know how much longer she needed to be here, how long it would be until she could see Nessar again, then she could maybe have had the will to keep going, to keep fighting through this. But, of course, there was no way Glustra was going to let her know that information. Whenever the demon wasn't eating herself into a gluttonous stupor, she was taunting the elf, trying to break her. She wanted to give her reason to doubt her husband, to taunt her into believing he would fail in his task.

"That's right, my pet," she would say. "Keep eating. He won't be taking you back with him. You'll just stay here, growing nice and round for me."

And indeed, Glesheri had gotten quite round as the time passed. She could see it every day as she looked down at her swelled belly. It's circumference was slowly getting larger by the day, or whatever passage of time there was here. She could see how her arms had gotten puffier, her hips wider, her chest softer. And she could feel how heavy she had gotten. The walks from her quarters to the halls to eat had gotten harder and left her more exhausted and hungrier than ever. Every waddling step was getting more and more difficult. It made her begin to wonder. Even if Nessar did succeed and returned for her, what kind of a state would she be in?

And eating was getting harder as well. With her belly pressing up against the table more often than not now, and her pudgy arms having gotten heavier, her efforts to shove more food in her mouth were becoming increasingly difficult. Yet, Glesheri wasn't about to go the way of Glustra's other prisoners, who ate like pigs at a trough. She wanted to retain her sense of personhood as long as she could. She wasn't about to give in and become an animal like them.

But, that gave the demon more fuel to taunt her with. She noticed the elf struggling to grab a piece of meat.

"Poor thing, let me help you," she said in her best feigned concerned voice. She then proceeded to hand feed Glesheri herself, the elf unable to resist, thanks to the spell. The demon laughed. "My, you are coming along quite nicely."

She stroked her fingers across the dome of Glesheri's nearly full stomach. She was nearing that point in the day when she would be too full to eat another bite and needed rest. Glustra rather admired her work. The little elf wasn't exactly scrawny to begin with, but she had blossomed magnificently into a ball of fat rather quickly, at least faster than she had expected. At this rate, she'd be lucky to still be standing at the end of the year.

Glesheri squirmed at the demon's touch. She knew that in her full state, she was really powerless to stop her, but that didn't change how uncomfortable she felt.

"You know, it would be a lot easier if you just ate like them," Glustra said, nodding over to the animal-like beings, who seemed as though they never left her tables. It was as if they had gotten so large, that eating was all they did, that they didn't need to stop and rest like she did. "Much easier to get the food in your mouth."

The elf shook her head.

"Please, if you think you're above animal instincts, then you are sorely mistaken. Why fight the impulse?"

She still said nothing.

Glustra shrugged. "Suit yourself, but you are going to give in eventually. After all, you are mine."

"Not forever."

"We'll see about that."

In the meantime, Glesheri had reached her full-point, and Glustra had stopped feeding her. "Ah, ah, ah, no more. Remember, we don't want you hurting yourself." She stroked her belly again, admiring it's taut roundness and the gleaming shine on its surface. "Besides, I have something to show you."
12132212313221113.title: Let’s go back to Glesheri and Glustra.

choices: As the year ends, Glesheri gives up.
As the year ends, Nessar gets tempted.
As the year ends, Glustra has a few more tricks up her sleeve.
As the year ends, someone comes to the rescue.
121322123132211132.content:
Glustra helped the overfed elf onto a litter, carried by some of the demon's servants. Glesheri could barely walk as it was, and certainly couldn't in a full state. "I think you're going to like this," the demon said with a smirk.

With a heave, the litter was lifted, and Glustra led the way as Glesheri was carried down the halls, past her own quarters, to the other rooms in the hut, the ones she didn't even know existed. She was a bit nervous, unsure what the demon would do to her. She knew she couldn't be harmed, as that would go against the bargain, but that didn't mean that something bad couldn't happen. At the same time, Glesheri was surprised someone Glustra's size could still walk so nimbly, whereas she was reduced to huffing and puffing, just sitting there in the litter. Then again, she wasn't exactly a mortal being.

She stopped in front of one of the doors, and Glesheri wondered how she could possibly know which one, as they all looked the same to her. "Have you ever wondered what happens to some of my guests? After all, they stay here for years on end. Surely, they can't always be expected to join my tables, not after they get heavy enough."

Truth be told, Glesheri tried to think as little about that sort of thing as possible. She wasn't going to end up here for the rest of her life, she kept telling herself. She swallowed hard, fearing what she might see. "N-no," she stuttered.

"You see, here's what happens when you give in to your instincts completely. You become dependent on me."

She opened the door to reveal, what must have once been a person, but now it was nothing but a massive pile of flesh and blobby fat, sprawled out on the floor. It nearly took up the entire floor really. The creature just lay there, mouth hanging open as one of the demon's servants continued to feed it an endless amount of food. If the thing had teeth, she could no longer see them. It just swallowed the food almost instantly, and then hung its mouth out for more.

Glustra was right up next to her ear. "Trust me, I know what you're thinking, and it's not torture. They rather enjoy this actually. All they have to do is lie there and enjoy the bounties of the earth without having to lift a finger. It doesn't care that it can't think beyond the basic need to eat. In fact, I'd say that this is one of the happiest existences a mortal can have. And it can be yours. It will be yours."

"It won't," she said firmly. "You won't get to keep me here. Nessar will come back for me."

"I wouldn't be so sure about that," Glustra said. "I'd say, he's on a pretty good path to forgetting you as we speak."

"You're lying," Glesheri hissed.

"Am I? And just how would you know otherwise?"

"Because I know him. I love him, and I know he wouldn't do that to me."

The demon got close to her face, letting her elbows rest on the elf's full stomach roughly. Glesheri groaned as the sudden pressure caused her great pain. "Remember, I'm the one keeping an eye on him, and I can tell you right now, he won't come back for you. He's found somewhere else to live, up north. In fact, he's got a nice little living situation; cozy rooms at an inn, a job, and I'm pretty sure he's going to be having an eye for the innkeeper's cook here pretty soon."

Glesheri fought back tears. "That's a lie! I'm not going to be fooled by your tricks."

"Tricks? My dear, why would I trick you? I have nothing to gain from that. Trying to outsmart your dolt of a husband, now that's something I would do."

She was starting to cry now. "You just want me to give up hope on him, to become one of those...those creatures," she said, nodding over to the pile of flesh. "I won't do it. You don't own me."

"Not yet, anyway," Glustra said. "But, as for giving in to me, you already have." She began kneading Glesheri's fat. "No one is able to resist me and my palace of pleasure."

"I haven't forgotten why I'm here. There is nothing you can say to make me believe otherwise."

The demon laughed. "Oh, that's right, you're here for children. My dear, do you honestly think you'll be able to keep a child at your size? Imagine what you'll look like when the year's up."

This gave the elf pause. "What...what do you mean. You said that you would..."

"Oh, I know what I said, and I do live up to my word. If your husband succeeds, your womb will indeed be opened. You can conceive as many children as you like, but I never promised they would all make it. Just look at how much you've grown. You'll just as likely lose as many in that fat gut of yours as you have many meals. Trust me when I say, you're better off here with me. At least then you could live in ignorant bliss like them." She smiled wickedly at the fat creature laying on the floor demanding even more food like a helpless child.

That broke Glesheri. She didn't know what to say, nor could she even think about what the demon was implying. In the meantime, her stomach began to growl fiercely.

"Time for your next feast."

1213221231322111323.content:
Never for a minute had Nessar lost track of time. He slowly, but surely counted down the days when he could be reunited with his wife once more. And in the last few months of that time, he was getting more and more hopeful. Even despite what he had learned during this time about the vampires that plagued the north, he still kept his positive outlook.

And he had been true to his word with the demon. While a great many of the young women had been taken over the years by the vampires, there were still a good number around who were eagerly looking for husbands. After all, the minute a woman had her first child in the north, she became protected from the vampires' watchful eyes. And indeed, several women in the village had taken an interest in Nessar. He was young, he was a man, what more did they need?

Still, he easily resisted them, constantly assuring them that he was already married. Though, that didn't stop a few determined souls who kept pointing out that his wife was nowhere to be seen. But, again, Nessar rebuffed their efforts, knowing that he would see Glesheri again.

The only woman in the village that seemed to leave him alone, despite the chance at freedom he represented was the young cook at the inn where he slept: Olga. She seemed to be the only one who could understand his predicament, having lost her sister to the vampires recently. She knew what it was like to be without someone important. Nessar feared her the most. The other women he could resist easily. They tried to hard. But Olga was capable of reaching out to him as a friend, and he avoided her at all costs, lest he be tempted by her kindred spirit. This hurt the young chef, since she felt that he seemed to hate her. Perhaps when this was all over, he might return with his wife and apologize to her.

In the meantime, Nessar had grown excited. He was now only weeks away from seeing his beloved again. He knew if he could just hold out a few more days, he would be happier than he could ever imagine. Still, knowing it was that close, yet so far away made it harder, and he knew that that would be the real test.

Over the past few days, he had been preparing to make his journey back into the forests to seek out Glustra's hut once more. He knew it would be several days in that forest, and he wanted to make sure he had enough supplies this time. He sat in the tavern, finishing his last meal before he would set off the next morning. People were going in and out as they always had done. He really didn't pay it all that much mind anymore. He was used to everyone's daily habits.

And it happened, as if out of a dream. The doors creaked open, and standing in the light was Glesheri, just as he had seen her that fateful day. He couldn't hide his surprise, and just sat there with a stunned look on his face. She rushed to him, sweeping him up in a tender embrace. "What...how...when..." was all he could stutter out.

She laughed. "Oh, you always had such a way with words. Aren't you going to tell me how much you've missed me?"

He smiled. "Of course, but it hasn't been a year yet. How did you...?"

"I was finally able to escape Glustra's hut. She kept a very close eye on me, so it was hard to find a chance to get out. Thankfully, she's more concerned with her 'pets.' I found my chance to run away. Of course, she wasn't too smart, since she accidentally let it slip that you had gone north, so I was able to find you."

Nessar wanted to take her in his arms in that instant, but something still felt off. "What about the deal? What about being able to have children?"

Glesheri shook her head. "Glustra was never going to give us that. I overheard her one day, and her true plan was to find a way to make me her prisoner. Nessar, you were right. It was awful."

"So, what about us having children?"

"We'll figure something out, we always do. Nessar, I'm just so glad to be back here with you. I just want to spend the whole night holding you in my arms."
1213221231322111323.title: As the year ends, Glustra has a few more tricks...

12132212313221113232.content:
Nessar's brow furrowed in confusion. He could tell that something was just not right about the situation. Everything felt to nice, neat, and convenient. He wanted to believe that his wife had really returned to him, but he had to acknowledge that his gut was telling him to beware. But, he had to play this naturally to avoid suspicion.

"I'm sure you would. Why don't you go upstairs to my room? It's just on the right there. I need to finish up down here."

Glesheri wandered off upstairs, a wry smile on her face. Nessar watched her go before dashing out of the tavern as fast as his legs could carry him. Unfortunately, he wouldn't be able to take all the supplies as he had planned, but he needed to see the truth for himself. He ran to the nearest stables and hastily paid the man for the first available horse and took off southward. At least this way, he had a good headstart over whoever she was. If she was indeed his beloved wife, he would return and apologize profusely, but he had a good feeling he would find the truth in the woods.

The horse had started to give out as soon as he reached the edge of the woods. Just as well, he thought.

His journey into the forest took him several days. He knew there were still a few more before the full year was up anyway. At least this way, he was hidden from whatever force was coming after him. Again, he was forced to live off of whatever he could find, but at least his mind was somewhat at ease.

It was probably good for him anyway, since it helped him lose track of time. He could spend several days here and wait patiently. Every day, he did go off on a little walk, hoping he would find the mystical hut once more. And eventually, one late afternoon, he did.

His heart leapt and he ran towards the light in the window, for once eager to see it. He sucked in a breath and opened the door. Again, he was met with the same scene he had first walked into: tables lined with food, mindless flabby beasts devouring with abandon, and the enormous and round Glustra sitting at the head of the table, eating with relish and stroking her own swollen middle.

Her eyebrows raised in surprise upon seeing him again. "Hm, so it has been a year, hasn't it? Honestly, I was hoping you wouldn't even show. But, in case you didn't notice, your wife was already returned to you. The sneaky little bitch ran away on me."

Nessar shook his head. "I don't believe you. That wasn't her."

"Are you sure?" Glustra smiled wickedly, a dribble of blood running down her cheek.

He hoped he was right about this. He was about to take a huge gamble on not just his life, but his wife's. "It wasn't. I know my wife. She is determined, kind, and puts others before herself. She wouldn't have begrudged the lives of her future children just for her own happiness."

The demon sat back in her chair, no longer devouring her food. In fact, her expression looked rather sour. She snorted. "Hmpf, so you have proven yourself after all. A shame, really. I was just starting to like your wife as my newest pet. Still, a deal was a deal, and I suppose you have proven that idiot deity, Yva wrong, so I can't complain there. Very well, I shall return her to you. Ladies!"

She snapped her fingers and several of her servants came in, bearing a massive litter. It took nearly a dozen of them to lift the massive structure and its occupant. Nessar's eyes widened in surprise as he realized what he was seeing. When the litter was set down, he saw Glesheri.

No longer was there the small, but plump little elf, but now a small mountain of a woman. Her stomach was a massive dome that eclipsed nearly the rest of her body and dominated her figure. It quivered and jiggled with each of her heaving breaths, as though just sitting had worn her out. Her arms and legs hung limp and useless, swaddled under layers of cushy fat. She could hardly lift her arms and instead chose to just let them rest on her bulbous gut. He couldn't see her backside but imagined that it too had a sizeable amount of weight to it, as she had to have gotten wider just to accommodate her enormous size. Her cheeks were swollen and puffy and left her eyes in a slight squint. Still, it was the same Glesheri he knew and loved, and her expression was one of joy.

"You came back for me!" she squealed in her slightly huskier voice. "I knew you would. Oh, Nessar, I've missed you so much." Her pudgy fingers and toes were the only parts of her that could move in excitement. It was very clear to him that she could no longer stand to greet him.

Glustra smiled again. "As promised, she is free to leave once more. She can now conceive as many children as her heart desires. And I'll even be extra nice. I will send you two to wherever you wish. As you can see, I doubt you two will be able to travel on your own." She waited for Nessar's response.
12132212313221113232.title: Nessar feels that something isn’t right.
