121322123132211132321.content:
After having taken in the initial shock, Nessar came up to Glesheri and took her hand tenderly. "There wasn't a day that went by that I didn't think of you. I'm so glad you're safe."

He had to think for a minute, though. Where would they go from here? He couldn't exactly take her back to the Verge. There was a pretty good chance they would not be welcomed back. And the fact of the matter was, Glesheri was enormous. It would be hard to find a home, let alone keep her fed. He imagined she had indeed gained quite an appetite. He couldn't take her back north. True, the vampires supposedly left a woman alone once she had children, but he wasn't taking any chances. It seemed there was really only one option.

"Glesheri, if you'd like, I think I could make you very happy in the city of Adinah. You'd be well-cared-for beyond your wildest dreams, and we would be welcomed there with no trouble. I know your home was the Verge, but I think we can make a good life for ourselves in the city, but that's only if you want to."

The elf shifted as much as her body would allow in her seat. She hadn't really thought about where they would go after this whole ordeal was over. In fact, for what had probably been the past few days, which felt like months to her, she was starting to lose her resolve and thought she might never get to leave. However, Nessar's offer was very sincere, and she did believe that things could work out for them. She nodded. "Yes, I would be happy anywhere," she said.

Glustra snorted. "Not like it'll matter to you anyway. You won't be able to see much beyond your own bed. But, as you wish. You will find yourselves in a home suited just for you in Adinah."

With that, the hut seemed to vanish away, and Nessar found himself sitting beside his enormously fat wife as she lay on one of the largest beds he had ever seen. True to her word, they were in a cozy, but sizeable home in Adinah. He recognized the architecture. True, it wasn't his old apartment in the city, but there would have been no way he could have fit Glesheri in there.

Speaking of which, he watched his wife laying there, her massive belly wobbling with each breath. He went to her and gave her a warm embrace around the neck. "I can't believe you're really here," he said.

"Yeah," she laughed, "though certainly bigger."

He had been trying to avoid the topic. He wasn't sure how she felt about her size. "Yeah, how did that happen?" he asked cautiously.

She proceeded to relay to him her adventure in the demon's hut: how she was cursed to eat nearly endlessly. When she was finished, she looked slightly red in the face out of embarrassment. "I feel so ashamed," she said.

His eyebrows raised in surprise. "Why should you be? It wasn't your fault. Glustra put you under a spell."

"I know, but I still feel...I don't know, embarrassed by it all. Nessar, I'm more than just a fat and happy wife, I'm huge. I can't even get up anymore, and even though the curse has worn off, it's not going to change the fact that I will probably still eat a lot...and maybe only get bigger. I love you and everything, but I don't want to be a burden to you, too helpless to do anything myself anymore."

He kissed her. "You'd never be that to me. I love you no matter what. Sure, it isn't going to be easy, but I'm willing to do what it takes to make our lives together as wonderful as possible. And besides..." he took a handful of her flab and squeezed gently, "I kind of like this a little, much more of you to love. Now then, I believe there was the matter of children."

Glesheri practically melted at his touch. She had missed it so much. But, she stopped when he mentioned children. She hadn't forgotten the demon's words. "Nessar, wait. I'm worried. I know that now I'm supposed to be able to conceive a child, but at my size, am I going to be able to carry it? I'm worried for their safety."

He nuzzled against her forehead. "I will personally see to it that you are well cared-for through the whole thing. I won't let anything happen to you. Besides, children or no, I haven't seen you in a whole year. We've got some catching up to do."

Glesheri giggled, enjoying the feeling of being with her husband once more.

1221.content:
It was a scene of revelry in the yurt of the Head-Crusha clan.

Kumis and rare alcohols from the west flowed like water. Elvish dancers, captives taken in successful raids, bobbed and swayed among the orcs to tunes plucked on strings to the beat of boarskin drums. In one corner of the tent, two Orcs settled their friendly rivalry in an epic wrestling match while in the other corner the shamans regaled the younger warriors with the tales of glorious conquests and dangerous hunts. In the center of everything sat the cause of the celebration; the butchered and broiled corpse of a vicious manticore, a legendary beast whose fur was stained red with the blood of those too weak or feeble to slay it, and whose defeat was the source of this great victory feast. Its skull would adorn the yurts of clan leaders centuries from now, and its crimson pelt lay across the throne of the warrior who struck the final blow that slayed the vile beast, a warrior whose name inspired fear and awe as it swept through the Dustbowl like a typhoon.

"To tha great Bralga Head-Crusha, tha greatest warrior in all o' Yndyre!"

A great tumult rose up as dozens of orcs raised their cups in a toast to her. Bralga Head-Crusha, seated at the head of this great congress, lifted her own goblet, a trophy taken from a noble fop who strayed too close to her territory, and drank deeply. Running a broad thumb across her favorite battle-axe resting at her side, fine silk from the provinces of Futotta-Machi draped across her shoulders, Bralga looked over the scene with a rather pensive expression. To her clan, the great warrior looked to be quietly reveling in her glory as the mighty do, surveying her realm with a troubled brow. Perhaps she was plotting her next great battle, or perhaps considered a romantic conquest for the evening. This seemed to be a popular theory, as several men and woman stood up to boast of their prowess, hoping to earn her favor.

The truth, however, was a lot simpler. She was damned bored.

It was something that had brewed for quite some time, and the manticore fight had finally driven that ugly fact home. The elders and shamans spoke volumes of the beast's tenacity and ferocity, calling it the avatar of Ardoid himself, yet one blow from her mighty axe and the creature crumpled like a collapsed yurt. She played along of course and celebrated with her pack but she was utterly furious. Where had the challenge gone? What happened to the days when her battles soaked the ground with her own blood as well as her enemies, when she broke her weapons fighting and resorted to her fists and teeth? What good was the skull of the most vile beast in the Dustbowl when it was no less difficult to tear from its body then crushing an ant underfoot?

What was the point of being the greatest warrior of Clan Head-Crusha when there was nothing worth fighting? By the Gods, she thought to herself, give me SOMETHING worth my damned time...

"Bralga Burrrup Head-Crusha...."

Bralga turned to glare daggers at the sentry, a bottle of foreign ale clutched in his hand. She couldn't help but roll her eyes; the man was already tipsy. How many bottles had he downed by now, ten? Tch.

"What d'you want?" Bralga snarled.

12211.content:
"We caught dis strange merchant sneakin' around," the drunk orc mumbled.

Bralga smirked, figuring she could use some entertainment. "Bring him here."

Standing up from her throne and stretching out her back, Bralga took up her battle-axe and propped it up on the table in front of her, resting her hands on the head of the double-sided cleaver. She loved to make a good first impression by brandishing this fire-hardened meteor iron weapon in front of her captives. Some of the celebrating orcs took notice of the movement and quieted down to watch as an oily, irritated voice became audible from outside.

"-and if you scuff these boots I'll have your head, you brutes! I'm due in the capital any day now and if- OUCH!"

The tent flaps parted as two orcs strode in, gripping the shoulders of a man rubbing a sore spot on his upper arm and throwing him at Bralga's feet. He was dressed exotically but elegantly in a thick black fur, with a heavy rucksack on his back and a conical hat hiding the top of his head. As the man looked up towards her, Bralga's hand instinctively went for the handle of her weapon at the sight of his visage before she realized the man was wearing a white mask, with two inky dots for eyes and a long thin line curved into a smile. His gaze seemed to drift upwards, past her sturdy hips and rippling abdominal muscles and heading upwards as he got to his feet.

"Aha, pardon me, I didn't mean to intrude, I just was intrigued by the size of your lovely...tents," the merchant said, his gaze lingering on Bralga's heaving bosom before he drew fully upright, which for him was still hunched over slightly, tapping his fingertips together. "See I was just heading west to-"

"Who are you?"

The man jumped at the sudden demand. "Er...Kyō." Kyō Naginata."

"And what made you think you could just intrude on the lands of Clan Head-Crusha?" Bralga said, a chorus of boisterous laughter erupting behind her. Kyō Naginata, cowed as the orcish woman towered over him, drummed his fingers together faster and faster as he searched for the words to say. "What's he got on em?" Bralga called out over the head of the poor merchant.

"Just a buncha silks an stuff..." the orc called back.

"Take 'em," Bralga called out lazily in response. "Then send this mewling weakling packing!" She lifted her goblet up to her clan and prompted a rousing celebratory cheer at the bullying of this merchant.

"N-now wait just a moment, you can get silks anywhere, why me!?!" Mr. Naginata protested.

"Consider it one of those payments you give to your own great warriors...whatsit called...taxes!"

"Perhaps I could trade for them back?" the merchant said frantically. "I'm...a collector you see..."

"You don't have anything else Clan Head-Crusha wants," Bralga laughed as she turned to head back to her throne. "Go back home and crawl into your comfortable bed."

"Are you certain? You do seem rather...unfulfilled..."

Bralga froze, turning back sharply to the merchant. The men nearby had wandered back into their revelries, so it was much like they two of them were alone.

"What do you know of how I 'seem', merchant?" Bralga spat back.

"Oh, nothing, nothing," Mr. Naginata said, steepling his fingers. "I just know quite a few warriors like yourself from back in the day. Great warriors, so good in fact that they grew...rather bored."

"I'm not bored!" Bralga insisted. "I...I am the greatest warrior in all the Dustbowl, there is nothing I cannot do!"

"Ahh, my friends said the same thing to me once, more or less," Mr. Naginata mused. "But then again, I had to wonder...what was the point of being the greatest warrior when there was nothing worth fighting?"

Bralga glowered at the merchant as he opened his fur cloak, reaching inside to rummage around. For some reason, in this light, she couldn't see any part of him underneath that outer cloak. How odd.

"Perhaps in exchange for my cargo..." Mr. Naginata said, holding something out to her. "I can give you this? I think it might solve your problems." Bralga took the gift in both hands, turning it over once, then twice. It shouldn't have been all that impressive to her and yet, there was something...

"Lurga, Jingor!" Bralga shouted to the two guards that brought him in. "Return this man to his caravan, take nothing from him and escort him to the edge of our lands." The two burly orcs looked shocked and confused, but one angry look from Bralga sent them packing.

"Oh thank you, blessings upon you, Bralga Head-Crusha!" Mr. Naginata cried out happily as he backed out of the tent after them. "You will not regret your choice today, milady! After all, Mr. Naginata always sells quality!"

Taking a deep bow as he made his exit, Bralga wondered for a moment how the strange man knew her name. Perhaps she was famed outside of the Dustbowl, she thought proudly. Returning to her throne as the party continued on, she looked over her new prize with interest...
12211.title: A Peculiar Fellow

choices: Bralga keeps training hard and gets better...and bigger.
Bralga recruits some of her clan to become sumos as well.
Much later, word begins to spread of a super-sized sumo wrestling orc.
122112.content:
Three suns passed over the lands of Head-Crusha since the great feast and the departure of the strange merchant, and things were slowly falling back into routine. As hangovers and bloating wore off, craftsmen returned to their tools and herdsman returned to their fields, while the youngest and nimblest patrolled the outskirts of Head-Crusha territory atop of fast and agile warboars. Two scouts on the Eastern side made idle chat, bragging about their amorous conquests the night of the Manticore Feast when their sharp ears and eyes caught sight of a single figure riding atop a warboar of his own. Turning their boars around, they rode out to meet the visitor, their ragged swords drawn.

"Hey! You!" they grunted, cutting off the visitor's path. "What you doin in Head-Crusha Clan territory?" The visitor lowered his hood, revealing himself to be an Orc, shorter and stockier then most, with a shock of short black hair and, most notably, milky white eyes with no pupils or iris to speak of. Pulling a face, the Orc sniffed at the air and pondered a moment.

"Yegoth and Oghash, is it? No!" he jabbed a thick callused finger towards the lady orc among the two. "That is Oghash's coat, not Oghash herself. You are..." The Orc sniffed the air again. "Bulak. I'd recognize the gait of your warboar anywhere."

Yegoth and Bulak looked at one another awkwardly before the latter spoke up. "Y-yes. Many apologies, Zudagog. We just doing our jobs."

"As you should," Zudagog the Vigilant smirked before sniffing at the air again. "Hrmm, eating well, have we? What has my sister slain since I've been away?"

Bulak blushed, placing her hand defensively against the potbelly bulging from her fur tunic. "It was the Crimson Manticore."

"Ah, that's a wily one. Very well, I'll leave you two to work off that blubber then." Spurring his Warboar, Zudagog passed the two sentries, his spirits lifted substantially. After all, he wasn't truly home unless he coddled some of the younglings. It had been an admittedly bad habit he picked up because of who he was. Being a blind Orc with a taste for the civilized life was a death sentence in the Ookh Dustbowl.

That had certainly been the intent the night of his father's sky burial, when his friend made his move for the head of clan Skull-Crusha. He could still remember waking up to the murderous look in Kharag's eyes, right before an axe sprung from the darkness and lopped off his friend turned rival's hand before it could plunge into his chest. It was the last thing he ever saw with his own vision, as Kharag drew a second blade across his eyes before being thrown off; how he wished he could have kept them long enough to see his own sister fight off a dozen armed men long enough for him to be whisked away to safety.

Zudagog spent years in pain and agony on the outskirts of Futotta-Machi as the apothecaries tended to his wounds, certain he would have never been able to come home, when a messenger arrived summoning him to the court of Bralga Head-Crusha. He might not have been able to see his own sister in all her splendor, but when he entered his father's yurt, he could feel it in his bones that she was the one to lead the clan as she declared him to be her right hand, second to none but her among all of the Head-Crushas. It had been a glorious night of celebration, culminating with his reunion with his old friend and rival Kharag. He couldn't see it of course, but Zudagog so enjoyed hearing Kharag's screams of agony that night, coupled with that messy aftermath...

The ride to the main camp was quiet today, unusually so, since his sister almost always rode out to meet him on his return from the outskirts. Was she perhaps preoccupied? Shrugging it off, Zudagog rode on until he could hear the distinctive sounds of the main camp ahead. Passing by the outer yurts, he dismounted next to a heavily pregnant maiden singing a song to the baby in her arms.

"Zudagog, hello!" the maiden called out brightly. "How was the journey?"

"Uneventful as always, Mogak," Zudagog sniffed. "At the very least that ponce from the city won't be sending more hires to tangle with us. Where is my sister?"

"She's been in her tent since the celebration...entertaining that nubile elf dancer." Zudagog rolled his blank eyes as the maiden giggled. Reaching the flap of the main tent, he strode right in, completely unconcerned with catching his sister in a compromising position. She should have known better anyway.

"Bralga, what's this I hear about-"

CRASH

By the Gods, was Bralga trying to kill that waif? Breaking into a jog he ran into the center of the yurt where the commotion came from.

"Oh, M-Mr. Zudagog, sir!"

Zudagog titled his head as the elfish dancer sitting in the corner called his name. Sniffing the air, she seemed to be fully clothed, with some sort of book in her hands. What was-

BANG

"Haha, yes! You great sparring partner, now try and push me out of ring!"

The blind orc sniffed the air again, realizing that the center of the tent seemed to have been cleared out. He caught the whiff of chalk, probably drawn onto the ground. Most notably, he recognized the presence of his sister Bralga, her tunic shedded in favor of only her short trousers and a wrapping around her bosom, shoving up against a rather large and slow fellow by the name of Goor, himself dressed in only his trousers.

"What in Ardoid's name are you doing!?!"

"Zudagog, you're home! One moment!" Bralga let out a warcry, nearly lifting Goor off his feet before she slammed him down again and flung him out of the center of the tent where he collapsed onto a stool, making it into splinters. Hair disheveled and a big stupid smile on her face, Bralga ran up to her brother and wrapped her muscular arms tightly around him in a hug.

"That milk drinker Sir Frum will not trouble us any longer?" she said brightly.

"No, of course not...but what is going on? Why does the elf have a book?"

"I can't read in Elfish, she can?" Bralga shrugged as the elf girl cowered in terror. "How else am I going to learn sumo?"

"...you're learning what now?"

"Sumo, wrestling style from farther east!" Bralga spread out her stance and stomped the ground, sending up dust clouds from her muscular action. "I think I can be good at it, too! You heard of sumos, yes?"

"I...of course I have, but..."

"Manticores and wyverns are no match for Clan Head-Crusha, brother!" Bralga ranted on. "If we wish to stay powerful and strong, we need to learn new things and challenge ourselves, yes?"

This was all a bit much to take in, Zudagog thought as he furrowed his brow. Why now with this obsession? How far would she take this? And more importantly, how would Clan Head-Crusha react to such a change? She did not have an heir yet, and if she was cast out, there was no question that the great Head-Crusha would fall to infighting and be gobbled up by their neighbors.

On the other hand, Zudagog suddenly realized, this could be a golden opportunity. This newfound interest in Futotta-Machi culture could be the first step in more peaceful relationships with the more civilized urban cities. They could trade for knowledge and luxury goods instead of stealing them, and perhaps they could even procure some of their famous swords and bows for use in their warbands. Such advances could make Head-Crusha even more powerful...perhaps, powerful enough to unite the Ookh Dustbowl under one banner for the first time in centuries?

"Well, if you are serious about this..." Zudagog said gruffly.

"Oh, very!" Bralga said proudly. "Bralga Head-Crusha will be the greatest sumo warlord ever! Now, elf girl, what does book say about sumo's diet?"
122112.title: I Wanna Be a Rikishi

1221122.content:
The next time the clan moved to better hunting grounds, a new yurt went up among the expected tents and dwellings in the Head-Crusha camp. Bigger then even the main tent where feasts and celebrations were held, the clan did not need to be convinced to enter and look around when the command was given to gather in the new tent.

"Come, gather around ring!" Bralga Head-Crusha shouted as the first Orcs entered the yurt. "Hurry! This important!"

The tent was surprisingly sparse, perfectly circular with wide open spaces and crude wooden benches around the walls. Subtle magical enchantments hung in the air overhead, keeping the expansive tent alight, especially on the center, where a wide circle of grass enclosed in chalk had been beaten and smoothed into a flat surface. Bralga herself stood proudly in the center, looking fiercer then usual as the sleeves of her silken deel stretched against her thick arm muscles.

"Clan Head-Crusha!" Bralga announced, unleashing a celebratory roar from her clan.

"Bralga!" a particularly vocal warrior woman called out. "Is this new combat arena?!?"

"This is...a sumo ring!"

Confused stares abounded as the orcs all gazed in wonder.

"Is...is new fighting style?"

Bralga nodded. "This new style of fighting that we shall master to conquer enemies!"

The reaction wasn't what she had hoped. The overeager orc from earlier looked intrigued, but few others did. Most looked confused, but some looked rather irritated. Was this why they had been made to hunt more, to raid foodstuffs and grains from traders instead of gold and valuables like they always had?

"We already best clan in all of Ookh!" one heckler cried out. "Why we need new fighting? Old fighting is best!" Shouts of agreement echoed off the tent walls. Bralga's confident snarl faltered slightly, but not entirely. She knew her desire to escape from the mundane boredom wasn't shared by the rest of the clan, but Bralga still knew what made her people happy, and knew what they wanted more then anything else.

"Will be hard to learn new fighting style, yes," Bralga admitted. "But will be helpful when we face....Clan Bone-Rippa!"

A thousand orcish eyes lit up at the mention of that name, in a way that could only grow from the deepest of animosities. The rivalry between Head-Crusha and Bone-Rippa was such an animosity. Their feud was the stuff of legends, baked into the very mythology of the orcish people in a way that could only be accomplished by the orcs. The last true equals to Bralga's horde, Bone-Rippa was an insurmountable foe, and above all a worthy adversary, and what more could a warrior want then a worthy adversary.

"Bone-Rippa...fight us?" one orc said incredulously.

"Bone-Rippas never offer to fight..." another piped in.

"Because they know we beat them if they come around!" Bralga announced as the silent confusion began to melt into a supportive rumble. "We learn new fighting style, so they think they have chance! But will we give them chance?"

"NO!" a dozen orcs roared.

"Then we need warriors to learn new style!"

"I will learn!" the headstrong warrior girl from earlier shouted, storming up to join her clan leader! Four other girls her age saw this display and, not willing to be called cowards, shouted their support and joined the small group, each volunteer receiving a tumultuous cheer.

"We will learn new fighting style!" Bralga cried out, both fists in the air. "And we defeat Bone-Rippa good! Because NONE CAN BEAT CLAN HEAD-CRUSHA!"

The din was so loud that you could hear roaring a mile away as every orc leapt to his or her feet, battering their shields and stomping their feet in celebration. Zudagog, sitting near the front of the rambunctious crowd, remained seated, grinning as he knew he received an appreciative glance from his sister. After all, without his help, Turgi Bone-Rippa would have never agreed to the sumo match to settle their long-standing grievances with their rivals. A fine warrior in her own right, Turgi had ascended to the head of her clan much in the same way as his sister had, through violence and treachery. Turgi, however, had watched her own father butchered by his brothers and had since lost the stomach for the inter-clan warfare that characterized the rivalry between the two clans, instead choosing to focus on hunting, raiding caravans, and shoring up what defenses she could. Her reign was in dire straits though, not helped by the fact that she tended to eat more then she hunted and fought, so when Zudagog offered her a chance to participate in this sumo match with Head-Crusha and earn some prestige in a less violent way, she jumped at the opportunity.

Was it an orcish way of doing things? Perhaps not, but Zudagog and to a lesser extent Bralga were out to make things different.. And that started with this slim chance of turning a rivalry into a friendship through a mutual love of fighting. You couldn't get much more Orcish then that, could you?

---

Buzzing with excitement, the orcs of Clan Head-Crusha finally filtered out of the yurt, the last of which being the gruff Zudagog, leaving Bralga and her volunteers behind.

"Now, have seat in front. Will give quick explanation of rules." Bralga said, undoing the sash of her tunic. "Thaciona will give you first meals."

"Meals?" one of the orc girls asked as Thaciona, the elfish girl who had been translating the manual for Bralga, stumbled forward with large bowls in her arms. "We need special diet?"

"Yes, sumo is much like wrestling, only you try to throw out of ring, and you have special body." Bralga finished undoing her fasteners and disrobed, leaving the volunteers in stunned silence.

"Do not be too embarrassed," Bralga chuckled. "This will be outfit you wear! Special for fighting style!"

Bralga being dressed only in a loincloth and a chest wrapping was indeed enough to stun to silence, but not as much as seeing the change in her physique. Her arms and legs still bristled with powerful muscles, but instead of the row of abdominal muscles they expected to see, the great clan leader sported a potbelly, gently wobbling as she adjusted her stance. The addition of this lump of fat drew their attention to her body for the first time and how different it seemed to be. Her arms, for instance, seemed to be thicker with more then just muscle, and now that they weren't hidden by the deel her hips were definitely looking a hair wider. Even her strong chin seemed to be widening out.

One by one, the girls realized what this new fighting style meant for them, reinforced when Thaciona dropped a heavy bowl of rice and meats in front of them. A couple made eyes towards the door, and only the loud and boisterous orc girl from earlier still looked eager to learn, but regret was setting in. They couldn't turn back now though. They made a vow by volunteering to help, and it would bring shame to their families if they backed out from a chance to fight those Bone-Rippas.

"Right, we begin with stances!" Bralga announced, beginning the lecture of the first chapter of the book, one that she had learned by heart at this point, as her trainees began to reluctantly dig into their meals.

1232.content:
“Hey! Catch her!”

“Don’t let her get away”

Running through a snowy forest in a long Kimono dress was not the plan Licsoku had for her day, but now, thanks to a botched attempt at scoring some free food, the long-haired Futakuchi Onna was running ankle-deep through the drift.

Her bare feet were surprisingly adept at traversing such environments, and quite cold resistant, but there was a different reason that she could hear her pursuers getting closer by the moment.

Spying a large rock to her left, the Yokai quickly changed course towards it. She slipped underneath the overhang, spotting suddenly that her footprints were going to give her away. With a quick darting motion, her long black hair rose up around her head like tentacles, lashing at the snow and smoothing its surface. With mere moments to spare Licsoku withdrew her hair just as they were upon her.

A trio of men, covered in rigged armor with demonic face-plates stopped, their long Katanas gleaming in the reflected light.

“The tracks end here” one pointed out.

“The demon must have taken to the treetops” a second pointed out.

“Straight ahead then, let us bring her back to the Shogun!” the third one stated, egging them on as they continued forwards.

Licsoku sighed as their crunching footfalls fell silent as they ran into the distance. This was her third failure this month. The easiest and most familiar way for a Futakuchi Onna to find food was to trick people; this was why the entire race looked like beautiful long-haired women. Their strategy would be to find a stately home on a cold evening and wander up to their door, shivering as they pretended to be lost and needing shelter for the night. Once the owner of the home lets them in they would act naturally, keeping the act up until everyone else falls asleep. This is where phase two came in.

The Futakuchi would feign sleep, getting up in the middle of the night to locate the houses food stores and larders. Sitting themselves with their back to the food, the Futakuchi’s hair then gets to work. The long tendrils grab everything they can reach, and bring them towards the back of her head. This opens up to reveal a second mouth, brimming with sharp teeth strong enough to bite through solid steel. The tendrils stuff the mouth with as much speed and gluttony as they can, as the Futakuchi’s belly swells and swells, thanks to their natural stretchiness, until she looks full term with child.

Once she had had more food than a human would eat in a month, the Futakuchi gingerly rises to her feet, her hair going lank once more as she cradles her full stomach tenderly, and leaves via the nearest exit. To an onlooker she appears as simply a mother-to-be going about her day-to-day business.

Normally Futakuchi only ate like this rarely, allowing them to go back to slim and frail-looking. But Licsoku had had a good string of luck for quite a while (several short-sighted house-owners had contributed to this), meaning she had not slimmed back down to her usual self. Now Licsoku sported a thick round belly that sat on her thighs at all times, thick tree-trunk-like thighs, plump arms and a round face. This made her a dead give-away whenever she tried to score a free meal; resorting to her being chased across the snowy landscape.

This wouldn’t have happened if Licsoku had not eaten so much once she realised she was on a streak of success’s; but her greedy nature got the better of her, meaning within a month she had eaten enough food to last a single human a year.

Now though she was starving…fat and starving, what a wonderful ironic combination…

Grumbling to herself, Licsoku grabbed the pale pudge that resided beneath her long dress and huffed, her breath turned into visible particles in front of her as she contemplated her next move. Repeatedly picking up and dropping the weighty sack of fat, she considered her options.

She could try moving to another area? The landscape would be unfamiliar, but people there might not have heard of creatures that look like women, but steal your food in the night. Or she could try one of the local monasteries, they were quite happy to hand food out…it wouldn’t be much but it would be something. Or she could keep trying other homesteads, perhaps if she was careful she could be more tactful with her appetite and stick around for a while?

Decisions decisions…

12332.content:
The light was drawing in, tinting the Eastern snow a beautiful orange as it descended beneath the horizon. These were the hours of twilight and for one resident of the land of Futotta-Machi this was the last few hours of light she got for training.

Fumiko spent most of her days training; training her mind in meditation, training her reflexes in martial arts, training her body through rigorous exercises but most of all she was trying to use her last hours of light to get as much food into her body as possible.

As the young woman sat at the table stuffing her face with as much rice as she could scoop down her throat as possible you would wonder why something would go to such lengths to ruin what would be otherwise seen as a perfect body. Fumiko was strong, shockingly so in fact, and with only the barest hint of fast on a slight pot-belly that could barely jiggle…but for her dreams that was only the beginning, she needed bigger…much bigger.

“You still eating?” Came a cackle from the stairs top of the stairs.

“*Mmm hmmm*” Fumiko mumbled as her chopsticks slid another mouthful of rice between her petite lips.

“Ha! Why you still trying to be sumo? You are way too small huehuehuehue!” Came the retort.

The dark-haired girl slammed her empty bowl to the wooden table, “That’s why I am eating you shrivelled raisin!” She snapped. Fumiko had wanted to move into her own place and start her career so much, so much in fact that she had rented a room in a house belonging to this old geezer. In the beginning she thought Mr Nakumura was going to grope her or something equally creepy; but no, instead the old man seemed to get his jollies exchanging banter with her.

“Ha! You want to look like a sumo? Go out and eat at the bars with the real sumo’s!” The bearded man taunted, pointing his cane at the door. Fumiko however quickly rose to his baiting.

“You know…I will! Don’t lock up; I’ll be back with a belly so full I will barely get it through the door!” The hot-headed girl stated, grabbing her winter Kimono and slinging it over her shoulders before marching out into the winter weather.

Fumiko’s village was a small home, located half-way up a semi-frozen mountainside where the elements loved to test the limits of all the people living there. The sumo-in-training had hoped this would give her some grit and stamina, but a lot of the time it just gave her a runny nose when she left the hose.

“*Achoo!* Stupid snow…” She mumbled, her feet dragging through the frozen fluff as the young woman made her way towards the tavern. Fumiko was no fan of this weather, not after her first winter anyway. It blew her scruffy hair into her eyes and went straight through her muscles to freeze her to her soul; it gave her all the more incentive to get fat as quickly as possible. Hopefully by next winter she would have acquired enough blubber to brace this foul weather.

Pushing the drapes covering the door to one side, Fumiko brought herself into the warm of the local tavern. After dusk it was quite a popular place; there were plenty of people drinking at the front of the bar, downing shots of rice-wine. Meanwhile a group of Samurai guards were playing some sort of betting game in the far corner, sitting on the cushions on the floor. Over in the other corner was a wandering Ronin smoking a pipe, keeping herself to herself. And also, like her cheap-shot-throwing landlord had said, there were sumos’ present as well.

There were two men and a woman, the latter of which Fumiko looked on in envy towards. She was the biggest of the three, her huge bulk overwhelming the cushion she had parked her immensity on while her bare belly spilled over her lap and almost hid her legs. She was as round as one of the lanterns hanging from the ceiling and must have weighed as much as an Ox. Oh how Fumiko wished she were that big; she imagined herself with the woman’s pillar-sized legs, bloated feet and big boulder of a gut, causing mini earthquakes when she stepped into the arena…oh that would be the life!

Shaking herself back to the real world though, Fumiko strode towards the bar. She was eager to get herself to that level as soon as possible.

“Give me a portion of rice!” Fumiko snapped at the barkeep as she slammed her coins on the countertop.

“You know…some people prefer to use manners when they ask for something…” The bartender replied lowly before calling back to the kitchen behind him.

Fumiko gave him a small scowl as he returned with a bowl. It was small, barely the size of the one she had just finished at home. “Hey! You call this a portion!” She snapped, pointing at the food.

The terse barkeep turned back to her, “For a shrimp like you…yeah.”

“Hmmm, look here’s some more coins; give me the same size as them!” On that demand Fumiko pointed towards the sumos in the far corner. As the man tried to retake the rice Fumiko grabbed the bowl and dumped the majority of it down her gullet; “And I am keeping this first serving.”

The muscular woman broke into a smug grin when she saw the look of surprise on the man’s face as he called back to make a bigger order; that showed him she was ready for the big time!

As Fumiko waited for her real meal, she spotted something…
12332.title: Fattening with Fumiko

choices: With samurai, sumo and a ronin present the duo are quickly evicted.
Retribution comes from the most unlikely of places as the pair advance.
Fumiko can easily take care of herself, the braggarts didn't know what hit them.
123321.content:
Fumiko took to roving her eyes around the sake house as she waited for her order. Plenty of people were having a drink, perhaps she should order one as well. Although the taste of the local rice wine was too strong for her. Mr. Nakumura drank plenty of it, he had offered her a bottle one time after she managed to trust that he was not a perverted old man looking to knock her out easy. It was horrid stuff, actually, and made up most of his diet although he remained a shriveled raisin. Fumiko had taken too much to drink, her first time, as she was out cold the rest of the night. She had missed out on all that time when she could have been training.

But she was never going to waste those remaining hours of the day for her training ever again! She pounded at the table she sat by, anticipating the tavern's rice, earning an annoyed look from other patrons.

People came an went. There was a ruckus from the gambling samurai, the sumos traded jokes, the ronin looked to have fallen asleep with her pipe snuffed out.

And that was when the shouting started.

Heads turned towards a pair of men who had just entered. They had fierce tones and faces reddened by the wind sweeping down over the mountains. They were in the midst of a heated argument, the subject quite disruptive.

"I've had more relations than you've ever known! Why, I once charmed the magistrate over a long weekend."

"Politics, bah," spat his companion. "Try wooing one of the kitsune acolytes that have yet to dedicate themselves to their meditation. They're quite strong lovers and much more fleeting than women."

Fumiko turned from the display with disgust. Pigs! Such lecherous men! It went to show that even in a place as pleasant to live in as Futotta-Machi, there could be the vilest of people. Fumiko willed herself to ignore them, eagerly eying the mountain of rice that came in a sumo sized serving. It towered over the bowl. She possibly may have bitten off more than she could chew but Fumiko had 'promised' to her landlord that she would come home with a bulging belly, a sign of her commitment to her training.

She dug into her rice, deftly working her chopsticks, getting the first morsels down her gullet. She was given a cup of traditional wine with her bowl, she wanted to eat more before trying it again. Have something in her stomach to absorb the taste and alcohol.

Unfortunately, the arguing chauvinists had sat themselves close to Fumiko's seat, and their talk of conquests was very rude and distracting.

"To say nothing of the wittily creatures further along the mountains. A once made a Futakuchi Onna swoon like a young maiden."

"That's nothing, show them the larder and a Futakuchi Onna will be your best friend! I out seduced a Jorogumo and lived to tell the tale!"

"Ha!"

By the gods were they rude. Fumiko fumed their direction, of their crude conversation going unchecked. Surely the rest of the patrons of the tavern could hear them? By now somebody should get them to shut up and turn them back out into the snow.

While she was looking across the tavern's seating she accidentally locked eyes with one of them. That turned out to given the men an unintentionally invitation.

"Tell me, girl, you wouldn't want to date a poor excuse for a man like my associate when I have so much to offer."

"Pah, don't listen to him miss," the other had a hint of the strong stuff in his system, the bravado laid on extra thick. "If it's a good time you're looking for, I can show you things this charlatan would never be able to perform."

Ugh! The pair of them were making Fumiko sick to her stomach, the very opposite of how she wanted to feel with a belly crammed with rice. The pair were not picking up on her distaste as the drew closer, all the more brash and argumentative.

"Such a strong woman you are, a weakling like him wouldn't have the stamina!"

"Ignore him, he proclaims too much when results are better than words."

Really, nobody in the tavern was curbing this rude, unwarranted pair? By now Fumiko was sure that everyone could hear them, she was just waiting on somebody to kick them out. She wanted to finish her rice in peace!
123321.title: The Disruptive Duo

choices: Such technique, what a fight! Fumiko wants to learn everything she can!
How does Tatsuki stay so big while so active? Is it all from the drink?
Now it's Otsuka getting arrested for disruption, with Fumiko caught up in it!
1233212.content:
"Go away!" Fumiko told the rude men, turning back to her meal. That tell-off did not linger in their thick skulls, as the two continued to try and one up each other with the wannabe sumo caught in the middle of it.

"I like a girl with your spirit! This fool of a man would never be able to handle you."

"Baka, he is all talk with nothing to back it up. The only girl to love him was his mother."

Mouth full of rice, Fumiko gave dark looks at both of them under her scruffy hair. Couldn't a girl gain weight for sumo in peace. Surely the antics of this pair would have gotten them thrown out for sure. She looked out across the tavern.

Oddly, the barman was counting a stack of coins. Along with the samurai, who were gambling with much higher stakes than Fumiko remembered them playing with. The jingle of a coin purse brought her eyes to the belt of one of the disruptive men, as he tightened the drawstring of a much smaller purse.

The implication disgusted Fumiko even more. Had they paid off the tavern staff and the authorities? Made them look away with such a monetary bribe? And she was equally disgusted by how much their attention was turned her direction.

"~Hey~*hic*" there was a low, feminine voice that was sounding quite toshed.

Both Fumiko and the men turned. A form lumbered to her feet, Fumiko had mistaken the woman for a set of particular dirty cushions set off to the side. The stranger had long black hair spilling out from her flat conical straw hat. She leaned unsteadily on a staff, dressed in a once blue samue over a grey tunic and loose sandals. Several more sticks, with a few drinking gourds, were tied to her back with a fraying rope. She was very plump around the middle, bigger than Fumiko but nowhere near sumo size, with a gut that looked like she enjoyed her drink. Indeed, she reeked of rice wine.

"~*hic* the lady said to go away," she stumbled over, that strong smell of alcohol overbearing. The pair of main looked as disgusted by her as Fumiko was of them.

"Go back to your drinking, wrench, this doesn't concern you."

"Aw, *hic* come on," she leaned in closer, precariously so. "Yur looking for a good time in all the wrong places."

If she was offering her company the men sure didn't go for it. "Leave us be, my associate and I are not men to cross."

"Ignore her," the other said with realization. "That's Otsuka. You know, the woman that was blacklisted from the monastery!"

The two laughed. "A good thing they did. Look at her, such a degenerate."

The Otsuka woman didn't appear to hear what they were saying about her. She stubbled closer, peering at the men through a gape in her hair, only one grey eye visible. Fumiko couldn't take this any longer, she was about to give the men a piece of her mind.

"Get away from us you drunken wretch!" He moved to shove her forcefully. The drunken woman tipped out of the way, her staff catching him as he tripped and fell hard on the floor.

"Oops, sorry!" Otsuka hiccuped in a mockingly innocent tone.

"Why you disgraceful savage!" The other man swung wildly. Otsuka staggered back, nearly falling over, her other leg seining up for balance and catching the guy in the chin as she struggled to regain her balance. He spun about in a cry of pain.

"Watch out!" Fumiko warned, as both men recovered and charged at the drunken woman from both sides. She was to inebriated to move, how could she fight back with those hits had just been flukes?

Although Fumiko was recognizing that there might be a method to the madness. Otsuka bobbed out of the way again, each man punching the other in the face at where she had just been a moment before. She held her staff horizontally and lurched forward, pushing them off balance with her shifting weight.

"Hey! Watch it!" Fumiko barely saved her bowl of rice in time as the men tripped over the table, one set crashing into an uncleaned pacesetting. The other was more nimble on his feet, crying out as he took a fighting stance. He advanced, jabbing wildly at the drunken woman.

If Fumiko blinked she would have missed it. Otsuka tipped and swayed out of the way from each blow. He caught a jut of her staff to the groin for his troubles, sending him sprawling over his companion that had just gotten to his feet.

Otsuka made her own advancement as she lurched and tripped, her heft squashing both men as she twisted in midair. They howled in pain. She lurched up again, holding tight to her staff, was one of them scrambled up off the pile leaving his friend below. A spinning kick sent him careening out of the tavern, Otsuka pinning the remaining man to the floor with her full weight yet again.

Fumiko blinked, stunned. The entire fight had taken less than a minute. She looked to the round face of the drunken woman, flushed from the exertion. Or maybe it was the heavy drinking. Or now that Fumiko could see her face in full, the right side of Ostuka's face was scarred from a burn, the side that had been covered from her hair earlier.

"~Whew," Ostuka sighed, now sitting across from Fumiko in the wake of the tables destroyed during the fight. "Hello."

"Hello," was all Fumiko could reply back at the moment, slightly in awe of the fighting prowess she had seen. The woman had just fought them while drunk, right?

Below the unlikeliest of fighters the man yelled, although it was a bit muffled, as he tried to crawl his way out from under her. Ostuka struggled to remain on him, falling to the side. Although Fumiko had picked up on her movements enough to notice that her elbow clonked him across the temple, knocking him unconscious.

"You're...Ostuka?"

"Tatsuki Otsuka *hic*," the disgraced former monk replied with a drunken grin. She picked up one of her drinking gourds but was saddened to find that it was empty.
1233212.title: Drunken Mastery

choices: So how is the food in prison, as Fumiko and Tatsuki find themselves there?
All out brawl round two, as Fumiko and Tatsuki team up to dodge the law!
There's a perfectly orderly and non-violent way to resolve this dispute.
12332123.content:
Much as the fight had excited her, for Fumiko what was most important was that she could finish her meal in peace. She eagerly turned back to her rice but a crestfallen expression passed the wannabe sumo's face. "What happened to my chopsticks?"

Tatsuki was still searching for imaginary drops from her dry gourd. "*hic*?"

"Eww," Fumiko finally spotted the wayward chopsticks, at the bottom of a mess from an overturned, broken table from when the drunken monk fought off the disruptive duo. Fumiko sighed. "Well, I'm not letting this go to waste."

She began shoveling rice into her mouth with her free hand, chewing at a breakneck pace so as to make up for lost time. Her other hand cupped the bowl protectively.

"Yur sure eat a lot," Tatsuki said with slurred speech.

Annoyed at being interrupted again, Fumiko just scowled. Although the threat was lost from her full cheeks. "Ygn donf bu chulkt."

Tatsuki paused before searching about her possessions. "Sorry, *hic* no chalk."

"Mueau," Fumiko swallowed, "--No, you're one to talk!" Fumiko was a tinge jealous that Tatsuki Otsuka had more girth on her, as they looked to have similar heights and builds. "I've got to gain weight for sumo! I won't get anywhere if I stay at this featherweight weight class."

"Oh," the disheveled monk nodded knowingly, having procured a bottle. "Sumo s'takes a lot of training."

"I knowgh," Fumiko replied curtly as she ate through her words.

"Lots'a discipline," Tatsuki made a sour face. It had not been booze but soy sauce.

"I'm plenty *gulp* disciplined!" Fumiko retorted, with a handful of rice to her lips as she talked with her mouth full. This woman didn't know just how much of the day Fumiko dedicated to training her body.

"That's the one!" a furious voice came from the entrance to the sake house. The disruptive man who had been kicked out of the shop was back with local guard, their swords drawn. "She's the miscreant right there!"

Tatsuki was pouring the rest of the soy sauce in an emptied drinking gourd. "Who, *hic* me?"

Half forgotten, the other man started to stir from underneath Otsuka's rump and began crying out again.

A guard came over. "On your feet, both of you."

"Hey!" Fumiko protested, spitting out some of her precious rice. "I didn't do anything but have my dinner interrupted! She's the one that was fighting them."

A set of guards had descended on Tatsuki Otsuka, trying to heave her up and remove an actual bottle of sake she had managed to find.

"Actually," the owner of the restaurant spoke up from his counter, the rest of the place having oddly become vacant of the other customers in the wake of Ostuka's fight with the two men. "They were both causing disorder, interrupting my other customers."

Fumiko swallowed the wrong way, having a coughing fit from rice almost entering her lungs. "I didn't--" she gestured towards the two men, the one that had gone for the guard and the other recovering from being the drunken monk's pillow, "they paid off everybody else when they were the ones causing a ruckus!"

"Isn't that what they all say," the cynical guard replied. "You're both under arrest for a breach of the peace!"

Arrested? All Fumiko had wanted out of the evening was more dinner.
12332123.title: Does the Crime Fit the Punishment?

choices: ...a rather run-down hovel.
...a monastary.
...a large and wealthy-looking mansion!
123321232.content:
"Listen you-!" Fumiko started to fume, but was cut off as her arms were violently wrenched behind her back, a coarse rope tightened around her wrists. "I-"

"Enough of your tall tales," the guard sneered at her. "We're going on a walk to the magistrate and then to a nice cozy cell, and if you so much as breath too loudly I'll put you down myself!"

"Ssuch rude....rudenesh," Otsuka slurred as the other guard struggled to keep his grip on her as she swayed, her beer-fed belly wobbling in time with her movements. The guard restraining Fumiko rolled his eyes.

"Just hit her aside the head and carry her, you fool."

"She's twice my size!" the other guard complained, sparking another pang of jealousy inside the wannabee sumo as Otsuka pitched forward, the guard approaching from behind. "I'm not going to lift her fat ass on my shoulders."

This time Fumiko saw the subtle hints before it happened, catching the drunken woman shifting her stance ever so slightly, her head tilting at just the right angle. Fighting drunken loudmouths was one thing, but she wasn't seriously going to try and fight off the city guards, was she? She couldn't...she wouldn't!

The guard reached for the drunken monk's arms, letting out a little gasp of surprise when she ducked out of the way and grabbed his wrist over her shoulder, giving a great tug and lifting the guard onto her shoulders!

"Heard shomeone ssay...liftin' people s'hard...?" Otsuka murmured, tossing the guard off her shoulders where he crashed into a heap behind her. "See...very *hic* easy..."

The guard in front of Fumiko reached for his sword, but Fumiko had had enough. This corrupt fool had accused her of a crime she didn't commit, helped to cover for an abusive drunkard that tried to harass her, and was about to kill the woman who at least up until this point had saved her life.

And perhaps most egregiously of all, he had utterly ruined her dinner!!!

*CRACK*

The guard reeled backwards, blood covering his face as it poured from a nose shattered by Fumiko's forehead strike. Teeth bared, the man drew his blade with a flourish and swung wildly in her direction. Fumiko dodged the blows, a few coming close enough that she could feel the temperature of the cold steel on her skin, and ducked behind the bar in time to avoid a stab that embedded itself in the sturdy wood. Hearing the sounds of furniture being smashed where Otsuka was fighting, she glanced towards the corner to see the admittedly amusing sight of seats flying through the air and the distinctive sound of metal on wood.

Hearing the sword being pulled free behind her, Fumiko tried to chew off the ropes binding her hands together, but it was too tight. Salvation came however when a sword flew across the room from where Otsuka was fighting, landing in between Fumiko's legs and embedding into the floor. Thinking quickly, she cut the ropes with the edge of the sword and rolled to the side as her own opponent vaulted the bar and made a rough stab in her area. With the blood coating his lips and staining his snarled teeth, he looked particularly savage as he rounded on her, but she was undeterred. If there was anything she knew from the art of sumo, it was that when you lose control, you lose the fight, in or out of the ring.

"Would you like me to rearrange your nose again?" Fumiko taunted.

"I'll kill you AND your drunken lout of a friend!" the guard hissed, waving his blade threateningly. "You stupid, skinny..."

The Guard felt the wind and the life knocked out of him as the wannabe sumo charged, slamming into his chest and knocking his weapon clear. Fumiko may not have had the bulk of a sumo yet, but she had the strength and style of one, and on a regular old brute like this one, it worked just fine. Knocking aside tables and glassware as she traveled, the sumo performed a textbook maneuver to launch an opponent out of the ring, and the guard smashed clean through the wall of the restaurant, moaning briefly before he fell unconscious. Flexing her arms triumphantly, she found that the original troublemaker and his friend were long gone, as was the owner. Scared away, or heading to find more help? Probably best not to stick around and find out.

Fumiko nearly started another fight when someone clapped a hand on her shoulder, only to realize it was Otsuka, looking no worse or sober then before. Behind her, a very out-of-sorts Guard was crouched over on the ground, his head firmly planted into the wooden floorboards like an ostrich.

"I think...we should find 'nother hidey hole," Otsuka hiccuped. "I know a placesh..."

"Lead on then," Fumiko insisted.

The pair of them ducked out the side door, just as a commotion sounded out front. Her head starting to cool from the adrenaline rush, Fumiko thought about the situation at hand as she trailed the drunken woman through the snow with surprising speed and agility. Becoming an outlaw was not going to help her on the path to becoming a proper sumo; her best chance was to lay low for a while until this blew over, hoping that the guards would lose interest with a relatively minor crime. This would cut into her training dramatically, but what else could she do? Her mood was already souring quickly when Otsuka staggered to a stop.

"We're...hic....here!"

Fumiko blinked, realizing the woman had brought her to...
123321232.title: I Fought the Law and the Law Got Its Hide Tanned

choices: Hiding out hits a snag as Ostuka and Fumiko run out of food.
Fumiko asks Ostuka to spar with her, to continue her training.
Wanting to gain weight quickly, Fumiko tries to copy Ostuka's diet
The hovel provides shelter only for so long, as the outlaws are soon found out.
1233212321.content:
"What a dump!" Fumiko cringed. The ruined hovel made Mr. Nakamura's place look like a palace. The building, all half burnt wood and tattered banners, listed to one side, having to supported by various mounds of rubbish next to it.

"You actually live here?" Fumiko asked, horrified.

"S'not really," Tatsuki Ostuka slurred, ducking into the door, "but itss a good place to 'void notice," she punctuated with another hiccup.

Unfortunately, Fumiko didn't have many options but to trust the disgraced monk at this point. The incident at the sake house was going to draw a lot of undue attention. Fumiko made her way inside, careful to not brush against any load bearing supports, or the whole hovel might collapse on them.

The interior was dank and dim, with a bit of a smell, but thankfully it was dry and not too cold. Ostuka was trying to light some kindling over a small fire, although clearly she had too much to drink as she failed to keep the sticks in the correct positions.

Fumiko sighed, finding herself a spot to sit on a mound of rags. "Here, let me."

The trainee sumo channeled her frustrations into hot friction along the sticks, starting a small fire that made the accommodations more bearable. The hovel could have been a lot worse.

The drunken monk must have frequented this place, as she loosened a different drinking gourd stashed away in a wall nook. "So, wash your name?"

"Fumiko."

Ostuka took in this information with a long draught of her gourd. "And what makes you want to be a sumo?"

Fumiko stopped adding more sticks to the fire. "How did you know I want to be one?"

"S'popular place for sumos, there," Ostuka gestured, "and your fighting style is sumo based, not the most dish'iplined."

"I'm plenty disciplined," Fumiko fumed. "I'm training very hard at this!"

"And hot tempered," replied the drunken woman.

"Well--" Fumiko tried to think of a rebuttal but was caught off guard by Ostuka's mirthful glance. While she had gotten Fumiko landed into this mess, she had also helped her out of it, and that wasn't even the direct root of the problem. "--why wouldn't you be angry, with those deplorable men paying off the sake house for their lecherous causes! Nobody else stood up to 'em. And those sumos at the higher weight class can brush it off because they think they're so high and mighty."

"So you think you're better?"

"I will be better," Fumiko declared. "I'm going to be the strongest, the toughest and the biggest sumo in these mountains." The declaration fell flat in the ruined interior of their current hideout, and her rumbling stomach reminded Fumiko that she was setback on her original goal; upping her caloric intake so she could gain weight for sumo.

A twang of jealousy at Ostuka's plump, bulging form filled her voice again as Fumiko asked "Don't you have anything to eat around here?"

Ostuka looked pensive. "Posh-ibbli, if the mites haven't gotten to it."

That didn't fill Fumiko with confidence as she watched the disheveled monk dig around pots and baskets. "Plenty of red beans."

"Give me," Fumiko said, sad it wasn't a steaming bowl of rice but she needed something to stay on her regime.

Ostuka passed her a bowl. "I got picked fish in here," she opened the wooden lid of a vessel, releasing a sour stench. "Herring, eel..."

Fumiko gritted her teeth and willed her nostrils closed. "Some of that too."

As she watched the preserved fish congeal on the bowl of red beans, Fumiko contemplated the calories she could get. The fish was at least a protein source, and the red beans were pretty much paste and baking away from being like a red bean bun for desert.

"I think I might have some stuff hidden away for a hotpot," Ostuka continued, now that she had found a pot to sit on the flames. Silence descended in the hovel for several minutes as Fumiko chewed and chewed as Ostuka readied a steam pot of miscellany. It was getting a bit steamy in the shack, sweat formed on Fumiko's brow. Her host also looked red faced, or that was probably just the drink, as she brushed her long black hair aside.

Up close, Fumiko got a full look at the burn over half of the monk's rounded face. The burn scars spread across her cheek up towards her ear, with the organ and eye being unscarred. The scar itself was a lurid color as Ostuka looked to have had a dark, wine colored birthmark on that side of her face before the burn.

Curiosity getting the better of her, Fumiko asked after she had swallowed her last mouthful, "So how did you get burned?"

Ostuka took a long swing to empty the last of her gourd, also getting herself a bowl of beans. "Do you really want to know?"

"Yes."

Ostuka paused to eat her own food. "The magistrate threw hot coals from a lantern on my face as punishment."

"She...what?" Fumiko might have choked on her food. The magistrate of Futotta-Machi was said to be a beautiful, yet steely woman who operated on top of the feudal hierarchy that operated in these Eastern mountains.

"S'not really much of a story," Ostuka said, deflecting the issue.

Fumiko tried to piece together what she had learned about her drunken host in this short timeframe. "But those perverts said you were kicked out of a monastery, but you don't have any fox tails."

"Fox tails?" Ostuka replied. "Oh, the Kitsune. No, their monastery is one for meditation and ritual to contact the higher powers. I belonged to the monastery of warrior scholars, ones often in service to the magistrate's court."

Fumiko was about to ask more but another bowl of red beans and eel was pushed into her face. "Eat up, once your done I'll take this off the boil."

Diet beat out curiosity as Fumiko focused back on her food. The conversation died down to the crunch of red beans and slurps of eel. Fumiko had only seen the former monk drink her meals up to this point, but Ostuka could put away the food as well. Soon the hotpot was finished, a miasma of spent ends, bits of food scraps and some lone veggies about to spoil. Nothing spectacular but not that horrible. Provided there was food to be had, Fumiko would train to better her appetite and weight class.

13.content:
Ooh, sounds mysterious. Very well, where would you like to go now?

Samin Desert: Perhaps the harshest climate in the region, the Samin Desert is not an easy place to live. That however, hasn’t stopped its inhabitants. Various warlords stake their claims out in the sands and will battle with each other for precious resources. Some of the best warlord are known to have the conjuring powers of a vessel-djinn in their possession as well. Natural-djinn also live in the area, forming cities and societies of their own where they can pursue their endless quest for knowledge.

Roiling Bay: Found in the southernmost tip of the land, Roiling Bay serves as Yndyre’s major trade hub. This bustling city is home to many species, but the demographic is mainly made up of human pirates and sea traders as well as the handful of adventurous merfolk who trade with them. Just what lies beyond the southern seas? Well, that is for our pirates and sea farers to find out, but it is rumored that sirens might lie nearby.

Motee Marshes: Connected to the border of the eastern region, the jungles of the Motee Marshes are steeped in mystery. It is quite easy for one to become lost in this vast jungle. However, it is not devoid of civilization. The naga clans build massive temples and stone structures in the heart of this land, forever devoted to the gods. Rakshasa tribes run and hunt on the fringes of the area, trying to find the biggest and baddest game out there.

131.title: Samin Desert: Warlord and djinn sound so romantic.

choices: Follow Grargi as she heads for the dining hall.
The warlord and his advisor discuss what to do next.
Grargi gets lost in the halls.
1312.content:
The streets of the city of Adinah were home to many things, but mostly they presented a huge opportunity for anyone wishing to sell their wares to the largest customer base in the land. Sure the market stalls of the Samin Desert were famous, but they were located far from many potential buyers. So the streets of Adinah were the best alternative. And it is here where one warlord from the Samin Desert itself can be found searching for his first purchase on rising to power.

“Remind me again why I have to do this…” Warlord Sal-Dalin muttered to his advisor as they wound their way through the narrow passages between the city stalls, his eyes keenly observing for any potential pick-pockets eyeing him up.

“My lord, you MUST have a harem, it is customary from any person within a position of power to surround themselves with beauty; it shows status, it shows wealth (the bigger they are the better), connections and builds positive relations with other regions” the adviser reminded him in a slightly scolding tone.

"Fine, but let us be done with this affair as soon as possible, I find these markets detestable” Sal-Dalin noted as he stared daggers at some salesman trying to oversell a piece of pottery for far more than it’s worth.

The duo made their way through many stalls, some dealing in potential members for a harem, but each time Sal-Dalin was not satisfied.

“But my lord, she is beautiful and extremely well fed” the warlords advisor exclaimed, trying to convince the man that a very overweight Harpie was being sold for a good price. Sal-Dalin simply shook his head, from what he knew of harpies they were constantly as hungry as a starved pig. It would be much cheaper to find a thin Harpie and let nature take its course.

“No, come along Tar-quil, I see nothing here” Sal-Dalin stated flatly, eager to get away from the creepy salesman.

“My lord, please stay, I…I might have something in your taste right here!” the man in the shop stuttered before hurrying himself and the fat feathered woman away, returning with a pitch-black and much thinner slave. “A Rakshasa from the Motee Marshes, very rare coloring” the man gestured as the potential buyers surveyed the new entrant. She was clearly a Rakshasa, quite well-built and with black skin and short black fur.

“Is she…safe? I hear the Rakshasa’s eat…meat…plentifully” Sal-Dalin half-asked already knowing which way he leaned with this potential purchase.

“I can assure you she is quite tame, I had her claws trimmed this morni-YEOWCH!”

Sal-Dalin and Tar-Quil jumped as they watched the cat-like woman lunge at her “handler” digging her long canines savagely onto his hand. Thankfully her arms were tied, or things would have become much bloodier. The stunned pair watched as she was quickly ferried to the back as well, with the shop-keeper returning a few minutes later, hand-bandaged and a rope being held in the other.

“One last one….I can assure you this one does NOT bite” the salesman almost scowled as he tugged on the thin chain. And out from the back emerged a thin, red-skinned woman with a pair of long horns and fur-covered cloven hooves on her feet. “I can offer a low price on this one, most turn their noses up at keeping a…demon in their harems…” he stated, teasing the woman’s species out with a grin. While she was rather short and petite, her horns jutting out the sides of her head and her blood-colored skin easily singled her out as a demon.

“A demon!? How by the gods did you come by one?” Sal-Dalin asked in shock. Demons were immensely powerful and servants to nobody but their basal urges.

“I will not drag your stay in our beloved city out with a tale of how I can across such a rare and beautiful creature, but if you are interested I can have her ready to go immediately”.

Sal-Dalin stared at the woman, her beauty was entrancing, even though he could not see her face fully due to her bowed head, and a demon would certainly shut Tal-Quil up about needing a whole harem if he had a DEMON in the palace. “We will take her” the warlord stated firmly as he advisers eyes bugged, she might be trouble.

The ride back was uneventful, almost eerily so in fact. The demon simply sat on the horse that had been provided, hands clenched into fists, her body physically trembling.

After some time on the road, they made it back to Sal-Dalin’s palace. It was modest by palace standards, barely taller than the surrounding buildings and possessing little in the way of distinct architecture.

On arrival, the Warlords new consort was shown her quarters and given some robes to wear.

“Here is your dress, veil and top, I hope they are to your liking; we have also provided you with the best room in the palace, there is a built-in spring if you wish to freshen up” Sal-Dalim stated, offering the clothes. While they were rather revealing, they were certainly not as ridiculous as the almost string-like garments the demon was currently dressed in. He hoped that the idea of wearing something more appropriate might cheer her up, but she still refused to meet his gaze. Sal-Dalim wondered if her refusal to look at him was a pride thing, demons were normally care-free, so being caught must really have shaken her.

***


Some time later the warlord and his advisor were in the throne room, discussing general affairs, but mostly the recent acquisition.

“I am telling you it is bad luck to keep a demon in the palace, let alone what mischief she may cause, she probably spent the whole trip back plotting some horrible revenge” Tal-Quil ranted and raved, pacing back and forth in front of the throne.

“Calm yourself man, she is as timid as a baby unicorn, I am sure we won’t be having an trouble from her” the warlord sighed, rubbing his forehead with his thumb and fore-finger. As he did, a *clip-clop* noise signalled the aforementioned demon’s arrival. “Ah! Here she comes now!” Sal-Dalin announced as the entrance curtain to the room parted revealing a figure with light-brown skin and a pale expanse over her stomach. It LOOKED like the warlords demon he bought for his harem…but her skin color had changed! How did this happen?

“I…I hoped this wouldn’t h-happen” the woman stuttered, now dressed in a short light-blue dress and matching top & veil bearing the warlords banner symbol on them.

“What…what!?” the advisor exclaimed, almost jumping out of his black robes.

“My….former master misled you…I am not a demon…at all, he p-poured red dye over me to try and get a better price…I am actually a minotaur” she continued, muttering towards her hooves as she poked the ground with the tip of one of them.

“I knew that trawling the markets was a bad idea” Sal-Dalin grumbled as he glared at his advisor. “Tell me; what is your name?”

“Grargi, master” the minotaur replied, now holding her tail in both hands. Rising from his throne, Sal-Dalin took a closer look at her. It seemed the shifty salesman had shaved some of Grargi’s fur in places, to make her look more demonic, like her legs and the tip of her tail. Her loincloth had also hidden her udder, which thanks to the short skirt Sal could now just about make out.

“Aren’t you rather…small for a minotaur?” Sal asked, causing the half-cow to flinch a little.

“Y-yes, I am, I was the smallest of my family” Grargi pointed out.

“Well, I will send for someone to scrub your bath, I am sure it is stained redder than a battlefield right now, for now make yourself comfortable in the dining hall, I will have someone prepare you a meal.”

At this Grargi gave a short bow and hurried off, her hooves clip-clopping off into the distance. She never had much of an appetite, but after this ordeal, she could really go for a big hot meal.

*Chapter provided by Trampltrum
1312.title: Not as Advertised*

choices: We pamper them endlessly. They are a gift from the gods.
We treat them as our equals. Our line cannot continue without them.
They are more than concubines. They are our companions.
Only the gods can give us a sign that two people were meant to be.
13122.content:
Sal-Dalin sat upon his throne, a deep contemplative look upon his face. "My lord," Tal-Quil began to plea, "let's not do anything rash now. Even I was fooled."

The warlord shook his head. "No, no, I'm keeping a clear head. And I intend to do nothing short of what is expected of a man in my position. I will organize a small party to go back to Adinah and retrieve our little merchant friend, quietly, of course, and without making a scene. Besides, that'll keep his head fresher for when I mount it outside my walls."

For the young warlord, that was actually tame by comparison to some of the bolder actions he had taken upon becoming chief of his clan. Tal-Quil breathed a small sigh of relief for that. "There is still the matter of the minotaur, sir. What are we to do with her? I mean, it wouldn't be practical, and she's certainly not suitable, and..."

"Oh, not as suitable as a demon or a rakshasa, both of which would have been great dangers?" Sal-Dalin mocked. "To be honest, this is even better than we could've hoped. At least with her, she could bear me sons, strong ones at that. I've seen what male minotaurs can look like. As a demon, she was more for show. Minotaurs are just as unseen in these parts. She's exotic enough. The only thing unsuitable about any of this was the price we paid for her."

Tal-Quil was at a loss for words. When the warlord made up his mind, there was very little anyone could do to change it. "So, you'll keep her?" was all he could ask.

He shrugged. "I see no reason not to. She's a wife, she's something different to show off, she can give me sons, and she's submissive. What more do I need to ask for? We found what we were looking for."

"Well, there is still the matter of perhaps finding a few other wives to fill out your harem. A warlord is judged by..."

Sal-Dalin only gave him a sharp look. "No more markets," he said shortly. "A true warlord takes his wives from the spoils of battle."

Tal-Quil shrunk back. "Of course, sir. Right away, sir."

The young warlord, in the meantime, decided to actually speak with his new bride. Sal-Dalin may have been ruthless with his enemies, and he may have had a reputation for his tough-love approach to ruling his own people, but let it be known, he was not a cruel man. He recognized that frightened look in the minotaur, and he wanted to put her at ease about her new living arrangements.

He found her slurping down a hot broth prepared by his cooks. Given how she practically inhaled her food, he was inclined to believe she hadn't seen a hot meal in a while. He was actually surprised. Not many foreigners could handle some of the hotter spices of the south. Then again, perhaps she was eating too fast to notice.

Sal-Dalin sat across from her, and that was the first time she became aware of his presence in the room. She gasped a little, wiping the hot soup from her muzzle before bowing her head a little. He laughed. "You don't need to stop on my account," he said. "I merely wanted to see that everything was too your liking."

Grargi nodded, not daring to meet his eyes. "It is, you majesty. Thank you."

"Majesty?" he said with a loud guffaw. "Now, that's a good one. No, no, my dear, I'm not like the king of that noisy city. We warlords are much more humble than that. None of us rule the south, though many would like to. We fight for land, for resources, and such, and that's about it. If anything, we're just very good generals, running our armies."

"I see," she said. She seemed almost afraid of him whenever she spoke. That was to be expected, he thought. She was in a new land, having been bought by a warlord who slaughtered armies on a whim.

"Tell me about yourself," he said gently, hoping to elicit more than just a few simple sentences from the minotaur.

She looked at him curiously for a moment, not sure if he was serious about his question. Eventually, she spoke up. "There's not much to tell. I was born on a farm and raised by my parents. I was one of seven kids, and we all worked the fields once we were old enough to walk. It was fun because we got to be outside all the time. That must sound boring to you."

"Not at all," he said. "Contrary to what others have said about us, many of our people would like nothing better than to have a stable lifestyle like that. The constant fighting between our tribes wears us down. But, how did you end up in the market."

Grargi swallowed another spoonful of soup. "Well, my family fell on some hard times. One of the local barons was starting to overtax all of us. My parents couldn't afford to take care of all of us. Some man came by our house and offered to take some of us in exchange for money. He promised my parents he would be taking us to some sort of school to help us get jobs in the city. He took me and two of my sisters. He lied to us. My sisters were sold a few weeks ago. I don't know where they went. Erigine might have been sold to a brothel, but I don't know for sure. And that's when you found me."

Sal-Dalin felt justified mounting this crook's head on a pike once he found him. Such an absolute monster. The warlord wished there was more he could have done for the frightened minotaur. He would have liked to have found her sisters for her, but in a big city like Adinah, they could be lost to the world. Instead, he laid a comforting hand on her shoulder.

"That is all over now," he said. "Know this, you are safe in my home, and I will never lay a hand on you unless you will it."

"But, I'm now your wife, or your concubine, or something now," she said, tears forming in her eyes. "Aren't you supposed to..."

"Shh, I will not do anything unless you ask. One thing you should know about a warlord's wife is..."

1313.title: More Desert Choices
