13131.content:
Alexia's blades whirled, and she struck down another bandit. As the man fell, she turned to face down another one. All around her were the sounds of combat, the clash of blades and the screams of the wounded.

Alexia loved it all.

Soon enough, though, the battle (really more of a skirmish) came to an end as the morale of the bandit group broke down completely and the survivors fled into the desert. Alexia lifted one of her curved swords into the air, and let out a yell of triumph. The soldiers under her command (at least those who could) imitated the action. After that, it was time for the usual activities after combat. Wounded warriors had to be looked after, the dead were gathered for the last rites, and a million other little things.

Alexia left those matters to her soldiers, and instead walked over towards the merchant caravan. It appeared that not one of the bandits had gotten near it, an unqualified victory for her. This was, after all, the first merchant caravan that had approached her for protection, had given the proper respect and deference when asking to travel through her territory. She'd be a sorry excuse for a warlord if she couldn't police the lands she'd claimed, after all.

She paused as she passed the nearest wagon, seeing herself in one of the mirrors that was being transported aboard it. She was dressed in her armor, which consisted of a metal cuirass that she'd stolen when she'd set out on her own. Her wide hips and strong legs were clad in simple pants, and she wore a pair of sturdy boots. She noticed some wounds marring her bronze skin, though nothing fatal. She ran a hand through her red hair, and shook her head. There was a reason she'd walked over here, after all. Better to not get sucked into preening over her appearance like some of the airheads in her father's harem.

The caravan leader, a middle-aged man dressed in fine silks that almost concealed his potbelly, saw her approach. He got up to meet her, and bowed to her.

"It would appear that the tales of your skill were not exaggerated in the least, Lady Alexia," he said.

Alexia smirked. Sure, he was laying on the flattery a little thick, but it felt damn good to hear after today's battle. "Naturally. You sought my protection, and I have granted it. I always keep my word."

"Of course, of course!" the merchant replied, bobbing his head up and down. "And, I was thinking..."

Alexia waited for a moment, then made a gesture with her hand for the man to continue. "Well, my company's caravans travel this way quite often, as it is one of the safer routes from the Roiling Bay up to the center of the realm. And your control of the area has made it safer! So, my thought is that a friendlier relationship between my company and your army could only benefit the both of us."

"What did you have in mind?" Alexia asked.

"Why, with a gift of course! I am prepared to offer you..."
13131.title: Alexia the Desert Warlord

choices: …raven haired beauty and a bit plump at that.

131311.content:
"Why, with a gift of course! I am prepared to offer you my daughter to be your concubine."

“Is that so? Alexia asked, watching how the merchant stared at the blood dripping from her blade. “Are you sure you wouldn’t want to offer me a son instead?”

He tore his eyes aware from the gore staining the sand and fixed his wide eyes on hers. “No, Lady Alexia, word of your…” He paused as he searched for a tactful way to put it, “…tastes…has spread some ways, so I am well aware that such an offer would be to your liking.”

“Really?” she wondered aloud, adding as much false shock to that word as she could. “And what, pray tell, else about me has ‘spread some ways’?” putting a bit of force in her voice.

The merchant leader sputtered and turned a frightful shade much paler than his typical swarthy hue. He then spent the next several minutes praising Alexia and her band of warriors. She rather thought that made up some of it on the spot, but it all sounded rather good in any case. She might need to borrow some of the tales herself to better stake her claim as the powerful and rightful ruler of her territory.

While he continued to blather on, Alexia turned her focus to the possibility of adding another woman to her harem. The several she had already were fantastic and well worth the trouble she had in keeping them happy. Yet, a new one might be a welcome change of pace. She did feel some concern about the process though. The others came to Alexis of their own will, wanting nothing to do with the threat of suffering under one of the more brutish warlords that stalked the Samin. This merchant’s daughter might not be so willing to be used as trade object, much as Alexis faced before she struck out on her own.

She decided she could at least examine the woman; see if it was worth her time and effort. The rest of her band were still busy with their tasks while the scouts moved ahead to investigate the path ahead.

“Is she with you?” Alexis interrupted the merchant at last.

“Y-ye-yes, of course, Lady Alexis, I thought you might be interested, so I brought her along just in case.” Alexis saw the twinkle in his eye, and knew he was eager to close a deal that was so close, he could almost taste it. “Please, if you wouldn’t mind, come this way.”

He then turned to lead the warlord back along the wagon train. Several carts later, he peaked through the cloth and asked someone to step out. He helped the young woman to step out into the blazing sun where Alexis got her first good look of her potential new woman. She is a…
131311.title: An offer

choices: Clattering mail and hooves...a wandering knight errant, perhaps?
The beating of wings. Ooh, this should be interesting.
Grunting? No, wait...is that a warboar?
13132.content:
The Samin Desert is not a realm for the timid. Few dare to brave its desolate wastes, save destitute souls with nothing to lose or traders taking a million to one gamble on crossing. It is a world of sand and death, where the sting of scorpions wait amidst the dunes, dancing mirages come to life to torment the minds of the weak-willed, and hardened warlords scour the sands in search of money and power, holding their lives and the lives of their prey cheap. And yet, many still chose to brave the dunes, drawn by its mysticism or the promise of great rewards for those that survive, and some may even come to a small oasis that seems to pop out of the ground as one approaches.

The closer you get to the cluster of trees, the more the oppressive heat and blasted wind fades, until you can touch the bark of palm trees amidst a balmy, almost pleasant breeze, an almost magical feeling after so many days underneath a burning sun. Indeed it is a magical feeling, because amidst the trees, you might just find the creator of this little sanctuary from the blood and sand.

"Ahhh..."

Sirocco sighed, basking in the noon sun as she reclined in her hammock strung between two palm trees, swaying back and forth with the wind. Dressed in her chest wrap and sarong, the light blue Djinn glistened in the light like the cool waters of the oasis, her wild orange hair falling in bundles around her head. Resting her eyes, she smacked her lips thinking of the last good meal she had. A succulent veal, roasted to perfection with a hint of lemon. She reached down to stroke the curve of her stomach, remembering how she had given the merchant who brought it for her quite a lot of gold and gems for that meal, it was so good. How long ago was that, then? A month? Maybe two? Perhaps when the merchant came back he'd find another offering for her.

It annoyed her to no end that this long waiting period between visitors had become the norm. Was her mission so difficult that it needed further explanation? Bring her a meal worth her time, and you'll be rewarded. Much less complicated then the deals and bargains that she once used to play the desert like her own personal chessboard, an activity she had long ago gotten bored with, and to be fair a lot more fun, since it was something she couldn't experience herself. Oh sure, she could summon up a succulent feast with the blink of an eye, and to the dulled senses of a mortal it would indeed be succulent. But to a Djinn, especially one like her? It was sustenance, and bland sustenance at that, so easy to tell that it's not the real thing. She wanted flavor, texture, something delectable that she could enjoy because real, mortal hands made it.

The breeze suddenly picked up, and Sirocco's eyes opened wide. She could tell in an instant from the sound of shifting sand upon the horizon; someone was coming! Sirocco stepped out of the hammock, her toes sinking into the sand as she held a hand to her ear, picking up the sounds of...
13132.title: Sirocco

choices: The orc woman recovers the next day, and makes her wish.
The orc woman stays with Sirocco for quite a while, recovering from her trauma.
The orc woman wakes up in the middle of the night, she's up to no good!
131323.content:
It was indeed a warboar, Sirocco could tell from a distance. Some would be surprised to see an exotic creature such as that so far from the dustbowl, but the genie knew better. Boars were hardy creatures, able to survive almost any environment, and while they were no camels their low, wide stance made them better for trekking across the desert then horses at the very least.

Enough speculating though...it was time to put on a performance. Turning her back to the approaching figure and staring wistfully into the distance, pretending not to notice anyone coming. The aloofness helped to make her seem alien and exotic to those that came to her mystical oasis, ensuring those who brought her gifts that she was the one they were looking for. She sniffed the air as the hooves drew closer. Dust, leathers, fur...and fresh blood. An orc, no doubt about it, a creature as unusual in the desert as those rideable boars. She'd never even been visited by orcs, even after hundreds of years of visitors from all around. This might be fun!

Finally, she smirked to herself as the sound of the boar's trodding footsteps lessened, and a heavy thump indicated the rider had dismounted.

"You See-roco?" came a questioning grunt of a voice, deep but unmistakably feminine. The djinn winced at the mispronunciation. Definitely an orc, she thought as spun around, fanning her hair out behind her elegantly.

"Oh...a -ulp- visitor, for me?" she said playfully, only pausing when her stomach swung around with her and almost tossed her off balance. "My, haven't we come a long way!"

"Er, yes, I suppose," the orc woman said, looking mildly annoyed but mostly confused. Sauntering up to her gave Sirocco a chance to look over her new visitor, standing a head taller with a mane of tangled black hair, severe dark eyes, and typically gray-green skin. Her bare arms and lower legs bulged with powerful muscles, and it looked like they had been put to use recently; the fur on her animal skin jerkin was matted with dried blood in places, a fresh bandage was wrapped around her forearm, and her left eye was squinting from a nasty looking swollen bruise on her cheek. Sirocco made sure to note the spear on her back as well as the jagged sabre in her hilt...just in case.

"So what is it the great Sirocco can do for you, my darling?" the djinn cooed, confident that even this brute of a woman posed no danger to her.

"I hear you grant wishes for a good meal," the orc woman said. "I make you one." Sirocco blinked at the orc's bluntness as she shook a satchel strap off her shoulder and began preparing a cooking area right there in front of her.

"Uh, well...go ahead," she said. "Feel free to gather water from the spring, if you need it." The orc nodded in thanks, fetching some to put in a bowl. Getting the impression that the orc wasn't the talkative type, she waved her fingers and the hammock vanished and reappeared between the two trees next to her. Lying down to leave the orc to her work, the smells of burning wood filled the air, along with...

"Done."

Sirocco blinked, rising from the hammock at once to float over to the orc woman, eager to try out what possible concoction the orc could have made, only to find a singular large pot with brackish liquid and chunks of vegetables and meats floating inside.

"...soup?"

"Stew, but...yes," the orc nodded. "Simple, but good and hearty, filling too. Try some."

Sirocco yelped as the orc shoved a piping hot bowl into her hands, nearly singing her fingers in the process. She stared at the offending bowl, barely hiding her look of disgust. Months, almost years of waiting, and she was visited by a strange new creature, only to get...soup! That was barely a meal, barely even the START of a meal! Why if anyone had dared to pass this off as worth her time back in the old days, they'd find themselves blasted into neat little pieces and rearranged backwards! SOUP? She looked back at the orc, expecting her to be smirking or barely restraining laughter, but she was stone-faced. Rolling her eyes, the djinn summoned a golden spoon and took a generous helping of the soup, popping it into her mouth.

"Is this really the best you can offer me?" she said as she chewed and swallowed. "I've given judgement on many and...oh....oh!"

What...what was that? That savory flavor? Right away, she dove in with her spoon to sample it again, eager to see what that wonderful taste was and...goodness, could it be? Dustroots and carrots, who knew they'd be so delightful together? And it's so thick and hardy, she could feel her whole body warming up with every bite, and even in this weather she didn't break a sweat! It was...by the gods, it was astounding!

"So, did you like it?" The djinn was shocked out of her reverie by the orc's question. The spoon seemed to lay forgotten in the sand, she realized; she had tried to lick the bowl clean.

"It was...good!" Sirocco said, pleasantly surprised as she summoned a second spoon. "Another helping, please?" The orc quietly ladled another spoonful and Sirocco almost dove in, keeping her head together but indulging in the stew with delight.

"Ohhh, no need to bother with pretense, you have your wish!" the djinn said, practically glowing as she stuffed her cheeks full. "Make your wish, my dear, whatever your heart's desire!" She stared excitedly as the orc crossed her arms, thinking to herself what she could get from this magical denizen. A flawlessly made sword, a mighty new warboar, perhaps even a powerful magical item to help her win every battle and never be harmed again. She could make them all just for her and then some, and there was no doubt her many enemies back home in the Dustbowl would give their oversized canines to have just a fraction of what this woman had won.

"I'm...not sure," the orc woman said. "I hadn't expected this to even work, but it was my last chance." Her voice cracked in the last few words and Sirocco saw the most surprising thing of all; a tear welling in her eye.

"Well...I can make anything, you know!" the djinn said, emitting dancing lights from her hands in a display of her powers. "Weapons, armor, gold, anything to help you fight your-!"

"NO!"

The djinn jumped backwards as the orc woman barked at her, baring her teeth.

"No more fighting! No more killing! I...I can't. Not anymore." The orc woman, breathing heavily, leaned against one of the palm trees, clutching her head. "Every time I try...her eyes, staring back at me...questioning...why I..."

Sirocco stepped forward cautiously, and realized that her shuddering breaths weren't from anger, but from open weeping. The orc woman sunk to the ground, holding her head in her hands as she kept sobbing. Dropping all pretenses of above-it-all aloofness, the djinn summoned a silken blanket, soft to the touch, wrapping it around the orc woman's shoulders. Bored as she may have been, her heart still ached at such a sight.

"There there..." she said reassuringly, patting her gently on the shoulder. "You stay as long as you need to, my dear..." This was an offer she'd never made to her visitors, not even once, but perhaps this was the one person in all the realms who needed it right now.

More then before, she was immensely curious about what this strange woman wanted from her.
131323.title: The Djinn and the Orc

choices: ...just crazy enough to work. Sirocco accepts!
...maybe a little too crazy. Sirocco says no.
...but not crazy enough. Sirocco has another idea!
1313231.content:
"Morning, my dear! Sleep well?"

Sirocco smiled, hovering a few inches off the ground as the orcish woman stirred, then blinked her eyes open, still curled around the animal skin blanket she slept under.

"Have you been...watching me?" the orc woman said suspiciously. "Djinn don't sleep."

"Why of course not," Sirocco lied, a little giggle escaping her lips. "Now, why don't you freshen up and we can talk, hm? The oasis is magically purified."

The woman grunted and shrugged, which the djinn took to mean 'thank you', pushing herself to her feet and staggering towards the water. Sirocco peered towards the horizon, spotting no telltale dust clouds for miles around.

"Say," she said idly. "You wouldn't happen to have any more of that soup would...what are you doing?"

The orc woman stopped wading into the oasis as the water reached her knees. "I'm...freshening up?" the woman said, like it was the most obvious thing in the world as she reached towards the bottom of her jerkin.

"I just thought you were going to splash water on your-" she started to say before the orc woman suddenly pulled the garment up and the djinn was suddenly made acutely aware of how long it had been since she had some real companionship as she exposed her chiseled, flawless abdominals and two perky but sizeable breasts flopped out, barely restrained by a rather thin chestwrap. Tossing the jerkin to shore, she reached up to undo the topknot of her hair, letting the whole mess fall in an elegant curtain down to her shoulders while Sirocco watched those perfect arms bulge with muscle. Dipping her head in the water entirely, she got just a hint of her rippling back muscles before she rose up again, shaking her head like a dog drying off as she combed through it with her fingers, giving off a satisfied sigh. The djinn's expression didn't crack, though she hoped that the cold sweat she broke out in watching this orc 'freshen up' wasn't noticeable, and she made an effort to suck in her stomach a little better, to no avail. Luckily for all involved, as the orc woman stepped out of the oasis, shaking the sand from her jerkin, she didn't seem to notice or care that they were both soaking wet right now.

"S-so, I don't think I got your-"

"Glem," the orcish woman said as she redid her hair.

"Oh, that's an odd name for an Orc."

"Because it's not," Glem said simply. "Almost the word for sand. First I could think of just now."

"Oh, I think I see, a pseudonym," Sirocco said delicately. "Trouble with the law?"

"No." Glem let out a deep sigh. "Let's...just say I forgot. Better for us both."

"Ah," the djinn said thoughtfully, her purple iris' gleaming as her mind worked. "So, it seems like what you want is a fresh start, then."

"Yes, and maybe you help?" Glem asked.

"Why of course! You did earn the wish after all! Just say what you want and-"

"No no, not wish. I have..." she trailed off, searching for the right word in the common tongue. "Proposal!" She didn't even wait to ask as she sat down on the overturned pot from last night, taking a deep breath. Sirocco got the distinct impression that Glem was about to give a 'proposal' that she had been prepping for days, maybe weeks.

"So...I don't want to kill and fight," she began. "But, all I know are two things; fighting, and cooking. So if I can't do one, I do other."

"Mmm," the djinn said noncommittally.

"This desert then, very perilous. Hard to cross, many die. But oasis like this, good place to stop and refresh!"

The image of Glem's chiseled biceps popped up in Sirocco's head again, her light blue cheeks darkening a bit as they flushed.

"If there were...place of rest here, then many could come and stop to refresh. Not just water, but place to sleep, and good meal! And I can make good meal! That would be good for me!"

"So...your wish is to make this place into a resting place for travelers?" Sirocco said, raising an unimpressed eyebrow.

"No no, not a wish! Proposal!" Glem repeated, reaching a fever pitch. "Now, with magic you can help make this place, and that way, more people bring you meals! People come in safer groups to find you, and news can spread over djinn that grants wishes for food! It's good idea, yes?"

Sirocco...was actually somewhat intrigued by this idea. Sure she didn't like the idea of turning her domain into a caravansarai, but it would be a great way to get more people to bring her a good meal in exchange for a blessing of her magic. And it would be a good business too, she supposed...and a nice thing to do for all involved, and...okay, maybe her whole motivation for thinking about this was exploding out of that tiny jerkin that Glem wore, but it wasn't a half bad idea.

It was a crazy idea...

132.title: Roiling Bay: Good, I need a good seafaring adve...

choices: A map for a famous treasure
A small metal chest; what does it contain?
1322.content:
Wind was blowing and the sun was high in the sky. There wasn't a cloud in the sky above Port Charcarias as ships wove in and out of her docks. Port Charcarias was a small city among many in Roiling Bay, but was the one that pirates frequented the most.

That day, some fishermen already noticed a pirate ship, with a golden whale as figurehead, and a flag with an easily recognizable Jolly Roger: a skull with two eels popping out of the sockets and twisting their bodies. That was Elizabeth Robin’s; known as "Sea legs", ship.

She was pretty famous among the pirates for being one of the very few female captains, and one of the youngest, and also because her crew was the only one where all the members were female.

If for a pirate a woman on board brought bad luck, one could only imagine what would happen when all the crewmembers were women.

However, Elizabeth was also known for her skills, as rumors said that her ship, the "Sunny whale", originally belonged to another pirate, until the day she stole the ship from under him; and many people were as much afraid of stumbling across the sunny whale as much as meeting a Kraken.

Elizabeth was on the top deck, where the wind was blowing her golden braids, while the sunlight reflected off her tanned skin. She was wearing a captain’s hat and a large pirate jacket, left open while the other clothes, a short white blouse and a pair of extremely short shorts with a large belt, revealed her hourglass figure.

Once the ship stopped moving Elizabeth went towards the ramp, and called her second in command. "Katy!" The captain bellowed across the deck.

Answering was a woman of roughly the same age but taller, with reddish-brown hair kept in a pony-tail that almost touched the ground. She was wearing a pair of long trousers, a corset and a shirt that left her large cleavage exposed and a pair of long gloves.

"What do ya’ need captain?" said Katy.

"I'm going to Scylla's, I should return to the ship in an hour at most. In the meantime, you give the orders, and make sure we are ready to set sail once I'm back."

"Yes captain but, shouldn’t we get more stocks? Arlene said the depot is almost empty. And we need to sell the jewels we stole to those old nobles" replied Katy before taking a sip from her rum-flask.

Elizabeth shook her shoulders, "Fine, send someone to buy enough stock for a week or two, but do it quickly, we set sail when I return and not a moment later. As for the jewels, we'll sell them at the Rock-fang"

"Aye aye captain" replied Katy taking another sip of rum, but noticed with displeasure that it was empty.

"Hey! One of you sea-whores bring me another flask!" That was the last Elizabeth heard before setting foot into port.

------

Scylla's was a notorious tavern for those who habitually visited Port Charcarias. It was cheap (but very few dared risking their life and ordering something to drink) and it was the perfect place if you wanted information about undiscovered treasures, mysterious outlaws or simple gossips. Though getting that information wasn't as easy as it seemed, and was definitely not cheap.

The owner, Norm, was your average tavern owner: short, chubby, a big nose with a riotous moustache and a head so bald it looked like he had covered it in boot polish. But no-one dared to tangle with Norm, even when he tried to kick patrons out, thanks to his assistant, Wilda, a minotaur that was as tall as she was large, who made sure no-one laid a finger on her boss.

At that moment, Elizabeth was playing "du-do", a game with dice where you can make a bet on the others results. Elizabeth loved that game, and she was winning as usual. She had already won a hundred gold coins, a pair of golden necklaces and a wooden leg (it was just a random wooden leg, but she wanted to win it out of spite for the now one-legged pirate sitting to her left), and now was about to win something she was really really interested in, and the main reason she went to the bar in the first place.

The woman and the man in front of her had their iron glasses down, with the die inside.

The two stared into each other's eyes, in the hope to find the sign of a bluff.

Then Elizabeth shouted "I say three fives."

The man brushed his long beard and replied "Fourrrrr sixes."

"Seven Fives" replied the tanned blonde.

The other pirates at the table gasped. That was a large bet considering there were only ten die in total.

"It seems you really want to lose that "scale of the sea"…" the brutish pirate commented, pointing at the gem in Elisabeth's earring. It was a light-blue gem that shined on its own. "Eight sixes" replied the man with a grin.

Elizabeth kept her cool, and gave a quick look under her glass, then she said: "Four jollys"

A big smile, lacking a pair of teeth, appeared on the big brute's face. "Ah-ha! I doubt it!" And revealed the five die under his glass. Not one of them had a "one", the equivalent of the jolly, face.

"Give me that!" Said the brute anxious to get his reward as he leaned over the table..

Elizabeth put a finger to his forehead, "uh-uh-uh; do you think I don't have four jollys under my glass? I have five die…"

A drop of sweat poured dripped from the Brute's face... and Elizabeth revealed her die. There were four "one" faces.

"You can't mess with "sea legs" so easily" said Elizabeth putting a hand on her lips and blowing a kiss while crossing her legs.

"And your nickname is well earned" commented eagerly a man next to her, gazing at her long tanned legs, before the blonde imprinted her boot on his face with a sift twirl.

"It's impossible! you cheated!" The opposing pirate protested furiously, slamming his hand on the table and preparing himself to punch Elizabeth, if not for the woman’s quicker reflexes as she drew the flintlock pistol from her belt, and pointed it directly towards his face.

Elizabeth noticed the minotaur raising her head with a frown on her face.

"Don't worry Wilda, I will be finished with my transaction immediately." Then turned her head toward the bearded man.

"I'm sorry Rob the Repulsive. But you lost" said the woman stretching her hand "Now give me it."

The man grunted and handed her...
1322.title: Captain Elizabeth "Sea-Legs" Robin

choices: The rest of her crew are acting strange
Elizabeth started to feel strange
13222.content:
A small metal chest. Elizabeth was no fool though, and immediately opened it a crack to make sure she was not about to be duped. A stream of golden light flickered out, across her gaze as her eyes lit up with greed.

As the pirate captain shut the box though she heard a few dozen clicks.

“Shouldn’t yar know ya cannot trust a pirate?” The sour-puss pirate remarked with a grin on his cracked lips. He and a few of his crewmates had surrounded Elizabeth and were all pointing pistols at her. “Ya cannot shoot all of us…” He added, beckoning a hand forward for Elizabeth to return the well-won goods.

“Very true…it seems you have me…” Elizabeth relented, holding her hands up in surrender…then with a swift movement she fired her pistol up towards the ceiling!

The other pirates looked up in horror as a chandelier came rocketing down towards them. Meanwhile Elizabeth tucked the box under her free arm and jumped onto the table, then used Rob the Repulsive’s face as a stepping stone for her boot as she leapt upwards and over him and his crew.

She was out the door in moments…only for more shipmates to surround her outside the door, blocking her escape.

“Shoot haaaaar!” Came the cry of the injured pirate captain as pistols and cutlasses were drawn. Elizabeth scanned her eyes frantically left and right, then something caught her eye.

“Sorry, no time to play boys…” She remarked, jumping backwards onto a plank that was leaning against a cart. Then with another well-aimed shot she fired at a rope holding a load of fish, freshly caught that morning. The sack of salmon plummeted onto the other end of the plank, catapulting the acrobatic pirate upwards and onto a balcony.

Elizabeth landed in front of a young terrified washerwoman; silencing her with a suave kiss, the pirate clambered up onto the rooftop and began running across the masonry, jumping from one building to the other as pirates tried to chase her from the streets below.

The pirate captain could see the mast of her ship drawing closer and closer. Thankfully she was used to this kind of ridiculous escape, and she was outpacing her pursuers. As she drew to the end of the row of houses, Elizabeth jumped onto a washing line and slid her way down.

“SET SAIL!” Elizabeth bellowed at her crew as she hit the end of the washing line and began pumping her legs across the cobbled street.

“YOU HEARD THE CAPTAIN!” Her first mate yelled to the rest of the crew as they began to hurry back and forth across the deck.

As Elizabeth neared the end of the dock the ship pulled up the plank and started to move from harbour. The blonde woman turned to see Rob the Repulsive turning the corner, his face still in-filled with shards of the chandelier from the bar. The captain backed up a bit then ran full pelt and jumped with all her strength.

Her body slammed into the side of her ship, but her hand managed to catch the rope while one of her boots jammed itself in a porthole. Sighing with relief Elizabeth began to pull herself up the side of the wooden ship and onto the deck. Turning around she saw the other pirates finally approach the end of the dock, some trying to jump as well but succeeding in only falling into the salty seawater below.

“Haha!” Elizabeth crowed. “Tough luck boys! Perhaps you can sell some of that crystal lodged in your captain’s face to pay off the tab!”

Turning to strut in another taunt Elizabeth passed by Katy, with a casual flick of her wrist Elizabeth knocked the bottle of rum out of her first-mate’s hands and into her own. “Next time, try not to set sail until after I am on board…” Elizabeth hissed before downing what remained of the bottle and chucking the empty glass overboard.

“Aye aye captain…” Katy huffed, thinking that she had actually done a good job. The captain was on board and the rival pirates hadn’t laid so much as a finger on the woodwork, what was the problem? “You going to come and celebrate with the rest of us?” Katy asked as Elizabeth started to make her way inside.

“Not yet, I just want to look at my prize…” The captain answered as she headed into her quarters.

The captain’s quarters of the Sunny Whale were very well decorated. Elizabeth had laid out as many of her sentimental trophies as possible throughout her sleeping quarters and it provided quite the trophy room. There was that ring she had stolen from a lustful siren she had outwitted, the tooth of a shark that had plowed into the lower decks, and the peg-leg from a long-retired rival pirate gang among other things.

Elizabeth though was not interested in her current décor; sitting herself down at her desk and putting her booted feet up, she re-opened the small box to take a better look at her prize.

It was a medallion; round and made of gold, with two serpents eating each other’s tails on it. Elizabeth leaned over her desk and grabbed some string, threading it through the medallion and then draping it across her neck.

It looked pretty fetching, resting down softly in her cleavage. Suddenly, Elizabeth swore she could see the serpents move, devouring each other’s tails further and glowing bright yellow.

As soon as the spectacle started it had finished. Strange…Elizabeth had heard of cursed items before, but she had never believed in them. It was probably a trick of the light…or the rum setting in.

Shrugging it off as nothing Elizabeth stood up and headed back outside. However there was no crew to be seen.

“Right…celebrations…” The blonde muttered to herself as she headed below deck. As she reached the dining quarters though something peculiar happened…
13222.title: A fancy escape

choices: Suddenly, a ship appears on the horizon
The ship docks in Carchan, time to store more food
132221.content:
Elizabeth walked under the deck, and found all the crew already sitting on the barrels around the table.

She took a seat next to Katy, who was chugging down the rum from her bottle as usual.

"You could've told me the party was ready" commented the captain to her first mate with a wry smile.

"I did" replied the redhead before letting out a belch "*URP* Eh Kojina, pass me another bottle" she said to the half-orc sitting in front of her.

"Sure" replied Kojina throwing a bottle to the first crewmate, while drinking a bottle herself. This latter detail surprised Elizabeth, from what she remembered, Kojina hated rum, but she shrugged her shoulders and ignored it, maybe she decided she liked it now.

In the meantime, the other crewmembers were making a big noise together, which disappeared after a big bellow from the ships cook.

"Shut-up, if you want to eat something!"

Yelling at them was a portly woman with long black hair, wearing a stained brown apron in front of her round belly. She was Arlene, the chef of the crew. While Elizabeth was the captain of the ship, in the kitchen, Arlene was the undisputed ruler.

All of the crewmembers watched with trepidation as the chef served the usual slop with eggs and fish. Elizabeth was surprised by what was seeing; the moment a pirate-girl got her grub, she would quickly eat it and asks for seconds once she finished every scrap, could it be that it was better than usual?

Elizabeth ate it, but for her it seemed the usual slop, and yet, even the youngest members of the crew, Phania and Lessya, were having seconds.

Lessya and Phania were a couple of blonde twin elves with short hair, they where the ship boys (or in this case, girls) and Phania wore an eye-patch on her eye (which eye changed continuously) only to distinguish herself from her twin.

Still, once the large pots were emptied and nearly everyone was having seconds, Elizabeth made her speech.

"Alright girls! I hope you're enjoying your lunch" probably even too much, she thought "because today we're gonna sail to the rock-fang, so it's going to be a couple of weeks journey! But be prepared, because we're assaulting every noble ship we're going to see, so I want you all ready! I'm talking especially to you, Winona" said Elizabeth to a harpy with white and gray feathers, like those of a seagull, and the mouth full of slop, with some sauce dipping from her lips.

This harpy was the crew lookout, thanks to her race's enhanced vision, meaning that her job was to warn the captain about whatever she glanced at on the horizon.

Still, there was no answer from the harpy "Winona, did you hear me?" Barked Elizabeth, louder this time, "Winona!"

This time the harpy heard it and with a clawed hand on the forehead, said "Aye aye captain" before diving back to empty her bowl. Elizabeth wasn't much surprised by that, Winona was far from the brightest of the crew, but what bothered her was that barely anyone listened to her today.

"Seriously, what's happening to you? This seems the usual slop Arlene makes…" Speaking of Arlene, she couldn't find her anywhere, where has she gone already?

This didn’t bother the captain much, and simply said "Alright, crew! Lunch time is over! Everyone go back to their job" and gave a glare to the young elf twins "Even you two! I want the deck to sparkle" said before getting up and going back to her cabin, where she could admire her treasures.

Elizabeth was playing with an emerald idol in her hands. According to the person she stole-ahem, gently took it from, it was made by a tribe in the Motee marshes and represented a goddess. Though for Elizabeth was more a fat tiger-woman in a buddha-like pose (And body). She liked it, especially because it was so round it seemed like it could roll away from her hands at any given moment. Once she got bored she placed it carefully back in the chest.

She looked at her newly-acquired treasure, the necklace she was wearing, and noticed that the snakes on it were biting their tails... had it always been this way? She shrugged it off and left her cabin.

She reached the navigator's room. "Hey Kojina, how is the navigation going?" Asked Elizabeth, as she abruptly opening the door.

The half-orc turned around with her hands behind her back.

"W-well" replied the navigator.

Elizabeth got closer to Kojina. She was a half-orc, meaning that, while her face was still thin-boned in-build, rather pretty and human-like, she had some small sharp canines and a green-gray skin. She also had long black hair and was on the chubby side.

"Where are we now?" Asked Elizabeth as she leaned onto the table covered with maps.

While the captain was distracted, Kojina put the fish she was hiding in her mouth and swallowed it as fast as she could. Elizabeth heard some munches and turned around, but Kojina tried to stay vague.

"Can you answer me, please?" Repeated the captain.

"Oh, sure" said the half-orc pointing on the map "at the moment we're here, but judging by the wind and the pressure, we have to take a long trip to avoid the storm, but it will take just three-four days longer"

"Couldn't expect nothing less from you" said Elizabeth in a proud tone. Kojina was, after all, one of the best navigators of Yndyre, and had all the maps memorized in her head.

"Yeah... thanks" replied Kojina awkwardly. In truth, there was no storm coming, but wanted to take the long route so the ship had to stop to Carchan, where they could get more food.

"Do you happen to know where Katy is?" Asked Elizabeth.

"N-no, why would I?" Asked Kojina.

"Well, according to the rumors, you two are pretty close" said Elizabeth, grinning maliciously.

"Pffft it's just a rumor. Probably spread by Arlene, she should just think about cooking…not who is in bed with whom" replied Kojina leaving the room, mentioning the word 'cooking' had made her hungry again, and she absolutely needed to raid the pantry.

Elizabeth shrugged, "Whatever, better get some rest if it will be a long trip" with a stretch of her arms.
So she leaned on a chair and took in the sun, noticing how the crew around her was strangely quiet. It had been one weird day, thought the pirate captain.
132221.title: A really bizarre crew

choices: The tent of a magician! Maybe he knows something about the medallion
One of her crewmember is followed by an angry mob! What happened?
1322212.content:
Elizabeth was playing cards with some of the other crewmates and, as usual with the cocky captain, she was winning.

"I bet twelve golden coins" said Kojina, the half orc, dropping the handful of coins into the middle of the table.

"I'm in" said Katy between munches of anchovy.

"Katy, can you please stop chewing… at least during the game?" Asked an annoyed Elizabeth.

The red-head’s brow furrowed and she crossed her arms like a child who had been scolded. Meanwhile the other two players gave a quick nonchalant glance to both sides, until Nuta hid her fruit under her chair and Kojina quickly swallowed the fish she was slowly chewing.

Elizabeth didn't notice that, as she was too busy looking at her cards, and then said "I raise thirty gold coins" and pushed a much larger pile of money into the center of the table.

The mermaid sitting next to her made a slasher smile and, pushed her money, said "I'm in!" and laid back in her chair.

Elizabeth grinned "Oh, so you accept the challenge, Nuta? Could it be you're still bitter for me having captured you some time ago?"

"As if!" Replied the mermaid moving some of her long white fins out from in front of her face "I'm an official crewmember, right? And besides, without my songs, you wouldn't have any entertainment."

"Yeah, whatever…I still would get plenty of entertainment watching these lot lose at card games…" said the captain. "Kojina, do you have anything? You have to add at least an extra eighteen golden coins"

Kojina pushed her share of money "of course I'm in!" she roared showing her little sharp canines.

"I'm out" said Katy dropping her cards on the floor.

"What a chicken…" commented Kojina.

"I'm not a chicken" yelled Katy with her face turning redder "I just know I can't win a game with our captain". Hearing this Elizabeth raised her chin and made a smug smile.

"I don't even know why I decided to play cards with you. I'm gonna get more rum…" grumbled the redhead, leaving the room and shaking her empty flask for emphasis.

"Sooo, does anyone want to eat those anchovies?" Asked Nuta stretching her hand toward the half empty box with oil and fish in it.

Elizabeth slammed a fist on the table, and the coins jumped into the air. "Nuta, we are trying to play cards, not eat! Besides, you've already eaten alot during breakfast. Do you want to go from a fish to a whale?" Asked Elizabeth looking at Nuta's still waifish light-blue body; but marred by the swollen gut that protruded an inch further from her frame. The mermaid was not wearing very modest clothes, a little piece of clothing wrapped around her chest, a short skirt and a pair of bracelets, nothing more.

Nuta retired her hand with a sigh.

"Good" said Elizabeth "Now, if no one else has anything to say, I guess we have to show what we..."

The door opened sharply, slamming against the wall. It was Lessya, the twin without eyepatch (or was she the one with one? Nobody could remember).

"Captain, Winona has just seen Carchan at the horizon, we should dock in about ten minutes!"

Elizabeth raised a brow "What? Why would we stop at Carchan? I said we needed to reach the Basody-pelago!"

Kojina whistled and raised her eyes, hoping that Elizabeth didn’t realize it was her who changed the course of the ship.

Luckily, Elizabeth didn't notice her strange behaviour (recently there has been a different "strange behaviour" in all the crew anyway), put her captain coat over her shoulder loosely and left the room.

"Winona, are you sure that is Carchan?"

"Aye captain!" Replied the harpy from the top of the mast.

Elizabeth went to the prow and checked the horizon with a telescope. There was a peninsula with a large somewhat bear-shaped rock and a small town where the buildings had blue roofs. It was Carchan without any doubt.

"But why are we going to Carchan?" Wondered Elizabeth under her breath as she closed the telescope.

"We can get some new stocks" answered a voice on her back, the captain turned and saw Rihan, the shipwright of the Sunny Whale.

She was the tallest member of the crew and, with all her muscles, the strongest too; with her size, it wasn't uncommon for some people to mistake her for a dark-skinned orc (even moreso than the half-orc Kojina), a mistake she doesn't forgive. Her skin was tanned, almost bronze-like, and some short dirty blonde bangs popped from under her bandana.

"Oh, so you stopped lazing around on your hammock?" Asked Elizabeth putting a hand on her hip.

"It's not my fault if this ship works so well that I don’t have to lift a finger some days" replied Rihan patting the solid wood of the ships rails.

"Whatever" said Elizabeth passing near the shipwright, and noticed how Rihan had some cream dotting the side of her lips. This made Elizabeth suspicious, and went to the kitchen to clear a thought that had been nagging at her.

"Arlene!" Yelled Elizabeth stomping her boot "Arlene where are you?"

"I'm here"

From the pantry emerged Arlene, the cook.

"Rihan just told me we need some stock, is it true?"

"Well, just check the pantry" answered the black haired woman with a gesture of her hand.

The captain went inside and noticed how the pantry was almost empty. How could it be? They had stocks for a month and yet, in the span of a week or so, they were nearly finished. The sound of munching answered her questions. Arlene was snacking on a slice of melon, and Elizabeth could see the peel from further slices left on the shelf. Yes, all her crew recently had been snacking nearly all the time, and Arlene made some pretty large portions during lunches, and there had never been any leftovers.

Out of pure instinct, Elizabeth grabbed the medallion around her neck for a moment, then checked Arlene's belly. The cook had always been portly, but the captain could see that her belly was protruding more than usual, some of the pink skin clearly visible under her shirt, and wondered how much she truly snacked with the pantry at her complete disposal. Her train of thought was interrupted by the sudden movements of the ship, a sign it must have docked.

The blonde captain ran outside and screamed "Ok, you damned bitches, we're staying at Carchan for a few hours! I don't want any trouble, so avoid beginning a fray, ok? Feel free to spend all the money, but we need some gunpowder for the cannon and enough food for a month or two! Speaking of food, I don't know what got into you, but you all must stop this snacking! Our supplies aren't unlimited! Have I been clear?"

"Yes, captain!" Replied some of the crewmembers within earshot namely; Phania, Lessya and Katy.

Elizabeth sighed and went back to the pantry to get a bottle of rum, she desperately needed it.

-----

Elizabeth walked into the chaotic harbour, between screaming salaryman and pirates insulting each other, and wasn't surprised to see all the crewmembers busy with buying and loading crates onto the ship. It was food. Lots of food. She saw Rihan taking two large crates filled with eggs, Kojina a chest with fruit, which wouldn't have been bad if these fruits weren't sweet and very sugary, and Katy a smaller one while with the other hand she was emptying her flask of rum.

Walking in front of a tavern, she exchanged a gaze with a young, large men who was sitting near the entrance, and the men immediately fled inside. Elizabeth smiled smugly, he was a rival pirate until he and his crew assaulted her ship, but that proved to be a big mistake, and in the end, she killed all of his crew and burned his ship, while leaving him on a raft with just a bottle of rum and a gun loaded with a single bullet, but it seemed he was lucky enough to survive.

Then she saw the two elven twins snatching a couple of fish from a stand, but with a gaze she intimidated them to get to work. Apparently the two did, until she felt something cold near her butt, and noticed how the two left the fishbone in her pants.

"Those little..." cursed Elizabeth "Once we're aboard, I'll make them clean the ship until I can see my reflection on the deck…"

But before her rage could explode, something caught the pirate captain's attention...

13231.content:
Csarvia was laying in the chair of what used to be the captains cabin in the sunken pirate ship she now called home. She had moved in a few months ago, after deciding that the beach she lived in wasn't an ideal home, even though she then spent most of her time working in a tavern called "The Royal Parrot". In that tavern, she heard lots of tales from the sea. Csarvia had always been adventurous, and hearing these tales were a primary reason of why she stayed. Her knew home was once filled with treasures, these she sold, being payed in high quality food, which left some pudge on her body. However, there was one treasure she didn't sell, a map, not just any map, but an enchanted map. Even though being in water, it wasn't damaged, so it must be some kind of protection spell.

The map was written in an unknown, presumably ancient language. She went around the village surrounding The Royal Parrot asking if someone could read it, so far only some traveling wizard could read the lines "Ancient Relic" and "Island Of Fire". Despite all the tales she had heard from the sea, Csarvia had never heard of any "Island Of Fire", though she thought she recognized one of the islands on the map.

Now she was laying there, in her chair, her butt slightly too big for the chair, wondering if she should go searching for the island or go to the village, trying to get more information.

13232.content:
The salty air blew calmly over the open water of the southern sea. A vast, blue expanse touched by few land dwellers but the bravest of seafarers and whoever may have the mettle to stand boisterous sailors for countless hours. Anna Skyriver was not either of those things and yet here she was, in a cabin on a wooden ship, floating into the great unknown.

It's a bit past dinnertime and the sun hangs low in the sky, shining directly into Anna's cabin as she scribbles in a journal. Her day today had been boring, as most days tended to be. It was three weeks into her journey and she still had not quite bonded with any of the members of the ship's crew. Sometimes she wondered why she was on this ship in the first place, but her mind would always come up with the same answer: she had to be for the sake of discovery.

Anna is an esteemed member of the Adinah Archaeological Society, the foremost repository of ancient civilization and history in all of Yndyre. While on an expedition to the Samin Desert of all places, Anna found a map of the sea with strange markings all over its back in a box within a cavern that must have been untouched for hundreds of years. An expert in cartography, she had never seen a map this large or detailed of the southern sea in her time. Even merfolk maps did not contain the amount of information that this one did. After taking it to one of her colleagues who is an expert in language back at the Society, she discovered that its markings are an ancient Djinn script and upon rough translation pointed to a specific place in the sea that existed outside of charted boundaries. It went on to explain that great treasure lies within a temple on an island there, the riches of a tribe that went off in search of enlightenment and never returned.

Never one to turn down an archaeological expedition, Anna chartered a merchant ship from Roiling Bay to take her to the island and off they sailed and had been sailing. Despite her adventurous attitude, Anna was quite a shy creature. It took a lot of courage for her to even charter this boat in the first place and she mostly kept to her room, writing one thing or another in her books and reading historical tomes borrowed from the Society's vast library. She always dressed modestly and prudently, currently wearing loose brown slacks, knee-high black boots, a chocolate brown jacket, and a cream colored blouse. They hang loosely to her adequately sized curves, a fit hourglass shape with rounded breasts and buttocks. Though she had a body many women would die for and many men had thirsted over, Anna was a virgin and had little interest in the pleasures of the flesh. Her mind was consistently set upon one thing: knowledge. She didn't want to cloud her scholarly pursuits with a sex life, no sir.

Writing in her book, Anna's concentration is rudely broken by a commotion above deck. Men yelling, running on the creaky wooden boards, swords clanking together, and even a bit of gunpowder exploding. Oh no. Could this be...? Just then, Anna's cabin door is kicked in by a disheveled looking woman. Her revealing outfit made it abundantly clear she was on the portly side, a chubby double belly pooching from her midsection, thick thighs dotted with cellulite. Shit. These are definitely pirates. Today just got a whole lot more exciting, maybe for the wrong reasons. She barked in a salty accent, "Yer comin' wit' me, lassie."

The woman hauled Anna to the main deck, allowing her to take in the disarray caused by the pirates. Men were being thrown overboard if they were alive or dead, pools of blood and ripped fabric adorned the floor, and the pirates, who were all women and who were all at least chubby, pillaged the cargo hold, loading up crates of whatever this ship was hauling. What was this ship hauling, anyway? Who cares. Anna knew her doom was imminent and couldn't control the intense beat of her anxious little heart. To her surprise, though, she was not being taken directly to the edge of the boat, she was being taken to a woman. A woman who was currently bent over into one of the crates, peering deep inside for something she really wanted. A woman wearing nothing on her legs but knee-high red leather boots and a pair of underwear skimpier than anything she'd ever seen before. A woman with a very, very large ass. As they approached the butt, the woman holding Anna called out, "Oi! Cap'n! This lass's different! I reckon she's an elf or somethin'!"

The captain's torso and head emerged from the crate, holding her treasure: a block of cheese. As Anna was dropped to her knees the captain took a bite, savoring it and rubbing her exposed tummy before asking between chews, "What's an elf like ye doin' on a cheese ship? Ye the cheesemaker's daughter or somethin'?"

Still nervous as ever, Anna spit out, "I-I charted this s-ship miss, er, ma'am, captain! I'm looking for an island, w-with treasure! I'm still trying to go there s-so if you want some treasure you could, um, take me? And we can share?"

The captain stopped for a moment and laughed the kind of laugh only a fat pirate could. "Are ye pullin' me fat leg, lass? Ye reckon I be belivin' that?"

Sensing impending doom, Anna desperately defended herself. "It's true! I have a map! If I may make a p-proposition to you ma'am, captain, er... What is your name?"

She proudly took another bite of her cheese. "I be Captain Gillian Davies, the Derriere! Have ye heard o' me lassie?"

"I, uh, I don't believe I have, Captain Davies." Anna quivered. If she fucks this up, she's dead. Sinking to the bottom of the ocean to be swallowed by a whale.

"Well, me 'n me pirate crew here 'ave been terrorizin' this sea fer years now! We find ships like these, clear them out, loot all th' grub, 'ave a great feast, 'n find more ships! We must 'ave a name fer ourselves, right?" She seemed a little worried. Maybe reassuring her would work.

Anna decided to lie. "Oh... Now that I think about it I have heard of you! Lots of stories of food trade ships going missing... That's you?

She took another victorious bite of cheese. "I knew it! They always told me me whole grub pirate schtick wouldna stick but look at me! Terror o' th' high seas!" She lowered her voice and crouched down to Anna's level "Say, do ye know if they 'ave any pastry ships? All these thin's are cheese 'n meat 'n spirits, but this big booty needs some cake, do ye know wha' I mean?"

She had her. Thank the gods. "I don't believe they do fully cooked pastry shipments, just of the raw ingredients. But... if you let me take you to this island you'll have so much treasure and wealth that you could have as many sweets as you want, whenever you want? How does that sound captain?"

She thought for a moment and said, "That sounds... great. I dunno why I ne'er considered plunderin' riches instead o' grub afore. I'll take ye t' this island but, jus' so ye know, if thar's no booty, ye're ripe t' facin' a cruel 'n unusual punishment fer trickin' me. They don't call me th' derriere fer naught!" Captain Davies smacked her wide rear with her open hand. Yikes. Anna did not want her death to be "crushed by massive pirate ass" but at least she knew she wouldn't be the first.

And so, Captain Davies let Anna go back down to her cabin and retrieve her things before setting sail for the mysterious island. The new ship was a lot more spacious than the old one, and more lively too. Reading a tome became more difficult with the much fatter crew thumping around, chowing down on plundered riches, having burping contests, and just generally being loud slobs. But at least she was getting where she was going, right? She scribbled in her journal. Today had been quite an exciting day.
13232.title: Anna Skyriver, archaeologist

choices: An island dotted by stone statues and an imposing temple.
A thick jungle isle.
A deserted isle with nothing on it. Uh oh.
132321.content:
The next few days of journeying with Captain Davies and her crew had not been too difficult for Anna, even though they were a murderous group of pirates. She wasn't expecting them to be so... pleasant? Not that she was complaining! She would take this over getting eaten alive by sea creatures any day.

Anna's welcome on the ship was warm, she was given her own room, albeit a small one, and was told to ask the Captain if she ever needed anything at all. Was this a genuinely kind-hearted group of women or were they just using her as a key to the treasure? Anna didn't want to think about it.

Anna found the Captain to be a friendly, yet somewhat callous person. She was blunt, boisterous, and had absolutely awful manners. At the same time, she cared deeply for her crew, always seemed in a good mood, and was surprisingly cordial any time she and Anna would interact. She often wore a blue tricorne hat which she must have stolen from a hapless sailor over her shoulder length brown hair, frayed and frizzed from the salty air. Her coat also seemed stolen, a gray and blue jacket a size too small for her somewhat portly frame. She wore a dark corset on top of a white undershirt, which she used to draw attention away from her tubby waist and towards her bountiful bum. Anna had seen much bigger butts in her day, but few that made her as jealous as the Captain's. Her cheeks were globe-round and enormous: Anna estimated about 70 inches around. Captain Davies never wore a pair of pants in her life: she wanted desparately to flaunt what she had, and she had a lot to flaunt. Despite their difference in species and skin color (Anna a pale white and the Captain a light brown Human, like you would see from desert folk) the two women were about the same height, a moderately tall 5'11".

One night, the Captain knocked on Anna's cabin door while she was deep into a passage detailing ancient Orcish customs. Anna didn't have a chance to get up before the Captain burst in, two pitchers of mead in her hands and jollily proclaimed, "Oi! Elf lass! Let's see this map o' yers 'n get drunk! Do ye like mead?" She pulled a wooden chair from the corner, spilling some drink from one of her glasses, and stuffed her butt in it. The fat from her cheeks bulged from under its arms. Anna could almost hear it screaming in agony as the Captain excitedly handed her one of the pitchers.

Even though she rarely partook in alcohol consumption, Anna decided to accept the drink. Who knows what would have happened if she turned her down, right? She murmured politely in her soft, quiet voice, "Oh, yes. Thank you very much, Captain Davies. My name is Anna, by the way. I think we might have gotten off on the wrong foot." She extended her free hand for a formal greeting.

The Captain pushed her hand away. "Nay, I don't go fer those standard greetin' thin's. Much too borin'. Let's clink our glasses together 'n chug, Anna!" She extended the big cup of mead toward her. "To untold riches!"

The elf followed suit with a more nervous "To untold riches!" and got her glass clinked a little more forcefully than she was expecting, spilling some alcohol on her jacket.

Both women chugged from their glasses, the Captain much longer than Anna. After depleting half her supply in a single drink, Davies let loose a deep belch, followed by a single hiccup. She scrunched over in her chair, exasperated. "'Tis times like these I wish I didn' always wear this damned corset. I be mighty full o' cheese, Anna. I be so compressed in this thin'! But I gotta show off me arse somehow!"

Anna chuckled, taking another slight sip from her mead. "I understand, Captain." She bent over to retrieve the map from her bag. "If I may ask, ma'am, and I mean no offense by this of course, but why do you feel the need to display your bottom so proudly? I'm just a curious person, unfamiliar with pirate customs."

Davies thought for a moment, taking a deep swig from her drink. She thoughtfully responded, "Well, ye must know that th' best pirates in history all had or 'ave a signature definin' trait. Fer example, Thomas th' Fearsome had a wooden arm. Bluebeard was known fer his bright blue beard. Mary th' Minotaur was a minotaur. *HOOOORRP!* 'n me definin' trait be this fat booty o' mine. When scallywags remember me in th' distant future, they gonna reckon o' th' poppet who crushed sailors wit' her humongous arse 'n looted 'n ate lots o' grub so she could keep crushin' sailors! A true pirate legend! *OURRP!* Farrgin' corset makin' me burp..."

Anna had taken out the map after listening deeply. This was quite an interesting human. "Thank you for telling me that, Captain. Every day we'll know more of you pirates and how you live day to day."

The two perused the map, got seconds and then thirds of Mead, and turned in for the night drunk as skunks after a dinner of cheese and bread. As the days wore on, Anna became less of a recluse with Davies's encouragement, speaking and eating with the crew, and getting drunk with the Captain, listening to her stories of looting the high seas and telling her of her many expeditions around Yndyre. The two were becoming quite close, and even though the ship was hot and smelled like cheese, Anna began to think of it as a home, an honorary member of the Grub Pirate Crew.

A week later on a particularly cloudy afternoon, Anna was rousted from her studies by the lookout screaming "Land!" She felt her heart jump. She knew they were there. Getting up as fast as she could, she breathlessly joined the rest of the crew above deck as they approached...
132321.title: Anna's pirate journey

1323211.content:
The ship floated anchored as Anna and its crew gazed upon the sight before them. It was a sandy isle, not too big of an isle but an isle nonetheless. Its beach gently sloped upward into a grassy hill, interspersed with vegetation and coconut trees. Erected between those trees were large 20 foot stone sculptures of heads, their rocky, crudely carved eyes staring emotionlessly out into the water which surrounded them. The biggest point of interest on the island was the massive temple which crowned the top of its hill. It was ornate and imposing, the decorated steeple of its entryway beautifully scraping the sky. Anna had never seen anything like this before, not even in her studies of Djinn civilization. The architecture wasn't even in line with their customary style. An enigma, sure, but she breathed a sigh of relief that the place did exist. Now she nervously hoped that whatever was inside the temple would be enough to satisfy her bottom-heavy friend.

Anna stood next to the Captain, whose mouth gaped open. This must have been beyond her expectations. Davies gave Anna a strong pat on the back, nearly knocking her over, laughed a deep belly laugh, and bellowed to her crew, "She's real! Har har! She's real! Come then, lower a lifeboat fer me 'n th' Elf lass posthaste! We've got riches t' plunder!" She then turned to Anna and said, "Thank ye fer bringin' us here. If I get rich from this ye'll ne'er lift a finger in yer life again." Anna nodded, accepting her thanks even though she had really no choice but to bring the Captain along.

The lifeboat ran aground on the isle's beach. A crab scuttered up the sand by the boat, burrowing into the ground. As Anna and Davies disembarked, the Captain wobbled a little bit, stopping for a second. She exhaled and pleaded, "Hang on jus' a minute, wait up. I haven't got me land legs yet."

The two slowly made their way up the hill, the Captain dizzily hobbling along. As they walked, Anna admired the stone heads, scribbling frantically in her journal her observations and questions: Who made these heads? How long have they been here? How did they get the stone here to make them? Why are they all looking out into the sea? Do they serve any purpose?

Soon, they reached the gateway of the temple, a grand archway leading into a quiet courtyard. As they walked in, the two womens' boots clacked upon the stone slab floor. The yard was totally empty. Anna postulated that it must have been some sort of common meeting place for whoever worshipped here. Something odd she noticed was that there was no iconography of the Gods anywhere to be seen. Typically temples like this had at least some statues or carvings of whichever God the building was built for, but there was absolutely nothing here except for the ornate carvings that also decorated the temple's exterior.

At the center of the courtyard was a spiral staircase leading downwards into the ground. The duo descended into the earth for what seemed like a millennia until they finally reached a hallway, lit only by torches. The Captain was confused as to how they stayed lit, to which Anna responded that it was a very typical magical incantation for Djinn temples, nothing quite out of the ordinary. At the end of the hall was a stone door, painted in a dull green and blue. The two pushed the door with their combined strength, managing to open it with a great effort. Their effort paid off.

Opening the door revealed a massive chamber absolutely filled with offerings: gold, silver, rubies, sapphires, and emeralds, jewelry beyond comprehension, mountains of ancient gold coins and expensive trinkets. At the other side of the room was a large circular structure with stairs leading up and through it. Both Anna and the Captain stood motionless with their jaws on the floor, not sure what to even do in this situation. In the middle of the room was a red velvet throne upon which a glass bottle containing a blue smoke sat. Anna noticed this, realizing she had seen something like it before.

As the Captain stood still in shock taking in the riches which she now assumed were hers, Anna broke away, going to the throne. She picked up the bottle and opened its cork, releasing the smoke. It poured out the lip of the bottle in a linear stream, forming into a little blob of smog a few feet from the throne. Finally noticing the strange events before her, Davies was snapped from her gold trance, powerwalking towards the commotion and shouting, "Wha's this then? Wha' did ye do?"

Anna calmed her. "Relax, Captain Davies. Watch." As she watched the smoke began to take the form of a tall, voluptuous woman. Though she wore no clothes, her blue skin was as opaque and smooth as a doll, without blemishes or genitals. She did, however, have a belly button on her chubby tummy. Her face was formed next, beautifully made up with thick black eyeliner and red lipstick. She wore two golden hoop earrings and a gold necklace with thick beads around her neck, along with many bracelets of multiple precious materials. A short head of hair finished the woman, who strutted toward Anna on her bare feet with slight blue residue. She had a very sultry voice, and a dainty twang in her accent one night expect a farmer's wife to have. She spoke to Anna, "Greetings, my new master. I am a Djinn, born of alchemy 434 years, 3 months, 6 days, 10 hours, and 6 minutes ago. I was created by Ehsan of Monument Island before she left to the Great Unknown. What is your name, master?"

Anna gripped the bottle, looking the Djinn straight in the eyes. "I am Anna Skyriver, an Elven archaeologist from the great city of Adinah." She motioned to the Captain, extending the palm of her hand to her. "And this is my friend, Captain Gillian Davies, a sailor of the high seas. We come in search of information regarding this place and the people that once resided here."

Davies butted in, rushing next to Anna, putting her chunky arm around her. "'n riches! We wants th' great treasure here!"

The djinn laughed. "I'm afraid you can't have any of the treasure here. Not that it's mine and I'm keeping you from it, no. It's cursed, you see. It cannot leave this room."

Anna sensed Davies's disapproval. She quickly asked, "Djinn, is there any way to lift the curse?"

"The only person who can remove the curse is the person who put it on in the first place. That person is my creator, Ehsan, but he hasn't been present in this plane of existence for 400 years."

Anna once again felt Davies's leer. She had to salvage something, else she knew she'd be smothered by booty tonight. Before the Captain could insult the djinn, Anna cut her off, muffling her mouth with a hand and asked, "What do you mean this plane of existence? How can we find her? You see, my friend here does not want to leave empty handed."

The Djinn conjured two chairs from smoke for the women, one courteously larger than the others, and invited them to take a seat. Then she started her lesson. "A long time ago there was a sect of djinn who broke from the main community in the Samin Desert over theological differences. You see, the djinn are a scientific and atheistic people: we believe the gods are not gods but simply incredibly powerful beings. The main group of djinn believe that once a person dies, they are gone forever. However, the sect I was created by believed differently. They believed the soul of all living beings coexists between an unknowable amount of parallel universe, each one radically different than the last. When one dies, they are transferred to a parallel soul within another universe to live again. They were ostracized for these beliefs and left the desert for this island, upon which they created this temple as a waypoint for transferrence between different planes of existence. Using forbidden forms of magic, my creator conjured a portal within the circular structure beyond us and she and the rest of her people went inside, to the Great Unknown."

In their chairs, Davies sullenly crossed her arms while Anna scribbled wildly in her journal. She stopped writing and looked up. "So, how would we go about reopening this portal?"

The djinn thought for a moment. "First of all, you would need a very powerful sorceress. This magic is quite difficult to pull off. Second, you will need ingredients for a binding substance. The blood of a corpulent vampire. Eternal snow which does not melt. The seeds of a vato flower. Gorgon venom. Finally, the sweat of a princess. Enchanting this substance will allow you to open the portal in this room and follow the djinn to wherever they ended up."

Surprising Anna, Davies rocketed up from her chair. "We'll do it! But a wee price t' pay fer such massive wealth!"

13232111.content:
The djinn chuckled. "I'm glad to see your enthusiasm, but this will likely by an adventure fraught with danger and peril. You may very likely perish, along with my master. Are you sure you're up to the challenge?"

The Captain grew closer to the djinn. "O' course we be! I eat danger 'n peril fer breakfast! If anyone dares cross Captain Davies th' Derriere I'll sit on 'em 'til thar lungs give out!"

Anna also stood up. "Well, it sounds like we're off on an adventure. You don't mind if you come with us, djinn? I could use your help and insight."

"I would be honored, master. Besides, what else is a girl to do? Sit down here alone until you get back?" The two women laughed and started off before being interrupted by the djinn. "Quickly, master, if you can I'd like to make a request of you. I do not have a name. You simply must give me one, else I cannot leave the building I was created in."

Anna felt stupid. She sighed and apologized, "Oh, I'm so sorry! I knew that rule but it must have slipped my mind." She thought for a moment, and then got an idea. "How about Kayka, after the great Djinn scholar?"

She smiled. "I would be honored, master." Just then, black tattoos appeared on both of the djinn's arms and around her waist. Anna recognized the tattoos as being words in the ancient script written on the back of the map that led her there. "I am Kayka. Let us go."

Going up the spiral staircase was much harder than going down it. When the trio eventually arrived at its top, the two mortals were panting and heaving, Davies much more so than Anna. It was a cakewalk for Kayka, who promptly conjured a glass of water for her master to drink. Davies saw this and was very interested yet incensed. She shouted, "Hey! Why does she get a glass o' water? ...Can I get a glass o' water?"

Kayka kept walking. "I can conjure you anything you desire within reason, as long as master has no complaints."

And so, Davies got her glass of water... and another glass of water... and a pitcher of mead... and a slice of pie... and the rest of the pie. By the time the party returned to the beach, the Captain was stuffed and tipsy, trying to rub her belly through its corset. She asked Anna, "So wha' are we goin' t' do- *BOORP* first?"

Anna replied, "We're getting the best sorceress in Yndyre to join us. Lucky for you, we go way back."

That sorceress was...
13232111.title: Monument Island (Part 2)

choices: "Caloric intake. Same as you, master."
"Sexual intercourse." L-lewd...
"You can't from out here." Two months of feasting and travelling later...
132321113.content:
By the next day, the pirate ship was once again swaying in the sea wind, en route back to the mainland for the first time in a long while. Within the ship, Anna, Captain Davies, and her pirate crew were having a large breakfast provided by their new djinn companion. Kayka's powers of conjuration were very much being abused by the women, but she didn't mind. Conjuration didn't take much energy and if master was happy, she was happy.

Anna leaned back on the mess hall bench, her stomach more engorged than it's ever been in recent memory. She politely stifled a burp with her hand, excused herself, and said, "Captain, I understand that you're excited about the circumstances, but don't you think we're indulging a little much? This is the third feast we've had since we've set sail and I don't know how much my poor stomach can take!"

Across from her, the Captain dug deeply into a huge stack of pancakes, shoveling overloaded forkfuls into her maw. Mouth completely full, she reassured Anna as she chewed. "MMMPH! Nonsense! We've got, mmnn, celebratin' t' do! Eat yer, mmmph, grub 'n stop complainin'. Now... *GULP* tell me about this sorceress we be goin' t' get. Wha's she like?"

Anna gave herself a belly rub while she explained, "Well, her name's Barri. She's a succubus that got kicked out of the succubus society for being too short." The Captain snorted, mouth too full of pancakes to laugh. Anna continued, "Yes, she absolutely holds a grudge. Don't mention her height when you meet her, she'll probably kill you."

At that moment, they were interrupted by Kayka silently plodding towards them, swinging her curvy hips. She sat down next to her master as she greeted her. "Do you desire anything more, master? Perhaps some more pancakes?"

Anna waved her hand, still clutching her stuffed tum. "No, no, but it's much appreciated, Kayka. If I eat any more I think I'll pop." She paused for a second. "You know, I think I have some questions for you, if it's not a bother."

Kayka chuckled and smiled at Anna's formality. "It's never a bother, master. Ask me anything you please and I'll do my best to answer."

Before she could ask anything, the Captain let loose an enormous belch, which was met with applause and cheers from the crew. She immediately went back to loudly stuffing her face. Anna looked at Kayka with all seriousness, keeping her voice down as she politely asked, "Do you think we could go somewhere more quiet? The racket in here is starting to get to me." Kayka nodded. The two of them stood from their bench, Anna saying to the Captain, "Excuse us, Captain Davies. We're going to retire to another room for some Q&A." Davies didn't even respond, simply giving the duo a frantic nod as she continued to be immersed in her syrupy breakfast.

Back in Anna's cabin, Kayka laid down on the bed as Anna opened up her journal for some note taking. She was a little lethargic from her feasting, but still excited to learn more about man-made djinn. "So, the first thing I'd really like to know is what it was like to be stuck in a bottle for hundreds of years. How did you keep busy?"

Kayka stared at the ceiling, basking in her momentary rest. "A lot of it was a blur for me. It felt more like fifteen minutes rather than 400 years. I guess I was just preparing myself for you to summon me, master."

Anna looked up from her book. "No need to be so formal, Kayka! You don't need to call me master all the time. Call me Anna."
