Racovania was a gloomy place, even during the day. Hardly a bustling metropolis, what would be a quaint little town of commonfolk in any other location was recontextualized by the things that loomed around it: drooping, dense trees, ever-steepening mountainous crag, and a series of ornate, gothic castles in the middle distance. The residents of Racovania took it for granted that the denizens of those castles watched their every move, lurking in the night.

The party snagged a couple of rooms at the town's inn and waited for nightfall, snacking idly on Kayka's conjured food because there really wasn't much else to do. Then, at sunset, Anna and Barri left their other two party members at the inn so as not to overwhelm their mark and went together to a specific castle in the distance, one belonging to an old friend of Barri's.

***

Barri's short stature made it difficult for her to reach the already high up door knockers on the vast gate that stood before them, so Anna reluctantly did it for her. She was admittedly a bit skittish about this whole "ask a vampire for some of their blood" thing, but under the circumstances she just had to grin and bear it. The knock reverberated through the stone of the castle's interior, and soon enough they were greeted by a rather tall, gaunt butler with a sharp fashion sense and a wispy voice. He held a burning candlebra near his face. "May I assist you ladies?" he asked in a friendly tone. Hey, maybe vampires aren't as hostile as they seem.

Before Anna could stammer her way through an introduction, Barri spoke up. "Yes, we're here to see Miss Zeena Stranken. I'm an old friend of hers. Could you tell her Barri is here for a visit and a favor?" The butler nodded his head slowly and grunted so as to say "one moment please" and gently closed the door.

Waiting outside the castle door, Anna nervously started a conversation. "So, Barri, what's your relationship with this Zeena?"

Barri giggled. "Oh, we made an incredible team a long while ago. I helped her fatten up some gals so she could feed better. Did you know that the more weight a girl has on her, the better her blood tastes? At least, that's what I've been told. Blood drinking doesn't get my rocks off, you know that." She giggled again. Gulp. This did little to soothe Anna's discomfort. She had only read about vampiric practices, it was another thing to know they're right around the corner.

The butler returned shortly after, waving the duo inside. The entry hall was cavernous, dotted inconsistently by golden spots of candlelight. The red carpet below them smelled of dust, and cobwebs hung across the stone walls. Beautiful, massive paintings of landscapes adorned these walls, their beauty somewhat obscured by the dismal lighting conditions. The butler lead the two down a few halls and up a spiral staircase until they reached the sitting room of the Mistress.

And there she was. Sitting in an ornate red velvet chair at the head of the room was Zeena Stranken. Her face was just about as traditionally beautiful as Barri's, with high cheekbones and plump, red lips that contrasted well with her dull grey skin. Her long, jet black hair hung down behind her. She wore a tight black dress that accentuated her thin but curvy figure, its deep v showing off an ample amount of cleavage between her round breasts. She crossed her skinny legs in the chair, one of her hands holding a paperback book and in the other a goblet presumably filled with blood. She took a sip and looked up at Barri and Anna, eyes lighting up.

"Helloooo!" Her voice was higher and bubblier than her gothic demeanor suggested. "Barri, it's been so long since I've seen you! You haven't changed a bit!" She rose from her seat and shuffled over to the two on her high heels. Standing up, she was a bit tall, maybe 6 foot 1 or 2.

She went in for a hug, lifting up the little succubus with ease. Anna began taking notes in her book. Jeez, vampires be strong. Barri was clearly in a death grip as she groaned, "It's, urrrg, wonderful to see you too, Zeena. Let me... nnnn... go... please."

Zeena put her down and apologized. "Oh, I'm sorry. Sometimes I forget my own strength." She laughed a high pitched laugh that gave off more "pretty princess" vibes than "vampire mistress of the dark" vibes. She took another sip from her goblet. "So, who's your friend with the notebook?"

Anna looked up from her notes. "Oh, I-I'm Anna. I'm from the Archaeological Society in Adinah. Me and Barri go waaay back, haha. I actually helped her out of a major jam back in the day."

Barri friendily backed her up. "Oh, it was quite the jam. I'll have to tell you about it sometime."

Zeena clapped her hands together. "So, shall we go down to the den and catch up? Discuss this favor Mr. Smith mentioned to me? I would offer you something to eat, but unless you want some blood, I don't think I have anything." She giggled again, leading the duo down the stairs with her.

***

The den was nice and cozy. Comfy chairs, a fireplace, bookshelves, a bearskin rug, a mounted deer head, it had it all. Zeena sat sideways on an armchair, legs draped over the arm. She looked at the two girls, who sat opposite of her on a sofa. They had just finished telling her the story of their journey and what they needed from her. She nodded her head and smiled, showing off her fangs. "I think I can help you, but you know I'll need something in return. Favor for favor, right?"

Barri sat back, Anna taking notes on the sidelines. "Oh, I was wondering where that went. You looked sooooo much better with it, baby."

She lowered her voice to a raspy whisper. "You know I agree! But that bitch ratted me out to everyone after she saw me! I had to lose it or be persona non grata with my family!" She looked around the room, to check if anybody was listening. "That's where you come in. I need you to get her fat. Really fat. We both know how good you are at expanding waistlines. Make her into a blood-guzzling piggy and you can have a direct line into my arteries." She extended a hand to Barri. "Deal?"

Barri shook Zeena's hand. "It's a deal."

Stefan Lazarescu strolled down the unassuming Racovanian road. His mind was on one thing: his meager job. Stefan, a young, lively man, was the assistant and apprentice of the famed Minotaurian pastry chef Bramble the Great. Bramble was an imposing figure with a hot temper and not-to-be-fucked-with attitude, but perhaps the most talented dessert chef in all of Yndyre. He had served under the emperor for a time before going freelance and eventually ending up in Racovania under the lease of the influential Stranken sisters who loomed above the town like gargoyles in their castles.

Every year around the harvest, Cameena Stranken would send a messenger down from her abode with an extra large commission for Bramble: lots and lots of cakes of various make and model for a special festival. Years ago, Cameena, a notorious vampire in her day, had acquired a taste for non-blood food and became a vegetarian, swearing off human blood forever. This breakage from the vampiric ways ostracized her from her family and friends, causing her to withdraw from much of her social life. She re-emerged many years later, glutted and fat from her sedentary lifestyle and generous diet with a proclamation to the town of Racovania. In order to gain the favor of the townspeople, she would throw an annual harvest ball and feast, open to all who wished to attend. These feasts were always lavishly catered with the finest of foods, including a plethora of cakes baked by the one and only Bramble the Great.

And so, Stefan rolled the last few of Bramble's works for this year's ball on a cart before him: four vanilla-chocolate swirl cakes thickly coated in overwhelmingly sweet icing and dotted with strawberries and raspberries on the top and sides. The storage house was luckily just up on his right, an unassuming little cottage that'd be easy to miss if he hadn't been there many, many times the past week or so. He stopped the cart by the door and slipped the key into the lock, but before he could turn the tumbler, he heard a curious noise muffled through the wood. It sounded like a woman's voice, but he couldn't make out what she was saying.

Slowly and cautiously, he turned the key, unlocking the door. Twisting the door handle and carefully sticking his head through the crack, he surveyed the terrible sight. To say the storage building was in disarray would be an understatement; it was positively wrecked. Some tables overturned, cake and icing residue coating their tops and some even on the walls... Hey, one of the tables was even cracked! But, oh gods, the cakes. They were all gone, the only traces but stains and crumbs. Stefan's eyes bulged out of his sockets. Who did this?

That question would be quickly answered by the same woman's voice he heard through the door crooning, "Ohhhhh... Ye're so good at this, Kayka~..." Kayka? Stefan opened the door a little more and moved into the room silently. Behind one of the flipped tables near the back of the room was an... odd sight to say the least. Two women, a human and a djinn, both very obviously the culprits. The human, a fat chick with a large ass and a remarkably engorged stomach, crouched on her hands and knees, giving her big belly room to exist without getting squashed. She had her butt out in the air, which was currently being caressed by the seated djinn, a flabby blue woman who looked like a swirled ice cream cone. Stefan watched for a moment as the djinn stuck her tongue out and licked the human's butt cheek, eliciting another groan from her. He then noticed that there was icing residue on her rump. Had she been sitting on cakes and getting the djinn to clean up the mess so nothing went to waste?

Stefan cleared his throat and got a quick, nasty look from both ladies. Gulp. He started, "Uh, who are you people and why are you in the storage room? Did you eat all the-" but the thought was cut off by them wordlessly getting up off the floor. GULP.

1331.content:
In a little village of the Motee Marshes, there was a great ruckus. All the people were leaving their huts and were directed toward the same places; all the people were bringing something with them: food. Every person either had a chunk of meat, and it didn't seem to be a preference of a specific kind, a fresh pike, or just a couple of papayas. Among those people, there was Jiroo.

Jiroo was a young boy of the village, only 8 years old, but that day, it was the first time for him to bring food for the goddess. This tradition began only a couple of months ago, when, apparently, a goddess arrived demanding a lot of food or she would've had destroyed the village, and every few days, all the citizen had to bring their share to the altar to satisfy their demand. Jiroo never had the occasion of bringing food before though, his parents thought it might have been too dangerous for him, but the boy wanted so desperately to see the fearsome goddess, that his father allowed him to go.

So Jiroo was bringing a peccary leg, with a big smile full of excitement and fear at the same time. He followed the crowd, his older sister grasping his hand, until he reached the altar.
It was a large rectangular stone, with torches at its corners and three some pots with perfumed ashes at every side.
The people got in line and, one after another, everyone put their food. The village was very small, barely 100 inhabitants including the children, but the citizens managed to amass enough food for a large family.

"Where is the goddess?" Asked an impatient Jiroo.

"She hasn't arrived yet" replied his mother.

The kid waited thrilled for the goddess. Would have she come from the sky in a storm? Riding a wyvern? Erupting with a flame? And what was she like? All these answers were answered after a few minutes of waiting.

The goddess came simply walking from the forest, and it wasn't exactly how he expected.
The goddess was a lady with a doughy body covered almost entirely in orange fur with black stripes, sans for the palm of the hands, the plants of the feet and the belly. The latter was especially noticeable; it was big and sagged in front of the thick thighs.

Her face was round, with puffy cheeks. She had big yellow diamond eyes, a black cat-like nose and a pair of black horns near her tiger ears. The hair on her head was short, barely reaching the chin and was black at the tips.
She was wearing a simple piece of cloth around the chest, which wasn't very large compared to the rest of the body, and a loincloth covering the genitals (if a goddess had any, thought Jiroo). The clothes had gold coins attached to them, which tinkled at every step when the clothes waved.

This wasn't what Jiroo expected, as to him; she resembled more a fat cat than a vengeful goddess.

And he was right as Tejral, wasn't a goddess, but a rakshasa, a tiger-like creature that lived in the marshy jungle. They were a race of skilled hunters, able to catch even the largest Triceratops with their strength.

Tejral tried to make the most serious and scary expression she could put. And all the humans slowly retreated while she advanced toward the altar. Then she sat, and her expression switched toward a happy and gluttonous one, with a big smile while she licked her lips, and her striped tail wagged back and forth behind her.

Tejral too lived off hunting, until, after stumbling across a village of humans, she noticed how those tribal people were scared of her, and came up with the "vengeful goddess" idea. Either the villagers paid her a tribute in food, or she would've destroyed their village utterly. The plan worked, and she suddenly found a very easy way to get all the food she wanted. Why bother hunting when she could get much more without breaking a sweat?

The rakshasa was devouring all the goods that were on the table. The villages there were full of good hunters, so she could taste all the delicious meats of the area every day, and they even left some fruits too; she wasn't a fruit lover too, but why bother to refuse them when they were so good? Especially the red and juicy ones; and in that moment she sunk her fangs into one, and all the sweet juice poured on her soft cheeks.

Three humans, along with a much older one, came in front of her. Tejral could see the terrified expression on their faces, with one breaking into a sweat. Two humans had a wooden flute in their hands, and the third a little drum.

"My goddess, Tejral" said the old man, the chief. Even if old, he still had a body that would make any average person envious, after all, he wasn't the chief only because he was the wisest (but not wise enough to see through Tejral's facade, thought the rakshasa with a grin) "I thought you might enjoy some music while you're eating our offering" he added, and pointed at the other three with his hand, waiting for Tejral's approval.

Tejral, with a mouth full of food like a chipmunk's, nodded. Some music wouldn't have minded her, and if it was good, she might had begin to "honour" this village more with her presence.

Tejral was, in fact, too greedy to stop to a single village, she wanted more. And thus, most of the villages in the area were serving her, bringing food on regular basis. And noticed how some began bringing more for her approval, either with more food, gold offering (a Rakshasa never refused gold) or other services.

Naturally, all of these had some consequence, as the once slender Tejral had almost doubled her weight in a few months. And her previous slender form could have been proved by the golden bracelet on her wrist, which was too small for her flabby arm.

Thankfully, the villages didn't questioned how could have a goddess gained weight, and so far Tejral was having the time of her life, even if her new size brought a couple of drawbacks, the pros were just too many.

She liked the music they were playing, but she didn't bother too much, as she was concentrated to the food on the altar. Once she was finished, she patted her overstuffed gut and asked for help to get up.

"I hope you appreciated our offering" said the chief.

"I did" replied Tejral with a big smile "I won't destroy this village" then she turned to her "scary face" "But I ask for another offering in three days, at the same hour.”

"Ok, we will" replied the chief bowing to his knees.

"Then, I shall take my leave of you," said Tejral, holding her belly as if she was pregnant, and slowly going back to the jungle.

Tejral walked slowly back home, while trying to remember which village was next morning. She had now planned meals *ahem* offerings with most of the villages in the area, but even after a couple of months, she hadn't remembered it quite well.

"Oh yes, the one near the waterfall" said Tejral at low voice. That village was full of fishermen, and thinking about the delicious fish she would have eaten the next day, made the rakshasa already hungry, despite all the stuff she had eaten not long ago.
Then, as if a real goddess heard her desire, she saw a peccary with three piglets. She licked her lips, and raised her hand with sharp claws, while also grabbing a branch which seemed sharp enough to work, and then she moved as quietly as she could, and jumped toward it with a surprise attack.

Unfortunately, the animals were too fast and escaped, while she was winded after a few meters of running. She tried to throw the branch as a spear too, but missed all of them.

Tejral stopped, with her still full belly rising and lowering with her breath. She was getting too out of shape for such activity, but her stomach was getting so used to all the extra food, she needed more to satisfy her gluttony. She thought perhaps she could demand more food from the villagers.

She walked back to her tree and sunk her claws into the bark, pulling her weighty form up until she arrived at her tree-top hut. One of the downside of this "goddess" play was that she had to walk a lot to get her food, if only she could stay in one of the villages forever...

She lowered herself onto her pile of fur that served as a bed, next to a dusty javelin who hadn't been touched in months, and closed her eyes.

The next day, she woke up, and her large stomach, having digested all the food of the day before, was growling, demanding to be filled. Tejral was more than happy to oblige, and left the hut to go toward the next village...

13331.content:
In the deep jungles of the Motee Marsh there are many great golden palaces that erupt out of the canopy like glittering mountains; the greatest and largest of all these houses the queen of the most populous race within the steamy jungles, the Naga Queen.

Within her titanic golden palace there are many rooms for the queen’s usage. One in particular nobody is allowed within, save for the queen and her chosen bride. Outside armed guards stand tall, their tails not even twitching as they stand motionless, halberds in hand. But inside this room there was plenty of movement going on.

If one was to gaze within this sacred room they would see a gigantic bed, made of many silken cushions and spreads, with giant golden snake statues on each corner. And on the bed was the naga queen herself, laid flat on her back with her arms splayed out, long black hair askew and her eyes clenched as her fangs bite her bottom-lip in pleasure.

“Yes! YES! YES!!!” The queen screamed as her wife and lover lay on top, her snake-like bottom half wrapped around her larger partner’s larger tail.

Their entwined tails lashed around wildly as the pair engaged in the intimate act of naga love-making. As an all female species, the naga needed a way to keep their population up, so females had evolved to fill either role. There were legends that there were once Naga males, but due to low population percentages between the sexes, some isolated all-female cities evolved this trait and the males died out once they re-integrated.

But there was still a small problem. Naga women only laid one egg at a time, and their gestation period was very long…with one exception. A Naga queen could give birth to one hundred eggs at a time, and spent just as long gestating them as any other female would one. This was partially why Naga queens were larger than standard Naga, their bone structure needed to be stronger to hold the extra weight pregnancy would bring.

Naga were not the only all-female race in Yndyre though, but they were the only ones with such low population growth. Which was why it was deemed necessary that the queen find a wife as soon as possible after her coronation; luckily for Coatzintli, her childhood friend and once hand-maiden had become her partner and then wife. The coronation had finished only a few hours ago even, and already the pair were “celebrating” hard.

Coatzintli screamed at the top of her lungs as she felt her wife enter her over and over, their tightened tails made every motion all the more pleasurable. The serpent sovereign lashed her arms around her wife’s back, holding her tight and pushing even more as she felt her pleasure reach its peak.

“C-mon, so close…” Coatzintli grunted as beads of sweat from her wife’s brow dripped onto her face. Then it happened, there was a sudden rush, and a feeling of being suddenly full before both snakes lost all their energy and collapsed together in a heap. All their rolling and thrashing however had led to them rolling towards the edge of the massive bed, and with a heavy thud both rolled over onto the golden floor, bedspread falling across them moments later.

“Li…I think we fell off…” the smaller naga giggled as both started laughing uncontrollably. Thankfully, despite the guard hearing the noise, none rushed to the “rescue”. They had been given explicit instructions to not disturb at all costs. This gave both Naga the chance to fall asleep on each other as they bathed in the afterglow, the tips of their tail sticking out of the sheets and holding on to each other firmly.


***



One week later…

“Ugh, why do I have to entertain this…monkey…” Coatzintli huffed as she stood stock still while her attendants were in the middle of dressing her in all her finery.

“It is to show the humans that we mean business by having them meet with the queen…and please don’t call them a monkey during the trade.” Her wife explained with a slight pleading tone at the end.

“Fine Patli…” The queen huffed as the final robes and ornaments were attached to her form. “How do I look?”

Patli gazed upon her wife in all her finery. A massive and magnificent headdress rested upon her crown, tipped with the longest feathers of the local birds of the Marshes. A thin piece of fabric was dressed across her modest bosom, with small gold rings dangling from it. Her smooth belly was exposed to the elements, to allow her skin to breath in such a hot climate; and right at the point where her brown and black-striped skin met her scales she wore a flowing dress, bedecked with many precious jewels.

“Beautiful as always.” Patli stated with a smile.

“Ha! You never say anything else do you?” Coatzintli replied, slithering over and leaning down to give her wife a small kiss on the cheek.

“Because it is always true.” Patli replied, tapping the queen on the nose as they turned to enter the throne room.

Coatzintli could not help stare back however, Patli was dressed in far less resplendent clothes, but they still made her look even more beautiful than before. Patli had beautiful turquoise, red and black stripes that ran laterally up her scaly body until they met her smooth orangey-brown skin. Her black hair had been braided and tied around her head, unlike Coatzintli’s which was left to flow behind her. Coatzintli was always enthralled by her more colorful partner; Naga queens were not only bigger than normal Naga, but they had duller colors too (most likely a leftover of some trait where they had to camouflage). But Patli's colors were more than just for show, the venom in her incisors was extremely powerful, capable of knocking any of the massive Saurian beasts that roamed the jungles out cold for several hours, and killing anything smaller than that. Thankfully for the Queen, she had nothing to fear, Naga's were notoriously poison-resistant.

As they slithered hands in hands, Coatzintli felt a little gurgling coming from her middle. Placing one of her right hands on it seemed to settle it, so she paid it no heed for now.

Entering the golden throne room, the queen slithered her way up onto her dais. There was no way a Naga could sit on anything remotely like the more humanoid thrones; so instead they had these large bed-like surfaces for the queen to curl her serpentine body onto. Patli had her own smaller one to the right of the main dais.

With her advisors arriving shortly after and lining up beside the duel thrones, the massive golden doors creaked open to reveal a man in silver armour and wearing a strange helmet with a thin crest running up it.

Twirling his curled moustache to announce his presence, the man unrolled a scroll and began to read from it. “May I present to the royalty of the Naga Kingdom, her Excellency, The Duchess Esmeralda De Cortenza, owner of the Great Western Trading Corporation!”

The man instantly took a step away from the doors as flanks of guards, wearing the same armor as the first man, marched into the room. In between the pair of serried ranks was an absolute whale of a woman. She was wearing an immense light-blue dress that flowed to the floor in a large dome shape (Coatzintli wondered if there was some hidden device under it to keep the fat woman upright). She was wielding a fan and waving it as if her life depended on it, it was quite clear she was not here for the weather. A massive powdered wig adorned her head and her face was colored a pallid snow white, save for a single black dot on her lower lip.

“Welcome to my palace Duchess.” Coatzintli began (she remembered her mother’s pleasantries routine off by heart). "I am queen Coatzintli, this is my wife Patli and my advisers, I hope your travel through my jungles was pleasant?”

The woman began to beat the fan even harder until it looked inches off from scraping her immense cheeks. “Well!” she began, “Aside from ze weather being 'ot enough to boil a cat, it vas pleasant enough. But now, let uz talk business…”

As the sow-like woman prattled on, Coatzintli felt the queasiness in her belly return again, only much stronger this time. Then, she could bear it no longer.

“Excuse me!” Coatzintli mumbled, placing one hand over her mouth the queen slithered off her dais and out back through the door she came in through.

“Li!” Patli cried out, before turning towards the stunned Duchess. “The Queen has been feeling unwell recently, I do apologize!” Patli thought up before slithering after her spouse.

She found Coatzintli back in the dressing room, her head leaning out of the window. “Li, are you ok?” Patli asked, placing a hand on her wife’s back.

“Yes…just…don’t look down…bit of a royal mess there now...” Coatzintli mumbled, before turning to face Patli. “I…I think I’m pregnant…”
13331.title: Enter, the Serpent Queen

133311.content:
In the Naga Kingdom there were certain ceremonies that had to be done; coronations, welcoming the rainy season…and announcing when her highness was pregnant. It was a rather quick affair, the queen would stand on a balcony give a little wave a little speech and then would retreat inside. It was normally sprung on the public however, so nobody ever saw it coming; it made all the cheers all the greater and there were normally public events afterwards such as special food stalls, activities for the hatchlings; it was all a nice day out. But one person was not looking forward to it…

“Why do I have to wear this?”

“It is tradition, your mother wore it when she was first pregnant.”

“It’s itchy all over my scales.”

“You only have to wear it for a few minutes.”

“I look bloated.”

“You look radiant.”

“I feel bloated.”

“Well you are already two weeks along.”

Patli was correct, it had only been a week since the incident with the Duchess (a trade deal that had only gone down well thanks to Patli’s quick-thinking and the Queen’s advisors), and Coatzintli was already physically showing to the world that she was pregnant.

The Naga’s belly was now convex, sticking out a few inches from the rest of her torso. Her size would have confused most humans, who would have to wait four months to get around this big; at least there was one advantage over the mammals Coatzintli had…she wouldn’t have that weird popped-out belly-button the humans got during the final months. That was something she always found odd about those monkeys…why did they have a small hole there anyway?

As for why Coatzintli was already so clearly showing, it was because of the incoming size of her brood. While ordinary Naga had one child maximum per pregnancy…the Naga Queens could have much much more; and Coatzintli did not like that idea at all.

“I am going to get so huge…” The Queen muttered as she stroked her belly with two of her arms and propped her back up with the lower ones.

“It will be ok…we always dreamed of having a family.” Patli comforted, taking her wife’s hands in her own.

“I know…but I…I didn’t want to get pregnant so soon…I wanted to explore, see the jungles…see the world. Not become a massive baby-factory like my mother.”

“You can’t blame her for this…” Patli added quietly.

Coatzintli gripped her wife’s hands tightly. “I know…it was not her fault she got sick…but I still have my regrets…I know what you are going to say next, we shouldn’t have had sex on our wedding night…but gods you looked so good in that dress…”

Patli smiled at the compliment. “We could find a compromise? Like we could have your dais transported around other places so you can see the world…once your first pregnancy is over anyway, the people would be horrified if you just disappeared part-way through.”

“I know I know, I am a symbol of prosperity and fertility to my people…gods know I will be for the last part, I’m going to be gravid if there are a hundred of them in here…” Coatzintli gently rubbed the mound again, looking down at her stretched brown and black skin; she was thankful at this point that Naga were so used to eating such vast quantities of food in a single sitting, no way was her belly going to accommodate this pregnancy otherwise.

The pair pressed their foreheads together and embraced into a gentle hug. As they did, Patli pinched some of Coatzintli’s skin. “Are you eating properly?” The Naga asked, pulling out of the hug and giving her wife a stern look.

Coatzintli rolled her eyes, god THIS part.

“You need to up your intake; otherwise you won’t have the strength.” Patli scolded. “And don’t tell me you don’t like the idea of getting fat, everyone gets fat every wet season…I mean I remember last wet season SOME chubby Naga I knew got so big she burst her dress in front of that Merfolk peace envoy, good thing he had such a sense of humour…”

“Ugh! Why do you keep bringing that up!” Coatzintli pouted. “Mention that again and I will have you sent to the dungeons.” The Queen added, jokingly poking her wife on the nose.

“Mmmm, I bet you would like to have me in chains for a while.” Patli giggled.

“You know it…anyway, there is a difference between me getting chubby once a year and me getting…that big…” Coatzintli almost hissed as she remembered the sheer size her mother had become before she fell ill.

“Li, nobody cares if you get fat…in fact the people expect it of…you…wait, are you worried that if you get fat I won’t find you attractive anymore?” Patli pried.

“Dunno…maybe…” The queen muttered.

“LI! Ugh! I told you before, I.love.you. I married you for Yva’s sake!” Patli smacked her face with one of her many palms. “I don’t care how fat you get, you could be as big as the palace and I would still think you are the hottest thing to slither around this jungle!”

“Even if my cheeks get super duper fat?” Coatzintli pined; she always had been super sensitive about how fat her face got every wet season, and the threat of getting even bigger made her super self-conscious about it.

“They would just be extra-adorable and extra-pinchable!” Patli cooed, “No speaking of adore, your public awaits!”

***


The journey to the balcony felt like it took forever. Coatzintli hugged her mound as she slithered towards the doorway bathed in bright light that the jungle floor rarely saw.

“Presenting her Highness Queen Coatzintli!” A guard bellowed as the Naga slithered into the eye-line of the crowd. The audience erupted as they caught sight of Coatzintli in her pure white robes meant to symbolize fertility and her golden headdress that was a gesture of thanks to the gods for the miracle of the life growing within her.

The green queen did not know if she really wanted to thank the gods at this stage. Sure she loved Patli and that night of passion she wished she could have over and over again…but this after-effect would cripple her chance to see the outside world. Well, maybe not…Patli did have a plan. But if she really did get even half as big as her mother did, that would be a lot of Naga needed to hold a palanquin big enough for her…perhaps they could coerce some stronger races to lend some guards for a trip? Perhaps some clever designer had built a carriage that could be pulled? Hmmm, thinking things over as she waved to the crowds, Coatzintli thought that maybe there was a way to see the world even in her immense post-pregnancy state…
133311.title: A Crowd Warmer

choices: Patli continues to work behind Coatzintli's back to keep her wife well-fed!
Coatzintli hosts a banquet for lesser naga royalty, including her many sisters.
1333111.content:
Ever since the announcement that Queen Coatzintli was with child, the Marshes had erupted in festivities.

The Queen (now referred to posthumously as the Queen Mother by Coatzintli's people) had been a well-beloved ruler for many decades. Even in the long lifespan of the naga, not even the oldest of the snake women could remember a ruler who took so well to the throne. Most of her reign had been a peaceful time of prosperity, and it was her leadership that saw the birth of the shaky alliance between the Naga and the Rakshasa who shared the marshes. The naga people thrived under her leadership, and had become quite accustomed to celebration. Every season, it seemed, the Queen Mother had given her kingdom another reason to rejoice. From births upon births to peace treaties to royal diplomats visiting to an especially fruitful rainy season, it wasn't hard to see why the recent generations of naga who had lived under the Queen Mother's rule had linked ceremonial duties with celebratory ones.

So, still riding high on the coronation of their new queen, the news that she was to bear children was met with even further raucous celebration.

"This is..." the queen tilted her head slightly at the sight in front of her, "...Patli, what's the word I'm looking for?"

"Wonderful? Generous? Delicious-looking?"

"No, I was thinking along the lines of 'unnecessary'..." Coatzintli's upper set of arms crossed underneath her impressive brown bust, "I'd hate to call it 'wasteful' because it's very nice. But it's... kinda wasteful."

Laying dead in the great stone dining hall, felled from what looked to be a combination of poison and spearhead, several of the kingdom's finest hunters had offered their queen a gigantopithicus. These great orange apes were uncommon offerings, given their peaceful nature and the fact that they towered over even naga of royal breed. That being said, they were delicious. It wasn't common that they were taken by the hunters, thanks to their sheer size and power. How they'd managed this, Coatzintli was more than a little curious.

"How is it wasteful?" Patli asked from beside her wife, slithering in front of her and spreading her arms wide so as to truly capture the size of the peoples' offering, "The captain's guard said that all of the festivities drew it out of the marshes. It was self defense, my queen!"

"Okay, then maybe we shouldn't have all of these festivities." Coatzintli offered sagely, "It's the dry season, so we should be conserving resources... and gigantopithici are peaceful."

"Peaceful and delicious." Patli countered with a shrug of her four shoulders, "It'd be wasteful not to eat it."

And, even though she was loathe to admit it, Coatzintli could see the merit in her wife's argument. Her hunters and guards had gone to great length to procure what was, in naga culture, a delicacy. Giga-meat had been a favorite of Coatzintli's since she was just a little girl, elbowing her many sisters for scraps. She hadn't had it in years, and the smell of it was beginning to make her resolve a little weak. Her turgid brown stomach, ripe with child, squelched longingly at the sight of so much of it in one place...

"Guards!" Coatzintli's fanged mouth opened wide, her upper hands clapped together while the lower ones habitually rested on her gravid stomach, "Get this monkey to my chefs post-haste. Have them prepare it for supper!"

Yes your highness! four armor-clad naga women saluted, tapping the dull ends of their lances to the stone floor of the palace before slithering into place. Strong arms wrapped around the various limbs of the great ape, joined quickly by another two sets of four, and hefted the massive monkey towards the great hall. Six naga held it high, so that its protruding stomach didn't scrape against the floor. The queen and her wife reconvened among themselves as the guards hefted supper away to be prepared.

"A wise decision, Li." Patli smiled, "I'm sure your servants will be pleased that you're taking a liking to their generous offering."

"I hope they aren't too pleased." Coatzintli tugged her full brown lips tersely, "We really shouldn't be killing those things willy-nilly."

"I'll be sure to tell them in a royal decree." Patli nodded sagely, "Can't have our queen unhappy now, can we?"

"Stop." Coatzintli laughed a little, "You're never going to get me to see myself as Queenly."

"If you're not the queen, then that royal decree is literally just me shouting out on the plaza." the smaller naga said, running a hand up her lover's swollen stomach, "Now, enough of that. You go take a royal nap while I see to the preparation of dinner."

The two naga women embraced, Patli's more colorful scales wrapping around the wide hips and tail of her queen. They parted with a kiss and a flirtatious wave, Patli wiggling her fingers cutely at her long-time lover. As Coatzintli slithered away, Patli hurried down the hall and caught up to the captain of the guards. Reaching into her satchel, she pulled out a few golden coins. The Captain's yellow eyes widened and her fanged mouth smiled appreciatively at the weight in her hand.

"I didn't really expect you to be able to do it." Patli smiled as she dropped the gold into the captain's hand, "Your queen says no more Gigantopithicus... for now... buuuut you know how those pregnancy cravings get. Maybe see if you can score something a little less endangered. Big game, but not endangered."

"You're a sly one, your highness." the Captain of the Guard chuckled, "Generous too."

"Remember that." Patli winked, "If her highness starts to ask questions."

The Captain of the Guard winked back and pretended to lock her lips.

Li might have had plans for her life post-partum. But Patli had plans of her own. Big plans.
1333111.title: Coaxing Coatzintli into Corpulence

choices: Patli's plan is working—Coatzintli's getting fat, spoiled, and hungry!
Patli's plan is working, in a sort—Li's not going to lie down easy on this!
Patli's plan isn't working fast enough—she needs a shortcut!
13331111.content:
Coatzintli, the great serpent and queen of the Naga, hadn't left her chambers in days. The people of Maya, the capital city, hadn't particularly minded her absence. The collective idea was that, due to her condition, she was to remain in her great stone palace. A queen so young, about to give birth to such a mighty load of children, it wasn't inconceivable to the public that she would need to prepare. And thanks to the ready machinations of the queen's ready wife, that idea had resulted in many offerings being left at the base of the stairs leading up to their palace.

Every day, golden trinkets and jewelry were left to celebrate the Queen's ravishing beauty. Feathers from winged serpents and mighty eagles that soared overhead were brought to decorate and accentuate her regal demeanor. Gold and rings were brought by any and all who wished her a long and happy life, marriage, and motherhood. But—and this part was very important—all those who wished such a young queen strength during such a momentous occasion brought food.

Birds felled by bows and spears, great "lesser" snakes that had been felled in battle, and mammals of all shapes and sizes were brought daily to the Queen and her palace. In respect to her wishes against eating "peaceful" creatures, the people were to only bring her what they felt wouldn't offend. Monkeys (no Gigantopithici, but few were that lucky to start!) were her favorite, but plenty of other beast met its fate in the name of Queen Coatzintli's "continued health through pregnancy".

"This is completely unnecessary." Coatzintli panted as she lay on the dais, her stomach distended with supper rather than child, "I can go one day without... urp... stuffing my face."

"Nonsense, my lady." the smaller naga slithered to her wife's side to touch the royal stomach, "You are with child. The shamans say that you're to have an especially large birthing. You need your strength."

For the past few days, Coatzintli hadn't left her chambers. She'd lazed around, being waited on hand and foot by the royal servants. Even when she had been merely one of many princesses, she hadn't been so sedentary. She was always slithering around the palace, making trouble with Patli or her sisters. But ever since she'd been named Queen, all she'd done is eat.

"You're spoiling me." Coatzintli puffed, her breath heavy and ragged. She winced as Patli's fingertips brushed against the tight skin of her stomach. With the steadily growing swarm of snakelets inside of her and the feasting she'd been doing lately, it was hard to tell what was sapping her strength more. The weight of the future generation of naga, or the amount of food it took to feed them.

"Your people are spoiling you." the smaller snake purred proudly into her wife's ear, rubbing concentric circles gently into her softening brown belly, "They love their queen."

"Too much." Coatzintli whined, "They love their queen too much."

"That's just the pregnancy talking." Patli smiled, reaching for a small wooden bowl of panacea, "Here, this will settle your stomach."

Patli glanced over her wife's figure. Her stature was great in size; she towered over all of the other snake women in the city in meters, not heads. But even in her great height, the offerings that her people (offerings helpfully "suggested" by none other than the worrying wife of Coatzintli herself!) had taken their toll on her girlish figure. The swell of her stomach had begun to hang with child, this much was inevitable. But the ample amounts of fat that clung to her sides, the breadth of her breasts, and the girth of her arms could not be ignored either. The Queen was growing, that much was certain.

Not quickly enough, for Patli's tastes.

"Feeling better?" Patli cooed, stroking her queen's black feathered hair as her mighty head lay in her lap

"A little." she cooed like a hatchling one-tenth her size, "Thank you Patli."

"Of course, my queen." the littler naga smiled.

She closed her eyes, picturing what her bride might look like at a truly queenly size—Coatzintli's mother had left quite a high bar for future generations of naga to aspire towards. So large that she couldn't leave this very room, with its wide stone doorways that gave berth to literally everyone else in Yndyre but their very queen. The thought of her sweet little Li at even half that size gave her a wicked sense of excitement.

If that monkey king in the Plains could have his harem of fat wives, why couldn't Patli? She was a queen too, you know.

"More, my love?" Patli held up a sweet to her lover's lips, even their snake-tongues could appreciate the nectar and flavors within, "Dinner will be quite a wait from now."

Coatzintli agreed with a weak smile, reasoning that it would be a while until dinner was ready. As she bit into the hard candy like-substance, her golden eyes rolled into the back of her head. An army of flavors rushed to dance across her serpent's tongue, devoid of half the taste buds that any other half-mammal had. Flavors were such a rare thing for the Naga, thanks to their biology. She'd only bitten into such riches once or twice during her life as a princess, but as a queen...

"Ohhh..." Coatzintli huffed, "That's... that's really good..."

"You deserve a lot better than 'really good'." Patli purred, hand-feeding her queen the rest of her sweet, "You're our queen. The mother of the next generation. You deserve everything."

"You're sweet." Coatzintli managed as she came down from the flavor rush, her eyelids heavy, "I don't deserve you."

And as the Queen fell into a deep slumber, her wife's small hand rolled up onto her doughy brown side. She grabbed a handful of ample queenly flesh, and bit into her bottom lip as she felt the fat of her wife give way to her touch. Her heavy sleeping form may have pinned Patli beneath her, but you would be remiss to hear her complaining.

"Sleep, my sweet little Li..." Patli hissed as she fondled her queen's extra fluff, "And when you wake up, I'll make sure you get a nice, big dinner..."
13331111.title: Patli's Progress

choices: Coatzintli ate a servant!
They were attacked!
133311111.content:
Coatzintli awoke to another bright day and attempted to roll over onto her back but found it too difficult.
"Patli, are you there?" She called. She was suddenly overtaken with the smell of food- breakfast at last! she thought. She drooled at the thought of her first of an ever increasing number of breakfasts. It had been months since Coatzintli had even stood up, but the thought of moving at all was exhausting alone, never mind actually carrying out the action. Patli came in with four, no, five servants, each carrying two trays. Patli stayed with Coatzintli while the servants all went back to out the door.
"Good morning, my queen." Patli said with a loving tone. "How are you doing this morning?"
"I'm starving! Hurry up and feed me!" Coatzintli demanded. Patli laughed and began to hand-feed the ever growing queen, admiring her form. If her highness were to stand, her stomach would just barely miss the floor. At this point, though, her tail muscles had atrophied enough that she would need help to even hold herself up, let alone walk. Her heaving chest was larger than the tiny serpent's entire upper body. Coatzintli's arms were useless, her hands slowly being consumed by her ever-increasing corpulence. Her tail had grown in length and girth, now long enough it could wrap around Patli twice over- if it had the strength. Coatzintli's face was more of a blob, her neck only distinguishable from the rest of her thanks to the five chins she now sported. And to think she's on an empty stomach. Patli thought as she heaved an entire raptor into her gaping maw, beginning Coatzintli's meal. By the end of their feeding session, Coatzintli had eaten five Triceratops, at least twenty raptors, six monkeys, and an entire Tyrannosaurus Rex. Her stomach, now taught with food, hung over the opposite side of the bed, forcing Patli off.
"That-yawn-was a good breakfast." Coatzintli said, smiling as she rubbed her stomach. "Could I have more?"
"More?" Patli said, shocked at what she had just heard. Her shock was replaced with pure delight as she realized what this meant: it's worked! Or, at least is working. Her plan was coming to fruition. "Of course, my queen! Anything for you!" Patli said with new vigor in her step.

After about a week of this routine, the queen was in a state of near constant eating. Food at almost all times was being brought to her, and she ate all of it. Patli came in to check on the queen, and what she saw delighted her to no end:
The queen's bed was removed some time ago after she had destroyed it under her mass, and she now lied atop a large number of pillows. Her stomach rose into the air, visibly expanding as she ate more and more. It was large enough it could fit at least ten naga inside- rainy season naga. Her bust was in a similar state, each breast at least half the size of her stomach. Her face was sat atop a mountain of chins, too many for Patli to count from where she stood. The queen's arms were completely useless, consumed by fat piled upon fat, her many hands had disappeared beneath her ever-expanding mass. Roll after roll flowed down her entire frame, pooling on the floor as though she were a volcano, her flab the lava oozing out. And her tail. It wrapped around the room, twisting as it needed to just to be able to fit inside the space. Patli watched for an entire hour as the queen devoured her food without a second thought. Tyrannosaurs, Triceratops, Stegosauri, all of them entered Coatzintli's maw with ease, sliding down her mullet and into the depths of her stomach. She imagined her brood must be similarly engorged with so much food having been provided for her. Patli went up to her, "Good to be the queen?" she asked in jest, patting her stomach. Coatzintli didn't seem to hear her, too focused on devouring more and more food. Patli smiled and looked at her expanding stomach. Patli could feel the skin shifting as more and more entered the seemingly bottomless pit that was Coatzintli's stomach. Patli rested her head upon the ever-growing mass, enjoying every second of what was occurring. It is good to be the queen, she thought to herself. Then, something happened that Patli wasn't expecting:
133311111.title: Coatzintli the Vast

choices: Coatzintli back to her senses! She's ashamed, distraught and utterly horrified!
Coatzintli doesn't even notice. Is Patli worried about her wife's mental state?
Upon seeing this, the servants panic and run! News spreads like wildfire!
1333111111.content:
It came out of nowhere.

Things had been proceeding as a routine part of Coatzintli's around-the-clock feedings. No one had realized what exactly was occurring until it was simple too late. The servants had been bringing their plates up to rest on their gargantuan queen's forms so that Patli could personally feed her. As disrespectful as some might've have found this, it was the only way to make things practical.

The first servant to have fully ascended Coatzintli's bulk, to appear before the fattened face of her monarch, tripped. Not from any random act either. It was because Coatzintli had tried to lurched forward once her eyes rested on the large plate of food. Her food-addled state had blinded her to the fact that such an action was unnecessary. Food was only a few moments away. But she hadn't cared, she could no longer tolerate any interruptions in the stream of morsels given to her. She grew impatient and the poor servant paid for that.

While Coatzintli couldn't move that much, her lurch had caused her immense bulk to wobble and shake. It was just enough that the servants struggled to stay upright given the large weight of the plates they were carrying. The servant fell forward even as she tried to remain balanced. As the servant and the plate came rushing towards her face, Coatzintli opened her mouth wide. But the palte and its food never made it to her mouth. No, it went sailing just over the queen's head. Instead the servant fell into her gaping maw. The poor girl barely had to scream in dismay before her head passed Coatzintli's lips and before anyone could do anything, the rest of the servant girl followed suit, disappearing down into the queen's gullet...
1333111111.title: Coatzintli ate a servant!

choices: "No, no. This is all wrong. I must find a way to undo what I have done..."
"I rule in these lands. My queen will feast, and if anyone DARES defy me..."
13331111112.content:
The servants, most of whom had fallen over or were otherwise distracted after Coatzintli's sudden movement, hadn't realized what had just happened. Patli came to her senses, whipping around and saying in a calm manner,

"Everyone just leave the food in this room. Wherever is fine; I would like some privacy with my queen." The servants obeyed, setting the food down and making their way out of the room, unsure as to what had changed. My queen, Patli repeated to herself.

Patli moved to feed the glutton lying before her, making sure not to make the same mistake as the now digesting servant had. Hours passed, and by the time Patli had run out of food Coatzintli was falling asleep, the digestion process tiring her. Patli had an internal dialogue with herself,

Is this what I want from my queen? I'm loving every second of this, but I've lost the person who I fell in love with. What I have left is a pile of ever-growing bulk. Coatzintli's mind is gone, completely overtaken by a desire for food.

She is my queen, is she not? I can rule even if she cannot. And besides, she is in a clear state of euphoria over this whole situation, each piece of food increasing her pleasure and desire.

She ate a person! An actual person! I cannot simply overlook this... can I? Will anyone notice? What will people say?

She could eat the whole damn city for all I care! And why should I? I am the queen just as much as she is. I have the power, and she has willingly handed it over to me. As long as I keep her fed and keep this from happening again, things will be fine. Besides, I could always employ some... political maneuvers to keep things quiet.

But that is awful! But... no. This is wrong. This is wrong on every level possible. Right? Isn't it? Of course it is. I have destroyed her, as a person. What made her unique, what made me love her, is now gone, replaced by a sack of corpulent flesh taking up more and more space in our castle. But... she does seem happy.

Patli watched as her wife slept, her frame rising and lowering with each of her breaths. She still wasn't the size of her mother, but then again Coatzintli had said that she hadn't wanted to be. But, maybe she should be. Should she? Patli's desires flooded into her mind, and she moved to lean against the gurgling mass that was her stomach. Patli found herself at a crossroad: her desire verse Coatzintli's. Who was to be the dominant queen, and who would roll over for the other?
13331111112.title: Mindless Glutton

choices: Her plan works! Now the queen is eating more, and sleeping right after eating
Her plan does not work as expected, now the queen is just really lazy
The Eagle Warriors cannot find the root, it is out of season
133311113.content:
Some mornings later, Patli was slithering her way up to her beloveds’ chambers. Clutched in her many arms were platters of rich food; the queen had not been eating as much as her wife had hoped, so she had made sure that the selection she brought up were extra strong-smelling, to tickle her pregnancy cravings.

Approaching the super-sized double doors, Patli hip-checked them open. “Li, I brought you some… meats…” she began, noticing that the room appeared empty.

Placing the platters on the neatly-made bed, Patli began to slither around frantically, “LI LI!” She cried out, as her tail rolled over something on the floor. Turning around, the worried serpent found queen Coatlzintli’s crown and royal finery. Oh gods! What if someone had kidnapped her!? She was pregnant with their babies! If she was put through too much stress, she might lose them!

Rushing from the room as fast as she could, Patli began to scour every square inch of the palace, notifying every guard that she could that the queen was missing. She checked the kitchens, the guard’s quarters, but as Patli leaned out of a window, she spotted something. There was a figure in the royal gardens, not wearing the usual royal guard’s armor. She couldn’t make out who it was, so instantly made her way down the stairs and out into the courtyard.

The figure hadn’t gone very far from where the diminutive Naga had initially spotted them; dressed in a brown leather shawl to cover themselves.

“Stop right there!” Patli yelled as she slithered up to the figure and snatched at the shawl; “What… what are you doing here!”

Standing in front of her, was her royal highness. Removed of all her royal jewelry, queen Coatlzintli looked struck a much less regal figure; her size however still kept her looking very imposing. In just those few weeks, she had grown even larger. Many pounds had clung themselves to her shape, and her belly was even more gravid than before.

“Ugh… I was hoping to get some exercise… outside… where nobody could see me…” Coatlzintli admitted, hands clutching her arms as she shifted nervously.

“You gave me such a fright…” Patli replied. “I thought someone had abducted you!”

Coatlzintli scowled, her four arms lowering to her belly and clutched it, “Do you think anybody can abduct me like this? Look at me! I’m huge!” What proceeded was almost a guided tour of the queen’s troubled parts; pinching her double chin, holding out her arms to show how they jiggled, hefting up her colossal breasts before letting them drop back to her belly. “I can’t get too big Patli, I need to shed some of this…”

Patli took Coatlzintli’s hands in her own, “I know you’re frightened about this, but you need to be careful, too much stress can harm the children.”

Coatlzintli felt herself almost wishing she had never gotten pregnant; she wanted to at least see the world before relinquishing to her fate as a fat bloated egg-laying mass. It was such a selfish thought though, the young queen could barely look Patli in the eye as the idea rolled around in her mind.

“Fine… just… let me get some fresh air before I go back inside.” Coatlzintli stated as she eyed up one of the stone benches.

“Alright, I will get the guards to call off the search.” Patli agreed, as she left the queen alone to return indoors. Almost instantly she passed a hurried group of them; “The queen is just taking a break. Make sure nobody disturbs her.” She instructed to the burly women.

This wouldn’t do at all, how was Coatlzintli supposed to get even close to her predecessor’s size if she kept resisting nature like this? Patli would have to think up some kind of solution to the problem.

---


Two weeks later, and an idea finally came to her.

Coatlzintli and Patli were sharing some private time together in their private chambers. Patli had to cuddle up next to her queen now; the gravidity of her majesties’ form was making the idea of slithering under her life-threatening. Most of this however was centered in Coatlzintli’s big pregnant belly; the queen hadn’t been putting on weight quite as fast as she had in the past few weeks before the courtyard incident. It seemed her worrying was affecting her appetite.

As the pair nuzzled together, Patli offered some more treats to her queen, dangling them above her head. The pair were sort of falling in and out of half-sleep, the larger of the two moreso though; and as Patli watched, her lover seemed to be more easily persuaded to eat like this.

So when another sweet was dangled above Coatlzintli’s head, and her long forked tongue lazily plucked it from Patli’s brown fingers, an idea came to her. Making a mental note of her plan, she rested her head on the queen’s shoulder and they both slipped into proper sleep.

---


The next day, Patli slithered her way into the main barracks. There most of the royal guards who were not on duty were training. The building felt so much hotter and humid than the others, as the various snake-women trained. Biceps bulged, girl-abs strained, and long muscular tails flexed; for anyone that found such things attractive, they would have thought they had gone to the afterlife.

But Patli was not here to ogle, she was on a mission.

Heading to one particular part of the barracks, she found what were referred to as the Eagle Warriors. Naga that dressed in eagle feathers during battle, and were often the scouts and harassment troops; their speed and maneuverability being far greater than the burlier women in the barracks.

“Attention!” Patli snapped, calling the slimmer women over. “The queen has become restless as of late; I need you to go into the jungles and find some medicinal herbs. The kind used for sleeping draughts.” The Eagle Warriors simply saluted; Patli was the wife of her royal majesty, what she said goes.

As Patli watched the women equip themselves for a trip into the deeper parts of the jungle, she smiled to herself. All she had to do was grind a little of the herbs into Coatlzintli’s food, the mild sedative should make her easily suggestible, and more likely to give in to both her cravings and Patli’s insistence that she overeat.

That was the plan anyway…
133311113.title: Resisting Nature

choices: Coatzintli tries to fight her appetite so as not to get too big.
Coatzintli gives into her appetite. They are her children after all.
1333112.content:
Pregnant or no, Coatzintli was still expected to perform her duties as queen, and that meant one thing: playing host to the handful of cultures that were brave enough to venture this far into the jungles. In this case, she was expecting visitors from both the Samin Desert and the little mountain village of Futotta-Machi. She was used to the comings and goings of the Djinn scholars. They were always interested in the temples of her villages, specifically those dedicated to Ciros and Nilheia. They liked how the architecture of the temple aligned with the movements of the sun, moon, and stars, and were always wanting to study them. She couldn't understand why. If anything, the even larger temple to Zolneas was more impressive. It was also more active, as the Naga found a special affiliation with the serpentine goddess of fire. Still, the Djinn liked to flock to her capital, seeking to climb to the tops of these temples for a special place of meditation.

The Kitsune monk she was expecting from Futotta-Machi was another matter entirely. She knew very little about this race and their monks who resided in the monasteries located high in the snowy mountains. What she did know was that they were known for weaving the finest silks, hence her visit.

Coatzintli rubbed her bump affectionately. "Please cut me a break and don't cause trouble today," she whispered to it. Still in the early weeks of her pregnancy, she was still getting quite nauseous from time to time. She would prefer not to have a repeat of her incident with the duchess.

The first admitted into the palace was a silhouette she recognized very well. If one were just looking at his shadow, they would've assumed he were one of the hulking warlords of the south. Coatzintli knew better. Djinn males were often tall, broad, bulky, and angular, compared to their softer, smaller, and more curved female counterparts. She was certain that if she could stand on the tip of her tail, she would still be half a foot shorter than this giant. Knowing that the heat of the jungle was humid and wet, instead of dry like the desert he preferred, he had forgone his usual robes, wearing only his long, satin pants, allowing the queen to see the full extent of his bare chest, which looked chiseled enough to carve diamonds on. No...quit staring, Coatzintli told herself. She loved Patli, but there was no denying an exotic attractiveness exuded from this creature, and the vibrant indigo skin did nothing to help that.

He stood before her, his fingers pyramided together as he gently bowed his head. She looked up at the two dark eyes that were so hard to read. Djinn were like that; they rarely expressed feelings, and so it was hard to know what they were thinking. They always had this expression of bemused curiosity on their face, as if they thought you were something to be studied and dissected. That was absurd, of course, she knew. They were usually very friendly, just hard to know exactly what to say with them. She returned the bow with her head. "Mojit," she greeted, "I am honored to have you as my guest."

Mojit finally smiled. "The honor is all mine. I feel blessed to be with you to celebrate your latest joy."

He nodded towards her protruding stomach, and she shyly looked down. That was a rather high compliment coming from the Djinn. They were not born like other creatures. At best, she understood them as ethereal beings that just came into existence. For him to attempt to empathize was rather high praise. "I'm sure that's not all you're here for," she said.

Mojit laughed. "Indeed, but perhaps we may discuss that over dinner. I have brought all your majesty's favorite treats from the south, and even a few spices I talked some sailors out of."

While she still did dislike the idea of eating constantly and getting huge, she couldn't help but acknowledge that Mojit knew her well. She did, after all, consider him a friend.

She would have conversed longer, but they were interrupted by the arrival of her second guest. It was almost comical how much her two guests differed from each other. Whereas Mojit was boxy and angular, the Kitsune was rather round and plush-looking. No one could quite hold a candle to her mother's immense size, Coatzintli thought, but this one was sure trying. She stood at about her own height, but looked four, if not five times the size of the Naga queen.

She was rather interested in the unique appearance of these creatures. The monk's hair was as white as could be, and trailed down her back, brushing against the equally white and fluffy tails that trailed behind her. She wore a long, pale-pink robe and had an adorable, round, motherly looking face. As she finally waddled up to the queen, she did her best to bow. "Mother Kayo," Coatzintli greeted. "I hope you found your travel here pleasant."

The older woman nodded. "Indeed, I have been meaning to visit this place since I had heard of its existence. These jungles are simply gorgeous. Oh! I had no idea you were expecting. I would've brought you a special dress made of our silks if I had known."

Coatzintli only nodded. "It's not necessary, but I thank you. I think we will still arrange a fair trade while you enjoy your stay. Mother Kayo, this is Sage Mojit, a Djinn from the Samin Desert."

He nodded to the Kitsune. "I had heard of the Kitsune's alluring beauty, but I am thrilled to be seeing it in person."

She giggled, blushing. Coatzintli only rolled her eyes. Mojit was always such a charmer. He used to do it to her mother all the time. "Well, why don't we take this all to the dining hall? Her majesty has prepared a welcome feast for you both," Patli said, coming through the doors.

XXX

Dinner was actually a rather pleasant affair. Her guests were both cordial, conversational, and the best part: no nausea. Coatzintli would actually have counted it a good night. "I've heard your monks engage in a sort of active meditation," Mojit said to Mother Kayo, "please, tell me more about it."

The Kitsune dabbed her mouth with her napkin before speaking. "It's really very simple. Our monks find activities which they enjoy and use them as a means of meditating and getting closer to the divine. For example, several of my sisters will tend to our beautiful cherry tree gardens as their meditation. One could even take up as simple an activity as cooking for this. Though, I say simple as if it's easy. We have one, Sister Ozami, who is an astounding chef. Some of her dishes...well, they're the reason I've put on a few pounds lately." She patted her belly.

A few? Well, Coatzintli reasoned, maybe the cook wasn't the only reason. Mojit nodded solemnly. "It sounds very peaceful. I should perhaps visit your monastery in the future. Our scholars engage in several meditation strategies to gain enlightenment."

"Mojit, you still haven't told me the reason for your visit," Coatzintli said.

He sighed. "Well, we've been seeking more of a guarantee of our safety around here. The jungles are quite treacherous, and so many of us have been using paths through the catacombs to the west to get to the cities, but lately so many of them have disappeared. We would like a promise of our safety traveling through here."

Coatzintli thought for a moment, but eventually said, "We've always been on good terms, Mojit. My people would never do you harm. Unfortunately, I cannot say the same for the Rakshasa, though. Perhaps we can arrange some sort of service to escort you and your people through the jungles? My warriors are used to those cats and could help take care of them for you."

"Perhaps," Mojit said, closing his eyes. "I will need to think on it."

She knew that could take quite a while. Djinn were very contemplative and rarely made an instantaneous decision. "It has been quite an eventful evening," Coatzintli finished. "Perhaps I can give you both tours of the temples tomorrow. But for now, I think a good rest is in order."

She tried rising, but found that task to be quite difficult, as if something were weighing her down. Oh, gods! She looked down. Had her belly grown within the span of a few minutes. No, no, that couldn't be right. Yes, they were growing, but not that quickly. Oh! She looked at the massive spread of food on the table, or what had been the feast. Sure, the Kitsune woman ate quite a bit, but she had demolished quite a bit herself.

Patli seemed to figure it out and rose herself to show the two guests to the servants who would lead them to their rooms. She returned in a moment, a smug smile on her face. "What are you so happy about?" Coatzintli growled.

"Nothing, just proud of you," she said, touching her forehead affectionately. "Looks like I'm not going to have to worry about you eating enough."

"Oh, ha ha. You planned this somehow, I know you did."

Her wife chuckled. "I did nothing of the sort. Did I force you to eat all that? Last time I checked, you did that yourself. If you're not doing it on your own, then the little ones certainly are. I told you before, they're hungry, and need plenty. It seems your own appetite got the best of you. Up you go."

Patli slowly helped her up, placing a hand on her back as they went back to their own chambers. Coatzintli cursed her own appetite. This wasn't going to be easy.
