1411.content:
Sunlight drifted into the open windows of the temple, forcing Lalsini awake for yet another day of being the high priestess to Yva. She lay there for just a few more blissful minutes, letting the sun warm her massive body. Many would have thought that the luxurious and pampered lifestyle of the high priestess must get boring after so many years, and indeed there were times where it was for Lalsini, but all in all, it was worth it.

She rolled over and let her hand drift over the edge of her bed to scratch the head of her beloved Ajax. The handsome black leopard yawned sleepily and arched his back as his mistress continued to scratch. "Mm, good morning, my love," she yawned sleepily.

He rubbed his head tenderly on the edge of her belly, which was spilling over the side of her bed. It felt warm and tickled a bit. He was always so affectionate.

Presently, Valendra, her eldest daughter came in to greet her with breakfast, or rather the feast that constituted as breakfast, for her. Lalsini had sixteen daughters to be exact, and her eldest three already had children of their own. Of course, she had had a few sons here or there, and three of them had been paired off well with only the best women in the village. Yes, Yva had blessed her with an incredible brood, though she was still young; there was time to have perhaps a couple more. She had proved a very fertile priestess over the years, easily able to conceive twins and once triplets. A few more little feet running around would be nice.

Looking at the grand spread before her, there was no doubt that the Dew-Drop Forest had indeed been blessed by the goddess. Biting into one of the succulent fruits offered to her, Lalsini relished her job as being the physical embodiment of the wealth of the land and her people. Certainly, she was that physical embodiment. She was a large, rotund woman, most of the weight settling in her round, doughy belly. Twenty-some children and eating like a queen every day will do that to a person. That however, had not excused the rest of her body. A good portion of her weight laid in her enormous breasts, and she was not unaware of the thickening of her thighs. She found her double chin simply beautiful. Truly, she was the physical form of excess and fertility, her people expected her to be.

"Oh, Valendra, you should join me," Lalsini said, remembering her manners. "I couldn't possibly eat all this by myself."

As her eldest, and as all her daughters lived with her and were treated just as well in the temple, Valendra was by no means small. Though, she was half her mother's age, more or less, meaning she was only half her size. She was a rather plump young woman, though now bordering on fat, and her mother just adored her beautiful round face. "I think you could," she said coyly to her mother, "but it does look good."

"That's the spirit," her mother said as Valendra joined her. "Where's Diomedes?"

She was referring to the lion companion who was never far from her daughter. He was a suitable mate, when she selected him for her eldest; powerful, protective, and not to bad on the eyes either. "He's watching the kids," she replied, scratching behind Ajax's ear. The leopard purred.

The sun was well past up when she finally finished eating, and Lalsini sat back to rub her full stomach. Ajax only too eagerly rushed to kneed her belly with his large paws. "Oh, you are so good to me," she purred. She fingered the jade charm on her necklace which contained Ajax's human spirit. She was really tempted to have a little early morning delights with him.

Much as she loved this moment, it did not excuse her from the rest of her duties as high priestess. After a few minutes to let herself digest, she rolled back and forth a bit to get the momentum to stand and waddle to her main chambers where she held audiences with the villagers. Some of her fellow women would come to voice minor complaints, or she would hear from their fairy messengers. As always, she would be expected to ask Yva for her advice on such matters and come back with answers the next day.

Along the way, she greeted a few of her other daughters who were enjoying the pleasures of the temple. It was so wonderful to see how happy they all were here. Huffing and puffing, she finally made it to the soft, velvety couch where she entertained those who came to voice their concerns. As always, some refreshments had been set out for her to snack on throughout the day; today it was a mix of nuts, wild berries, and fresh honey to dip them in. She settled in, Ajax resting at her feet, ready to take on just another day. Her first visitor was...
1411.title: Lalsini

choices: Excited. Valendra must begin training to be the priestess immediately.
Angry. She's not willing to give up her place that easily.
Frightened. Something still doesn't feel right about this.
Actually, she doesn't have time to think. A new pressing matter comes up.
14112.content:
A small, glowing, green figure hovered into her chambers. It bobbed and weaved about the room before alighting on Lalsini's hand. She was used to such visits. Many women hardly saw her in person. Rather, they sent their fairy messengers to relay information to each other. The fairies were a special gift from the gods, the druids believed. They spoke the language of the gods, and could only mimic human speech. They therefore served as wonderful companions for delivering important messages.

Lalsini recognized this one in particular. This adorable little, green fairy belonged to Mapelis, one of her closest friends. While sweet and kind, Mapelis was a bit of a glutton. Lalsini chuckled to herself, knowing this was probably another request for her to have lunch with the high priestess. That woman would do anything for the delicious temple food.

But that was not the message she received at all. "My lady," the fairy said, repeating her master's message, "a miraculous sign has appeared! The central fire has been lit!"

This was...unexpected. The great fire pit in the center of their village only became alight when the goddess Yva had something very important to say. That wasn't necessarily a bad thing always. But, usually Lalsini could always sense when such important matters were approaching before it came to this. She was completely blindsided by this turn of events. What could be so important that even the great goddess would not give her some inkling that something might be happening?

The high priestess was now very curious, and she hefted her bulk up from her couch with quite a bit of effort. She needed to see this for herself. She called for a litter at once, as she was at such a size that she could no longer walk great distances without assistance.

Her party arrived at the center of the village shortly. Lalsini saw that already many women had gathered from the village to observe this strange phenomenon. It wasn't completely unheard of, but these instances were rare. Several of her own daughters had come with her to see it, many of them being too young to have remembered the last time this had happened.

She stepped down from her litter tentatively and approached the roaring flame in the stone fire pit before her. The yellow-orange flames danced in the sun. Mapelis approached her. "Good, I see that you got my message," the rotund, dark-skinned woman said. "I hope I wasn't disturbing you."

Lalsini waved her off. "This is a matter that takes precedence over any other business I may have."

"So then, you know what this means?"

The priestess shook her head. "I'm afraid not," she said. "For once, Yva has not given me warning about this message. I shall have to meditate on it. Surely, this is an important sign, and I will need to stay vigilant."

The woman bowed. "I shall have all preparations made."

They had set up a small tent in front of the pit where Lalsini could sit and try to commune with the goddess. She never liked to brag, but one of the few things she could do well was establish a connection with nature to hear the will of Yva fairly quickly. She hoped this would not be a long ordeal. She had heard that priestesses in the past could sometimes go into trances for days.

She planted her ample rear down upon the cushioned pillows provided to her in the tent. A priestess always comes prepared, she knew. Lalsini took a few deep breaths and let her mind drift into nature.

However, all was not quiet. Murmurs and whispers were coming up among the villagers as they wondered in awe at this event. But, it was the next sounds she heard that troubled her.

"Oooh, pretty!"

"Adina, no!"

Lalsini opened one eye. Her six year-old daughter, Adina had begun to wander too close to the fire, and Valendra had gone after her. Just as the older sibling pulled her sister away from the fire, a stray flame licked Valendra's hand. Despite her immense size, Lalsini was up in an instant and went to tend to her.

"Valendra, are you okay?" she asked.

"Yes, mother, I'm fine. I was just trying to..."

"By the gods!"

Valendra looked at her hand after her mother gasped. Unbelievably, where her hand should have been burned, or at least singed just a little, there was nothing. It was as if the flames had not touched her at all. Even stranger, mere seconds later, the fire in the pit dwindled down to nothing more but a few embers. Even more whispers emerged.

"I...I...I'm sorry," she said, tears forming in her eyes. "I didn't mean to ruin anything."

Lalsini said nothing, still unsure about what all of this meant. It was Mapleis who spoke. "It's a sign from Yva. She...she's marked you somehow. You are untouched by fire. Lalsini, surely this is your sign. Surely you know this means that Yva intends for your own daughter to be the next high priestess."

A cry of approval and merriment rose from the crowd. Lalsini's brow still furrowed in confusion. Valendra looked frightened.

* * *


"Are we sure that's what it means?" Lalsini asked to Ajax that night.

The lithe feline had been transformed back into a human. Lalsini did this frequently to spend the night with his company. He was tall and handsome, sure, with his dark hair and skin, and those gorgeous orange eyes, the same ones he had as a feline. But most importantly, he was a good listener, and sounding board when she was ever troubled.

He curled himself around her, wrapping an arm over her pillowy waist. "Such things have been known to happen," he said. "You yourself were born under an eclipse. The goddess works in mysterious ways."

"But, that's not normal, is it? The position of high priestess has never been something hereditary before."

He nodded. "No, but it goes to someone who has the utmost respect and reverence for Yva. You've raised Valendra to be such. It does not surprise me in the least."

Lalsini bit her lip. "I just don't know. Something feels off about all of this."

He nuzzled her side. "If you feel so worried about this, then reach out to Yva yourself. You always say to ask her whenever you're troubled."

Eventually, she nodded off to sleep, her mind plagued with a whirlwind of thoughts about today. She hoped the goddess would bless her with an answer while she slept.

By the next day, the high priestess felt...

1421.content:
This was not at all how this trip was supposed to go, Ketis thought as she was roughly tossed into what appeared to be a prison of sorts carved into the cavernous hole she had been swept up into. To many, such logical and rational thoughts during a time of distress such as this would seem strange. To Ketis, this was natural, and in some ways, distanced herself from the danger she was really in. Her captor had hardly said a word, and worse still, she had no idea what her captor looked like. It had all been such a blur. One minute she was checking her map, and the next, some sharp claws had snatched her up and carried her into the darkness before she could utter a scream.

Her eyes were still adjusting to the darkness as she scanned her surroundings. She had been traveling through the canyons on her way to Adinah. She had heard of a rare scroll she wanted to get her hands on, and the canyons seemed like the most logical route to take. It was much shorter and less dangerous than the jungles, she had thought. From what she could guess, looking around, she was still somewhere in the canyons, just within the walls of them. Ketis had seen several little holes pocketed along the high rock walls. She wondered what they were for. She supposed now, she would find out.

Ketis heard something shift in the darkness, and she pulled herself back as far in the cage as she could to avoid whatever it was. She tried to calm herself with rational thoughts. If her captor had intended to kill her, they would've done it already. They would not keep her prisoner. Again she heard more scuttling, but with the added screech of claws scrapping against the stone walls and ground. She almost screamed when she saw two pale faces peek in at her.

They were humanoid in appearance, with feminine features, so she assumed them to be female. One was significantly older than the other, and she assumed from their traits that they were related. Perhaps a mother and daughter, or two sisters, she reasoned. Their faces were pale and angular. She could just barely make out claws on their fingers and she thought she saw a hint of scales below their waists. Their black hair was strewn about their faces, and their beady eyes never stopped looking at her.

"She'll do," the older one said. "You are getting lazy in your hunting."

The other one groaned. "It's fine," she said. "Look, she's already a little-"

"A little," the older one said in a mocking tone. "The key word is 'little.' Do you see how much work it's going to take? We'll be wasting away before she's ready."

The younger one huffed. "Well, if she won't do, then why don't you go out and hunt? You've got legs, and you seem to be such an expert."

Her eyes narrowed. "Next time, maybe I will, and I won't share with you. You, come here."

The command was directed at Ketis. It seemed their argument had not distracted them enough from their prisoner. Shivering slightly, Ketis crawled over to where the older creature was waiting. "W-what are you?" she stammered.

"Shut up!" the creature screeched, and proceeded to grab Ketis through the stalagmites forming her cage and yanked her closer.

She proceeded to inspect every inch of Ketis with her sharp claws. She felt her arms, pulled her closer to examine her face, and definitely took her sweet time pinching her rather soft sides. Ketis felt very uneasy even after the creature released her. "Like I said, she'll do," she scoffed to the other. "She's your catch. You take care of her. Just see how long it takes. And you call yourself a lamia."

"Lamia," so that's what they were, Ketis realized. She had only heard of them from a few scant writings here or there, but no one had ever seen them or their culture up close. Probably because no one lived to. If she remembered right, they drank the blood of their victims, but that was all anyone really knew. So what did they mean about getting her "ready?" Surely by now they would have drained her and left her body to rot without a care.

The younger one returned shortly, opening the one door to the cell, made out of a large stone that had to be rolled away. She slid a large wooden bowl in the cage. Ketis pulled it towards her and sniffed. It was some sort of grainy mixture, but it seemed edible. The lamia had shuffled away before she could ask any other questions. Reluctantly, she took a bite of the mealy substance. Again, it did not seem poisonous, so she ate a little bit more of it. It soon became apparent that this stuff was rather filling, and they had given her much more than she actually needed.

Wait, that was it! Of course, why hadn't she put it together before. Yes, they drank the blood of their victims, but why just keep hunting? The bigger the prey, the more blood they had. It was so simple. Capture unsuspecting travelers, fatten them up until they were "feast ready," and then they ate their victims.

Ketis paused for a moment to think this over. There was no way she was going to be able to avoid eating while she was here. Likely, the lamia would be checking up on her to make sure she ate her rations, and she hated to think what would happen if she didn't. There was no immediate escape either. Then again, these lamia did not seem like the brightest of creatures. She wondered. Maybe she could find a way to outsmart them and then escape. Yes, that was it. She'd have to observe them more to figure out their weaknesses.

But why rush? This was a rare and unusual opportunity. She was going to see and be a part of lamia culture. She could document it all. The lamia had still left her with her bag of scrolls, ink, and quill. She would be the first to document how the lamia lived. All she had to do was stall for time. Again, these creatures weren't all that smart. She could make that work to her favor.

Stomach full and hard as a rock as she barely managed to polish off her first meal among the lamia, Ketis realized this wasn't at all how she planned this trip, but she would make the most of it. Maybe she could even fool them into giving her something better to eat than that mealy stuff. Hm, the possibilities.

14213.content:
Ketis was making it one day at a time. For the most part, she wasn't afraid of her captors and let her fascination with their culture and behaviors be her coping mechanism to deal with this situation. That being said, she wasn't stupid either.

Every day was practically the same. One of the two lamina would throw her a bowl with the grainy mixture roughly three, sometimes four times a day. Ketis also took notice that they seemed to give her a little more each day, hoping she would start to pack on pounds faster. The djinn scholar figured out how to play this right. For the most part, they left her unsupervised when she ate. She would eat perhaps half of the mixture, and would hide the rest under rocks, or once she dug a small hole in the ground to hide the extra rations. After enough observations, she discovered what the mixture was made of. It was some kind of meal made from grounding up the various mushrooms and fungi found in these caverns. A few other things were added, but it was mostly the fungi. It didn't taste bad, but it sure wasn't tempting either.

Yet, that didn't change the fact that the food was addictive. It had to be something in the mushrooms themselves that caused this, Ketis reasoned. Every day, after finishing her meals, she longed for the mixture thrice more, despite how bad it tasted. For now, she was able to fight these urges, but there were some nights where she would eat a little of the extra rations she stowed away.

And it certainly did what it was expected to do. The mealy substance added weight to her frame rather quickly, even if she wasn't eating her full rations. She was getting wider and softer with each passing day. Every day, the lamina would demand that she stand close enough for them to inspect her. They pinched, prodded, and poked every bit of her, always finding that she was getting plumper, but thankfully, not fast enough to their liking.

At first, Ketis feared that they might decide that she wasn't worth the time and drain her right there, but something else changed all that.

The djinn was used to the quiet in her cell. Her captors rarely talked to her, and when they did, it was taunting her with how fat she was becoming as they inspected her. Any other noises she heard from the two usually came when they were bickering at each other. Today was much different. Ketis awoke that morning to the sounds of thumps, bumps, and lots of screaming. She bolted upright to see the two lamina dragging some human girl into another stone cell.

She was a rather pretty girl, blonde hair that fell into delightful curls, blue eyes that looked like ice. She was dressed rather richly as well, and Ketis figured she was some noble from the city. However, it was unmistakably clear that the girl was rather fat, her plump, round gut bobbing and wobbling with each forced step she took as the lamina dragged her in. She had rosy round cheeks with plushy little arms and legs. Not a bit of her was thin. She wouldn't last long here, Ketis thought, feeling sorry for her.

"Do you know who I am?" the girl roared. "I am Maurlie Elbrey, daughter of Lord Elbrey, and when he hears what you did to my traveling party, you'll pay dearly! Do you hear me?"

Then again, maybe Ketis didn't feel so sorry for her. She seemed like a spoiled brat. At the same time, she couldn't contain her excitement. She was about to witness how Lamina fattened their victims, without her being the victim that is. She was ready to take notes.

The two creatures finally shoved the girl into the cell, where she fell face first and rolled about the dirty ground. "Oh, I'm going to make you wish you were never born!" she cursed. "How dare you treat a lord's daughter this way? I demand to speak to whoever is in charge!"

The sisters paid very little attention to her and talked as if she weren't there. "Now see," said the older one, "that is how you catch prey that's actually worth the time. Your skinny little catch isn't anywhere close to this one's size."

The other rolled her eyes. "Whatever. Look, you've got one, I've got one. We take care of our own in our own way."

"Suits me just fine, but take good notes, dear sister; I've been doing it right for years. Now, go get me a bowl."

The younger one was still much too submissive in front of her sister to argue, and scampered away to grab a large bowl of the meal. They slid it over to their new prisoner. "What in all the gods' names is that?" she said with a look of pure disgust.

"It's food, and you're going to eat it," the elder lamina hissed. "Or so help you if you don't."

The spoiled noble began to throw a fit. "I will do no such thing. You can't order me around, and I'm not eating this slop! How dare you serve this to someone of my stature?"

The older lamina shuffled over to the other side of the cage and yanked the girl over by one of her plump arms. She squealed in terror. "You'll eat it, my dear, and like it, or else."

The girl kicked the bowl and its contents splattered all over the cell, and some of it onto the face of her captor. "No!" she said again. "If you're going to feed me, you are to bring me food fit for my stature. Now, away with you."

142131.content:
From Ketis point of view the human girl must have been one of the bravest or foolish people in all of Yndyre. Not only she had just dissed and insulted a being that was more than capable than sucking her blood dry, she just did it in a closed cage with nowhere to scape to.

It was both figuratively and literally like teasing a giant cobra once you are inside its pit. She had to give it to Maurlie, she stood her ground like a proud royal, but maybe her father should have used some of his money to teach her how to behave on a hostage situation.

“This is about to get Interesting” – Ketis said to herself, muffling her own voice to not call the attention of the Lamia.
The Lamia slowly rose, losing her hunched posture, becoming taller and far more threatening, took a quick breath and launched herself over the girl making a hissing sound which echoed through the darkness of the cave.

“Oh sorry, what was what you said?” – Said the Lamia over the girl’s body as her serpentine arms lift and wrapped around the chubby figure of Maurlie.

“Me, I…”

The human girl struggled trying to release herself from the lamia’s tight hug, but judging by the way her body contorted on the pressure it seemed that not even the strongest human in all of Yndyre would have it easy to scape, so the chances of a rich noble girl who never had to lift anything heavier than a fancy purse were practically nonexistent.

Ketis knew that it was a morbid spectacle, that may end up with some blood, well lots of it, splattered around, but her scientific intrigue was pushing her to see it in first row and take note of all of the details. If she was going to die anyway, at least she would take a chance to learn from the experience!

“I remember you said that my food is not good enough for you?” - Inquired the lamia. - “Do you have an idea of how hard is for us to fetch all those mushrooms? to cook’em at the right temperature? And season them with the right herbs?”

Maurlie did not answer, most likely because she was barely capable to breath under the Lamias embrace, let alone speak.

“So, I apologize my ~lady~ you are going to eat them one way or the other, you hear!”

In that moment the Lamia stared directly into Maurlie’s eyes and began doing what Ketis would only assume was some type of hypnotic enchantment as her eyes glow yellow, red, and orange in different patterns.

For Ketis It was incredibly fascinating, terrifying and utterly horrific, but fascinating nonetheless. She had seen similar behaviors back into the desert, where cobras and other reptilians would lure their prey with their eyes down into their lairs to devour them more comfortably, no surprise Lamias could do it too! She wondered if Nagas could do the same, although if it was just like that she found weird that they had not used on her.

...Yet

Maybe it was extremely exhausting to perform so they only used it when absolutely necessary or when confronted with a less than cooperative prey, as it was the case. So she kept a close look upon the macabre spectacle. One for her research, two to aid the poor girl after its done and three find a way to avoid it ever happening to her.

The lamia stared into the girl for what appeared to be a few minutes, after which she just relaxed her body and left the human fell into the humid floor of the cavern, after which she just walked away from the cell, noticeably fatigued, as she needed to be supported by her partner.

“That will show her” –Said the serpentine woman – “And for you, girl, you better behave if you don’t want to face a similar fate”- Remarked at Ketis, who still was lying in the back of the cavern cell.

Both Lamias left the small cavern, introducing themselves into the pitch black darkness from the rest of the caves, leaving Ketis and the unconscious Maurlie alone inside the cell, not before leaving another rounds of mushroom mush.

The Djinn did not lose a moment and immediately went to attend the human girl.

Upon reaching the chubby woman she could immediately notice the level of violence the Lamias were capable to exert by just rolling themselves on their victim; Maurlie’s skin was all red with bruises along the areas the reptilian woman had co
ntorted on her body, and her face was pale with a faint bluish tone, probably due asphyxia, no surprise she had fainted, the girl probably couldn’t even breathe.

Ketis was ready to lay the girl down in her lap to check her other vital signs when suddenly and without a warning Maurlie just…woke.

In a swift move Maurlie, who a few moments ago had just been knocked out unconscious, straight opened her eyes and stood up, cleaned her dress and started to pick up the leftovers of the plate she discarded and place it along the others.

Then, to add to Ketis surprise, Maurlie sat and started to eat the mush. Not even showing a slight hint of disgust or the repulsion she had previously exposed, no, all the contraire she slowly downed every bowl with gusto.

For Ketis this was obviously result of the hypnotic stare of the Lamia, if not she could not explain the sudden change of the human girl and her utterly lack of concern about the situation.

Meanwhile, Maurlie…

She could explore the outside world, and maybe go look for why the Catacombs were loosing its merchants.

1432.content:
The Caverns of Sarkos has always been an uninviting place. A labyrinthine inner structure that guarantees all outsiders are doomed to be lost forever. The unstable sharp pillars of rocks that hang in the ceiling of the caves, looking ready to fall down on any unsuspecting traveler at a moment's notice. The dry feel of the rocky terrain, further accentuating how barren of liveliness this accursed region is. The rows upon rows of previous wandering souls, all frozen in stone, faces deformed by fear and terror, lined up rather neatly around every corner of the caves.

Combine all that with this being the den of the Gorgons, and anyone in their right mind would correctly label the Caverns of Sarkos a literal Hell on Earth. Perhaps not the entire fiery pit, but definitely one of its many levels of suffering.

One such statue-that-was-once-a-breathing-human nearly topples to the ground by the passing force of a hurried body.

"Oh no...!" the figure, cloaked in a body-covering hood that was once an opulent red curtain, hisses in alarm and reaches to steady the lifeless statue.

She manages to save the lifeless exhibit from crumbling to pieces on the ground, more so to prevent any noise of giving away her presence. She sighs in relief, the immediate danger over. Her mind is now free to study the frozen corpse before her.

"Oh, what did they do to you..."

It's a young woman. Human. Dressed in the familiar sleeveless blouse and skirt of those from Roiling Bay way down at the South. How someone from that fishing village found themselves way up here is anyone's guess. It doesn't change how such a young and pretty soul didn't deserve having her life cut abruptly.

"May Damus guide you to rest," she stretches her sharp-nailed, scaly arms forward, caressing the statue's fearful, tear-streaked face, leaning close to plant a kiss on the forehead.

Respectful rites delivered, she turns around quickly, continuing down the labyrinth in hurry. Her feet strike against the stone surface, careful to not kick any loose rocks or pebbles as she makes her way beyond, out to where freedom awaits. She passes more and more of the petrified victims, but she doesn't stop. She's careful not to knock them over, but she continues on as though in a race against time. And really, she is; she has until dawn to make it out. The sun rises, and as does all life back at the temple. The priests and guards realize she's gone, and there will be search parties out to get her, only giving up once it becomes clear she is no longer in the region.

The thought of that makes her pick up the pace. Slowly her hurried walk turns into a short jog. She must be out of the region by daylight. She must get away now.

Her mind drifts back into what has led her on this path. The life of the Priestess of Sarkos is by all means a grand one. Carrying the honor of representing the will of the gods, having everyone look to you as the beacon of wisdom and guidance, and, most enticing of all, have all your needs and wants satisfied, never in short supply of the most succulent of meats, the finest drink, and the utmost reverence from your peers.

All at the sacrifice of personal freedom. For your service to the gods, you must never set foot outside the world of mortals, for you now belong to the gods. For your stance as fountain of wisdom and guidance, you must sever all ties to family and loved ones, for you no longer walk among them. For your ascent to the highest stance, you must never move for yourself, for the people are now your extended limbs and it is sin to strain your divine-worthy body.

The life all Gorgon maidens are raised to aspire towards. Locked inside a gilded cage, safe and sober, yet sapped of all worldly connection.

To young Medea, that was no way of life. Her family wanted her to have that life, not her. Her society forced her to take up the mantle, with her having no say in the matter. Once, Medea had thought to entertain them, to let her be made Priestess and give them what they want. And yet, the more she thought about, the more she realized there would be no turning back.

Brimming with determination, she keeps at her hurried pace, navigating the labyrinth with the ease curious travelers and trespassers wished they had.

Her cloak billows suddenly, a gentle but firm breeze suddenly hitting her. Looking forward, she can see the outline of the cave's entrance, providing a great view of the night sky.

She has made it out at last.

Medea outright dashes, momentarily overcome with exhilaration as she has finally made it to her destination. She runs, her triple-toed, scaly feet kicking away at the rocky terrain. She runs, her lips curling into a bittersweet smile as she is filled to the brim with excitement and sadness. Once she's at a reasonable distance, she comes to a halt and turns around, her hands shooting up to lower her makeshift hood.

For the first time since she was very young, when she would go out recklessly and explore, Medea looks upon the entrance to her beloved home from the outside. She can understand why travelers would wander in. To any outsider, the cavern entrance is nothing short of awe-inspiring. A gigantic formation of rock, protruding from the ground in the shape of a windpipe, with four distinct jagged pillars, two hanging from the ceiling, two more on the ground, creating the impression of a snake's fangs. The real marvel, however, is how the jagged pillars are made of luminescent stone.

Medea looks upon the entrance to her home somberly, the snakes that make up her hair writhing in anxiety. For what must be the umpteenth time, she wonders what consequences her actions will entail. She runs away, and she'll no doubt be condemning another maiden to be made Priestess. She goes back, and she will be miserable for the rest of her life.

She takes a deep breath, and lets it out. She turns around.

"Farewell, all..." she whispers to the wind.

She covers her face with the hood once more.

And she walks anew, heading towards an unknowable destiny. It might be a mystery, but at least she has chosen it. Whatever comes, she is ready to accept it.

Question is...where to?

Her eyes gaze upon the massive landscape before her. Such an open world, and no clear destination in sight or in mind. Medea had forgotten how awfully big the world was.

But she must move. She can't linger anywhere near the Caverns of Sarkos, or anywhere in the West for that matter.

And so she steels herself. With renewed determination, she moves forward, heading in the direction of...
1432.title: Medea: A Priestess on the Run

choices: Medea eats & drinks, while trying to make the girls feel at ease.
Later, as Medea turns in for the night...
14321.content:
The wind blows strongly up in the North, especially in the middle of winter. There are plains of grass as far as the eye can see, and the roads are clear and straight. Nothing at all like the disjointed, desolate, rocky ranges of the West. Already there is a sharp contrast to what she is used to.

And Medea is loving it. Yes, the air is cooler, and it does feel odd to traverse a region that is nowhere near as rocky as back home, but such change exhilarates her. This must be what being on an adventure feels like!

Yet, if she had a map, she'd know she's still a long way from being in the inner part of the North. Definitely nowhere near close to, say, Racovania. But she knows she's gone in the right direction, and not just because of the colder climate and the winter snowfall. The legendary mountain range of Overvektige Peaks is visible even from where she is. Not close, and yet she can make out the distant silhouettes.

Of course, right now her first priorities are another matter.

Firstly, she's been traveling from West to North for...three days, she thinks. It's so easy to lose track of the flow of time. The sun and moon had gone down three times, right? But...the sun had gone down just now, so maybe she was on her fourth day? Ugh, her head was spinning.

Point being, she had been traveling on foot for only the gods know how long, and she was tired.

Secondly...actually, wait. Three...two...one--

*GRRRRRRRRWL*

Ah, right on time. The angry cries of her belly, demanding sustenance. It had been growling like so and hurting for a while now. She was starved.

Tired and hungry. Not a favorable combination. Worse, there was no sign of civilization anywhere. No village in sight--

Lights. Out of the corner of her eye. Curious, she looks to the side, and lo, as though the gods heard her plight, there lies a small settlement. Nothing extraordinarily big, but there are buildings. One of those must certainly be an inn!

"Oh, Zolneas be praised!" Medea beamed. "Her fire guides me to sanctuary!"

"Oy! Outta tha way, gobshite!"

Alarmed, the Gorgon clutches her hooded cloak to herself tightly, turning around in defense against the traveling merchant who'd rudely shouted at her. The twin horses pulling the merchant's cart whinny in discontent as their driver yanks the lead ropes to avoid trampling the idiot on the road.

"You wont to die?!" the portly man slurred. "Git outta tha road!"

Medea regarded the human, careful to keep her eyes hidden under her hood. "Oh, a thousand pardons, sir."

She made to step to the side, but winced as she put force on her foot upon taking a step. She experimented with her other foot, finding the results to be the same; her soles making contact with the earth resulted in a little pain. Looks like her feet had all but given up at the notion of more walking.

"Uh, excuse me?" Medea asked politely. "Sorry to be a bother, but are you, by chance, heading for that small town down the road?"

"Ah?" the merchant blinked before responding slowly. "Aye. Got a stop ta make. Lots o' goods to drop. Whatsit to ya?"

"Oh, well, if it's no trouble..." Medea crossed her arms behind her back and craned her upper body forward, unintentionally making her big breasts bounce. "May I ride on your cart? Our destinations are one and the same."

"Oy, oy, oy! Wot do I look like, da royal carriage?!" the human's face curled in disgust. "Ain't my problem wot sort of wench wanders too far off home! Now outta da road!"

Medea, surprised, took a step forward. "Sir? Have I...Have I offended you in some way?"

"Oy, bitch," the merchant growled. "I won't say it 'gain. Outta the--"

A particularly strong breeze came, blowing at Medea's cloak powerfully. She managed to keep her hood on her face, but the rest of her body was momentarily exposed.

The traveling merchant's eyes beheld the lime-green scales with black lines. For the first time, he took a good look at the woman.

And at once, he blanched.


***



"Thank you for the ride, kind sir!" Medea smiled, jumping from the cart.

The merchant gave a curt grunt, keeping his gaze forward.

"Safe travels!" Medea waved in farewell, heading in the direction of the inn, cheerfully ignoring how the man muttered some odd curse and something about never setting foot on this "cursed region" ever again.

Humans can be so funny.

Her stomach growled again. She rubbed a tender hand on its flat surface. And the pain in her feet shot up again.

She made for the inn.


***



"Another beer!"

"Coming right up!"

The tavern-inn was lively this evening. Patrons everywhere, ordering big while the beautiful barmaids went about with smiles. To complete the merry image, the band was playing a lively tune, with one of the barmaids singing a jolly shanty.

"Aye, Dani!" one of the many barmaids groused playfully. "Don't go getting all the attention!"

"Strike me for doing my job, Elsa!" Daniela snarked, swinging her broad hips mockingly in the direction of her co-worker as she served a fresh glass of beer to a customer.

"Ah, you two," Marta, one of the bustier barmaids, smiled.

From her place behind the bar, Adela the owner took a puff from her pipe, enjoying the sight of her business booming and her girls happily working.

Truly, nothing could destroy this merry image.

"Oh! New customer!" Frenda, a young blonde and one of the newer workers, announced. "Welcome to--"

Adela quirked a raven eyebrow at the young lady's greeting ending in a horrified whimper. What could have provoked such a response? She and everybody else looked.

The new arrival was intriguing on first sight, covered in what appeared to be a curtain of rich red fiber that had seen better days. It was draped over the figure like a cloak, a makeshift hood sewed on it. The individual's eyes were hidden by the shadows of the hood, and the cloak did a great job covering her up.

Except for her arms and legs. Her limbs, bare and covered in lime-colored scales with black lines. But her feet. Three toes splayed out, tipped by a black talon, and a fourth toe dangling by the ankle.

And that long, reptilian tail trailing and wiggling behind her...

The realization struck everyone in the room like thunder.

Medea, for her part, kept calm under all the stunned stares and made her way to the center of the bar. "Uh, yes, excuse me? May I speak with the owner?"

Adela recovered quickly from the shock. She'd seen a lot in her travels before she settled down as an inn owner. A Gorgon suddenly showing up was unexpected, but not unwelcome. "Ah, that would be me. How may I help you?"

Medea smiled and bowed her head forward in respect. Hopefully that little gesture would put all the other humans at ease. "I request a room for the night. How much--"

"Oh, no need," Adela waved her pipe dismissively. "Plenty of income has come in tonight, and far be it for me to charge the first Gorgon to ever set foot in my inn."

Medea bowed gratefully. "You are most generous, Miss...?"

"Adela," the slender woman smiled. "Anything else I may provide you with besides a room?"

At that, the snake woman's stomach protested loudly for all to hear.

Medea blushed. "Some food and drink would be good, too."

Adela chuckled. "Have a seat. One of my girls will see to it." She dutifully ignored the looks of abject horror and betrayal she received from said barmaids.

Medea simply smiled, sitting down at the closest table, causing every other patron to either scoot away or to outright leave.

"What's keeping you girls?" Adela drawled, eyeing the fidgeting huddle that was her workers.

"D-D-D-Do we ha-ha-have to?!" Elsa whimpered.

Adela brought down her pipe, and at once her youthful features looked narrower. "Fine then, I'll make this simple."

The barmaids breathed a sigh of relief.

"Frenda, tend to her."

"Why?!" the blonde wailed as the other girls edged away from her as though she was cursed.

"You didn't finish your greeting," Adela shrugged. "Now get to it. We don't make customers wait."

Medea smiled warmly. "Nice to meet you!"

She received a startled yelp in response. Medea sighed inwardly.

Her travels were going to be interesting.
14321.title: North-By-West Gorgon

choices: to leave! You don't have to go home, but you can't stay here.
to go up to your room. Don't come down until I say it's okay.
to go sit in that corner. The less we see of you, the better.
143211.content:
The young barmaid, Frenda, said hardly a word to Medea as she took her order. Her eyes fixated on the gorgon's scaly tail. Medea tried to put her at ease. "Oh, you like it?" she joked, wriggling her tail. "I promise, it won't bite."

Frenda squealed and retreated back to the kitchens. Medea shrugged and sighed, hoping things would get better.

Back home, she had been considered quite beautiful, even as a child. She could remember friends and neighbors telling her parents what an adorable child she was. And as a young maiden, she had been known to get a few sweet honey treats from some of the men who were too shy to speak to her. Of course, the favorites among the potential candidates for future priestess were always beautiful, she remembered. A priestess was supposed to be perfect, unblemished, a treat for the eyes of the gods. She hated that she was pretty for that reason.

Still, this was no time to be thinking about home. She had made her decision and there was no turning back. Even if she did come back, she'd be more than just shunned by her people. Who knows what they would decide would be her punishment for running away from such an important position.

When Frenda came with her food, she slid the plates over to the gorgon gently, trying to keep her distance, as if the creature would swallow her whole then and there. Medea politely said thank you, and decided to keep it like that. One step at a time, she thought. If she could show them how kind she could be, maybe they would understand.

The roaring of her stomach disrupted her thoughts and she knew food was the top priority now. She didn't realize that humans had such a variety of foods. Gorgons weren't really farmers, as there wasn't much in the way of rich soil and sunlight in the caverns. Meat was whatever was dumb enough to wander too deep in the caves. Mostly, they kept to a diet of whatever naturally growing plants there were in the caves and a few smaller creatures they could trap. Honey combs were kept in the caves, but only as the occasional treat.

What lay before her was much more than that. Fresh, steaming bread, something she had never seen before, and a thick stew made with a heavy and greasy meat of some kind with root vegetables. Gods be praised, why hadn't her people heard of such bounty? She dug in with gusto, devouring her food with relish. It tasted just as good as it looked, and before she knew it, she had ordered another bowl of stew.

She looked up and saw the barmaids and the other patrons looking at her fearfully. Oh, she must've looked a terrible sight eating impolitely like that. She wiped a bit of meat juice off her cheek and smiled, trying now to eat her food slower and savoring each bite. It was even better that way anyway, she reasoned.

The other barmaids gossiped among themselves about their new patron. "You think...you think she's a scout?" Frenda asked fretfully. "They're...they're planning to come and slaughter us aren't they?"

She started to wimper into Marta's generous chest. The bustier lass stroked her hair. "No, of course not," she soothed. "Still, what are those things doing on the surface? We left them, and they left us alone. That's how it's always been, always should be."

Elsa shuddered. "Do you see those feet? Ugh, they're so ugly."

Daniela was the only one with a spine in the bunch. "Yeah, well, beast or no beast, I'm making my tips tonight." She strode over to Medea with her fresh bowl of stew. "There you go, enjoy," she said with a smile.

Medea beamed back. "Oh, thank you!"

Dani wasn't sure what prompted her to do so. Perhaps she was just curious, or maybe she really did see the gorgon as friendly. "So, uh, what brings you here? I mean, don't get a lot of...whatever it is you are around here."

The gorgon seemed as though she were waiting for that question all night. "Oh! You really want to hear it. It's the awfullest thing. See, there's this temple, and..."

A door flew open as a weary traveler stumbled in the door. The wind blustered through the halls. He forced the door shut and turned about to the rest of the bar. "Cold as Damus' heart out there," he muttered. "Winds took a right mighty chill all of a sudden. Oi, innkeep, get me a..."

He stared distantly down the bar, mouth agape. He raised a hand, pointing a shaky finger across the way, right at Medea. The winds had blown her hood off and now everyone could see her exactly as she was. Much like the rest of her, her skin was a vibrant lime green, smooth and delicate. If she were a human, she would have been called quite beautiful, and many men would have fought for her hand. It was the golden yellow eyes that seemed to pierce through one's skin and the writhing mass of forest green snakes wriggling on her head that sent shivers down the spines of all the patrons.

Medea gasped, and whipped her hood back up, trying to conceal her tears. Even Dani, who she was so close to making a connection with had started to back away. As she looked around, she saw that all the patrons had scooted to the far corners of the bar, deliberately averting their gaze from her. She knew why. She had heard the rumors humans made up about them.

"No, wait," she tried to explain. "We don't turn people to stone...not on purpose...I mean, not unless..."

Adela marched up to her, her cheery demeanor now gone. "I've had enough of this nonsense," she shouted to the entire bar. Then she wheeled around on Medea. "You've caused enough trouble for one night. I want you...
143211.title: The Face of the Gorgon

choices: be one of the barmaids (as if!).
find something in town. I don't know. What am I, your babysitter?
work in the stables. It's about all you'll be good for.
1432112.content:
"You've caused enough trouble for one night. I want you to go up to your room and stay there until I say so," Adela barked. But, upon looking at Medea's downcast face, she softened a bit. "Look, it's nothing against you, but I can't have you scaring away my customers. Just...don't come down until business hours are done."

Medea wanted to speak, wanted to yell, scream, do something. How could they treat her like this? All she had done was be nice. And now, they wanted to treat her like some sort of ugly child that was to be hidden from the world. They wanted to treat her like...like a monster, she realized. Her parents had always warned her that humans couldn't be trusted, that they couldn't understand. She wanted to think they were wrong, that some humans were nice. But, she had been proven wrong.

Instead of saying anything, she ran up the stairs to the open bedroom, tears streaming down her face. She threw herself down upon the bed and sobbed into the pillows. How could they be so cruel?

She didn't know at what point her sobs led to a deep sleep, but she drifted off and only woke when the light started shining through her windows. Medea wanted to just lay there and continue to mope. Not more than a week being free from her oppressive environment among the gorgons, and she had proved she couldn't hack it on her own. She couldn't go home, though, so what was she to do?

Medea didn't get too long to dwell on these thoughts. One of the barmaids from last night was already in her room, opening the curtains and starting to straighten up. It was the braver one, Dani. None of the others would have probably wanted to come up here unless Adela bribed them, and even then, they probably would have found an excuse not to.

"Up and at it!" Dani called to the gorgon, starting to grab the sheets off the bed.

Medea growled. If it was a monster they wanted, it would be a monster they got. "Oh, is it safe now for me to show my face? I wouldn't have wanted to ruin your business," she mocked. "Last time I checked, it was my room. I don't have to do anything."

She didn't like being mean, but after the way they treated her last night, she felt they deserved it. Away from home and afraid she may be, but she wasn't about to roll over and be treated like some pest by these people.

Dani let out a snorting laugh. "Oh, really? You thought that was a permanent thing? Honey, please, Adela let you have the room for the night. She made enough that she was in good spirits. You want to keep the room, then you'd better start forking over some coin. Adela's only generous once in a decade."

Technically, Adela hadn't said that, but it was fairly well implied, Dani thought. Adela didn't just give stuff away for free. A combination of good business and a little too much to drink last night made her a little loose-lipped last night. But after all that had happened, Adela wasn't soon going to be making that mistake again.

Medea gasped. She hadn't thought about anything like that. Gorgons didn't exactly use currency. More or less, everything was traded and bartered, food necessities being the main commodity. But, in the brief time she had been out in the outside world, she became minutely aware of the currency exchange humans engaged in. But, how to obtain it?

The gorgon looked frantically about. "But, I don't have nay money. How am I supposed to...?"

"Get a job, duh," Dani scoffed. "Gods, what do you do, live under a rock?"

"Well..."

"Never mind. Point is, you have to earn your keep around these parts. Life ain't all smiles and sunshine like it is in Adinah. This is the north: life's tough, and you get used to it."

Maybe coming up here wasn't such a good idea, she thought. If she had known it was that bad, she might have reconsidered. More and more, this excursion was becoming less of an adventure and more of an ordeal.

Still, what could she do? She didn't exactly know what sort of jobs there were around here. She didn't really know what she could even do. Her whole life, she was raised to potentially be the high priestess. Plus, there was the matter of what she was. People would take one look at her, and that would be the end of a job. But her luck had to turn around at some point, right?

"What am I supposed to do?" she asked. "I've never had a job before. I don't even know what sorts of things I'd be good at."

Dani rolled her eyes. "Have to teach you everything. Maybe you could..."
1432112.title: Medea, the Outcast

choices: "It's time to show you the ropes." Training montage!
"It's time for breakfast." Can't start on an empty stomach!
14321121.content:
"Maybe you could take up a veil and work for us, if you like it so much here."

Daniela had meant it as a joke. A crude, mocking joke. This gorgon, working as a barmaid? Flay the thought! It was just impossible. Adela would never permit it unless she was looking to scare away customers and become a social pariah. And like any good tavern owner, she would not.

If she would, then Dani hoped to be struck down by Ardoid's arrow.

"Very well, then!" Medea stood up from the bed confidently, straightening her back and leaning her head back like a sophisticated lord would. "I'll see to Lady Adela about the job!"

"Maybe in your dreams!" Dani snorted, a cocky smirk spreading her lips. "But I'll indulge you. Let's go to her room and watch you get thrown out for all the town to see! Let me just go get the other girls...all staff must be present!" she added quickly upon receiving a dull glare from the snake woman.

"Fine then," Medea said slowly, tightening her cloak around her in a stiff manner before she marched out towards the door, her pace one of utmost confidence.

It was almost a shame, Daniela thought, that such admirable determination was about to be completely destroyed.


***


"You're hired."

Time seemingly came to a halt. Or rather, the entire room froze over as though suddenly perched on the highest point of the Overvektige Peaks. The assembled barmaids felt as such, with varying emotions of shock and horror to show it.

Save for Medea, whose smile was as bright as the morning sun as she beamed at the lean-but-curvy, raven-haired woman.

"Huggah...huggfuuu...honna...WHAT?!" Elsa managed, looking to be on the very verge of foaming at the mouth. "M-M-M-Ma'am, what in the gods' collective pantheon--?!"

"She works for us now," Adela reiterated coolly, earning horrified wails from her working girls.

Young blonde, waify Frenda looked as though she had been told she would be taken in her sleep. She fell back as though to faint, but instead fell onto Marta's generous chest, the brunette steadying the younger girl by the shoulders while looking between Adela and the gorgon in shock. Elsa outright fainted, her black hair spreading on the floor. Daniela...

Ardoid, strike me down.

"Oh thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you very much, Lady Adela!" Medea bowed gratefully. "I don't deserve such kindness!"

"You flatter me," Adela smiled and waved a dismissive hand, secretly enjoying the praise from such a feared being. Her inviting countenance shifted into one of business. "Think of it as payback. The free night is on me, but you owe me some revenue in light of the customers you scared away."

Medea frowned and opened her mouth.

"Unintentional or not. Life can be unkind," the raven-haired woman droned before the gorgon could speak out.

"With respect, Ma'am," Daniela cut in. "Wouldn't this be cancerous for profit? Patrons are terrified of her at first sight," she paused, registering the other trembling barmaids and her own (loathe she was to admit it) unease. "And us, too. Which would not be effective for work."

"It's not like I mean to scare you lot..." Medea grumbled under her breath.

Adela responded to the concerns by reaching for her pipe, igniting it, and taking a strong puff.

"For the customers, just cover Medea's head, scales, tail, and just about anything that gives away her true nature."

"So we mummify her?" Marta joked weakly, yelping as she earned a weary look from the gorgon.

"As for your concerns," here Adela released a cloud of smoke just as her patient countenance shifted into an annoyed scowl. "What are you, tavern ladies, or unweaned babies? Do I have to hold your hands through everything, hmm?! Whisper words of encouragement to go along with it?!"

All the young ladies present straightened up in alarm at the sudden shrill tone. For the barmaids, they were familiar with how Adela would get when coming down from a hangover or when one too many nonsense took place. They vividly remembered that time one particularly trigger-happy patron got mighty pissed and, in his stupor, tried to pick a fight with the passing Orc customer. Adela had kindly escorted the drunkard out. (Read: she'd dislocated the man's shoulder in her roughness and sent him flying face-first into the snow outside).

For Medea, combined with last night's startling display of anger at everyone, she'd come to the conclusion that no matter what, she should most definitely stay on the lady's good graces. The lashing out last night from her was shocking, but Medea agreed internally that at least it calmed the situation before mass hysteria broke out, even though she was still bitter about having to be sent to her room to balance the situation.

Now, with this job, she hoped to begin the first step of a long trek in fixing this ridiculous prejudice humans had towards her kind.

But back to reality, first.

"N-No, Ma'am/Lady Adela!" the girls chorused together.

"Good!" Adela barked before bringing her pipe to her lips for another puff.

And just like that, the anger was gone, replaced by her trademark cool demeanor. Medea couldn't help but stare in wonder; where humans like this, always flipping through emotions like a river, or was Adela just an individual case?

"In all seriousness," Adela intoned coldly. "Medea works here. Meaning she is one of you. And remember, any problems amongst yourselves...?"

"...we sort out between us." Medea looked on in awe as the barmaids chorused as one yet again. Such a level of discipline!

"Exactly," Adela nodded. "I'm confident you can all work together. For each other, for the inn, and for me."

"Yes, Ma'am/Lady Adela."

The raven-haired woman nodded in satisfaction, tapping her pipe twice on her desk.

They were dismissed.

Daniela motioned for Medea to follow them, but just as the gorgon went to follow...

"And Medea?" Adela called.

"Yes, Lady--"

"That," the inn owner cut off with a grimace. "No need to call me that. It's not like I'm royalty. Just 'Ma'am' or something along those lines is fine."

"As you wish, Lady Adela."

Daniela's palm met her forehead, and then she quickly reached to grab the gorgon by the shoulder and pull her out before Adela could so much as pop a blood vessel.

Once they were outside, there was a pregnant pause among them. No one dared break the ice as they processed this new development.

"So then..." Medea started with a tug of her hood to keep one of her snakes from coiling out into sight. "I'm one of you now."

"Don't remind us," Elsa muttered sourly, massaging her temple with one hand as she recovered from having passed out earlier.

"So what happens now...?" Marta looked to the older, more experienced Daniela.

"What do you mean?" the dark red-haired barmaid retorted. "We do as the Lady says. Time to chaperone the newbie."

"You are funny," Elsa scowled. "Good luck with that. I'm going to take a bath."

"Elsa," Daniela glowered, patience wearing thin.

The black-haired barmaid froze in her tracks before she let out a petulant, angry whine.

Satisfied, Daniela turned her attention to the quiet gorgon. "Okay, look, we don't like you, you don't like us--"

"Correction," Medea interrupted dryly. "You don't like me, for which I have done nothing, and I would like for us to like each other."

Daniela let out a string of incomprehensible curses under her breath before letting slip a coherent one so foul that Marta instinctively covered Frenda's ears.

"Fine! We will cross that bridge when we come across it! Just...just listen, alright? Here's how it works. You're new, you've no doubt never tended at a tavern or an inn before, and so we're going to show you how," here the dark ginger craned her head to the side, glaring at her co-workers. "All of us. Understand?"

To which she got glum nods.

She turned back to the gorgon. "Do you understand?"

"Yes," Medea gave an affirmative nod.

"Alright then. Proper introductions are due. I'm Daniela, I've worked here the longest."

She looked at her others and silently urged them to do the same.

"Elsa," the black-haired girl looked like she was fighting off a disgusted curl of the lips as she eyed the exposed bits of Medea's scaly flesh through her cloak.

"Marta, nice to meet you," despite her kind words, her eyes betrayed wariness.

"Fr-Fr-Frenda...I'm new, j-j-just like you now..." the youngest of the barmaids bowed low.

The runaway priestess gave each of them a nod with a polite smile. "I'm Medea. Let's get along, please."

"Perfect," Daniela waved a hand carelessly. "Now that we have that posh gig out of the way..."
14321121.title: The Gorgon Among Them

choices: The girls decide to take a much-needed breakfast break.
Suddenly, a customer comes in. Quick, hide Medea!
143211211.content:
"First, cooking!" Marta announced cheerily. "I'm usually the one in charge of this post, so I'll guide you. Now let's begin with something simple. Let's see....oh! Let's do a two-egg omelette!"

"Yes!" Medea answered readily before her enthusiasm shifted to curiosity. "Wait, what's an omelette? And...two eggs?"

"Observe!"

Marta was noticeably less frightful of the gorgon compared to earlier, perhaps a result of being on her favored station of head cook and the giddiness that came with teaching someone else the fine art of the culinary. It certainly helped that if Adela was okay with the gorgon, and Daniela was too (erm, more or less...), then who was she to object? She was still wary, yes, but Marta was always one to push for peace. Medea was one of them now, so no use striving for conflict. Not that she would ever do that, gods no. Certainly no one among them would.

Hopefully.

"So, you take the two eggs and--what are you doing?"

"Hm? Oh, sorry," Medea sheepishly lowered one of the eggs from where it had been held close to her mouth. "For a gorgon, eggs are quite the delicacy."

"You..." Elsa arched an eyebrow. "You eat them raw?" she spat the last word like it was complete sacrilege.

"What, you humans don't?" at the black-haired girl's feverish shake of the head, Medea shrugged. "Eh, different tastes."

"Well then, get ready to be amazed at the taste of cooked eggs!" Marta chimed in, her smile brimming with the eagerness to share in her passion for cooking. "So like I was saying, first we break the eggs--"

"Break them?" Medea blinked, and then shrugged. "Very well, then."

"Uh, no, wait, not like--!"

Too late, as Medea had already stacked the two eggs on her left palm, and then brought her right fist down upon them like a hammer.

"--that..." Marta finished, face stained with a mix of egg sauce and yoke. "Let's try that again..."

After a hefty amount of trial and error...

"Now keep your pan balanced. Tighten your grip, but not too tight! Okay, now watch what I do... See, like that! Now you do it!"

"Okay..." Medea took a breath. "Tight grip, but not too tight..."

"Aaaaaand..." Marta paused, looking intently at the sizzling omelette in Medea's frying pan.

A tiny pop rang out.

"Flip it!"

Medea did so, and if one were to ask her, she would insist that she flipped it as Marta had done. Yet somehow, the omelette flew right out of her pan and, with a sickening wet splat, hit the wooden ceiling.

"Aww..." Frenda whined, having looked on in awe and wonder at the gorgon's lesson, and thus disappointed that her hard effort ultimately ended in failure.

Medea threw her head back and groaned.

"Now, now, you'll get better!" Marta encouraged nicely. "Mistakes happen so you can improve. In the meantime, let's try steak now..."

Now that had started well enough. Medea followed instructions diligently, added the necessary implements in the right amounts, and had the meat cooking at a proper heat. But at the end...

"WHY IS IT ON FIRE?!" Daniela roared.

"SHE'S OUT TO KILL US!" Elsa shrieked.

"I just turned up the fire a little, it was taking too long!" Medea cried.

"WAH!" Marta and Frenda ran back into the kitchen with a bucket of water, dunking the fresh well water right on the burning pan.

The barmaids all breathed heavily, relief washing over their faces at the aversion of disaster.

"So..." Marta said kindly, yet shakily. "Practice makes perfect?"

Daniela face-palmed.


***



"Now, in this scenario, we're going to pretend you're serving," Elsa said in a stiff tone, sitting at a table. "I'll be the customer."

"Got it!" Medea answered with determination. "What can I get you--"

"Ah!" Elsa held up a finger. "You first say 'good morning', 'good afternoon', or 'good evening' as the situation calls for it. Always be polite. Asking outright for the customer to make a choice is being subtly rude."

"Oh," Medea blinked, absorbing the lesson. "You're right. I apologize. Ahem... Good morning, ma'am! What would you like?"

Elsa hummed, pleased. "Very good! But tone down the enthusiasm. Being eager is good, but too much eagerness can be mistaken for lunacy. Try to be a little subdued."

"Ah, alright. Ahem... Good morning, ma'am... How may I serve you today...?"

"Not that subdued! You sound like you're going to kill yourself!"

"Oh, sorry!"

The other barmaids couldn't help but look on with smiles. Despite what she would say, Elsa did in fact, in her own little way, start to warm up to their new unlikely barmaid.

Elsa sighed dramatically. "Let's just move on to serving the meal, shall we?"

And so they did.

"Why are the plates empty?"

"Because it's practice."

"Okay. Why am I carrying so many?" to her credit, Medea stayed calm even as she fought to keep four dishes balanced on her arms.

Elsa huffed. "Because part of being a barmaid is to serve fast and be as flexible as possible. We entertain as much as we serve."

Medea frowned. "You know, with my tail I could--"

"Absolutely not!" Elsa snapped. "Has it not sunk in yet that we can't casually show off a gorgon barmaid?"

"Well, the whole town is no doubt gossiping about me already..."

"No," Elsa waved a hand. "We tell them you left at the first instance of dawn. The rest, we'll work out. But enough of that. Step forward, and with grace! Imagine each of those dishes you're carrying is a succulent meal. Your job is to deliver each meal with precise grace."

"Grace, alright, I understand..." and Medea took steps forward, careful to keep her trembling arms as frozen still as possible. It was a tense moment, the barmaids looking on with great anxiety as their newest recruit waved through tables carefully. It was extremely worrisome how the plates tilted and looked ready to fall, but the gorgon did a good job. She was surprisingly nimble!

"This is...not so bad--" Medea started.

Thunk

"YEOUCH!" Medea howled as her toe came into contact with the leg of a table she'd stepped a little too close to. The others watched in abject horror as she fell to the floor, the dishes following after...

Medea snapped to attention. She swung her right leg, kicking upwards while keeping her toes outstretched. One plate landed neatly at their tips.

She spread her arms to the side, catching two with her palms.

She uncoiled her tail, letting it slink forward until its tip rose to the air and caught the final plate.

The other barmaids stared, dumbstruck.

"I-Incredible!" Frenda beamed, clapping eagerly while the others looked on in surprise and approval at the gorgon.

Medea smiled widely.

BAM!

"What's going on out here?!" Adela's voice thundered, scaring the daylights out of everyone.

And, tragically, causing Medea to lose her concentration.

The haunting sound of plates shattering on the floor echoed throughout.

Daniela face-palmed.


***



"Let's see how you do behind the bar," Daniela droned. "See that barrel over there? Hoist it up to the counter."

"Easy enough," Medea stated, bending down to grab at the large barrel.

She hoisted it up with little to no effort, only grunting when adjusting it over her shoulder. She walked to the designated area on the bar to where the barrel went for easy fillings. She put it down heavily, and yet carefully.

"Nothing to it," the gorgon grinned.

"Hurrah," Daniela deadpanned. "Now, just serve me a pint and you're all done."

"Ooh, and me too!" Marta chirped.

Daniela turned to the brunette. "No."

"Aww..."

"One pint of beer, coming right up!" Medea reached for a glass, placed it under the barrel, and turned the keg..,

...and nothing happened.

"What in..." Medea flipped the keg switch back and forth. Still nothing. "What the?!"

"Hold on!" Daniela realized what the problem was. "You forgot to take off the safety latch."

"Oh!" Medea nearly slapped her forehead. "Of course!" she went to remove the metal clamp around the hose.

And in her haste, she forgot she had left the keg open.

Meaning quite the amount of beer had accumulated at the tip of the release hatch, ready to set loose.

And so it did when Medea undid the metal clamp. A quick torrent of beer flew out of the metal hose connected to the barrel, drenching the gorgon and the nearby barmaids in the rich, bubbly liquid.

"Ugh!" Elsa snarled. "Now I really need that bath!"

"I got my beer after all!" Marta grinned.

Daniela face-palmed, this time both of her palms hitting her face as she groaned in miserable irritation.
143211211.title: Make a Barmaid (Sort of) Outta You!

choices: The new recipe is a disaster. What was Medea thinking?
The new recipe is a huge success, and the inn gets some good business.
Daniela trips over serving the food. No one will ever know what might have been.
1432112112.content:
They were about to sit down to a breakfast. Mornings in the inn were slow, and that was usually when the girls could get an actual sit-down meal in. Marta had gone to the trouble to fix an incredible spread. Eggs, sizzling bacon, fresh bread, milk and cream, and even a few berries that Frenda had found this morning were all set out on the table. Medea, though, still preferred her raw eggs, even if Marta was the best cook, much to the disgust of everyone else.

"Adela lets you make all this, just for yourselves?" she asked incredulously.

Elsa nodded. "Yup! If there's one thing Adela always stresses, it's that no barmaid should ever go hungry. Can't work on an empty stomach you know."

Medea shrugged, and decided to accept that answer as good enough. Sounded like a fair policy in her mind. She wondered if that was the reason humans were a tad plumper than she had initially imagined. Ever since meeting these creatures, she had noticed that many were a bit on the round side. But then, perhaps that was because this was truly a land of plenty, as she was beginning to see it. She had heard stories from the girls about the famous city of Adinah, which knew no hunger in any corner of its streets.

Yet, they had barely sat down for the meal when they all heard the door start to open. The boisterous sounds of rowdy men could be heard coming in.

"Shit!" Daniela shouted, rising quickly. "Quick, hide her in the kitchens or something."

Medea was in the middle of eating one of her eggs, and Marta made a disgusted face as she grimaced and dragged the gorgon into the kitchens with her. "Aww, but I wanted to see who it was," Medea said cheerfully.

"Yeah, well they probably don't want to see you," Marta hissed.

That stung the poor gorgon, and Marta softened a little. "I don't mean it like that. It's just going to take some getting used to is all. Besides, this is a good chance to get some more cooking practice in."

She beamed at the thought of that. "I get to cook again!"

The barmaid swatted her hand away before she could get to touching stuff. "You are to go no where near the oven or the skillet today. Just, hand me the stuff I need when I say I need it. Understand?"

Medea nodded, and sighed wistfully. She began handing the inn's top chef the ingredients she asked for, and fetching this and that. All the while, she could hear the goings on outside. Well, it was something anyway. Apparently, the rowdy group was a band of hunters, who were busy relaying their triumphant tales of their latest kill to Elsa and Frenda, who seemed to want to only flirt with the strapping young men, while Daniela did all the work.

"Horns wide as three men standing abreast," one said with great exaggeration. "Oh, and a surly look in that one's eye. They don't call him Ol' One Eye for nothin'."

"Oh, but you must have been so brave," Frenda swooned.

"Brave!" said another. "The little child here nearly wet himself at the sight of it. I rallied the boys together into the formation for the kill. Oh, when Ol' One Eye was caught in those ropes, he knew he didn't stand a chance. But, he died with dignity, he did."

"I hope he wasn't in pain," Elsa murmured.

"No, sweet face, he died swiftly," the man told her.

"Gods, get up off your feet, you lazy bones and help me," Daniela barked to the two. The two shuffled quickly to the roaring laughter of the party.

It sounded like so much fun out there, and Medea wished she could be part of it. "Are you listening?" Marta's voice boomed, shaking her out of her daydreaming.

"Huh?"

"I said, hand me the thyme," she repeated.

"Oh, of course."

Medea reached for a small bundle of herbs hanging from the walls. She took a brief sniff of it, recoiling away from the stench. "Oh, we can't serve this," she said. "It'll ruin the meal."

"Oh, so now you're a brilliant chef all of a sudden," Marta mocked. "I've been doing this for years, and I always have been serving this the same way for all those years. Now, hand me the thyme."

Medea yielded and handed her the offending herbs. She just knew it was all wrong. If she were back home, some lobi root would go perfectly with...oh! She might just have some on her. She rummaged through her cloak, realizing she always kept a few odds and ends in her pockets. She probably didn't realize that when she grabbed this cloak to run away with. Sure enough, there was a single root in her pocket.

The gorgon looked around. Marta would never let her add an ingredient to the stew. She was too firmly in the belief that she was the best cook around. Maybe she was, but Medea was sure of this one thing right now. Once the girl was no longer looking, as she tended to kneading the dough for some fresh loaves of bread, Medea took a knife and cut a few scrapings of the root and let it drop into the pot. The stew sizzled and bubbled for a second. That would give it a little extra kick, she thought. A lot of the male hunters in her caves wanted something with actual flavor to it when they came in hungry, she remembered.

However, she wasn't in the clear just yet. Marta caught her at the last minute. "What in Damus' halls do you think you're doing?" she roared. "Did I not tell you..."

"Where's that stew, Marta?" Daniela asked. "They're starting to get restless. Oh, there it is." The barmaid began laddeling out several bowls, and began walking back out to the men.

"No," Marta breathed, but then remembered what she was doing and struck Medea upside the head. "What were you thinking?"

"I just wanted to help," she said meekly.

"Yeah, well, no thanks to you, you've probably poisoned them." She looked warily out into the halls to see what would happen.
1432112112.title: Someone's in the Kitchen with Medea

choices: Their journey is a success, and even more customers come for the food.
Their journey is a failure, and all three are captured by the gorgons.
The three are too scared to go. They'll have to figure out something else.
14321121122.content:
Both women waited with bated breath as Daniela set the steaming bowls before the hungry hunters. Marta was genuinely terrified, and Medea was just hoping Marta wouldn't be too mad at her in the end. Neither heard anyone drop dead or gag, so that was a good sign. "Maybe they didn't notice," Marta said, breathing out what air she had been holding in. "So, what did you think you were doing?"

"I was just trying to help," Medea said with a pleading look on her face. "It's just some lobi root. We add it to a lot of our food to offset it's bland taste. We use a lot of spices actually to do that. I just had this on me from when I left. If I were to have some..."

"Oh, shut up, you," Marta said, "I'm trying to hear what's going on."

Daniela burst through the doors, and both girls stood at attention, fearful of what would come out of the waitress' mouth. She was smiling like an idiot. "I don't know what you did to this batch, Marta, but they are just eating it up. They've already asked for seconds. And more customers are coming through the door as we speak."

Both were at a loss for words. Medea was beaming with pride, but Marta was stuttering like an idiot. "But...I...she..."

"This isn't the time to go modest on me. We've got hungry customers, and they're loving what you're serving. Let's keep it going hot tonight, got it?"

She bustled out the door and the two looked at each other. The gorgon grinned from ear to ear. "So, I can stay in the kitchen tonight?"

Marta huffed and went to chopping vegetables. "Yeah, yeah, whatever. We'd better get started if we're going to keep up with all those orders. You got enough of that stuff?"

She patted her pocket. "For now. I'll need to find more if we intend to use this for another night."

The girl wheeled on her, waving a wooden spoon in her face. "Listen here, you, this was a fluke, and you got lucky. I'm not going to be putting up with this for much longer. We'll get through tonight, and never speak of this little mistake again."

Medea still had a smug look on her face. She wasn't about to let this moment go by. She had actually been successful, and no longer felt like a total fool among the humans. She continued to work quietly grounding the lobi root, humming pleasantly to herself.

All night long, the other barmaids came in and out grabbing more orders of the stew which was now becoming famous. All the while they praised the two girls for their excellent work in the kitchen. Medea returned the kindnesses with much appreciation, while Marta grumbled a few curt "thank yous" all the while pounding the hell out of the meat. No flighty little gorgon was just going to waltz into her kitchen with all her charm and just take over. It was HER kitchen godsdamnit!

In the meantime, it was hard to keep up with all the orders. Requests for the delicious stew were filling up, and both women ran themselves ragged just trying to ensure they could meet the demand. By the end of the night, everyone was exhausted, and they all collapsed on the empty benches in the hall.

"My feet are so sore," Frenda whined. "I don't think I've ever walked that much."
