Daniela let out a wearied laugh. "Good for ya. Means we all earned good tips tonight. Again, I don't know what you two did, but it worked."

Marta fumed, but said nothing. Medea wasn't about to let her one moment go away. "This," she said, holding up the last bit of lobi root. "I used it in the stew. I think if I could go out and get some more..."

"You let HER put something in the food!" Elsa screamed at Marta. "Why?"

"Hey, it wasn't my fault. She did it when I wasn't looking. You're just lucky you didn't poison all the patrons."

What was about to become yet another fight was broken up by the hobbling steps of Adela. "Girls, girls, there shouldn't be any fighting tonight. You had such a great run. I've never had business that good. Now, what was it you were saying, Medea did something to the stew?"

Medea rushed to her, holding out the root. Adela held it and examined it, before letting out a roaring laugh. "Well, I'll be damned. If it isn't a little Snakecoil."

She looked confused. "But, that's..."

The innkeep waved her off. "Oh, I'm sure your people have another name for it, but this is what we used to call it back in my day. Used to spice our mead with it. Gave it a good warmth. I haven't seen this stuff in ages. Pretty rare, as I remember it."

"It was pretty common back home," Medea answered. "I'd have to get more, but I'd run the risk of getting caught by my people."

Adela thought it over. "Well, can't have that now, can we? I'm not about to lose my golden goose so easily. Daniela, Frenda, you go with her to keep her safe."

"What!"

"You've got to be kidding," Daniela said. "We're not adventurers who do quests, with all due respect. We're barmaids."

"And last time I checked, you're barmaids who want to keep getting your tips, right?"

All three women looked at each other. There was no getting old Adela to budge on this. They'd have to suck it up and go.
14321121122.title: Medea, the Genius

choices: And so, the plan for artificial rare ingredients begins.
Or, perhaps, resident cook Marta can think of something?
143211211223.content:
Medea often wondered if humans were this prone to nervous breakdowns.

She'd been filled with dread when Adela had essentially ordered her, the escaped Gorgon Priestess, to go with Daniela and Frenda, two barmaids who'd certainly never survive the trip to Sarkos and back with their sanity intact, all the way back to said dreaded caverns, risk capture and possible deadly punishment, all to get more Snakecoil.

A perilous journey from North to West and back, risk capture and maybe something worse, definitely risk the mental well-being of her new acquaintances, all for the sake of just one piece of ingredient.

Medea would have been fine with taking the trip, provided she really had no choice in the matter. But bring along Daniela and Frenda? Or the other two? Gods, anyone at all? Medea would rather resign herself to the miserable fate of a Priestess than let others suffer for her crimes.

And to think, it had almost come to that.

"Well..." Daniela had said once Adela had haughtily sauntered away to the bar to tend to other customers. "You heard the woman. We might as well pack."

Medea, much as she wanted to object, could only bring herself to give her a look of shock and hurt.

"Don't!" Daniela snapped. "I'm not happy either, all right?" she breathed out, her sharp features softening. "What choice do we have? We must keep business going."

"Is it really that important?" Medea muttered. "Is it really worth risking your life?"

Daniela chuckled darkly. "I envy you, Medea." At the gorgon's confused stare, the barmaid continued ruefully. "You clearly don't have a care in the land. What happened to you, exactly? You just got bored of living under a cave and decided to see how us lowly mortals struggle about in life?"

Medea winced, but remained silent, patiently waiting for the redhead to finish.

"Some of us have responsibilities to uphold. Need to make that living. We need the income. If we don't get it, then what of the people we do this for? Elsa has four sisters in Racovania, one with child and widowed. Marta and I have our own families to support with this job. And Frenda..." Daniela's face softened considerably. "Has only this. No family, no friends outside of us. She just came to us, alone."

Medea processed the revelation quietly, realizing how single-minded she'd been looking at them. She thought barmaids were just that, barmaids. Just pretty women put to work at taverns and earn their wages. She hadn't stopped to think maybe there was more to it than that. It made her feel deeply ashamed for having added that Snakecoil to the soup. She'd meant well, but now they had to take a dangerous journey to keep the supply coming.

"And is business...not so productive in these parts?"

"We earn well, but not as much as some of us would like on some days," Elsa interjected, uncharacteristically somber. "It's what we get for living out of the reaches of Racovania. Independence from the vampires, but our little town needs to fend for itself."

A pause hung over the group.

Daniela sighed. "I'll go prepare mine and Frenda's bags. How far can we make it to Sarkos if we go by wagon?"

Medea was about to respond, but her words died upon finally taking notice of the young blonde who had been quiet up until now when she'd let out a sniffle.

"No, please..."

The other barmaids whipped to the youngest in their rank, eyebrows raised and faces contorted with alarm.

"Please..." Frenda's blue eyes stared forward at nothing, her arms wrapped tightly around herself. She was shaking horribly where she stood.

Medea stared at the blonde, then at the others. Her mouth fell open. "What...What is happening to her?"

Daniela ignored the gorgon, instead walking over to the near-catatonic girl carefully. "Frenda, hey, listen..." she placed a gentle hand on her shoulder. "Remember what to do. Breathe. Think only of the garden. Remember the garden. Think on that."

The eldest barmaid's words seemed to have the desired effect on the blonde. Her breathing grew more steady and she was blinking rapidly, snapping out of her stupor.

Medea took a step forward. "Is she well now?"

And then something horrible happened. Frenda's eyes registered the gorgon standing by, and at once she shrieked.

It was a good thing they were at the kitchen, and that Elsa and Marta rushed outside to tend to any late night customers outside, Medea reflected. Because otherwise any brave male traveler would have stormed the kitchen to find out what had made a young maiden scream so loud to the gods, and upon catching sight of the only gorgon present would have assumed the worst.

Daniela reacted quickly, clamping a hand over Frenda's mouth before her scream could reach an octave too high and attract attention from outside or, even worse, from Adela.

"Frenda! Frenda! Hey, hey!" Daniela had to wrap her free arm around the blonde when she started thrashing. "Calm down, child! Frenda!"

The blonde only let out muffled, wailing sobs from behind the older girl's hand, shaking her head furiously.

"What's happening to her?!" Medea gasped, her scaly hands flying to cover her mouth.

"It's a trauma!" Daniela hollered back. "None of us know, because she refuses to tell us! She always gets like this when told about the other regions of Yndyre!"

Medea's hands slowly fell from covering her mouth, realization dawning on her.

"Frenda!" Daniela snarled, glaring down at the girl. "You have to calm down! Don't make me knock you--OUCH!"

Medea didn't know what to expect in this situation. She'd never seen a case of one person holding down another overcome with hysteria. She especially didn't think sweet, friendly Frenda could be capable of violence. And here she was, proving her wrong by biting into Daniela's hand with all the force of a vampire on a blood feast.

"Why, you little BRAT--!" Daniela, blinded by anger, raised her arm high, fingers completely outstretched, her palm glistening ever so slightly by the light of the moon through the window.

Frenda's hands flew to her head, she shut her eyes, and wailed, awaiting the blow.

SMACK!

Medea grit her teeth, her head swinging to the side as her cheek stung from where she'd intercepted Daniela's intended slap for Frenda. But she kept her knees rooted to the floorboards, her arms wrapped tightly around Frenda as the blonde buried her face into her chest on pure instinct, sobbing.

Daniela only came to her senses when the snakes on Medea's head hissed in alarm, along with the fact that her palm had clearly not hit a cheek of soft baby fat, but rather one that felt like soft leather.

Medea turned her head to look up at Daniela, her arms embracing Frenda closer as the blonde continued to weep brokenly.

"We're not going."

Daniela blinked. "What?"

Frenda jerked for a moment in the gorgon's arms, but otherwise did not move.

"We're not going," Medea repeated, her words laced with firmness.

At once, the redhead scowled. "Oh, so you'd have me go all by my lonesome?"

"No!" Medea stood up, gently guiding Frenda to her feet. "The three of us will not go. We're not risking our lives for some stupid ingredient."

"Oh, were the world that easy!" Daniela snarled. "How will we keep the men and women who come in for more of that damned soup satisfied? Next thing you will tell me is that you have a miracle solution for us!"

"Perhaps I do," Medea retorted calmly. "There's more to the menu than that stew, yes? We'll present something else."

"Oh yes, I can envision it now," Daniela said sourly. "Good morning and gods save you, kind sir! What will you have today? What's that, the stew from yesterday? Ohhh, so sorry, sir. We are all out of the need to make it. Yes, so sorry. Very tragic. Have you tried our steak with biscuits on the side? It is to die for!"

"Your confidence is impressive," Medea droned.

"I was jesting."

"I know," Medea sighed. "But I do have a solution."

"By the gods, will you discover a gold mine for us next?" Daniela drawled in sarcasm. "But by all means, do share."

"We replicate the feel of the ingredient."

A pregnant pause as the gorgon's words seemed to echo around the kitchen area.

"...I repeat my earlier statement. What?"

"If we can't come across Snakecoil Roots here, then we'll have to use other ingredients that can have a similar effect on the food we serve. It's not that hard to create. And if that fails, well, with the gods' blessings maybe a merchant will have some?"

"...Merchants do come by often," Daniela conceded with a reluctant nod. "But by all means, I think our solution lies in making these so-called 'similar ingredients', because I sure as hell cannot fathom numerous merchants carrying an herb that grows only near the Gorgon's den."

"Indeed," Medea nodded before smiling gratefully. "Thank you for your faith in this."

"Oh, believe me, I don't have faith. I think we're doomed."

Medea pointedly ignored that, instead turning to look down at Frenda with concern. "Are you well now, Frenda?"

The blonde sniffled once, and then gave a nod. "Y-Yes..."

Medea smiled and turned to walk away, but her arm was grabbed softly by the girl.

"Thank you."

Medea's warm smile morphed into a beam, feeling for the first time genuine acceptance by one of the barmaids.

"I'll go tell Adela," Daniela spoke up, grimacing slightly. "Not like she'll be pleased, regardless of who tells her..."

"Gods be with you!" Medea smiled cheerfully, earning a giggle from Frenda.

"And may Omes strike you in the foot," Daniela grumbled.
143211211223.title: To Take a Third Option

choices: No one is willing to taste the beverage...except Frenda!
Adela walks in to check on them.
Some mishap happens, and the drink is spilled. Oops.
That time of the day again; customers walk in.
1432112112231.content:
Another day, another successfully turned in profit for the inn. The barmaids had run around all day, serving customers, entertaining the occasional flirt, and keeping the merry atmosphere going. The only slight bump to the mood would be that patrons kept calling for the stew from yesterday, and it eventually reached a point where Adela was forced to cave in and order her girls to give the people what they want.

They were able to excuse the lack of extraordinary flavor well enough. Every establishment faces a shortage of ingredients from time to time. These things can't be helped! Though this meant customers were a tad disappointed, it didn't tamper with business. The bar was even more popular than ever, and if it wasn't bar patrons, it was new guests coming to stay at the inn. Why, just this very morning, a traveling Orc came up and checked in for one day's stay!

Truly, life was good for these North-border barmaids.

"If this plan of yours doesn't succeed," Adela's carefree smile would have looked a lot more inviting were it not peppered with a warning malice. "Gods help me, scrubbing the floorboards and restrooms will be the least of your worries."

Daniela, amidst all the "Yes Ma'am"s and "Understood"s, kept exercising her "Don't shoot the messenger!" right; this was Medea's idea, not hers!

But yes, the gist of it was they were pressed to find a solution. Replicate the delicious dish Medea had unwittingly created, or gods help them with whatever sadistic punishment Adela had in store for them.

Which brought them all to their current team meeting.

"So to summarize," said Daniela. "We make our grub as delicious as that one time--"

"Hmph...!"

"--Oh, shut it Marta! As I was telling, we make our food better, or the old witch will--"

The wooden door leading into the kitchen suddenly swung open with all the force of a hurricane, echoing as loud as thunder all over the bar. Marta, Elsa, and Frenda all jumped with a shriek. Daniela let out a "By the gods!" cry, and Medea swirled around in alarm, her tail coiling itself around her legs for fear of it being severed by the door, the snakes that made up her long hair hissing in distress.

"Ah, silly me!" Adela's youthful features were creased in an obvious parody of innocence. In her perfectly manicured fingers was a single envelope. "I forgot to have this out for the courier! Would one of you be a dear and take it to him before he departs for Racovania? It would be awfully remiss of me to neglect correspondence to my dear cousin Helga!"

Before anyone could recover from the shock of being startled and volunteer, Daniela was already marching up to the inn owner, swiped the letter as politely as she could, and marched stoically out the door, towards the exit of the inn.

"Medea, you tell them!" the redhead drawled on her way out, sounding like she was very much done with life's immature shenanigans.

"Me?" the Gorgon blinked, looking momentarily astounded as she registered that yes, Daniela, the Head Barmaid, had just put her in charge. "Right, ehhh..."

She turned to face the uncertain looks of the other barmaids. Frenda's nervousness, Elsa's apprehension, and Marta's doubt. Medea felt unsure all of a sudden, to be faced with the expectation of others like this. But then her gaze focused more on Frenda's blue eyes; amidst the anxiety was clear hope.

Hope in her, the Gorgon. Medea blinked once, feeling a strange feeling of warmth rise within her.

"So it's as Daniela was saying," the Gorgon continued with a renewed sense of determination. "We may not have snakecoil root anymore, but we can come up with ways to imitate the ingredient."

"Especially as it was used just for a soup," Marta chimed in. "Not like we got to add it to our steaks, chickens, eggs, bread..."

"We get it, Marta," Elsa cut in sharply before the prideful cook could fully ramble on. The raven-haired lass turned her attention to the Gorgon. "So how do we start? We go out to the market?"

Medea noticed how the second-oldest of the barmaids seemed particularly excited at that option. The young Gorgon had the distinct impression that she was the type to really enjoy outings, especially if there was a reason to purchase from the marketplace. And yet, despite how superficial it seemed, Medea remembered Daniela's words about Elsa having four sisters to support back in Racovania, one of whom was with child.

"Yes, it's the best place to start," Medea nodded. "But at the same time, I'd like to fully inspect the kitchen."

"What for?" Marta said a tad defensively, earning her a scowl from Elsa.

"There may be some things we can work with here," Medea explained gently, smiling politely.

Marta huffed in response. "Hoping to reap more success from blunders?"

Medea's smile fell.

"Oh, the gods have truly forsaken us!" Elsa bemoaned, rubbing a palm over her forehead. "Marta, just listen to her. Don't make me get Adela in here."

"Please Elsa, there is no need," Medea pleaded softly, holding her hands up amicably as she turned to Marta. "I don't wish anyone harm. I only want to help. I would be honored if you granted me permission to work in your kitchen."

"The day I let an outsider--!" Marta started loudly, approaching Medea with the intent of jabbing a menacing finger to her chest.

But she was stopped mid-stomp by, to the great surprise of everyone, Frenda. The youngest barmaid stood between the redhead and the Gorgon, holding her thin arms wide at length as she acted the role of a wall.

"Frenda..." Marta murmured, shocked at the undeniable reality before her.

"Marta," the blonde's tone was soft and firm at once. "Please stop it. You're being unfair."

Elsa and Marta were in shock. Frenda was always incredibly timid around newcomers, especially members of a different race. Combine that with the horror stories spread about Gorgons, and one would assume Frenda would never be standing where she is now, arms stretched out in defense of one of those humanoid reptiles. And yet she was. Elsa and Marta could only conclude that if Frenda was perfectly willing to come to the defense of the Gorgon, then perhaps she could be trusted after all. It didn't stop them from wondering what in Nilheia's holy name did Frenda see in her.

Medea, for her part, stared at the blonde's back in moved surprise. Until now, she had been used to the uneasy acquaintanceship vibe she got from the barmaids as a whole, but now with Frenda, she felt like just maybe, she was actually going to make a friend out of all this. The thought brought that warm feeling again. Her first friend outside home...

The idea of that felt...rather nice.

Marta sighed, her disapproving anger fading. She looked straight at Medea. "If Frenda speaks up for you, then I'll trust her judgment."

Medea beamed.

"Oh please," Elsa snorted. "I trust Daniela's judgment. Shows what little faith you have, Marta!"

"Watch it," Marta glowered.

"I have to agree," Frenda spoke up, giggling. "If Daniela trusts Medea, then that should be good enough for the rest of us!"

"But that's...!" Marta stared at the blonde, aghast. "Oh, you've been hanging around these two for too long, Frenda!"

Medea smiled as the other two laughed at the redhead's outburst. They're all like sisters, she mused. Sisters that stick together through everything. Was this normal for humans, Medea wondered. It made her all the more relieved that she had escaped the isolated life of being a Priestess of Sarkos.

"So then," Marta spoke up once the other two had stopped giggling at her expense. "What do you need from here?"

And the redhead near-instantly regretted asking so casually, for the Gorgon took that as permission to go about the kitchen like it was suddenly bequeathed to her. Medea started by strolling over to the fridge, opening it for a moment to take note of the condiments and beverages inside. Next, she inspected the cabinets above and below, making a thoughtful noise all the while, her tail swinging in tune to her cheerful mood.

Marta and Elsa shared an uneasy look, wondering just what the snake lady was up to. To their horror, they noticed Frenda look at the Gorgon with what could otherwise be called awe, the blonde's eyes glued on Medea as she went about the kitchen, taking only minor looks at ingredients that to the barmaids looked like they offered nothing. Frenda, however, had her hands clasped together as she waited with bated breath as to what the Gorgon would come up with.

Finally, after finishing her mini tour of the kitchen, Medea crossed her arms and closed her eyes, humming once again. Her right toes wriggled upon the wooden floorboards, imitating the impression of a tapping foot. Her tail waved back and forth, conveying the sense of a tactician ready to think of a winning move and a predator eager to pounce on cornered prey. Medea's eyes shot open, and at once she moved.

First she pulled out the milk carton from the fridge, together with a crystal glass from the cabinet.

"Hey, we only use those for wine!" Marta protested, but was ignored.

Medea poured some of the milk into the glass, which she then placed on the stove, lighting the fire beneath it. Next, she reached out and grabbed two peppers, hovering them over the warming milk and squeezing them in her hands. The red, spicy juice leaked from her hands, falling into the milk below. After tossing the pruned peppers away, Medea grabbed a raw potato, sliced it open easily with her claws, and dumped the raw mashed potatoes in the incredibly bizarre mix she was brewing.

"What in Damus' name...?" Elsa muttered in horror.

"And finished!" Medea declared triumphantly. "Ladies, I present a popular beverage from my home: Gift of the Mamba!"
1432112112231.title: Mix Cooking 101 for Barmaids

choices: Medea's recipes are a great success; they're the talk of the town!
The recipes are a success, but everyone wants to meet the mystery chef...
Word of Medea's recipes reaches Racovania.
Word of Medea's recipes spreads across the land.
14321121122311.content:
"Oi, girls, what did I...miss...?" Daniela froze upon noticing her fellow barmaids all gathered around a table, Medea standing opposite them. In the middle of the table stood a lone drink, looking nothing like any beverage she had ever seen. What sort of liquid was that...? And...did Medea do that?

She got her confirmation from observing how Marta and Elsa looked revolted, while Medea was positively brimming with pride. And Frenda...

Why was Frenda looking at Medea's creation with both awe and curiosity? Was that healthy?

"Gift..." Marta breathed, eyeing the pinkish-red beverage on the table.

"...of the Mamba...?" Elsa finished, looking rather green as she took into account what was used to make the drink; milk, red peppers, and some bits of raw potato sliced into it. And it was named after a lethal type of snake. "By Damus, just...what is this?"

"It's a popular beverage from Sarkos," Medea recounted fondly. "Ordinarily, it's first served to pubescent Gorgons to mark the transition to maturity. The warm milk represents maturing infancy, and the spices added to it refer to the jolt of growth. That sensation one gets when feeling no longer like a child. As though you have become aware of your new senses and how you perceive the world from that point on."

Medea smiled as she tapped the side of the glass, as though prodding at a new life. "It's a drink we share with the Naga. Named as it is in accordance to a tale on how Zolneas once happened upon a peculiar snake pinned to the earth by one of Ardoid's arrows that had accidentally veered off its intended path, thus striking the snake, which was not meant to die. Zolneas happened upon the snake, and, dismayed, removed the arrow.

"To Zolneas' surprise, the snake's injury healed by itself, looking as though it had never been pierced by the arrow. The snake coiled itself in reverence to its goddess and humbly requested a chalice to express its gratitude. Zolneas produced the chalice, and the snake placed its fangs on it. To the increasing surprise of the goddess, rather than venom, out from the fangs came what looked to be wine. She tasted it, and at once blessed the snake, declaring the beverage to be the best she's ever had. And so it came to be known as the Gift of the Mamba, for it being a present to both the goddess Zolneas, and a great drink discovered for all to taste."

Elsa, Daniela, and Marta looked slightly impressed by the significance of the drink. It's not often one gets to learn such fine detail from another culture. It made the Gorgon standing before them seem more...human, as bizarre as that sounded. But yes, she appeared much more approachable. It made the biased fear and uncertainty they had for her seem outright embarrassing and exaggerated.

Frenda certainly seemed over that. She looked positively captivated after hearing Medea's tale, like she had been hanging on to every word.

"But..." Marta spoke up after a moment of silence. "If milk and peppers are the main components, why did you add that bit of raw, mashed potato?"

To the great horror of the barmaids, Medea blinked in confusion.

"Potato? That was a potato? I thought it was some sort of bloated, round sugar cane!"

Daniela's hands floated in front of her, her countenance scrunched in a way that made her look like she was struggling from lunging at the Gorgon, or crushing her own throat. Elsa stepped away from the table, now looking at the beverage like it was a miniature volcano ready to erupt at a moment's notice. Marta...

"YOU ADDED A WRONG INGREDIENT?!" the chef roared, possessing all the rage of a deity towards a blasphemous mortal. "AND YOU DIDN'T THINK TO ASK ME FIRST?!"

Medea shrunk slightly. "Ayyyyyyeeee...got caught in the rush of creativity?"

"YOU IDIOT!" Marta gripped and pulled at her long brown hair.

"It should still be good!" Medea protested. "One wrong ingredient doesn't usually--"

"Ah-Ah! Say no more!" Marta snarled. "I'm throwing this...this...liquid weapon away before it destroys the bowels of anyone unlucky enough to--"

The chef froze in her angry rant upon realizing the wine glass containing the dreaded drink was not in its original position on the table. One quick glance to the side revealed the glass, held gently in the hands of the youngest barmaid, her lips coming into contact with the glass as she tipped it forward.

"FRENDA, NOOO!" Marta and Elsa shrieked together, the former making to knock the glass from the blonde's hands.

Frenda, however, was unperturbed by the hysterics of the other two, and actually raised a placating hand to stop Marta in her advance. She took a small, cautious sip of the beverage, a sip that soon turned into a generous gulp.

All eyes were on her, the barmaids looking with trepidation, while Medea stared in anxious eagerness, awaiting critique on her efforts.

"Well?" Daniela leaned forward, placing a hand on Marta's shoulder to keep her from capturing the blonde in her arms and performing the Heimlich on her.

Frenda hummed thoughtfully, processing the drink. Her cheeks turned rosy as she jumped a little upon feeling the spicy flavor hit.

"Wooh! It's...spicy," she clicked her tongue, feeling it itch from the burning sensation. And yet, she brought the glass to her lips once more, taking a quicker sip. "But...then it's...warm. Like tea! Or coffee, only spicy!"

"So you approve?" Medea beamed.

To which the blonde gave a beatific smile. "It's delicious!"

To say the other barmaids were floored would be a major understatement. Daniela recovered from the shock first, patiently prying the drink from the blonde's hands so she could sample it herself.

"Oh!" she gasped involuntarily from the initial spicy taste before the warming aftermath settled in. "What a curious drink!"

"You give her too much credit," Marta groused, taking the drink to try it herself. And found herself liking it. "Well, I'll be an Orc's aunt..."

"For you to say that, it must be quite good..." Elsa agreed reluctantly as she was handed the drink. It took some self-resistance, but she managed to force herself to take a sip. "Ay! A tad too spicy for my liking! But, ehh...it's not bad. I like the warm sensation afterwards."

"It's another benefit of the Gift of the White Mamba," Medea smiled. "My people and the Naga drink it especially during the winter season. A chalice of this is enough to keep any being warm for at least two days."

"Huh, and all you need is milk, some peppers, and sugar?" Daniela questioned.

"Oh, the sugar was just an extra addition. I thought it would lessen the spice effect for your human tongues," Medea scratched the nape of her neck sheepishly, her scales glistening under the sunlight from the window. "Also, believe me when I say that this concoction is actually inferior to the original served back at Sarkos or the Motee Marshes."

"Really?" Frenda piped up, looking at the Gorgon like a student eager to learn more.

"Oh yes, the dairy we use is of a special variety that's used just for this drink, and we don't use ordinary red peppers," Medea allowed a grin to form as she said the following. "We use Mar Peppers."

Elsa spluttered upon hearing that. "Mar, as in the single spiciest brand in all of Yndyre?! That which is said to turn your tongue into fire if ingested without proper care?!"

"The very same, although truth be told, I find that to be an exaggeration," the Gorgon shrugged. "We've used Mar for a lot of dishes back home, and at worst all we get is a tickling sensation to the tongue."

All the barmaids stared at her in silent bafflement. A tickling feeling to Gorgons and Nagas, and yet to them, humans, this tame version of the drink burned their tongues slightly. They could only shudder at what might happen to them if they ever got to sample a legitimate Sarkos-made Gift of the Mamba.

"Right," Daniela nodded sardonically. "But this is only a drink. What about an actual meal?

"Ooh, yes!" Frenda chirped, smiling widely as she looked to the Gorgon with that same eagerness from before. "Won't you share more of your amazing culture cuisine with us?"

"Frenda!" Marta cried, aghast.

Medea felt her cheeks flush, her chest beating with joy at the notion of being accepted.

"Frenda is right," Daniela shook her head, but smiled nonetheless. "Not just with food, I'm sure you have other drinks in mind, yeah?"

"If Daniela is fine with this, then I am too," Elsa said dutifully.

"Oh, why not?" Marta rubbed her temple. "At this point, I might as well be open to a new experience in cooking."

Medea did all she could to keep from showing how sentimental they were making her feel. She managed to keep the mist to her eyes still, but her tail was stretching and coiling in delight, and her snake-hairs moving about in happiness.

"Yes, indeed," Medea nodded, a determined grin on her face. "With your support, I'll do my best!"
14321121122311.title: The Wonder of Spices

choices: Except Adela seems to be...sampling the wares more than necessary.
Except one or two of the barmaids have gotten very much hooked on Medea's meals!
Except a duo of Gorgons has appeared, in search of the runaway priestess! Uh-Oh!
143211211223111.content:
And so, a consensus was formed amongst the barmaids.

They worked in a team formation to get the best results possible for this ambitious endeavor. Daniela and Elsa took to the tables, writing down orders, delivering plates and cups, and keeping the patrons entertained via talk or, mostly in Elsa's case, flirting. Frenda worked in getting the ingredients organized and ready for use by Medea and Marta, who cooked and prepared the meals restlessly at the kitchen. Adela, as keeper of the inn and manager of the girls, helped where it was necessary, be it assisting in serving or barking at the other girls to not fall behind.

There was no friction. Well, Marta was still rather sour at the idea of handing the reins to someone else (a non-human, at that), but for the most part, she'd grown to her new role. Besides, she had to admit, experimenting with new meal formations was...kind of exciting! The inner professional chef in her liked the idea of preparing semi-foreign dishes from another culture, and Medea was surprisingly adept!

So it should come as no surprise their teamwork yielded success.

"Here's the...uff...next one...!"

Marta's arms strained with the weight of the giant meat slab, big enough to have been literally a piece of a cow. Once she was sure she was hovering the meaty boulder over the table, Marta let go.

The table sagged and creaked slightly at the heavy meat dropped upon it.

"Thank you, Marta!" Medea beamed, flashing her claws. "I'll take it from here!"

Within seconds, the meat was divided into smaller sections, ones that, while still big, weighed a lot less, allowing the table's leg to spring back to normal. Marta briefly marveled at the display; who needs knives when you have Gorgon claws?

Shaking her head with an amused smile, Marta walked over to the counter, presenting one of the first of many dishes being served for the night.

"Two servings of leg of lamb with cream and extra spices for table four!"

Daniela rushed to the counter and picked up the order. "How's the other one coming?"

"Medea is starting on it now," Marta replied. "Who would have thought we would be delivering to the tenants in their rooms?"

"It's a new business practice, or so Adela says."

"Less mewling, more service, girls!" Adela hollered from the other end of the counter. "You want to earn those tips, or not?! And ELSA! Get back to the counter and await the next order, you little siren!"

Frenda, meanwhile, ran into the kitchen with a new bottle of season, fresh from the basement. "Medea, I've brought it!"

"Thank you!" the Gorgon flashed a warm smile to the blonde, taking the offered bottle to pepper its contents over the cooking meat.

Frenda's reply was a blush as she gazed in admiration at the snake woman's cooking.

"Did you...always do this?"

"Hm?" Medea briefly paused as she considered the blonde's question. She chuckled softly. "I did not. I only learned by watching others, whenever I asked for a meal to be prepared in front of me."

Frenda's eyes flew wide as she processed that. "Are you a royal where you come from?"

"No, no," Medea laughed, which Frenda noted sounded a bit forced. The Gorgon's eyes looked slightly downcast. "You could say I had everything I could want, but not what I wanted most..."

Frenda's heart dropped, feeling guilty for having brought up what were no doubt painful memories for her new friend. "I'm sorry..."

"Don't be!" Medea's downtrodden countenance shifted into her usual cheerful one. "It's in the past now, so no reason to think too hardly on it!"

"But still..." Frenda muttered, dark memories flashing in the corner of her mind. "I'd be willing to listen, if it would take it off your mind."

Medea froze, looking upon the young human in wonder. Her facade of cheerfulness fell away, revealing a genuine, grateful smile. She reached a hand to the blonde's head, making sure to keep her claws stretched to avoid scratching the human.

"Thank you, Frenda," Medea murmured, her warm smile still in place.

The blonde smiled back.

"Medea!" Marta yelled, scaring the two from where they stood. "What's going on? The client in his room is complaining, and we have other mouths to feed at the tables! And Frenda! Get over here and help! There was a spill at table

"Y-Yes!" Medea and Frenda chorused, hastily jumping back to their posts before Marta, or, gods forbid, Adela, could shriek at them again.

And so, through their combined teamwork and effectiveness in where they worked best, the Icy Arms Inn saw an increase in revenue unlike any it had seen in its twenty years. Travelers from the region came, many staying for three days to even a full seven days. The inn was already known for its comfortable accommodations for anyone this far in the North, but now its reputation of great rooms and comforts was preceded by the exotic, foreign cuisine it had added to its serving menu. And it all served to make the Icy Arms a popular site to frequent, whether to stay in a room or just to enjoy the pub.

Indeed, even those in the tiny little settlement worked their dues early and quickly just so they could stop by the Icy Arms and dine on the interesting menu.

Truly, things were great in the new (if temporary) life the Gorgon had established for herself amongst this settlement of humans in the North.
143211211223111.title: Spread the Word on Medea

choices: Things are going well until a mysterious stranger arrives with a cryptic message
Things are going well until some reckless satyrs arrive. Talk about a wild party
Things are going well until people start going missing. Are the vampires here?
Things are going well until word gets around of a mysterious cult creeping up.
1432112112231112.content:
With all the success came a few hiccups. It was bound to happen of course. Nothing was ever perfect. With all the added attention and new customers, there were a few unsavory sorts that wandered their way into the tavern. Occasionally, a bar fight would break out, resulting in Adela having to pitch them out into the street. That was actually more entertaining to watch than the actual fight itself. But, along the way, a few new surprises were making some interesting changes to the atmosphere of the tavern.

"Elsa! Do you have those drinks or not!" Adela called from the other end of the bar. It was an especially busy evening, and she had gone back behind the bar to alleviate some of Elsa's workload since she mostly handled her job on her own.

"*gulp* Just a minute," the dark-haired barmaid called, shuffling behind the counter.

Adela rolled her eyes. "And what in the world are you up to?" she said, turning around to see what was causing the holdup.

She really shouldn't have been surprised. The barmaid was hiding yet another plate of food she had gotten from the kitchens. True, their tough but fair manager had always been okay with the girls catching a bite here or there during their shifts to keep their energy up, she always stressed that it needed to be not when they had customers waiting. And, as of late, Elsa had developed a habit of snacking more often than she ever used to.

That had led to a few other changes as well. For a while now, Adela had thought there was something different about Elsa lately, and now catching her in the act, she figured out what it was. Among the girls who worked at the inn, Elsa was probably the most average-looking girl there. She didn't have curvaceous hips like Daniela, wasn't busty like Marta, and wasn't as young as Frenda. No, Elsa had always been the "plain" one among the group, but that didn't mean she couldn't get male attention if she wanted to. She was still beautiful of face and fair of skin. Men noticed her.

But now, Adela noticed something much different. All that extra snacking had given Elsa the start of a nice rounded belly. Her stomach looked wider, softer, and her apron clung much tighter to it. It wasn't much, but it was something the wise old tavern owner could pick up on. Not that she minded. No, up north, a girl needed a bit more meat on her bones, and it showed she was a fine and healthy woman. What bothered her was that she couldn't have a barmaid distracted by eating all the time.

"Oi, what do you think you're doing?" she bellowed. "We got orders to fill. You can eat when you get them done."

Elsa groaned. "But, we've been at it non-stop all day. I haven't eaten anything since..."

"About an hour ago," she finished for her. "You're not getting out of it that easily. Every time I turn around, you're eating something."

The young girl rolled her eyes and went back to work. "Can't help it when Medea is such a good cook," she mumbled.

Yes, that seemed to be a common theme around here. Everyone was getting hooked on the gorgon's amazing food, and now that effect was working on some of her own girls. Daniela had a habit of accepting a bite or two from the male patrons who wanted an excuse to keep her talking at their tables. Marta was, of course, cooking with Medea, and therefore needed to taste everything as they made it. And Frenda was just so fascinated by it all, she happily ate any new dishes Medea wanted to try out to see if it would go over well with the customers. And Elsa, it seemed, just liked to eat the food whenever she could get a chance.

"Just stick to the work, and eat on breaks, that's all I ask."

"Oh! Sorry, I didn't mean to do that," Adela heard a small voice say.

Speaking of Frenda, Adela had also noticed that she too took a special fancy to Medea's cooking, and it was showing on her much more than it was Elsa. Frenda was just one of those girls that seemed to gain a little padding everywhere. She still looked to be her same old self, just thicker. Her young, baby face had grown fuller over the past few weeks, her limbs a bit puffier, and she had started to widen a bit. Just now, she had accidentally bumped a table with her hip. It seemed that she wasn't aware of these changes herself.

Adela shook her head and went back to serving up orders. She was thankful for this little blessing in disguise that was Medea, but her girls had better get their head in the game if they wanted to keep up with all this popularity. And, at the same time, she may want to keep a cautious eye on the girls. If they weren't careful, they might find themselves to round to get around.
1432112112231112.title: Keeping it Together

choices: Business continues to grow- as do the barmaids.
Talk of the cult is growing. Is there actually something to this?
14321121122311124.content:
"What have people been saying?" Medea asked, her curiosity peaked. The day was done, the last patron had left, and Medea had heard the girls whispering about something and decided to poke her head into the conversation. Metra, Elsa, and Daniela gave each other looks as if asking each other, do we tell her?

"People are talking about a cult having arrived here." Frenda piped up, making the decision for the other three.

"A what?" Medea asked, confused.

Metra tilted her head. "You don't know what a cult is?" she said, once again dumbfounded at how much and yet how little Medea knew.

Medea, having spent her whole life underground, shook her head. She looked at Metra, sensing something was off- and indeed it was. Metra had gained some weight over the course of the last week, and while she was busty previously, now her chest stuck out enough that you had to stand a foot back or else end up making contact. That's not the only thing: Metra had weight piling everywhere else too, although it was much more noticeable in her chest region. Not that Medea picked up on that

"A cult is a religion which practices dark rituals and the like. Summoning undead, sacrificing to demons, those sorts of things." Elsa explained.

"Oh my gosh, that sounds awful." Medea says, placing her hands to her mouth. Elsa noticed, with some frustration, that Medea had barely put on a single pound. As it turns out, gorgon food is designed to be very fattening because they have to go long periods of time with very little to eat, although Elsa didn't know this.

"Enough of that, it's all just gossip. Who knows, right?" Daniela butted in, not wanted to scare the poor gorgon.

"Well, not like I'd give them the chance to sacrifice any of you to some dark god. They come after you, they're going to wish they had the chance to regret it." Medea said, taking a heroic stance. Frenda loved it, but Elsa gave her a look, asking,

"Wait, can you gorgons turn people to stone?" At that, the four humans tensed while Medea looked at Elsa, her snakes looking at the other three with, as they saw it, hunger.

"Well, yes, actually. Not many gorgons have that skill, but I was taught it at a young age." Medea casually said. All but Frenda froze, Elsa averting her eyes immediately.

"What's the matter? What, you think I'm going to turn you into stone?" Medea asks, continuing to stare at Elsa. "If I wanted to turn you to stone, you'd already be stone." She said, failing to reassure anyone at all.

"Ugh, come on you three, snap out of it. At least say something to her!" Frenda said, moving to stand beside Medea. Frenda reached for Medea's hand, who instinctively took it, not entirely sure why they were holding hands like that.

"R-r-right. Sorry... just... I was thinking that was all just myths at this point." Elsa said, breaking the tension. Daniela looked at Frenda, curious as to why she so immediately sided with Medea instead of them. She remembered Frenda's breakdown, and immediately stopped thinking about any of it, ashamed of her own action.

Metra said, "Well, I'm heading up to bed now. Goodnight. Need to work that nightmare fuel out of my system. Sorry Medea!" the last part she called as she went up the stairs.

"Yeah, let's go to bed. Come on, Frenda." Daniella beckoned, expecting the younger girl to follow her.

"Are you going to bed, Medea?" she asked, looking at the green gorgon with nothing but awe. "No, I'm going to stay up for a bit. I could use some dinner." Medea responded.

"Okay. I'm going to stay up a bit longer, alright Daniella?" Frenda said, clearly not looking for actual approval. Daniella was shocked at how Frenda seemed to cling to Medea's shadow, almost worshiping her every movement. "O-okay... then. Elsa, you-" she started to say, before seeing Elsa had gone into the kitchen, presumably to eat something. "*sigh* Alright then. Goodnight, everybody!" Daniella called to the three girls downstairs. Medea nodded, and Frenda immediately asked what she was going to make. The two walked into the kitchen, talking to each other as if long time friends.
14321121122311124.title: Cultists? Here?

choices: She's in the larder, doing some heavy sampling of her own.
She's out front, being harassed by a customer.
She's...not here?!?
143211211223111241.content:
News of the cult came and went, grabbing a few enterprising adventurers as it passed through, and soon things were back to routine for the barmaids at the Icy Arms. As Medea soon learned, such rumors were commonplace in this line of work; after all, when dozens of interesting travelers from all around the realm made camp for the night in one room, interesting stories were bound to spring up like weeds in an old garden, as Daniella explained to her. And they were lovely stories too; Medea, while waiting for a scrumptious meal to finish baking or a stew to come to a boil, had developed the habit of listening at the door to the conversations outside, gleaning new things about the world outside of her caves with Marta begrudgingly filling in the blanks when needed. She had always known there were other realms and places beyond the caverns she once called home, but to hear the stories and tales told over warm hearths every night felt like a whole new world opening up to her.

Just another wonderful thing about working here.

"Medea, you're supposed to be watching the stew!"

"I am watching it!" the gorgon insisted as she dashed over to the boiling pot. "You have to leave it sit."

"It's going to sink to the bottom and coagulate!"

"Yes, exactly!" Medea responded cheerily. "It's the best way to get the niko fruit juice at its spiciest!" Medea probably came across as condescending to the more experienced chef, but in truth she was just excited to be working with actual ingredients once again. With the huge increase in business, Adela had doubled down on the new selling point of exotic foods and ensured that Medea had everything she needed in the kitchen, even going as far as paying mercenaries and adventurers to travel south and pick up roots and spices that Medea needed.

Marta gave the overeager gorgon a look before grabbing onto a ladle and scooping up a portion of the soup, sipping it delicately. Her expression immediately softened as the delicious flavor hit her, though she quickly hid it again.

"...you sure this isn't magic of some sort at work?" Marta said grumpily, taking another sip.

"Well if it was you'd be turning to stone." the Gorgon pointed out as Marta took yet another long drink of the cooling stew. "That's the only real magic I know."

"Point taken."

"MARTA!" Adela barked from the back room suddenly. "Stop sampling and get to baking, we have a full house tonight!"

The human chef yelped, dripping a little of the soup onto her double chin and immediately busying herself with the food prep. Medea dashed over to help her, tail swishing back and forth as the two of them prepped orders. The days of Marta griping about having a second hand in the kitchen were long gone, and the two of them now worked in tandem, bouncing around and pumping out tasty exotic cuisine at breakneck speed. And as indicated by Marta being told to stop sampling, they bounced around quite a bit thanks to the delicious new cooking; since Medea's arrival behind the stove the busty chef had grown even bustier with time, straining her apron and testing the limits of the buttons trying to keep her two best friends in check. The chef regularly complained about the stares she got when trying to go about town, and once relayed a memorable story where her top had nearly burst off in the middle of a crowded store and the chaos that ensued afterwards. At the very least, she went on, they were largely distracted from the rest of her, indicating the healthy potbelly drooping over her waist.

"Blackspice Ale is finished!" Medea called out as she finished up another order.

"I got i-oof!"

"I have i-eek!"

Daniela and Elsa bounced against the doorway as they tried to enter at the same time, before Elsa stepped back, red-faced, and let the senior server go in first. Even then, her hips still passed within inches of the doorframe as she retrieved two mugs full of the black, sparking liquor and turned around, walking right into Elsa again.

"Hey, careful!" Elsa yelped, clutching her stomach as it wobbled to a stop.

"You're in my way!" Daniela snapped back.

"You're in MY way!"

"Stop arguing and get back to work!" Adela shouted from upstairs. The two girls huffed, then squeezed past one another as they headed to their tables. It was a particularly busy night for the girls, so a little bit of snippy talkback was expected, especially when they entered the kitchen. To put it politely, Medea thought to herself, it was getting a little small for the girls. Daniela's hips had begun to flare out so much that they regularly bumped into walls and shelves, and her thighs and rear were starting to get in on that action as well. Elsa on the other hand was just getting meatier and thicker all over, catching the eye of some city slickers from the south who liked their women on the meaty side and finally letting her rival the wide-reared Daniela as the resident eye candy.

Medea couldn't help but feel a little wary, since it was largely because of her cuisine that her new friends were starting to put on some pounds. Not to mention that even she had started to feel a little heavier lately, having a bit of trouble tying her apron around herself...

"We're running out of boar strips," Daniela announced. "Where's Frenda? I thought she was supposed to be running ingredients for us."
143211211223111241.title: Booming Business

choices: ...panicked and tried to escape!
...nonchalantly returned to their business like nothing happened.
...began to applaud?!?
1432112112231112412.content:
"I think she was running stew out to the customers," Medea recalled, making her way towards the kitchen door to peek outside.

"...said I wanted bluespice!"

"W-we don't have bluespice, th-that's not even a thing..."

The sounds of the argument echoed across the busy tavern even over the din of the rowdy patrons. Catching a glimpse of a meaty rear end past a table of drunken orc mercenaries, Medea craned her neck, daring to open the door just an inch wider to catch sight of Frenda, facing down a beefy looking man with beady eyes and a large red nose.

"The fuck do you mean you don't have it, it's plastered on all the signs!"

"W-we have Blackspice Ale, if that's what interests y-you s-sir..."

The man huffed. "Well OBVIOUSLY that's what I meant! Dumb wench..."

Medea glared at the bullying man as the conversation carried on. Unfortunately, as she found out, customers like this were all too common, the folks who were too drunk, stupid, or headstrong to think they were anything less then deities and expected to be treated as such. She didn't know how the other girls handled men like this day in and day out, though this fellow was particularly unpleasant; he looked rather unwashed and punctuated every mean thing he said with a personal insult. Poor Frenda was shaking so hard that her flabby form was jiggling on its own by the time she was done. Maybe Medea could make her one of those tasty melon tarts Marta was teaching her how to make. Those always put a smile on her face.

The Gorgon nearly shut the door and turned back to start making the tart when the chubby barmaid, still not quite used to her growing size, turned around just a little too quickly and knocked over a stew right into the angry man's lap. His eyes opened wide as he leapt to his feet, howling and shouting as his whole face turned cherry red.

"Omigosh, I'm so sorry sir!" Frenda yelped. "I'll get-"

"YOU STUPID BITCH!"

And he drew his hand back and slapped her across the face.

Frenda had barely tumbled to the ground when the kitchen door suddenly slammed open. Marta called out in confusion at the noise, and Elsa went ghastly pale as something green shot past her. Daniella had rushed to Frenda's side but felt herself being shoved out of the way by a thick green tale swaying back and forth furiously. Poor Frenda, through her painful sobbing tears, caught sight of a flash of black as the figure over her raised a hand in the direction of the rowdy customer.

"Medea!"

"Wait!"

"Don't-"

Medea brought her hand down in a flash of scarlet.

"YEAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGH!"

The large man fell backwards, flailing like a madman. Blood poured from four long gashes across his cheek and nose. His screaming silenced the whole inn as he stumbled to his feet, blinded by fear, and ran headfirst out the door. Medea, her chest heaving, looked down at her right hand to see blood smeared across her hands, dripping from the talons that pierced his skin.

The weight of what just happened came crashing down like a cave-in. Medea stood in the center of the room, completely undisguised, drawing attention to herself in the worst way possible. She looked over at Daniella and Frenda, the latter of whom was so shocked she even stopped crying and looked just as pale as the senior barmaid did. Elsa stood nearby, gripping an empty plate so tightly her hands shook as Marta gripped the kitchen door so hard her nails were digging into the wood. Adela, quiet as a ghost, had even wandered out from the back, her lips tightly clenched and her expression unreadable.

Medea wanted to run, leave all of this behind, but she couldn't seem to muster the energy to tear herself away. Thus she looked around the room in horror, her Gorgon features on full, horrifying display as the patrons...
1432112112231112412.title: No One Messes With My Friends!

14321121122311124122.content:
"Hey, Gorgon!"

Well, this was it then. Medea turned to face the customer on her right, a swarthy human from the South with a deep scar beneath his eye patch who had been conversing with the customer. She winced at the sight of blood flecked across his leather tunic.

"Y....yes?"

The man took a deep breath, gently dabbing the blood on his face with his kerchief.

"You can cancel his order, lass," he said, a twinkle in his good eye. "Methinks he won't be coming back here tonight." A burst of laughter came from the surrounding onlookers as the usual din of the crowd started to become audible.

"Uh..of course, sir..." Medea said, distracted by how utterly confused she was. Wiping her hand off on her apron, she backpedaled from the room as the one-eyed man got up to join another band of adventurers. Returning to her sanctuary in the kitchen, Marta slammed the door behind her the Gorgon as Medea fell into a chair. Marta opened and closed her mouth a few times as she tried and failed to form words until she finally found some.

"You just..." she began.

"Yes," Medea said bluntly.

"And everyone..."

"Mhm."

"And they didn't..."

"Yup."

The door opened again. Medea nearly leapt to her feet, thinking guards were coming to arrest her, but it was just Daniela, her arm wrapped around Frenda's chubby shoulders as the two waddled into the kitchen.

Or rather, tried to.

"Ugh, son of a...biscuit!" Daniella griped, catching her language in time as those thunder thighs of hers blocked the doorway again, this time with the help of Frenda's pudgy form. Squeezing herself out again, she turned Frenda around and pushed her in front of her, successfully conquering the doorway.

"Hey, no sitting around!" the elder barmaid urged. "We have business to take care of, girls!"

"B-but I..." Medea stammered.

"We'll discuss it after work, the customers aren't gonna wait for us to have a feel good conversation!"

"Hate to say it, but she has a point," Marta admitted. "Let's just get through today and see where that leaves us."

Shaking, Medea got up again, brushing off her apron before remembering the blood. Ripping it off, she trotted over to the pile of laundry in the corner and grabbed a fresh one. She still remembered how the tavern crowd reacted with hostility that first night when she arrived. What had happened to make them change their attitude so suddenly? Did the good food help them tolerate a strange girl making it? Was the man she attacked just incredibly unpopular?

"M-medea?" Something brushed against her tail, making her twitch. She turned around and was winded when Frenda grabbed her in an incredibly tight hug, burying her face in her chest.

"Th-thank you," she whispered through gentle sobs. Medea, totally blindsided by this move, patted the shorter girl on the back of the neck as she hugged back. After a few moments, Frenda finally broke away, rubbing away tears from her eyes. "Well...better get back to work..."

"Wait a minute!" Thinking quickly, Medea grabbed one of the pastries sitting on a plate nearby and put it in the girl's hand.

Frenda blinked in surprise. "But this is-"

"I'll make some more," Medea insisted. Frenda smiling gratefully, stuffing the pastry into her mouth and trotting off to resume her duties. As she exited the room, Medea could make out the sound of a slight burp. Giving her a wide berth and heading in the opposite direction into the kitchen was the very person Medea had been dreading the most.

"So..." Adela announced, glaring down at the Gorgon with a serious expression. "That little incident..."

"...I'll just go then," Medea said sadly.

"Go?" Adela raised her eyebrows a fraction of an inch. "Why?"

Medea blinked. "You're..you're throwing me out right? I attacked a customer, I exposed who I was-"

"You defended your co-worker from a drunken brute," Adela recounted. "I give you girls a hard time on occasion but I've never tolerated the patrons abusing my staff. What makes you think I'd be unhappy about that?"

Medea was speechless.

"As for you revealing yourself...why don't you take a look outside, at the table in the back, near the window?" Adela suggested. Confused, Medea tiptoed to the door and opened it a crack, peering outside at the table. There seemed to be a few explorers gathered around throwing dice, alongside a minotaur and...

"Another Gorgon?!?" Medea nearly shouted, drawing curious looks from the bar patrons. It most certainly was, an older woman with that unmistakable snake-tail hair. She wasn't even cloaked, and seemed to be laughing and talking amiably with her friends, including a rather pretty lady dressed in fashionable blues that she seemed to be sweet on. It was astounding and a little awe inspiring to see one of her own kind so out and in the open.

"You see, the thing about being a popular destination," Adela continued. "Is that you tend to attract all sorts of strange and odd people from around Yndyre. To the locals, you're plenty unusual, sure. To this lot?" She gestured to the crowd outside. "You'd have to work to stand out from the crowd."

Medea felt as though a great weight was lifted off her shoulders. She may have had new friends and a place to live and work, but until the moment where she ran out to defend her new friend from an angry drunk, it had been like she was in a cage. A roomy, pleasant cage, but a cage nonetheless. And to barge out of that cage and be told it was okay for her to leave...it was like the Gorgon spent her days on the run holding her breath and finally let go. In short...it felt like she was free. The fact that she wasn't going to get thrown out though did leave one important question, however.

"So...why did you come to talk to me, then?" Medea asked. And when Adela smiled...it felt like this was a different person then the bossy woman who ordered her to hide in the back so long ago. She was strict, sure, but the smile confirmed something Medea sort of knew all along; for all the times she made the other girls gripe and complain, she really did care deeply about them.

"Well," Adela continued...

She trudged through the soft grass and the wonderful sunlight, angry at everything around her. She hated the grass, the trees, the sunlight, all of it. 15133321.content:
Gruntilda made her way across the field of grassy hills far from Adinand she called. This was the life she thought to herself. Gruntilda was a... something. Standing twelve feet tall and nine feet wide, she walked on legs normally belonging to a gorgon with the nine tails of a kitsune, instead replaced with nine serpentine masses, trailing behind her. Her many, many arms stretched out as she let out a long yawn from her half feline, half canine head, reaching to scratch at the fur on her muzzle and no where else. Her stomach was a mostly muddled brown color with some hints of green, red, blue, and yellow, as well as a few others, visible around the edges. This pattern flowed up her chest and to the base of her neck, as well as down past her stomach and around to her tails and the inner sides of her legs. In almost every other place, scales of scattered patterns were visible, a veritable rainbow of colors spread across her back and around her being. If she were to look upon you, she would see you with her eight different eyes, each one serpentine in appearance. Her hair bounced all on its own, the thriving mass of snakes that it was. If it were to lay flat and still, it would flow all the down to her hips, but it instead dances around as though bored. Gruntilda, on the other hand, was hardly bored. She was enjoying life. One of her sisters came to sit next to her, saying.

"You ever wish you could go and explore places like Adinand?"

"Ha, we'd probably be shot on sight with our monstrous appearance," Gruntilda replied.

"Well, yes, but really though- do you?" She asked again.

"Do I what, Saia?" Gruntilda said with a laugh, confused about her question.

"Want to go explore? Like, see Adinand or Pyknos Verge, or any of those places, you know? Get away from this simple farmer life." Saia replied, clearly annoyed with her sister's lack of attention.

Saia wasn't the same as Gruntilda. She was only ten feet tall and had no legs but instead a tail, not unlike her sister's nine. Although she did have snakes upon her head, they weren't quite the same, instead being more like a mass of Black Mambas than her sister's more Gorgonian snakes. Her sister's stomach stuck out a good eight feet ahead of her, and she immensely obese. Her chest stuck out similarly, and her rump made it so that, while sitting, she appeared to be the same height as Gruntilda, if not taller. Her tail was quite thick, and was at least ten feet in length. She sported three chins and a puffy face which would have looked like it was made of dough if not for her fur. Her thighs were quite thick as well, and her arms where heavily padded with fat. Gruntilda noticed she was breathing heavily from the simple short walk between their home and the hill Gruntilda was stood upon. Gruntilda sat down and gave her sister's question some thought. After a long, long pause, she finally said,

"Yes, actually. Not because I want to get away from here, but because I don't want to be trapped here, you know what I mean? I'd like to know I could have more freedom than just this farm." Gruntilda said, sighing but still smiling.

"Hey, at least things are peaceful here, right?" Their brother, Mako, said as he walked over to them.

"Dinner time, you three!" Their mother called from inside their home. Mako watched as Gruntilda jumped up with ease, while Saia struggled due to her rotund form.

"Little help?" She asked her older brother.

"No problem, Mrs. Whale." He replied, smirking.

"Hey,-*pant*-at least I'm-*wheeze*-not as big as-*pant*-mom wants me to-oh, jeez-be." She said, panting after having barely lifted herself up at all, most of the work having been done by Mako.

"You're going to be if you keep eating the way you do. Besides, you can't fault her for it: it's the Naga in her talking." Mako replied as he began to head towards the house, the mouth in the back of his head seemingly licking it's lips, the scaled tendrils which comprised it twitching with desire.

"You coming?" He called back to her, his fish-like tail swishing up and down with calm anticipation.

"Oof... y-yeah, just... hey, do you think you could bring me my meal?" Saia said, somehow exhausted from the simple act of standing up.

"You're gonna be the size of ten whales if I start doing that. That sound good to you?" Mako teased, crossing both his arms.

"Yes, I get it, I'm a fat pig, just bring me my food!" Saia shouted, exhausting herself to the point of needing to sit down again. Mako laughed as he jogged to the house, ready to carry vast quantities of food to feed his sister's ever expanding corpulence.

***


Gruntilda was walking around their farm after a day's work when she saw something approaching. Coming over the hill, it was a traveling merchant. She sat down on the hill and waited, watching the merchant. Their home was not far from a village, though far enough as to keep them isolated. The merchant, seemingly a newcomer, stopped and gawked at Gruntilda. She waved hello, and the merchant feebily waved back. Gruntilda got up to approach, raising her hands as a sign of peace. The merchant, though clearly terrified, didn't run away. She got close and said,

"Hello there sir. How is your day?"

"H-hi... there. Um... my day has been good, uh... y-yours?" the merchant said, terrified of what he was speaking to. After some time and talk, the merchant warmed up to her presence, seeing she wasn't a threat. He thanked her for the nice conversation, and asked what she had come to see him for.

"Oh, I just wanted to make you didn't think we were monsters. A lot of people do, and then things get messy from there. I figure you're going to be running this route more than once, right?" Gruntilda answered, beaming as she did.

"That's right, ma'am. Well, thank you for the, uh, heads up. Sorry folks treat you that way. You may be big, but 'at don' mean you're not nice. 'Don't judge a book by it's cover,' that's what me mama always told me. Guess I should be glad I listened to her, huh?" he said with a laugh. He carried on his way, saying goodbye, and Gruntilda went back home, seeing only half an hour had passed- much less time than she had thought had passed. When she got home, she decided to...

151333212.content:
Gruntilda went down the mountain and towards the door built into the hillside that was her front door. Opening it, she saw her mother on the other side, cooking yet more food she was going to try and feed to her children.

Her mother was the hybrid to rule all hybrids. You see, her family didn't get this way by simple chance of love, no, they came into being with purpose. Her family had been attempting to incorporate as much of the other species as the could into their genetics, a tradition in their family stretching back long before anyone can remember. It was something no one had ever questioned, or at least no one could remember it being questioned, and Katta'atta, her mother, was the culmination of that. She was a being who bore every trait possible. Many, many horns, wings, many tails of many different kinds, skin of all sorts of colors, scales of all different patterns, fur of all different feels, a mouth in the back of her head comprised of snake-headed tendrils, normal hair growing alongside it, large claws, a great bosom, fins on her back, both gills and lungs, and, to top it all off, a body built more like a worm than a person. Her mother was a sight to behold, a one-of-a-kind abomination. The only thing she lacked was legs, something which didn't matter in the slightest since she had ten arms of all different genetic origins. Gruntilda knew that they had once been human, but had long since lost their resemblance to that, save for most of them being bipedal and standing upright.

"Oh, why, hello Gruntilda! So good to see you! I must've missed you this morning. Did you enjoy breakfast?" she asked, picking Gruntilda up and hugging her. Breakfast was more of a grand feast, as was every meal they had. Gruntilda often wondered where her mother got all the food that she did, but whenever she asked her mother would always say, "we moms have our ways!"

"Breakfast was delicious! I love your cooking so much! Say, have you seen Basilissa anywhere?" She asked her mother, struggling to hide the fact that her mother's embrace was stifling her ability to breathe. Gruntilda did take comfort in how soft the embrace was. Katta'atta was quite large, and not just from being a hybrid. She was an avid cooker and gluttonous devourer. She would be cooking food all day, much of it going into her gullet. If it weren't for her serpentine means of locomotion, she would have been immobilized long, long ago.

"Basilissa? Oh, I just sent her off with some food. She wasn't full from breakfast, poor thing, so she's been eating since." Her mother said with an endearing tone as she set down her daughter. "I imagine she's in her room. Here, I'll-" she then attempted to shift herself so that she wasn't so completely blocking the other hallway. Gruntilda just managed to squeeze past her before heading down the hallway to the flight of stairs and to her sister's room. Gruntilda knocked on the door, saying,

"Basilissa? Is it okay if I come in? Just wanted to chat with you."

"Oh,-*munch*-of course! Please,-*chomp*-come on in!" Yeah, that's her alright, Gruntilda thought. Her sister Basilissa, seemed to be of near identical genetic composure to her mother, in that her physical characteristics were quite similar. Thinking about it now, Gruntilda supposed her sister also thought like her mother: endearing, gluttonous... Gruntilda opened the door, seeing her sister munching away on what seemed to be portion five of twenty.

"Hi-*munch*-shish! How are-*glug, glug, glugl*-ahh-you doing?" Basilissa said, not bothering to stop eating or even look her sister in the eye.

"I'm doing fine, thanks. I figure your day is going well?" Gruntilda asks, watching as her sister eats ravenously, as though having been starved for days.

"I-*gulp*-am doing okay,-*much*-but I could-*chomp*-ush shome-*gulp*-more food." She said, making Gruntilda roll her eyes.

"You always need more food." She said.

"I'm-*munch, munch*-a-*chomp*-gro-*munch*-" she stopped talking, overtaken by the desire to eat more and more food. Gruntilda sat down on her bed next to her, barely fitting. "Hey-*glug, glug, glug*-can you-*chomp, munch, chomp*-" she started to say.

"...bring you more food? Sure, be right back." Gruntilda finished, to her sister's delight. She was hoping to be able to talk with her sister a bit more, but all she ever seems to do is eat now. That's a problem she's running into with her whole family: all anyone wants to do is eat. All except Mako, who just wants to do his own thing most of the time anyways. After making twelve runs of getting her food, you decide to...

15232.content:
Moving can be a huge change for people; new locations, new people and a new way of life. For Creta it was more the middle area that was relevant to her, as she had grown up in the streets of Adinah. The minotaur had fond memories of running up and down the cobbled streets, playing with the local kids and hiding from her parents briefly when they called her home for dinner.

But that was all a long time ago, during which Creta had fallen in love and tied the knot with her significant other. Although Creta’s new wife was not as familiar with all this.

“You there Emra?” The minotaur called out down the flight of stairs, as her spouse wandered up, crate in hands.

“Yeah just…taking in the sights…” Came the reply. Emra was a minotaur, just like Creta, but with pale white skin that faded to a couple of brown patches; one of which was located on her muzzle-like nose. She had long ears that drooped across her cheeks, long brown that was mostly straight except for the tips and a pair of thin gray horns that jutted backwards.

“Sooooo how’re you liking the big city?” Creta teased as she leaned over the landing, big smile across her own half-muzzled face.

“I’ve barely been here an hour…give me a little while to settle.” Emra eye-rolled as she smiled back at her wife, before dumping the crate of her belongings in their living room. It wasn’t the largest place around; there was a decent sized living room that led on to a single bedroom and another to kitchen. Inside the bedroom was another door to their bathroom.

Emra’s hooves clip-clopped loudly as she wandered around the perimeter, peeking into each room as she went.

“Like it?” Creta asked as she turned to her wife.

Emra stared as her partner entered the living room. Creta had perfect smooth coal-black skin and just as dark hair that curled naturally and laid across her shoulders. Her horns were short and gray, and her long ears flicked upwards, making her look constantly slightly surprised. Creta was also kinda chubby, with a rather pronounced bubble-butt and a belly that always just-about wobble each time she moved. This contrasted heavily with her muscular and toned wife.

“I like it has you in it.” Emra teased with a wink.

“Oooo you tease…” Creta purred as she drew close, muzzles nearly touching and her ropey tail began to slide up Emra’s hoofed foot and on towards her tough-as-iron thigh. “You that keen to try the new bed out?”

Emra kissed her partner on the lips and embraced her slowly. “I would love to…but it looks like it’s a single…and built for someone a bit shorter than us.” Emra explained before nodding in the bedroom’s direction.

“Oh dung!” Creta yelled, pouting something fierce as she went to check it for herself.

Emra chuckled, she hadn’t heard her wife swear very often, so it was quite funny to hear the light-hearted minotaur curse.

“I told the landlord we were a couple!” The darker-skinned bovine huffed again.

“Probably thought we meant business partners or something…probably isn’t very used to modern life.” Emra shrugged.

“Or he’s a pervert who wants us to scooch up together real close on a small bed, probably likes watching girl-on-girl action from a peep-hole.” Creta half joked.

“I like watching girl-on-girl action…” Emra butted in, “from a first person perspective of course.”

Creta couldn’t help giggle at that one. “I love how funny you are! …Now! Let’s get us something to eat…” The minotaur remarked, changing the subject as she began to rummage through a crate of food supplies.

As the chubby bovine sauntered into the kitchen, her wife called after her. “Don’t give me too much pork this time! You know what too much meat does to me!”

Both women were all too aware what too much meat did to Emra. When the pair first met they were still heifers; Creta fresh out of education, and Emra learning her parent’s trade. Emra’s father had taken his daughter to the big city on a trip to see where he sold his goods, and how he bartered and haggled with other traders. Creta was looking for groceries when she first saw Emra, and she cut quite a different figure to how she looked now.

The minotaur Creta saw that day was not the lithe toned woman she married, but a rotund fat teenager, with a gut like a sack of grain strapped to her waist and a face as round as a kart-wheel. They had quickly bonded when Emra subtly indicated she wanted to get away and do something more interesting; after that they exchanged addresses and kept in touch via letters, and the rest is history.

Emra had worked hard to slim down from her three hundred pound high, but it had left its mark on her. The pale minotaur’s legs and arms had never gotten that big, plus when she began to exercise seriously all that fat under her skin was replaced with muscle. But no amount of muscle could replace her huge gut and blobby double-chin.

So Emra had been left with a lot of excess skin around her neck and stomach. She was extremely sensitive about it, and even the carefree Creta didn’t dare to try and comfort Emra about it; the topic would just upset her. And she certainly had to be careful with Emra’s portion sizes; the poor woman had such a terrible metabolism that just a bit too much dessert forced her to train like mad for weeks to drop the weight it put on her figure.

As the muscular woman waited, Creta busied herself in the kitchen. She thought of herself as a not-too-bad cook, and longed to work in the kitchens of the tavern she worked in to improve her craft. But she did love playfully interacting with the patrons; she got on with them very well and would miss them if she was stuck in the back rooms cooking all day, so she took out her culinary interests at home. It was part of the reason why her uniform had been getting a little snug around the waist as of late.


***


“Ok hun, dig in!” Creta beamed as she laid out her creation on the couple’s small table. It wasn’t anything fancy, just some grilled meats and vegetables, but she was proud of it.

The pair mostly ate in silence, with occasional words of praise from Emra. “Mmmm, love what you did with the pork…” The long-horned woman stated, filling her mouth with another forkful.

“Hehe, I just covered it in some simple spices before I cooked it.” Creta laughed off modestly; “But if you really want to experience some fine dining, we gotta find you a job. My barmaid work will cover the rent and food…but not much else. If we want to live as lavishly as the king’s harem, we gotta really rake in the money.” She wasn't lying, Creta had lived modestly after moving out of her parents house. Her clothes were simple and plain, but comfortable. Thankfully she saved money on shoes because of her all-terrain hooves, it made up for how expensive minotaur clothes were. It took a lot of material to cover an 8-foot tall person.

“Don’t worry, I’ll be looking around town tomorrow as dawn breaks.” Emra replied as she swallowed her mouthful.

“And until then?” Creta asked with a wink.

Emra leaned in until her muzzle was against Creta’s ear, and whispered “We shall enjoy the single bed…”
